Copper:
Copper is a transition metal and trace element essential for various enzymes in the body, including cytochrome c oxidase, monoamine oxidase, and superoxide dismutase. It is commonly used in contraceptive intrauterine devices (IUDs). Copper is absorbed from the gut via high affinity copper uptake protein and likely through low affinity copper uptake protein and natural resistance-associated macrophage protein-2. Once inside the enterocyte, it is bound to copper transport protein ATOX1 which shuttles the ion to copper transporting ATPase-1 on the golgi membrane for transport into the circulation. Copper is nearly entirely bound by ceruloplasmin (65-90%), plasma albumin (18%), and alpha 2-macroglobulin (12%). Copper is incorporated into many enzymes throughout the body as an essential part of their function, including copper-containing IUDs which reduce fertility when released. Copper is approved and investigational for use in total parenteral nutrition and contraception with intrauterine devices.

Copper is a solid at room temperature and has been approved for medical use since the 1970s. It is classified as part of the Copper-containing Intrauterine Device, Decreased Embryonic Implantation, Decreased Sperm Motility, Diet, Food, and Nutrition, Elements, Food, Food and Beverages, Growth Substances, Inhibit Ovum Fertilization, Metals, Heavy Metals, Micronutrients, Minerals, Physiologic categories.
Oxygen:
Oxygen is an essential element for human survival, and medical oxygen therapy is used to treat a variety of conditions where there are decreased oxygen levels in the body. Oxygen therapy serves to increase blood oxygen levels and also exerts a secondary effect of decreasing blood flow resistance in the diseased lung, leading to decreased cardiovascular workload in an attempt to oxygenate the lungs. The treatment is used to treat emphysema, pneumonia, some heart disorders (congestive heart failure), and any disease that impairs the body's ability to take up and use gaseous oxygen. Hyperoxia, or higher levels of oxygen than ambient air, can be introduced under normobaric or hyperbaric conditions. The mechanism of action of oxygen therapy involves increasing the arterial pressure of oxygen and improving gas exchange and oxygen delivery to tissues, provided that there are functional alveolar units. Oxygen binds to hemoglobin in red blood cells with high affinity, determining the overall oxygen saturation level. The pharmacodynamics of oxygen therapy improve effective cellular oxygenation even at low rates of tissue perfusion and adjust hypoxic ventilatory drive by acting on chemoreceptors on carotid bodies that relay sensory information to higher processing centers in the brainstem. Additionally, oxygen molecules attenuate hypoxia-induced mitochondrial depolarization that generates reactive oxygen species and/or apoptosis.

Oxygen is a gas with a molecular weight of 32.0 and a topological polar surface area of 34.14. It is part of the chalcogens, elements, gases, medical gases, and miscellaneous therapeutic agents categories. Oxygen is approved and veterinarily approved, with a half-life of approximately 122.24 seconds.
Flunisolide:
Flunisolide is a corticosteroid with anti-inflammatory actions, commonly marketed as AeroBid, Nasalide, or Nasarel. It is used for the maintenance treatment of asthma as a prophylactic therapy, and its mechanism of action involves activation of glucocorticoid receptors. Flunisolide binds to plasma transcortin, becoming active when not bound to this carrier protein. Its anti-inflammatory actions are thought to involve lipocortins, phospholipase A2 inhibitory proteins that control the biosynthesis of prostaglandins and leukotrienes. The immune system is suppressed by corticosteroids due to a decrease in the function of the lymphatic system, a reduction in immunoglobulin and complement concentrations, the precipitation of lymphocytopenia, and interference with antigen-antibody binding.

Flunisolide is administered either as an oral metered-dose inhaler for the treatment of asthma or as a nasal spray for treating allergic rhinitis. When given as an intranasal spray, flunisolide reduces watery nasal discharge (rhinorrhea), nasal congestion, postnasal drip, sneezing, and itching on the back of the throat, which are common allergic symptoms. The half-life of flunisolide is 1.8 hours, and its molecular weight is 434.5. Flunisolide has a topological polar surface area of 93.06 and a log p value of 2.41. It belongs to the categories of Adrenal Cortex Hormones, Agents to Treat Airway Disease, Anti-Asthmatic Agents, Anti-Inflammatory Agents, Corticosteroid Hormone Receptor Agonists, Corticosteroids, and Cytochrome P-450 CYP3A Inducers. Flunisolide is approved for use but also has investigational status.
Alclometasone:
Alclometasone is a synthetic glucocorticoid steroid used topically for the relief of inflammatory and pruritic manifestations of corticosteroid-responsive dermatoses. It works by binding to the corticosteroid receptor, migrating to the nucleus, and enhancing and repressing various genes involved in inflammatory pathways. The mechanism of action is unclear but involves the induction of phospholipase A2 inhibitory proteins and the regulation of arachidonic acid release and metabolism. Alclometasone is a selective glucocorticoid receptor agonist and is part of the class of primarily synthetic steroids used topically as anti-inflammatory and antipruritic agents. It is approved for use in dermatology and belongs to several drug categories, including Adrenal Cortex Hormones, Anti-Inflammatory Agents, Corticosteroid Hormone Receptor Agonists, and Corticosteroids.

Alclometasone is a solid at room temperature and pressure, and its physical state can be described as a white or off-white powder. It is available in topical formulations such as creams, lotions, and ointments, and is typically applied to the affected area for a duration of several days or weeks, depending on the severity of the condition being treated.

Alclometasone has several clinical indications, including the treatment of corticosteroid-responsive dermatoses such as atopic dermatitis, contact dermatitis, and seborrheic dermatitis. It is also used to treat pruritus associated with these conditions. The drug's pharmacodynamics involve binding to the corticosteroid receptor, which leads to changes in gene expression and the regulation of inflammatory pathways.

In summary, Alclometasone is a synthetic glucocorticoid steroid used topically for the relief of inflammatory and pruritic manifestations of corticosteroid-responsive dermatoses. Its mechanism of action involves the induction of phospholipase A2 inhibitory proteins and the regulation of arachidonic acid release and metabolism, leading to changes in gene expression and the inflammatory response.
Medrysone: Medrysone is a topical corticosteroid used to treat various ophthalmic conditions, including allergic conjunctivitis, vernal conjunctivitis, episcleritis, and epinephrine sensitivity. The mechanism of action of medrysone involves the induction of phospholipase A2 inhibitory proteins, which in turn regulate the biosynthesis of inflammatory mediators such as prostaglandins and leukotrienes. Medrysone binds to the glucocorticoid receptor in the cytosol, which then migrates to the nucleus and regulates the expression of genes involved in the inflammatory response. The drug inhibits edema, fibrin deposition, capillary dilation, and phagocytic migration, as well as capillary proliferation, collagen deposition, and scar formation. Medrysone is available in a solid form and has a molecular weight of 344.5. It belongs to the adrenal cortex hormones, anti-inflammatory agents, corticosteroid hormone receptor agonists, corticosteroids, cytochrome P-450 CYP3A inducers, and cytochrome P-450 CYP3A4 inducers (strength unknown) drug categories. Medrysone has a topological polar surface area of 54.37 and a logP value of 3.36. It is approved for use in ophthalmology.
Fluorometholone:
Fluorometholone is a glucocorticoid employed primarily as eye drops in the treatment of corticosteroid-responsive inflammation of the palpebral and bulbar conjunctiva, cornea, and anterior segment of the globe. It has also been used topically in the treatment of various skin disorders. The mechanisms of action of ocular corticosteroids are not well understood, but it is believed that they act by inducing phospholipase A2 inhibitory proteins, collectively called lipocortins, which control the biosynthesis of potent mediators of inflammation such as prostaglandins and leukotrienes by inhibiting the release of their common precursor, arachidonic acid. The primary target of these proteins is the cytosolic glucocorticoid receptor, which binds to specific DNA sequences in the promoter region of target genes, leading to an increase in gene expression. Corticosteroids such as fluorometholone inhibit the inflammatory response to a variety of inciting agents and probably delay or slow healing by inhibiting edema, fibrin deposition, capillary dilation, leukocyte migration, capillary proliferation, fibroblast proliferation, deposition of collagen, and scar formation associated with inflammation.

Fluorometholone is a solid with a molecular weight of 376.47 and a topological polar surface area of 74.6. It has a logP value of 2.11. Fluorometholone belongs to the categories of Adrenal Cortex Hormones, Agents for Treatment of Hemorrhoids and Anal Fissures for Topical Use, Anti-Acne Preparations, Anti-Acne Preparations for Topical Use, Anti-Allergic Agents, Anti-Inflammatory Agents, Corticosteroid Hormone Receptor Agonists, and Corticosteroids. Its approval status is approved and investigational.
Beclomethasone dipropionate: Beclomethasone dipropionate is a synthetic corticosteroid agent and prodrug of the active metabolite 17-monopropionate (17-BMP). It is structurally similar to beclomethasone, which is a second-generation corticosteroid. Beclomethasone dipropionate is available in formulations for oral inhalation, intranasal, and topical use. Its anti-inflammatory, antipruritic, and anti-allergy properties make it useful in treating various inflammatory conditions such as asthma, allergic rhinitis, and dermatoses. The aerosol form of beclomethasone dipropionate is not indicated for the relief of acute bronchospasm. The protein binding of the main active metabolite 17-BMP was found to be 94-96% over the concentration range of 1000 to 5000 pg/mL. Beclomethasone dipropionate works by attenuating inflammatory responses associated with asthma, allergic rhinitis, nasal polyps, and corticosteroid-responsive dermatoses by suppressing the actions of inflammatory cells and inhibiting the release of inflammatory mediators. The half-life of beclomethasone dipropionate following intravenous administration was 0.5 hours, while the half-life of 17-BMP following oral and intranasal administration was 8.8 and 5.7 hours, respectively. Molecular properties such as molecular weight and topological polar surface area were also determined. Beclomethasone dipropionate is part of various drug categories and has approval status.
Betamethasone: Betamethasone is a long-acting corticosteroid with immunosuppressive and anti-inflammatory properties. It can be used topically to manage inflammatory skin conditions such as eczema, and parenterally to manage several disease states including autoimmune disorders. Betamethasone has potent glucocorticoid activity and negligible mineralocorticoid activity. The corticosteroid is indicated for the treatment of several inflammatory conditions, including topical monotherapy for pruritic and inflammatory symptoms of corticosteroid-responsive dermatoses, and as an injectable suspension to manage a range of inflammatory conditions including endocrine disorders, gastrointestinal disorders, and rheumatic disorders among other conditions. The mechanism of action of betamethasone involves inhibition of neutrophil apoptosis and demargination, and inhibition of NF-kB and other inflammatory transcription factors. It also promotes anti-inflammatory genes like interleukin-10. The protein binding of betamethasone valerate is to serum albumin and corticosteroid-binding globulin. The pharmacodynamics of corticosteroids involve binding to the glucocorticoid receptor inhibiting pro-inflammatory signals while promoting anti-inflammatory signals. Betamethasone has a wide therapeutic window, and patients who require long-term treatment with a corticosteroid should be counseled regarding the risk of hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis suppression and increased susceptibility to infections. The molecular properties of betamethasone include a molecular weight of 392.47, topological polar surface area of 94.83, and log p value of 1.79. Betamethasone is part of adrenal cortex hormones; adrenals; agents causing muscle toxicity; agents for treatment of hemorrhoids and anal fissures for topical use; alimentary tract and metabolism; anti-inflammatory agents; antidiarrheals, intestinal anti-inflammatory/antiinfective agents; corticosteroids; immunosuppressants; mineralocorticoids. Betamethasone is approved for use in both humans and animals.
Fluticasone Propionate:
Fluticasone propionate is a synthetic glucocorticoid drug that is available in various forms, including inhalers, nasal sprays, and topical treatments. It was first approved in 1990 for the treatment and management of asthma by prophylaxis as well as inflammatory and pruritic dermatoses. The mechanism of action of fluticasone propionate is unknown, but it is believed to affect various cell types and mediators of inflammation through its activation of glucocorticoid receptors. It also inhibits lung eosinophilia in rats. Fluticasone propionate is 99% protein bound in serum, with topical formulations binding to a lower extent. The drug has a half-life of 7.8 hours following intravenous administration and 10.8 hours following inhalation. Fluticasone propionate belongs to the adrenal cortex hormones category and is part of various drug categories, including anti-allergic agents, anti-asthmatic agents, and anti-inflammatory agents. Its molecular weight is 500.57, and its topological polar surface area is 80.67.

Fluticasone propionate is used to treat and manage asthma by prophylaxis, as well as inflammatory and pruritic dermatoses. Its mechanism of action is believed to involve the activation of glucocorticoid receptors, which inhibits lung eosinophilia in rats. The drug is available in various forms, including inhalers, nasal sprays, and topical treatments. Fluticasone propionate has a half-life of 7.8 hours following intravenous administration and 10.8 hours following inhalation. Its protein binding in serum is 99%, with topical formulations binding to a lower extent. The drug belongs to the adrenal cortex hormones category and is part of various drug categories, including anti-allergic agents, anti-asthmatic agents, and anti-inflammatory agents. Its molecular weight is 500.57, and its topological polar surface area is 80.67.
Fluocinolone acetonide:
Fluocinolone acetonide is a corticosteroid with high lipophilicity, primarily used in dermatological preparations and recently approved by the FDA for use in implantable corticosteroid devices developed by Taro Pharmaceuticals. This drug has been extensively used in various medical areas due to its anti-inflammatory properties. Its mechanism of action involves inhibiting edema, fibrin deposition, capillary dilation, leukocyte migration, capillary proliferation, fibroblast proliferation, collagen deposition, and scar formation. Fluocinolone acetonide has a reported half-life of 1.3-1.7 hours, and its molecular weight is 452.5. It falls under the categories of Adrenal Cortex Hormones, Agents for Treatment of Hemorrhoids and Anal Fissures for Topical Use, Anti-Inflammatory Agents, Corticosteroid Hormone Receptor Agonists, Corticosteroids, Dermatological Preparations, Cytochrome P-450 CYP3A Inducers. The approved status of fluocinolone acetonide is approved and investigational, and vet_approved.

The pharmacokinetics of fluocinolone acetonide are characterized by minimal systemic absorption, resulting in a lack of relevance for protein binding and half-life determination. Instead, the drug's mechanism of action is primarily focused on its ability to inhibit inflammatory responses through vasoconstriction, suppression of membrane permeability, mitotic activity, immune response, and release of inflammatory mediators. Its topological polar surface area is 93.06, and its logP value is 2.25, indicating a low water solubility.

Fluocinolone acetonide has been investigated for its potential use in various medical conditions, including inflammatory skin disorders, such as atopic dermatitis, contact dermatitis, and seborrheic dermatitis, as well as for the treatment of anal fissures and hemorrhoids. Its ability to reduce inflammation and promote wound healing has led to its approval for use in implantable corticosteroid devices, providing a localized delivery of the drug directly to the affected area.
Ulobetasol:
Ulobetasol is a highly potent corticosteroid that is primarily used in the treatment of severe plaque psoriasis and corticosterodermatoses. It has a structural similarity to halobetasol, but its high potency makes it more effective in treating these conditions. The mechanism of action of ulobetasol involves binding to the glucocorticoid receptor, which leads to changes in gene expression and downstream effects that occur within hours to days. Ulobetasol is bound to corticosteroid binding globulin in serum, and its protein binding profile is moderate. Its pharmacodynamics are characterized by a moderate duration of action, making it suitable for once or twice daily application. However, patients taking ulobetasol should be counselled regarding the risk of hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis suppression and increased susceptibility to infections. Ulobetasol is part of several drug categories, including adrenal cortex hormones, anti-inflammatory agents, cardiovascular agents, corticosteroid hormone receptor agonists, corticosteroids, dermatological preparations, and fused-ring compounds. It has been approved for use in various countries, including the United States.

In vitro experiments have shown that halobetasol propionate, a derivative of ulobetasol, has a half-life of 33 minutes. Ulobetasol is structurally related to halobetasol, but its high potency makes it more effective in treating severe plaque psoriasis and corticosterodermatoses. Triamcinolone:
Triamcinolone is a corticosteroid used to treat various inflammatory conditions in the body, including allergic rhinitis, acute exacerbations of multiple sclerosis, and localized hypertrophic infiltrated inflammatory lesions of granuloma annulare, lichen planus, lichen simplex chronicus, and psoriatic plaques. It can be administered as a one-time adjunct treatment of osteoarthritic knee pain or as a first-line topical treatment of corticosteroid-responsive dermatoses. Triamcinolone is available in different forms, including triamcinolone hexacetonide, triamcinolone acetonide, and triamcinolone diacetate. The primary mechanism of action of triamcinolone is the inhibition of phospholipase A2 on cell membranes, preventing the breakdown of lysosomal membranes of leukocytes, which in turn prevents the formation of arachidonic acid, decreasing expression of cyclooxygenase and lipoxygenase, and thus reducing the synthesis of prostaglandins and leukotrienes. Triamcinolone also inhibits nuclear factor kappa-B, which decreases the production of pro-inflammatory signals such as interleukin-6, interleukin-8, and monocyte chemoattractant protein-1. Additionally, triamcinolone binds to corticosteroid-binding globulin or serum albumin in the plasma, with approximately 68% protein binding for triamcinolone acetonide. The half-life of triamcinolone varies depending on the formulation, ranging from 2.7 to 2.8 hours.

Triamcinolone has a molecular weight of 394.44 and a topological polar surface area of 115.06. It is classified as part of Adrenal Cortex Hormones, Agents Causing Muscle Toxicity, Agents to Treat Airway Disease, Alimentary Tract and Metabolism, Anti-Inflammatory Agents, Corticosteroid Hormone Receptor Agonists, Corticosteroids, and Cortico. Triamcinolone is approved for use in various conditions and has been approved by the FDA and other regulatory agencies.
Prednisone: Prednisone is a synthetic anti-inflammatory glucocorticoid derived from cortisone. It is biologically inert and converted to its active form, prednisolone, in the liver. Prednisone is indicated for a wide range of clinical indications, including allergic, dermatologic, gastrointestinal, hematologic, ophthalmologic, nervous system, renal, respiratory, rheumatologic, infectious, endocrine, or neoplastic conditions. Its mechanism of action involves binding to the glucocorticoid receptor, inhibiting pro-inflammatory signals and promoting anti-inflammatory signals. Prednisone has a short duration of action, with a half-life of 2-3 hours, and is bound to protein in plasma to a lesser extent than other corticosteroids. Patients taking corticosteroids should be counselled regarding the risk of hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis suppression and increased susceptibility to infections. Prednisone is part of Adrenal Cortex Hormones, Alimentary Tract and Metabolism, Anti-Inflammatory Agents, Antidiarrheals, Intestinal Antiinflammatory/antiinfective Agents, Antineoplastic Agents, Antineoplastic Agents, Hormonal, Corticosteroid Hormone Receptor Agonists, and Corticosteroids drug categories. Prednisone is approved for medical use and has a molecular weight of 358.43, topological polar surface area of 91.67, and log p value of 1.66.
Mitotane:
Mitotane is a derivative of the insecticide dichlorodiphenyldichloroethane that specifically inhibits cells of the adrenal cortex and their production of hormones. It is used to treat inoperable adrenocortical tumors and Cushing's syndrome, causing CNS damage but no bone marrow depression. The mechanism of action of Mitotane is unknown, although it modifies the peripheral metabolism of steroids and directly suppresses the adrenal cortex. The drug has a half-life of 18-159 days and is a solid. It belongs to the categories Antineoplastic Agents, Hormonal, Antineoplastic and Immunomodulating Agents, Cytochrome P-450 CYP3A Inducers, and Cytochrome P-450 CYP3A4 Inducers (strong). Mitotane is approved for use in the treatment of inoperable adrenocortical tumors and Cushing's syndrome.

PHARMACODYNAMICS: Mitotane can best be described as an adrenal cytotoxic agent, although it can cause adrenal inhibition without cellular destruction. The administration of Mitotane alters the extra-adrenal metabolism of cortisol in man, leading to a reduction in measurable 17-hydroxy corticosteroids, even though plasma levels of corticosteroids do not fall. The drug apparently causes increased formation of 6-B-hydroxyl cortisol.

MECHANISM OF ACTION: The mechanism of action of Mitotane is unknown, although data are available to suggest that the drug modifies the peripheral metabolism of steroids as well as directly suppressing the adrenal cortex.

PROTEIN BINDING: Mitotane has a protein binding rate of 6%.

PHARMACOKINETICS: The half-life of Mitotane is 18-159 days, and it is a solid.

CLINICAL INDICATION: Mitotane is used to treat inoperable adrenocortical tumors and Cushing's syndrome.

DRUG CATEGORIES: Mitotane belongs to the categories Antineoplastic Agents, Hormonal, Antineoplastic and Immunomodulating Agents, Cytochrome P-450 CYP3A Inducers, and Cytochrome P-450 CYP3A4 Inducers (strong).

APPROVAL STATUS: Mitotane is approved for use in the treatment of inoperable adrenocortical tumors and Cushing's syndrome.
Flumethasone:
Flumethasone is a moderately potent difluorinated corticosteroid ester with anti-inflammatory, antipruritic and vasoconstrictive properties. As it is a privately bound salt, its anti-inflammatory action is concentrated at the site of application. This local effect on diseased areas results in a prompt decrease in inflammation, exudation and itching. Flumethasone binds to plasma transcortin, and it becomes active when it is not bound to transcortin. The immune system is suppressed by corticosteroids due to a decrease in the function of the lymphatic system, a reduction in immunoglobulin and complement concentrations, the precipitation of lymphocytopenia, and interference with antigen-antibody binding. Flumethasone is part of Adrenal Cortex Hormones; Anti-Inflammatory Agents; Corticosteroids; Dermatological Preparations; Cytochrome P-450 CYP3A Substrates; Cytochrome P-450 CYP3A4 Substrates; Cytochrome P-450 Substrates and Dermato. Flumethasone is approved and vet_approved.

Flumethasone is used for the treatment of contact dermatitis, atopic dermatitis, exczema, psoriasis, diaper rash and other skin conditions. The mechanism of action involves the binding to plasma transcortin, which becomes active when it is not bound to transcortin. This leads to a decrease in inflammation, exudation, and itching at the site of application. Flumethasone also suppresses the immune system by reducing the function of the lymphatic system, immunoglobulin and complement concentrations, and interfering with antigen-antibody binding.

Flumethasone is a solid at room temperature and has a molecular weight of 410.46, topological polar surface area of 94.83, and logP value of 1.83. It is part of Adrenal Cortex Hormones; Anti-Inflammatory Agents; Corticosteroids; Dermatological Preparations; Cytochrome P-450 CYP3A Substrates; Cytochrome P-450 CYP3A4 Substrates; Cytochrome P-450 Substrates and Dermato. Flumethasone is approved and vet_approved for use in various skin conditions, including contact dermatitis, atopic dermatitis, exczema, psoriasis, diaper rash, and other skin conditions.
Fludrocortisone: Fludrocortisone is a synthetic mineralocorticoid used to replace endogenous corticosteroids in patients with adrenal insufficiency. It is functionally similar to cortisol, the body's primary endogenous mineralocorticoid, and is structurally analogous to prednisone, differing only by a fluorine atom at the 9-position of the steroid structure. This fluorination is thought to be crucial to fludrocortisone's significant mineralocorticoid potency. Fludrocortisone works by acting on the kidneys to increase sodium reabsorption and potassium excretion, which helps regulate plasma electrolyte composition and blood pressure. It is protein-bound in plasma, mostly to albumin and corticosteroid-binding globulin. Fludrocortisone has a relatively short plasma half-life of approximately 18-36 hours, but its effects may work over the course of 1-2 days due to its exertion at the transcriptional level. As with other systemic corticosteroids, fludrocortisone may mask signs of infection by depressing the normal immune response, and infections occurring during fludrocortisone therapy should be promptly treated with appropriate antimicrobial therapy. Fludrocortisone is approved for partial replacement therapy for primary or secondary adrenocortical insufficiency in Addison's disease, as well as the treatment of salt-losing androgenital syndrome.
Hydrocortisone: Hydrocortisone, or cortisol, is a glucocorticoid hormone produced by the adrenal cortex. It is used to treat various immune, inflammatory, and neoplastic conditions. Discovered in the 1930s by Edward Kendall and named Compound F, or 17-hydroxycorticosterone, hydrocortisone has a wide therapeutic index and moderate duration of action. Hydrocortisone binds to the glucocorticoid receptor, leading to downstream effects such as inhibition of phospholipase A2, NF-κB, and other inflammatory transcription factors, as well as promotion of anti-inflammatory genes. The drug is available in various formulations, including oral tablets, enemas, creams, and ointments. Its mechanism of action involves decreased vasodilation and permeability of capillaries, as well as decreased leukocyte migration to sites of inflammation. Hydrocortisone is bound to corticosteroid binding globulin and serum albumin in plasma, with 90.1% bound to albumin. The drug has a molecular weight of 362.47 and a topological polar surface area of 94.83. Hydrocortisone is part of several drug categories, including 11-Hydroxycorticosteroids, 17-Hydroxycorticosteroids, Adrenal Cortex Hormones, and Anti-Inflammatory Agents. It has been approved for use in various conditions, including otic solutions for infections of the external auditory canal, tablets for endocrine, rheumatic, collagen, allergic, ophthalmic, respiratory, hematologic, neoplastic, edematous, gastrointestinal, and other conditions. A hydrocortisone enema is used to treat ulcerative colitis, while a topical ointment with antibiotics is indicated for corticosteroid responsive dermatoses with infections. Oral granules of hydrocortisone are used as replacement therapy for Adrenocortical Insufficiency (AI) in children under 17 years of age. Hydrocortisone has a half-life of 2.15h via the oral route and 1.9±0.4h via an IV dose. Its molecular properties include a logP value of 1.89, indicating that it is moderately soluble in lipids. Overall, hydrocortisone is a valuable drug for managing various conditions, with its mechanism of action and formulations tailored to specific indications.
Flurandrenolide: Flurandrenolide is a topical corticosteroid used to treat various skin disorders, including dry, scaling lesions. It works by binding to the cytosolic glucocorticoid receptor, which then interacts with basic transcription factors to increase the expression of specific target genes. This leads to diminished eicosanoid production and immune system suppression. Flurandrenolide is primarily effective due to its anti-inflammatory, antipruritic, and vasoconstrictive actions. It is usually applied as a cream or ointment, but can also be combined with polyethylene tape for added adhesion. Flurandrenolide binds to plasma proteins in varying degrees, and its molecular weight is 436.52. It has a topological polar surface area of 93.06 and a logP value of 2.87. Flurandrenolide is part of Adrenal Cortex Hormones; Anti-Inflammatory Agents; Corticosteroid Hormone Receptor Agonists; Corticosteroids; Dermatological Preparations; and Cytochrome P-450 CYP3A Substrates. It is approved for use in various countries, including the United States.
Prednisolone:
Prednisolone is a glucocorticoid similar to cortisol, with anti-inflammatory, immunosuppressive, anti-neoplastic, and vasoconstrictive effects. It is widely used to treat endocrine, rheumatic, and hematologic disorders; collagen, dermatologic, ophthalmic, respiratory, and gastrointestinal diseases; allergic and edematous states; and other conditions such as tuberculous meningitis. The mechanism of action involves binding to the glucocorticoid receptor, which mediates changes in gene expression leading to multiple downstream effects over hours to days. Prednisolone's protein binding is highly variable, ranging from 65-91% in healthy patients, and its half-life is 2.1-3.5 hours. Patients taking corticosteroids should be counseled regarding the risk of hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis suppression and increased susceptibility to infections.

Prednisolone is part of Adrenal Cortex Hormones; Adrenals; Agents for Treatment of Hemorrhoids and Anal Fissures for Topical Use; Alimentary Tract and Metabolism; Anti-Inflammatory Agents; Antidiarrheals, Intestinal Antiinflammatory/antiinfective Agents; Antidotes; Antineoplastic Agents; Antivirals. It is approved for both human and veterinary use.

The molecular weight of Prednisolone is 360.45, and its topological polar surface area is 94.83. Its logP value is 1.42.

In summary, Prednisolone is a powerful glucocorticoid with a wide range of therapeutic uses due to its anti-inflammatory, immunosuppressive, and vasoconstrictive effects. Its mechanism of action involves binding to the glucocorticoid receptor, leading to changes in gene expression that can have multiple downstream effects over hours to days. Prednisolone is available for both human and veterinary use, and its protein binding and half-life vary depending on the patient population.
Rimexolone:
Rimexolone is a 1% eye drop solution that is a glucocorticoid steroid, primarily used to treat inflammation in the eye. It is marketed as Vexol and has clinical indications for postoperative inflammation following ocular surgery and anterior uveitis. Rimexolone works by binding to the glucocorticoid receptor, leading to changes in genetic transcription involving lipocortins and prostaglandins, which ultimately suppresses the inflammatory response. The drug has a short serum half-life of 1-2 hours, and its molecular properties include a molecular weight of 370.53 and a topological polar surface area of 54.37. Rimexolone is part of various drug categories, including adrenal cortex hormones, anti-inflammatory agents, corticosteroid hormone receptor agonists, corticosteroids for systemic use, and more. It has been approved for use in the treatment of inflammation in the eye.

Mechanism of Action: Rimexolone is a glucocorticoid receptor agonist, which means it binds to the glucocorticoid receptor in the body and activates its signaling pathways. This leads to the suppression of inflammatory responses, including the production of pro-inflammatory cytokines and the activation of immune cells. Rimexolone also inhibits the activity of phospholipase A2, which is involved in the biosynthesis of prostaglandins and leukotrienes, further contributing to its anti-inflammatory effects.

Pharmacokinetics: Rimexolone has a short serum half-life of approximately 1-2 hours, which means it is rapidly distributed and eliminated from the body. The drug is metabolized by the liver and excreted primarily in the feces, with some urinary excretion as well.

Clinical Uses: Rimexolone is primarily used to treat inflammation in the eye, including postoperative inflammation following ocular surgery and anterior uveitis. It has also been used to treat other inflammatory conditions such as allergic conjunctivitis and blepharitis.

Adverse Effects: Common adverse effects of rimexolone include increased intraocular pressure, cataract formation, and optic nerve damage. Less common effects may include glaucoma, macular edema, and ocular infections. Rimexolone can also cause systemic side effects such as weight gain, mood changes, and increased risk of infection.

Drug Interactions: Rimexolone may interact with other medications, including warfarin, phenobarbital, and prednisone. It is important to inform the doctor of all medications being taken, including over-the-counter drugs and supplements, to avoid potential interactions.

Contraindications: Rimexolone is contraindicated in patients with known hypersensitivity to the drug or any component of its formulation. It is also contraindicated in pregnant or breastfeeding women, as well as in children under the age of 12 due to the risk of immune system suppression and other adverse effects.

Dosage and Administration: The recommended dosage and administration of rimexolone varies depending on the condition being treated. For postoperative inflammation, the usual dose is 1-2 drops instilled into the affected eye every hour as needed. For anterior uveitis, the usual dose is 1-2 drops instilled into the affected eye 3-4 times a day for up to 2 weeks. It is important to follow the dosage instructions carefully and to not exceed the recommended dose without consulting the doctor.
Clobetasol propionate: Clobetasol propionate is a glucocorticoid drug with higher specificity for glucocorticoid receptors than mineralocorticoid receptors. It was first described in 1974 and has demonstrated superior activity compared to other corticosteroids. Clobetasol propionate is used to treat moderate to severe plaque psoriasis as well as inflammatory and pruritic manifestations of corticosteroid-responsive dermatoses. The drug works by binding to the glucocorticoid receptor, inhibiting pro-inflammatory signals and promoting anti-inflammatory signals. Its long duration of action allows for twice daily dosing, but patients should be counseled about the risk of hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis suppression and increased susceptibility to infections. Clobetasol propionate is part of Adrenal Cortex Hormones, Anti-Inflammatory Agents, Corticosteroids, Cytochrome P-450 CYP3A Inducers, Cytochrome P-450 CYP3A Substrates, and Cytochrome P-450 CYP3A4 Inducers (strength unknown) drug categories. It has a molecular weight of 466.97 and a topological polar surface area of 80.67. The log p value of clobetasol propionate is 3.49.
Fluocinonide:
Fluocinonide is a topical glucocorticoid used in the treatment of eczema. It is a potent glucocorticoid steroid that binds to the cytosolic glucocorticoid receptor, leading to the increase in expression of specific target genes and the inhibition of inflammatory events such as epithelial adhesion, emigration, chemotaxis, phagocytosis, respiratory burst, and the release of various inflammatory mediators from neutrophils, macrophages, and mast cells. Additionally, fluocinonide stimulates the lipocortin-1 escaping to the extracellular space, where it binds to the leukocyte membrane receptors and inhibits various inflammatory events. The immune system is also suppressed by corticosteroids due to a decrease in the function of the lymphatic system, a reduction in immunoglobulin and complement concentrations, the precipitation of lymphocytopenia, and interference with antigen-antibody binding. Furthermore, fluocinonide acts as a physiological antagonist to insulin by decreasing glycogenesis (formation of glycogen), promoting the breakdown of lipids (lipolysis), and proteins, leading to increased circulating glucose concentrations (in the blood). There is also decreased glycogen formation in the liver.

Mechanism of Action: Fluocinonide is a potent glucocorticoid steroid used topically as anti-inflammatory agent for the treatment of skin disorders such as eczema. It mediates its effects to relieve itching, redness, dryness, crusting, scaling, inflammation, and discomfort associated with inflammatory skin conditions.

Pharmacodynamics: Fluocinonide is a potent glucocorticoid steroid used topically as anti-inflammatory agent for the treatment of skin disorders such as eczema. It mediates its effects to relieve itching, redness, dryness, crusting, scaling, inflammation, and discomfort associated with inflammatory skin conditions.

Physical State: Fluocinonide is a solid.

Budesonide:
Budesonide is a glucocorticoid that is used to treat various inflammatory conditions of the lungs and intestines, including asthma, COPD, Crohn's disease, and ulcerative colitis. It works by reducing inflammation through its binding to the glucocorticoid receptor, which mediates changes in gene expression that lead to multiple downstream effects over hours to days. Budesonide has a wide therapeutic index, meaning dosing varies highly from patient to patient. However, patients should be counseled regarding the risk of hypercorticism and adrenal axis suppression. The drug is available in various forms, including extended release capsules, inhaled products, and a nasal spray. It has a plasma elimination half-life of 2-3.6 hours and a terminal elimination half-life of 4-6 hours in asthmatic children aged 4-6 years old. Budesonide is part of Adrenal Cortex Hormones, Agents to Treat Airway Disease, Alimentary Tract and Metabolism, Anti-Asthmatic Agents, Anti-Inflammatory Agents, Antidiarrheals, Intestinal Antiinflammatory/antiinfective Agents, Autonomic Agents, Bronchodilator Agents, BSEP/ABCB11 Substrate. It has a molecular weight of 430.54 and a topological polar surface area of 93.06. The log p value is 2.9.

Mechanism of Action: Budesonide works by reducing inflammation through its binding to the glucocorticoid receptor, which mediates changes in gene expression that lead to multiple downstream effects over hours to days. This reduces the symptoms of inflammatory conditions such as asthma and Crohn's disease.

Clinical Indication: Budesonide is indicated for the treatment and maintenance of mild to moderate Crohn’s disease, as well as for prophylactic therapy in asthma and reducing exacerbations of COPD. A budesonide nasal spray is available over the counter for symptoms of hay fever and upper respiratory allergies.

Protein Binding: Budesonide is generally bound to corticosteroid binding globulin and serum albumin in plasma, with 85-90% protein bound in plasma.

Pharmacodynamics: Budesonide is a glucocorticoid used to treat respiratory and digestive conditions by reducing inflammation. It has a wide therapeutic index, as dosing varies highly from patient to patient. Patients should be counseled regarding the risk of hypercorticism and adrenal axis suppression.

Half-life: Budesonide has a plasma elimination half-life of 2-3.6 hours, with a terminal elimination half-life of 4-6 hours in asthmatic children aged 4-6 years old.

Paramethasone:
Paramethasone is a glucocorticoid with the general properties of corticosteroids. It has been used by mouth in the treatment of all conditions in which corticosteroid therapy is indicated except adrenal-deficiency states for which its lack of sodium-retaining properties makes it less suitable than hydrocortisone with supplementary fludrocortisone. Paramethasone reduces inflammatory reaction by limiting the capillary dilatation and permeability of the vascular structures, restricting the accumulation of polymorphonuclear leukocytes and macrophages, and reducing the release of vasoactive kinins. It inhibits leukocyte infiltration at the site of inflammation, interferes with mediators of inflammatory response, and suppresses humoral immune responses. The antiinflammatory actions of paramethasone are thought to involve phospholipase A2 inhibitory proteins, lipocortins, which control the biosynthesis of potent mediators of inflammation such as prostaglandins and leukotrienes. On binding, the corticoreceptor-ligand complex translocates itself into the cell nucleus, where it binds to many glucocorticoid response elements (GRE) in the promoter region of the target genes. The DNA bound receptor then interacts with basic transcription factors, causing an increase or decrease in expression of specific target genes, including suppression of IL2 (interleukin 2) expression.

Paramethasone is a solid and has an estimated protein binding of 80%. It belongs to the category of Adrenal Cortex Hormones, Anti-Inflammatory Agents, Corticosteroids, Corticosteroids for Systemic Use, and Cytochrome P-450 CYP3A Inducers. Its approval status is experimental.

Mechanistically, paramethasone inhibits leukocyte infiltration at the site of inflammation by limiting capillary dilatation and permeability, restricts the accumulation of polymorphonuclear leukocytes and macrophages, and reduces the release of vasoactive kinins. It interferes with mediators of inflammatory response by inhibiting phospholipase A2 inhibitory proteins, lipocortins, which control the biosynthesis of potent mediators of inflammation such as prostaglandins and leukotrienes. Additionally, paramethasone suppresses humoral immune responses by binding to glucocorticoid response elements (GRE) in the promoter region of target genes, including suppression of IL2 (interleukin 2) expression.

In conclusion, paramethasone is a glucocorticoid with anti-inflammatory properties that can be used to treat various conditions where corticosteroid therapy is indicated, excluding adrenal-deficiency states. Its mechanism of action involves inhibiting leukocyte infiltration, interfering with inflammatory mediators, and suppressing humoral immune responses.
Ciclesonide: Ciclesonide is a glucocorticoid used to treat obstructive airway diseases. It is marketed under the brand name Alvesco. Clinical indication includes the treatment of nasal symptoms associated with seasonal and perennial allergic rhinitis in adults and adolescents 12 years of age and older. Mechanism of action involves glucocorticoids such as ciclesonide can inhibit leukocyte infiltration at the site of inflammation, interfere with mediators of inflammatory response, and suppress humoral immune responses. The anti-inflammatory actions of glucocorticoids are thought to involve phospholipase A2 inhibitory proteins, lipocortins, which control the biosynthesis of potent mediators of inflammation such as prostaglandins and leukotrienes. Ciclesonide reduces inflammatory reaction by limiting the capillary dilatation and permeability of the vascular structures. These compounds restrict the accumulation of polymorphonuclear leukocytes and macrophages and reduce the release of vasoactive kinins. Recent research suggests that corticosteroids may inhibit the release of arachidonic acid from phospholipids, thereby reducing the formation of prostaglandins. Ciclesonide is a glucocorticoid receptor agonist. On binding, the corticoreceptor-ligand complex translocates itself into the cell nucleus, where it binds to many glucocorticoid response elements (GRE) in the promoter region of the target genes. The DNA bound receptor then interacts with basic transcription factors, causing an increase or decrease in expression of specific target genes, including suppression of IL2 (interleukin 2) expression. CRx-119:
CRx-119 is a novel synergistic combination drug candidate discovered using CombinatoRx combination High Throughput Screening (cHTS(TM)) technology, consisting of a low dose of the steroid prednisolone (3mg) and amoxapine. This drug candidate is being investigated for its potential therapeutic use in a broad range of immuno-inflammatory conditions, including periodontal disease and rheumatoid arthritis. The mechanism of action of CRx-119 involves the anti-inflammatory actions of glucocorticoids such as prednisolone, which can inhibit leukocyte infiltration at the site of inflammation, interfere with mediators of inflammatory response, and suppress humoral immune responses. Additionally, amoxapine acts by decreasing the reuptake of norepinephrine and serotonin (5-HT), which can modulate immune responses. The combination of these two compounds is designed to synergistically enhance the therapeutic effects of prednisolone without replicating its toxicity. CRx-119 is an orally available drug candidate in clinical development, with a target product profile aiming to selectively amplify certain elements of prednisolone's anti-inflammatory and immunomodulatory effects.

The pharmacodynamics of CRx-119 involve the interaction between prednisolone and amoxapine, which results in a synergistic effect that enhances the therapeutic benefits of prednisolone without increasing its toxicity. The low dose of prednisolone in CRx-119 is designed to reduce the risk of steroid toxicity while still providing adequate anti-inflammatory and immunomodulatory effects. The combination of these two compounds also allows for a more targeted therapy, as the immunomodulatory effects of amoxapine can help modulate the immune response and reduce inflammation in a more precise manner.

In conclusion, CRx-119 is a novel synergistic combination drug candidate with potential therapeutic use in a range of immuno-inflammatory conditions. Its mechanism of action involves the anti-inflammatory effects of glucocorticoids and the modulation of immune responses by amoxapine, which work together to provide a more targeted and effective therapy. Further research and clinical trials are needed to fully evaluate the safety and efficacy of CRx-119 in humans.
Fluticasone furoate:
Fluticasone furoate is a synthetic glucocorticoid used for the treatment and management of asthma by prophylaxis, as well as for treating seasonal and perennial allergic rhinitis. It works through an unknown mechanism to affect various cell types and mediators of inflammation, including activating glucocorticoid receptors, inhibiting nuclear factor kappa b, and inhibiting lung eosinophilia in rats. The drug is >99% protein bound in serum and has a half-life of 15.1 hours for intranasal administration and 24 hours for the inhaled formulation. Fluticasone furoate belongs to the adrenal cortex hormones category, is an inhibitor of cytochrome P-450 CYP3A, and has a topological polar surface area of 93.81.

Fluticasone furoate was first approved in 2007 for the treatment of asthma and allergic rhinitis. Its mechanism of action is not fully understood, but it is believed to work by binding to glucocorticoid receptors on various cell types, including immune cells and epithelial cells. This binding leads to a decrease in the production of pro-inflammatory mediators, such as cytokines and chemokines, which are responsible for the inflammation associated with asthma and allergic rhinitis. Additionally, fluticasone furoate has been shown to inhibit the activation of nuclear factor kappa b (NF-κb), a transcription factor that regulates the expression of genes involved in inflammation.

The drug is available as an inhaler and nasal spray, which allows for targeted delivery to the respiratory tract. The inhaled formulation has been shown to be more effective than oral corticosteroids in reducing asthma symptoms, as it bypasses the first-pass metabolism that occurs when a drug is taken orally. The intranasal spray is also more convenient for patients, as it can be self-administered as needed throughout the day.

Fluticasone furoate has a relatively short half-life, which means that its effects are rapidly reversible after stopping treatment. However, this also means that the drug needs to be taken frequently to maintain therapeutic levels in the body. The drug is metabolized by cytochrome P-450 enzymes, particularly CYP3A, and can interact with other medications metabolized by these enzymes. Therefore, it is important for patients taking fluticasone furoate to inform their healthcare provider of any medications they are taking concurrently.

In conclusion, fluticasone furoate is a valuable treatment option for patients with asthma and allergic rhinitis. Its rapid onset of action, targeted delivery to the respiratory tract, and relatively short half-life make it an effective and convenient treatment choice. However, its mechanism of action is not fully understood, and it can interact with other medications metabolized by cytochrome P-450 enzymes. As with any medication, close monitoring and communication with a healthcare provider are important to ensure safe and effective use.
Medrogestone: Medrogestone, also known as 6,17α-dimethyl-6-dehydroprogesterone, is a progestational agent derived from 17-methylprogesterone. It was conceived as an alternative orally effective contraceptive option. Despite its approval in Canada in 1969, it was never approved by the FDA and its current status is cancelled post-marketing. Medrogestone is a progestogen that binds to the progesterone receptor and suppresses gonadotropic hormones from the anterior portion of the pituitary gland, leading to secondary suppression of testosterone. It presents structural similarities to testosterone, allowing it to compete for the androgen-receptor-protein receptor sites in prostatic cells. Administration of medrogestone diminishes the response to endogenous hormones in tumor cells due to a reduction in hormone steroid receptors, leading to cytotoxic or antiproliferative effects. Medrogestone is highly bound to plasma proteins and its pharmacokinetics are dependent on the degree of plasma protein binding. In pre-clinical trials, medrogestone was proven to have four times more progestational activity than progesterone with a similar duration effect than the one found for 17-hydroxyprogesterone. Medrogestone does not present any androgenic or oestrogenic effect, nor changes in organ weight or histological appearance in adrenal glands or thymus. Its molecular weight is 340.51, topological polar surface area is 34.14, and logP value is 4.38. Medrogestone belongs to the categories of Adrenal Cortex Hormones, Cytochrome P-450 CYP3A Substrates, Cytochrome P-450 CYP3A4 Substrates, Cytochrome P-450 Substrates, Fused-Ring Compounds, Genito Urinary System and Sex Hormones, Pregnadien Derivatives, Pregnadienes, Pregnanes, Progestins, and Progestogens.
Fluticasone: Fluticasone is a synthetic glucocorticoid with two esters, available in various formulations for the treatment and management of inflammatory conditions such as asthma, nonallergic rhinitis, seasonal and perennial allergic rhinitis. The exact mechanism of action is unknown, but it is believed to affect various cell types and mediators of inflammation through glucocorticoid receptors, nuclear factor kappa b, and lung eosinophilia inhibition. As a topical formulation, fluticasone can also cause vasoconstriction in the skin. The drug has a half-life of 15.1 hours for intranasal and 24 hours for the inhaled formulation, and it is protein bound in serum to >99%. Fluticasone belongs to several drug categories, including adrenal cortex hormones, anti-allergic agents, anti-asthmatic agents, anti-inflammatory agents, autonomic agents, bronchodilator agents, corticosteroid hormone receptor agonists, corticosteroids, and dermatologics. It was first approved in 1990 and again in 2007 for various indications.
Hydrocortisone cypionate: Hydrocortisone cypionate is a glucocorticoid medication used to treat inflammatory and immune-related disorders, such as corticosteroid-responsive dermatoses, adrenal insufficiency, Addison's disease, arthritis, lupus, severe psoriasis, severe asthma, ulcerative colitis, and Crohn's disease. It works by binding to the cytosolic glucocorticoid receptor, which leads to the activation of various genes that regulate inflammation and immune function. Hydrocortisone cypionate has a half-life of 6-8 hours and is metabolized by cytochrome P-450 enzymes. It is classified as an 11-hydroxycorticosteroid, 17-hydroxycorticosteroid, adrenal cortex hormone, corticosteroid, and cytochrome P-450 CYP2C8 inducer. The molecular weight of hydrocortisone cypionate is 486.65, and its topological polar surface area is 100.9. Hydrocortisone cypionate is approved for medical use in humans and is also used in veterinary medicine.
Hydrocortisone valerate: Hydrocortisone valerate is a topical corticosteroid used to treat inflammatory and pruritic manifestations of corticosteroid-responsive dermatoses, as well as endocrine (hormonal) disorders such as adrenal insufficiency and Addison's disease. It is also used to treat many immune and allergic disorders, including arthritis, lupus, severe psoriasis, severe asthma, ulcerative colitis, and Crohn's disease. The mechanism of action of hydrocortisone valerate involves binding to the cytosolic glucocorticoid receptor, which leads to the translocation of the receptor-ligand complex into the nucleus. Once in the nucleus, the receptor binds to specific target genes and induces their expression, leading to the suppression of inflammatory responses and immune functions. Hydrocortisone valerate has a molecular weight of 446.58 and a topological polar surface area (TPSA) of 100.9. It is a part of several drug categories, including 11-hydroxycorticosteroids, 17-hydroxycorticosteroids, adrenal cortex hormones, anti-inflammatory agents, corticosteroids, cytochrome P-450 CYP2C8 inducers (strength unknown), and cytochrome P-450 CYP3A inducers. The half-life of hydrocortisone valerate is 6-8 hours, and it is approved for use in both humans and animals.
Prednisolone phosphate: Prednisolone phosphate is a glucocorticoid similar to used for its anti-inflammatory, immunosuppressive, anti-neoplastic, and vasoconstrictive effects. It is widely used in the treatment of various conditions such as allergic states, dermatologic diseases, edematous states, endocrine disorders, gastrointestinal diseases, hematologic disorders, neoplastic diseases, nervous system, ophthalmic diseases, respiratory diseases, and rheumatic disorders. The mechanism of action of prednisolone phosphate involves the binding to the glucocorticoid receptor, which mediates changes in gene expression leading to multiple downstream effects over hours to days. Prednisolone is 70-90% protein bound in plasma and typically binds to albumin and corticosteroid binding globulin. The half life of prednisolone phosphate is 2-4 hours, and it is part of Adrenal Cortex Hormones, Anti-Inflammatory Agents, Corticosteroids, Cytochrome P-450 CYP2A6 Inducers, Cytochrome P-450 CYP2B6 Inducers, Cytochrome P-450 CYP2B6 Inducers (strength unknown), and Cytochrome P-450 CYP2C19 Inducers. Betamethasone phosphate: Betamethasone phosphate is a prodrug that is rapidly hydrolyzed, providing rapidly accessible to agonize glucocorticoid receptors. It provides greater anti-inflammatory activity than with less sodium and water retention. Betamethasone phosphate is indicated intramuscularly to treat allergic states, dermatologic diseases, endocrine disorders, gastrointestinal diseases, hematologic disorders, neoplastic diseases, nervous system conditions, ophthalmic diseases, renal diseases, respiratory diseases, rheumatic disorders, trichinosis with neurologic or myocardial involvement, and tuberculous meningitis with subarachnoid block or impending block. It is also used intra-articularly in the treatment of acute gouty arthritis, acute and subacute bursitis, acute nonspecific tenosynovitis, epicondylitis, rheumatoid arthritis, and synovitis of osteoarthritis. Intralesional betamethasone phospahte is indicated in the treatment of alopecia areata, discoid lupus erythematosus, keloids, lichen planus, lichen simplex chronicus, psoriatic plaques, necrobiosis lipoidica diabeticorum, and localized hypertrophic, infiltrated, inflammatory lesions of granuloma annulare. Betamethasone phosphate is a soluble ester prodrug of betamethasone, which is rapidly de-esterified, allowing betamethasone to act as an agonist of the glucocorticoid receptor. The short term effects of corticosteroids are decreased vasodilation and permeability of capillaries, as well as decreased leukocyte migration to sites of inflammation. Corticosteroids binding to the glucocorticoid receptor mediates changes in gene expression that lead to multiple downstream effects over hours to days. Betamethasone phosphate has a short duration of action as it is rapidly hydrolyzed to betamethasone, and corticosteroids have a wide therapeutic window as patients may require doses that are multiples of what the body naturally produces. Patients taking corticosteroids should be counselled regarding the risk of hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis suppression and increased susceptibility to infections. Betamethasone phosphate is a solid, and its half-life is 12.47 ± 1.91 h after an intramuscular injection of 3mg betamethasone acetate and 3mg betamethasone phosphate. Betamethasone phosphate is approved and veterinary approved.
Prednisolone Acetate:
Prednisolone acetate is a corticosteroid drug that is used to treat a wide range of inflammatory and immune-related conditions, including allergic reactions, dermatologic disorders, gastrointestinal problems, hematologic abnormalities, ophthalmologic diseases, nervous system disorders, renal diseases, respiratory conditions, rheumatologic conditions, and infectious diseases. It is also used in organ transplant patients and for endocrine or neoplastic conditions. Prednisolone acetate works by binding to the glucocorticoid receptor, which leads to changes in gene expression that result in anti-inflammatory effects. The active metabolite of prednisolone acetate, prednisolone, is 70-90% protein bound in plasma. Prednisolone acetate has a short duration of action, with a half-life of 2-3 hours, and its therapeutic window allows for doses that are multiples of what the body naturally produces. However, patients taking corticosteroids should be counseled regarding the risk of hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis suppression and increased susceptibility to infections.

PHARMACODYNAMICS: Prednisolone acetate has a short term effect of decreased vasodilation and permeability of capillaries, as well as decreased leukocyte migration to sites of inflammation. The active metabolite, prednisolone, binds to the glucocorticoid receptor, inhibiting pro-inflammatory signals and promoting anti-inflammatory signals. Prednisolone acetate has a wide therapeutic window as patients make require doses that are multiples of what the body naturally produces.

Rubidium chloride (Rb-82) injection: Rubidium chloride (Rb-82) injection is a sterile nonpyrogenic solution of rubidium Rb 82 chloride, indicated for Positron Emission Tomography (PET) imaging of the myocardium under rest or pharmacologic stress conditions to evaluate regional myocardial perfusion in adult patients with suspected or existing coronary artery disease. Rubidium Rb 82 is rapidly extracted by the myocardium proportional to the blood flow, and participates in the sodium-potassium (Na+/K+) ion exchange pumps that are present in cell membranes. The intracellular uptake of Rb-82 requires maintenance of ionic gradient across cell membranes. The tracer is cleared rapidly from necrotic or infarcted tissue, and myocardial activity is noted within the first minute after peripheral intravenous injection. Areas of infarction or ischemia in the myocardium are visualized within 2-7 minutes after injection as photon-deficient, or “cold”, areas on the myocardial scan. The half-life of Rb-82 is 1.27 minutes. Rubidium Rb-82 is part of Radioactive Diagnostic Agent; Radiopharmaceutical Activity and has approval status as approved and investigational.
Vitamin A: Vitamin A is a group of fat-soluble substances that play essential roles in various physiological processes, including metabolic functioning of the retina, epithelial differentiation, growth, reproduction, immune response, and bone development. It is derived from dietary sources such as plants and animal products, and is enriched in the liver, egg yolks, and dairy products. Vitamin A is structurally related to and possesses the biological activity of all-trans retinol or retinol. The molecular weight of vitamin A is 286.46, and it has a topological polar surface area of 20.23. Vitamin A is bound to lipoproteins in blood in normal conditions, but may be up to 65% when hepatic stores are saturated due to excessive intake. It is effective for the treatment of vitamin A deficiency and plays vital roles in vision, epithelial differentiation, growth, reproduction, pattern formation during embryogenesis, bone development, hematopoiesis, and brain development. Vitamin A is also important for maintaining the proper functioning of the immune system. It has a half-life of 1.9 hours, and its logP value is 6.4. Beta-carotene:
Beta-carotene is a carotenoid with the molecular formula C40H56, composed of isoprene units. It is the most abundant form of carotenoid and serves as a precursor to vitamin A. Beta-carotene has antioxidant properties and is found in yellow, orange, and green leafy vegetables and fruits. It is considered safe by the FDA for use as a nutrient supplement and food coloring. Oral administration increases serum concentration by 60%, but does not affect concentrations in the heart, liver, or kidneys. In vitro studies have shown that beta-carotene ameliorates oxidative stress, enhances antioxidant activity, and decreases apoptosis. Beta-carotene is bound to plasma proteins and is rapidly transformed to retinol, which is highly bound to plasma proteins. The apparent half-life of beta-carotene is 6-11 days after initial administration.

Beta-carotene acts as an antioxidant by scavenging reactive oxygen species, such as singlet oxygen, through its conjugated double bonds. It presents oxidative modification of LDL and chelates free radicals, inhibiting lipid peroxidation. Beta-carotene is thought to be highly bound to plasma proteins, including the chylomicron and VLDL, and is rapidly transformed to retinol after absorption. The mechanism of action of beta-carotene is through its antioxidant properties, which protect cells from oxidative damage.

In terms of pharmacodynamics, oral administration of beta-carotene increases the serum concentration of beta-carotene by 60%, but does not affect concentrations in the heart, liver, or kidneys. Beta-carotene is registered to be retained by the chylomicron and transported in VLDL. After absorption, beta-carotene is rapidly transformed to retinol which is highly bound to a high number of plasma proteins.

Beta-carotene has a solid physical state and a molecular weight of 536.89. Its logP value is 15.23, indicating its lipophilic nature. Beta-carotene is part of several drug categories, including Alimentary Tract and Metabolism, Alkenes, Biological Factors, Carotenoids, Cyclohexanes, Cyclohexenes, Cycloparaffins, Dermatologicals, Diet, Food, and Nutrition, Emollients and Protectives, Food, Food and Beverages, Growth Substances, Hydrocarbons, Acyclic, Mi.

Overall, beta-carotene is a safe and effective antioxidant that presents significant efficacy against reactive oxygen species. Its mechanism of action involves scavenging free radicals through its conjugated double bonds, and it is highly bound to plasma proteins after absorption.
Vitamin E: Vitamin E is a term used to describe 8 different fat-soluble tocopherols and tocotrienols, with alpha-tocopherol being the most biologically active. It acts as an antioxidant, protecting cell membranes from oxidative damage, and its antioxidant effects are currently being researched for various clinical uses. Vitamin E supplementation is indicated for treatment of vitamin E deficiency, which can occur in conditions such as cystic fibrosis, cholestasis, and severe liver disease. The mechanism of action for most of vitamin E's effects is still unknown, but it is believed to protect cells against the harmful effects of free radicals. Low levels of vitamin E have been linked to an increased incidence of breast and colon cancer. Vitamin E is a solid with a molecular weight of 430.72 and a topological polar surface area of 29.46. It is part of the Antioxidants, Basic Ointments and Protectants, Benzopyrans, Cytochrome P-450 CYP3A Inducers, Cytochrome P-450 CYP3A Substrates, Cytochrome P-450 CYP3A4 Inducers, and Vet-approved drug categories. The half-life of vitamin E in premature neonates given an intramuscular injection is 44 hours, while the intravenous injection in the intestinal lymph has a half-life of 12 minutes. Vitamin E is approved for use as a nutraceutical and veterinary drug.
N-Ethylretinamide:
N-Ethylretinamide is a solid drug that belongs to the class of retinoids, which are derived from vitamin A. It is an ethylamide of all-trans B-retinoic acid, a potent regulator of cellular differentiation and tissue development. N-Ethylretinamide has been investigated for its potential therapeutic applications in various fields, including cancer treatment, skin health, and neurodegenerative diseases.

Pharmacological Properties: N-Ethylretinamide exhibits a unique chemical structure that allows it to interact with specific cellular receptors and enzymes, leading to changes in gene expression and cellular behavior. It has been shown to have anti-inflammatory and antioxidant properties, as well as the ability to induce apoptosis (programmed cell death) in cancer cells.

Clinical Uses: N-Ethylretinamide is currently being investigated for its potential therapeutic applications in various diseases, including cancer, skin disorders, and neurodegenerative diseases. Its ability to induce apoptosis in cancer cells makes it a promising candidate for cancer treatment, while its anti-inflammatory and antioxidant properties may provide benefits for patients with skin disorders or neurodegenerative diseases.

Mechanisms: The mechanisms of action of N-Ethylretinamide are not fully understood, but it is believed to interact with specific cellular receptors and enzymes, leading to changes in gene expression and cellular behavior. Its ability to induce apoptosis in cancer cells may involve the disruption of cellular signaling pathways, while its anti-inflammatory and antioxidant properties may be due to its ability to scavenge reactive oxygen species (ROS) and modulate immune responses.

Fenretinide: Fenretinide is a synthetic retinoid with chemopreventive and antineoplastic properties, used orally for the prevention of prostate cancer in men and breast cancer in women at high risk. It selectively accumulates in breast tissue and inhibits cell growth through apoptosis, differentiating it from vitamin A and other chemopreventive agents like tamoxifen. Fenretinide has been investigated for use in macular degeneration, with promising results. Its mechanism of action involves both retinoid-receptor-dependent and retinoid-receptor-independent pathways, making it a versatile candidate for breast cancer chemoprevention. Despite being an investigational drug, fenretinide shows great potential as a safe and effective treatment option for various cancers.

Diethylstilbestrol:
Diethylstilbestrol is a synthetic nonsteroidal estrogen used in the treatment of menopausal and postmenopausal disorders. It was also formerly used as a growth promoter in animals, but according to the Fourth Annual Report on Carcinogens (NTP 85-002, 1985), it has been listed as a known carcinogen. Estrogens diffuse into their target cells and interact with a protein receptor, the estrogen receptor. Target cells include the female reproductive tract, the mammary gland, the hypothalamus, and the pituitary. The effect of Estrogen binding their receptors causes downstream increases in hepatic synthesis of sex hormone binding globulin (SHBG), thyroid-binding globulin (TBG), and other serum proteins, and suppresses follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) from the anterior pituitary. The combination of an estrogen with a progestin suppresses the hypothalamic-pituitary system, decreasing the secretion of gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH). Diethylstilbestrol is a solid and has a molecular weight of 268.36, topological polar surface area of 40.46, and logP value of 4.96. It is part of Adrenal Cortex Hormones; Antineoplastic Agents, Hormonal; BCRP/ABCG2 Inhibitors; Benzene Derivatives; Benzylidene Compounds; BSEP/ABC

Diethylstilbestrol was initially used in the prevention of miscarriage or premature delivery in pregnant women prone to miscarriage or premature delivery. However, due to its linkage to a rare vaginal cancer in female offspring, the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) issued a Drug Bulletin advising physicians to stop prescribing DES to pregnant women. Since then, diethylstilbestrol has been primarily used in the treatment of menopausal and postmenopausal disorders. Its mechanisms of action involve estrogen binding to its receptors in target cells, leading to increased synthesis of SHBG, TBG, and other serum proteins, as well as suppression of FSH from the anterior pituitary. The combination of an estrogen with a progestin further suppresses the hypothalamic-pituitary system, decreasing the secretion of GnRH.

Despite its initial promise as a growth promoter in animals, diethylstilbestrol has been linked to several adverse effects, including the rare vaginal cancer in female offspring. While it was initially used to prevent miscarriage or premature delivery in pregnant women, its linkage to vaginal cancer in female offspring has led to its limited use in the treatment of menopausal and postmenopausal disorders. As such, diethylstilbestrol remains a valuable tool in the management of these conditions, but its use must be carefully monitored and evaluated due to its potential adverse effects.
Liothyronine:
Liothyronine is a thyroidal hormone T3, which is normally produced by the thyroid gland in a ratio of 4:1 compared to T4. It is composed of a tyrosine molecule with bound iodine and serves as the active form of thyroxine. Liothyronine was developed by King Pharmaceuticals and was approved by the FDA in 1956 for clinical use. The drug replaces endogenous thyroid hormone and exerts its physiological effects by controlling DNA transcription and protein synthesis through binding to thyroid receptors attached to DNA. It increases energy expenditure, accelerates cellular oxidation, stimulates growth, maturation, and metabolism of body tissues, aids in myelination of nerves, and enhances carbohydrate and protein metabolism. Liothyronine presents a large binding to plasma proteins, with around 99.7% of the administered dose found bound. It is important to consider that only the small unbound portion of liothyronine is metabolically active. In hormonal replacement, liothyronine is more potent and has a faster action compared to levothyroxine, but the time of action is significantly shorter. The onset of activity is observed within a few hours after administration, and the maximum effect is observed after 2-3 days. Liothyronine is a solid and has a molecular weight of 650.98. Its topological polar surface area is 92.78, and its logP value is 2.63. Liothyronine is part of several drug categories, including Agents used to treat hypothyroidism, Drugs that are Mainly Renally Excreted, Hormones, Hormone Substitutes, and Hormone Antagonists, l-Triiodothyronine, OAT3/SLC22A8 Inhibitors, OATP1B1/SLCO1B1 Substrates, OATP1B3 substrates, P-glycoprotein inducers, and System. The half-life of liothyronine is reported to be between 1 and 2 days.

Liothyronine is used to treat hypothyroidism, a condition where the thyroid gland does not produce enough thyroid hormones. It is also used to treat other conditions such as cretinism, myxedema, and thyroid cancer. Liothyronine works by replacing the missing thyroid hormones in the body, which helps to restore normal metabolic functions. It is important to note that liothyronine should only be used under the guidance of a healthcare professional, as excessive use can lead to serious side effects such as heart failure and bone loss.
Levothyroxine:
Levothyroxine is a synthetically produced form of thyroxine, a major endogenous hormone secreted by the thyroid gland. It is used primarily to treat hypothyroidism, a condition where the thyroid gland is no longer able to produce sufficient quantities of the thyroid hormones T4 (tetraiodothyronine or thyroxine) and T3 (triiodothyronine or ), resulting in diminished down-stream effects of these hormones. Without sufficient quantities of circulating thyroid hormones, symptoms of hypothyroidism begin to develop such as fatigue, increased heart rate, depression, dry skin and hair, muscle cramps, constipation, weight gain, memory impairment, and poor tolerance to cold temperatures. Levothyroxine is indicated as replacement therapy in primary (thyroidal), secondary (pituitary) and tertiary (hypothalamic) congenital or acquired hypothyroidism, and as an adjunct to surgery and radioiodine therapy in the management of thyrotropin-dependent well-differentiated thyroid cancer. Levothyroxine is a synthetically prepared levo-isomer of the thyroid hormone thyroxine (T4), which acts as a replacement in deficiency syndromes such as hypothyroidism. T4 is the major hormone secreted from the thyroid gland and is chemically identical to the naturally secreted T4: it increases metabolic rate, decreases thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) production from the anterior lobe of the pituitary gland, and, in peripheral tissues, is converted to T3. Thyroxine is released from its precursor protein thyroglobulin through proteolysis and secreted into the blood where it is then peripherally deiodinated to form triiodothyronine (T3). Thyroxine is bound to plasma proteins, including thyroxine-binding globulin (TBG), thyroxine-binding prealbumin (TBPA) and albumin (TBA). The higher affinity of both TBG and TBPA for T4 partially explains the higher serum levels, slower metabolic clearance and longer half-life of T4 compared to T3. Protein-bound thyroid hormones exist in reverse equilibrium with small amounts of free hormone where only unbound hormone is metabolically active. Levothyroxine exerts the same physiologic effect as endogenous T4, thereby maintaining normal T4 levels when a deficiency is present. The molecular weight of levothyroxine is 776.87, and its topological polar surface area is 92.78. Its logP value is 3.51. Thyroxine is bound to plasma proteins, including thyroxine-binding globulin (TBG), thyroxine-binding prealbumin (TBPA) and albumin (TBA). The higher affinity of both TBG and TBPA for T4 partially explains the higher serum levels, slower metabolic clearance and longer half-life of T4 compared to T3. Diclofenac: Diclofenac is a phenylacetic acid derivative and non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) that inhibits cyclooxygenase (COX)-1 and -2, the enzymes responsible for producing prostaglandins (PGs). PGs contribute to inflammation and pain signaling. As a first-line therapy, diclofenac is used to treat acute and chronic pain and inflammation from various causes. The addition of two chlorine groups in the ortho position of the phenyl ring reportedly increases potency. It is often used in combination with other drugs, such as aspirin, to prevent NSAID-induced gastric ulcers. Diclofenac was first approved by the FDA in July 1988 under the trade name Voltaren, marketed by Novartis (previously Ciba-Geigy). Its clinical indications include pain and inflammation from inflammatory conditions such as osteoarthritis, rheumatoid arthritis, and akylosing spondylitis, as well as injury-related inflammation due to surgery and physical trauma. The mechanism of action of diclofenac is through inhibition of COX-1 and -2 enzymes, which results in reduced production of prostaglandins G2, the precursors to other PGs. Diclofenac has a solid physical state and a terminal half-life of approximately 2 hours, with an apparent half-life including all metabolites of 25.8-33 hours. Its molecular weight is 296.15, and its topological polar surface area is 49.33. Diclofenac belongs to several drug categories, including Acetic Acid Derivatives and Related Substances; Acids, Carbocyclic; Agents causing angioedema; Agents causing hyperkalemia; Agents that produce hypertension; Amines; Analgesics; Analgesics, Non-Narcotic; Anti-Inflammatory Agents; and Anti-Inflammatory Agents, Non-Steroidal. It is approved and veterinary approved.
Diflunisal:
Diflunisal is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory agent (NSAIA) with pharmacologic actions similar to other prototypical NSAIAs. It possesses anti-inflammatory, analgesic, and antipyretic activity, and its mechanism of action has not been clearly established, though most of its actions appear to be associated with inhibition of prostaglandin synthesis via the arachidonic acid pathway. Diflunisal is used to relieve pain accompanied with inflammation and in the symptomatic treatment of rheumatoid arthritis and osteoarthritis. Diflunisal's pharmacological properties make it a useful medication for relieving pain and inflammation associated with various conditions, including rheumatoid arthritis and osteoarthritis. As a nonsteroidal agent, diflunisal does not have the same side effects as steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (SAS), such as stomach ulcers and digestive problems.
