The molecular weight of morphine is 285.34, and it has a topological polar surface area of 52.93. Morphine is part of several drug categories, including alkaloids, analgesics, anesthetics, central nervous system agents, and cytochrome P-450 substrates. Its approval status is both approved and investigational.

Mechanistically, morphine binding to opioid receptors in the brain and nervous system can block transmission of nociceptive signals, leading to analgesia. Additionally, morphine activation of the reward pathway through agonism of the delta-opioid receptor in the nucleus accumbens mediates its addictive potential. Morphine's pharmacological properties are complex and multifaceted, making it a valuable tool for managing pain but also a challenging drug to use due to its potential for abuse and addiction. As such, morphine remains an important part of modern medical practice despite the availability of newer, semi-synthetic opioids with varying strengths and mechanisms of action.
Desogestrel:
Desogestrel is a third-generation progestin and member of the gonane family, primarily used as a contraceptive agent in combination with other hormones. It was first approved by FDA in 1992 and is produced semi-synthetically from naturally occurring plant steroids. Desogestrel enters cells passively and binds selectively to the progesterone receptor, generating low androgenic activity. Its binding produces an effect similar to a transcription factor, modifying mRNA synthesis. The main metabolite of desogestrel is bound to albumin and sex-hormone binding globulin, with 96-98% of the administered dose found bound to plasma proteins. Desogestrel has a topological polar surface area of 20.23 and a logP value of 5.5. It belongs to various drug categories, including adrenal cortex hormones, combination contraceptives, and cytochrome P-450 CYP2C9 and CYP3A substrates.

PHARMACOLOGICAL PROPERTIES:
Desogestrel acts on reproductive systems by modifying luteinizing hormone and follicle-stimulating hormone, delaying the onset of menstruation, and increasing vaginal fluid viscosity. It also has metabolic effects, such as increased insulin secretion and resistance, increased lipolysis, and fat deposition. The drug's effects on lipids have been studied extensively, with inconclusive results.

CLINICAL USES: Desogestrel is primarily used as a contraceptive agent in combination with other hormones. It is approved for use in the US, Canada, and Europe.

MECHANISM OF ACTION: Desogestrel binds selectively to the progesterone receptor, generating low androgenic activity. Its binding produces an effect similar to a transcription factor, modifying mRNA synthesis.

PHARMACOKINETICS: The terminal half-life of desogestrel is 30 hours, and it is bound to plasma proteins by 96-98%.

DRUG CATEGORIES: Desogestrel belongs to various drug categories, including adrenal cortex hormones, combination contraceptives, and cytochrome P-450 CYP2C9 and CYP3A substrates.

APPROVAL STATUS: Desogestrel is approved for use in the US, Canada, and Europe.
Chlorthalidone: Chlorthalidone is a thiazide-like diuretic used for the treatment of hypertension and management of edema caused by conditions such as heart failure or renal impairment. It improves blood pressure and swelling by preventing water absorption from the kidneys through inhibition of the Na+/Cl− symporter in the distal convoluted tubule cells in the kidney. The exact mechanism of chlorthalidone's anti-hypertensive effect is under debate, however, it is thought that increased diuresis results in decreased plasma and extracellular fluid volume, decreased cardiac output and therefore overall reduction in blood pressure. Chlorthalidone also has been shown to decrease platelet aggregation and vascular permeability, as well as promote angiogenesis in vitro, which is thought to be partly the result of reductions in carbonic anhydrase–dependent pathways. These pathways may play a role in chlorthalidone's cardiovascular risk reduction effects. Chlorthalidone is bound to plasma proteins, with approximately 75 percent of the drug being bound to albumin. The molecular weight of chlorthalidone is 338.76, and its topological polar surface area is 109.49. Chlorthalidone has a logP value of 0.45. It is part of Acids, Carbocyclic ; Amides ; Antihypertensive Agents ; Antihypertensive Agents Indicated for Hypertension ; Benzene Derivatives ; Benzophenones ; Cardiovascular Agents ; Diuretics ; Drugs causing inadvertant photosensitivity ; Heterocyclic Compounds, Fused-Ring. Chlorthalidone is approved for use in the management of hypertension and edema.
Valproic acid:
Valproic acid, or valproate, is an anticonvulsant drug that was originally synthesized in 1881 by Beverly S. Burton. It enjoyed use as a popular organic solvent in industry and pharmaceutical manufacturing for nearly a century before its serendipitous discovery as an anticonvulsant in 1963. Valproate is indicated for the treatment of complex partial seizures, migraine headaches, and bipolar disorder. The exact mechanisms by which valproate exerts its effects are unknown, but it is thought to produce increased cortical inhibition to contribute to control of neural synchrony, as well as a neuroprotective effect preventing damage and neural degeneration. Valproic acid has a solid physical state, with a half-life of 13-19 hours. Its molecular weight is 144.21, and it has a topological polar surface area of 37.3. Valproic acid is part of several drug categories, including Acids, Acyclic; Anti-epileptic Agent; Anticonvulsants; Antimanic Agents; Antineoplastic Agents; Central Nervous System Agents; Central Nervous System Depressants; Cytochrome P-450 CYP1A2 Inhibitors (strength unknown); and Cytochrome P.

Mechanism of Action: The exact mechanisms by which valproate exerts its effects on epilepsy, migraine headaches, and bipolar disorder are unknown; however, several pathways exist that may contribute to the drug's action. Valproate has been shown to reduce the incidence of complex partial seizures and migraine headaches and improve symptom control in bipolar mania. It is thought that valproate produces increased cortical inhibition to contribute to control of neural synchrony, as well as a neuroprotective effect preventing damage and neural degeneration.

Protein Binding: Protein binding is linear at low concentrations with a free fraction of approximately 10% at 40 mcg/mL but becomes non-linear at higher concentrations with a free fraction of 18.5% at 135 mcg/mL. This may be due to binding at separate high and low-affinity sites on albumin proteins. Binding is expected to decrease in the elderly and patients with hepatic dysfunction.

Pharmacodynamics: Valproic acid has been shown to reduce the incidence of complex partial seizures and migraine headaches, as well as improve symptom control in bipolar mania. It is thought that valproate produces increased cortical inhibition to contribute to control of neural synchrony, as well as a neuroprotective effect preventing damage and neural degeneration.

Physical State: Valproic acid is a solid.

Half-life: The half-life of valproic acid is 13-19 hours.

Molecular Properties: The molecular weight of valproic acid is 144.21, and its topological polar surface area is 37.3. Its logP value is 2.76.

Approval Status: Valproic acid is approved and investigational.
Acetaminophen (paracetamol): Acetaminophen, also known as Tylenol, is a widely used analgesic and antipyretic drug that is recommended as the first-line therapy for mild to moderate pain conditions by the World Health Organization (WHO). It is available in various forms, including oral tablets, syrup, effervescent tablets, injection, suppository, and others. The exact mechanism of action of acetaminophen has not been fully established, although it is thought to exert central actions that lead to the alleviation of pain symptoms. Animal and clinical studies have shown that acetaminophen has both antipyretic and analgesic effects, lacking anti-inflammatory effects. The binding of acetaminophen to plasma proteins is low, ranging from 10% to 25%. Acetaminophen does not disrupt tubular secretion of uric acid or affect acid-base balance at therapeutic doses. It also lacks inhibitory activities against platelet aggregation and does not cause allergic reactions. The half-life of acetaminophen varies depending on the severity of injury to the liver, ranging from 4 to 8 hours after an overdose. Acetaminophen has a molecular weight of 151.16 and a topological polar surface area of 49.33. It is part of several drug categories, including acetaminophen and prodrugs, amides, anilines, analgesics, non-narcotic, antipyretics, central nervous system agents, cytochrome P-450 CYP1A2 substrates, CYP2A6 substrates, and CYP2D6 substrates. Acetaminophen was initially approved by the U.S. FDA in 1951 and is available over-the-counter in various forms.
Gefitinib:
Gefitinib is a drug used in the treatment of certain types of cancer, specifically non-small cell lung cancer. It works by selectively targeting the mutant proteins in malignant cells, similar to erlotinib. Gefitinib binds to the ATP-binding site of the epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) tyrosine kinase, which is often overexpressed in human carcinoma cells. By inhibiting EGFR tyrosine kinase, gefitinib inhibits downstream signaling cascades and reduces malignant cell proliferation. Gefitinib is the first selective inhibitor of the EGFR tyrosine kinase and is marketed by AstraZeneca under the trade name Iressa.

Clinical Indication: Gefitinib is approved for the continued treatment of patients with locally advanced or metastatic non-small cell lung cancer after failure of either platinum-based or docetaxel chemotherapies.

Mechanism of Action: Gefitinib inhibits the intracellular phosphorylation of numerous tyrosine kinases associated with transmembrane cell surface receptors, including the epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR-TK). EGFR is expressed on the cell surface of many normal cells and cancer cells. By inhibiting EGFR tyrosine kinase, gefitinib inhibits downstream signaling cascades and reduces malignant cell proliferation.

Protein Binding: Gefitinib binds primarily to serum albumin and alpha 1-acid glycoproteins, independent of drug concentrations.

Pharmacodynamics: Gefitinib inhibits the intracellular phosphorylation of numerous tyrosine kinases associated with transmembrane cell surface receptors, including the epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR-TK). EGFR is expressed on the cell surface of many normal cells and cancer cells.

Physical State: Gefitinib is a solid.

Half-life: The half-life of gefitinib is 48 hours.

Molecular Properties: The molecular weight of gefitinib is 446.91, and its topological polar surface area is 68.74. Its log p value is 5.45.

Drug Categories: Gefitinib is part of Antineoplastic Agents; Antineoplastic and Immunomodulating Agents; BCRP/ABCG2 Inhibitors; BCRP/ABCG2 Substrates; Cytochrome P-450 CYP2C19 Inhibitors; Cytochrome P-450 CYP2C19 inhibitors (strength unknown); Cytochrome P-450 CYP2C9 Inhibitors; and Cytochrome P-450 CYP2C9 Inhibitors.

Approval Status: Gefitinib is approved and investigational.
Amitriptyline hydrochloride:
Amitriptyline hydrochloride, also known as Elavil, is a tricyclic antidepressant (TCA) with analgesic properties, widely used to treat depression and neuropathic pain. It was originally approved by the FDA in 1977 and manufactured by Sandoz. Amitriptyline works by increasing the concentration of neurotransmitters such as norepinephrine and serotonin in the brain, which can help improve mood and alleviate symptoms of depression. The drug has a high protein binding capacity, with about 95% of the drug bound to proteins in plasma and tissues. The elimination half-life of amitriptyline after peroral administration is approximately 25 hours, and it has a topological polar surface area of 3.24 and a logP value of 4.85. Amitriptyline belongs to several drug categories, including Adrenergic alpha-1 Receptor Antagonists, Adrenergic alpha-Antagonists, Adrenergic Antagonists, Adrenergic Uptake Inhibitors, Agents producing tachycardia, Agents that produce hypertension, Agents that reduce seizure threshold, Analgesics, Non-Narcotic Analgesics, and Antidepressants. The drug is approved for medical use by the FDA.

The mechanism of action of amitriptyline is not fully understood, but it is believed to inhibit the membrane pump mechanism responsible for the re-uptake of transmitter amines such as norepinephrine and serotonin, thereby increasing their concentration at the synaptic clefts of the brain. This increase in neurotransmitters can help improve mood and alleviate symptoms of depression. The monoamine hypothesis in depression posits that deficiencies of serotonin (5-HT) and/or norepinephrine (NE) neurotransmission in the brain lead to depressive effects, and amitriptyline counteracts these mechanisms.

In addition to its use in treating depression, amitriptyline is also used to treat neuropathic pain, such as postherpetic neuralgia (PHN) and painful peripheral neuropathy associated with diabetes mellitus. The drug can be administered orally or intramuscularly, and its analgesic effects are thought to be due in part to its ability to increase the concentration of endorphins in the brain.

In conclusion, amitriptyline is a valuable treatment option for depression and neuropathic pain, with a well-established mechanism of action and a long history of use in clinical practice. Its high protein binding capacity and relatively long elimination half-life may require careful dosing and monitoring to ensure optimal therapeutic effects.
Hydromorphone: Hydromorphone is a pure opioid drug that has been available clinically since 1920. It is a semi-synthetic hydrogenated ketone derivative of morphine, with a chemical structure that differs from its parent compound in the modification of the hydroxyl group in the carbon 6 to a carbonyl and the absence of a double bond between the carbon 7 and 8. Despite these modifications, hydromorphone presents a very high potency and comparable side effect profile to morphine. Due to its addictive potential and overdose risk, hydromorphone is only prescribed when other first-line treatments have failed. The drug acts on different types of opioid receptors, including the mu-opioid receptor, with a binding affinity that corresponds to about 8-19% of the administered dose. In clinical trials, hydromorphone has been shown to be suitable for pain relief in patients who do not tolerate the side effects of or who suffer from renal failure or asthma. It is 5-7 times more potent than morphine with a shorter duration of analgesia. Hydromorphone is a solid and its protein binding corresponds to about 8-19% of the administered dose. Its half-life ranges from 2-3 hours for the immediate-release formulation, while the extended-release formulation has a range of 8-15 hours. Molecular properties include a molecular weight of 285.34 and a topological polar surface area of 49.77. Hydromorphone is part of several drug categories, including Alkaloids, Analgesics, Central Nervous System Agents, and Cytochrome P-450 Substrates. It is approved for medical use but also has illicit status in some countries.
Indometacin:
Indometacin is a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) with anti-inflammatory, analgesic, and antipyretic properties. It works by inhibiting the enzyme cyclooxygenase (COX), which is responsible for catalyzing the rate-limiting step in prostaglandin and thromboxane biosynthesis via the arachidonic acid pathway. This leads to decreased prostaglandin synthesis, resulting in reduced inflammation, pain, and fever. Indometacin is approved for symptomatic management of moderate to severe rheumatoid arthritis, including acute flares of chronic disease, moderate to severe ankylosing spondylitis, moderate to severe osteoarthritis, acute painful shoulder (bursitis and/or tendinitis), and acute gouty arthritis. It is known to have a biphasic disposition from the plasma, with a half-life of 1 hour during the initial phase and 2.6–11.2 hours during the second phase. Indometacin is bound to protein in plasma over the expected range of therapeutic plasma concentrations, primarily binding to plasma albumin but not to red blood cells. Its molecular weight is 357.79 and has a topological polar surface area of 68.53. Indometacin is part of Acetic Acid Derivatives and Related Substances; Agents causing hyperkalemia; Agents that produce hypertension; Analgesics; Analgesics, Non-Narcotic; Anti-Inflammatory Agents; Anti-Inflammatory Agents, Non-Steroidal; and Anti-Inflammatory Agents, Non-Steroidal (Non-Selective). Its adverse reactions may include gastrointestinal effects such as bleeding, ulceration, and perforation of the stomach or intestines.

Mechanism of Action: Indometacin is a nonspecific and reversible inhibitor of the cyclo-oxygenase (COX) enzyme, or prostaglandin G/H synthase. There are two identified isoforms of COX: COX-1 is universally present in most body tissues and is involved in the synthesis of the prostaglandins and thromboxane A2, while COX-2 is expressed in response to injury or inflammation. Indometacin binds to the active site of the enzyme and prevents the interaction between the enzyme and its substrate, arachidonic acid. It also inhibits phospholipase A2, the enzyme responsible for releasing arachidonic acid from phospholipids. Decreased levels of PGE2 leads to reduced inflammatory reactions.

Clinical Indication: Oral indometacin is indicated for symptomatic management of moderate to severe rheumatoid arthritis, including acute flares of chronic disease, moderate to severe ankylosing spondylitis, moderate to severe osteoarthritis, acute painful shoulder (bursitis and/or tendinitis), and acute gouty arthritis.

Protein Binding: Indometacin is a weak organic acid that is 90-99% bound to protein in plasma over the expected range of therapeutic plasma concentrations. It primarily binds to plasma albumin but does not bind to red blood cells.

Pharmacodynamics: Indometacin provides relief of pain, reduces fever, swelling, and tenderness by suppressing inflammation in rheumatoid arthritis. Its therapeutic action does not involve pituitary-adrenal stimulation.

Physical State: Indomethacin is a solid.

Half-life: Indometacin disposition from the plasma is reported to be biphasic, with a half-life of 1 hour during the initial phase and 2.6–11.2 hours during the second phase.

Molecular Properties: Molecular weight: 357.79, TPSA: 68.53, cLogP: 4.18.
Ipratropium: Ipratropium is a quaternary ammonium derivative that acts as an anticholinergic agent. It is commonly administered through inhalation, which allows for a local effect without significant systemic absorption. Inhaled ipratropium is indicated in combination with inhaled beta-agonist and systemic corticosteroids for the management of severe exacerbations of asthma flares requiring treatment. The mechanism of action of ipratropium involves its antagonistic effect on the muscarinic acetylcholine receptor, leading to inhibition of the parasympathetic nervous system in the airways and bronchodilation. The protein binding of ipratropium is low, with the bound state representing only 0-9% of the administered dose. The pharmacodynamics of ipratropium are short-acting, with the effect starting after 1-2 hours and lasting for 4-6 hours. Ipratropium is a solid with a molecular weight of 332.46 and a topological polar surface area of 46.53. The log p value of ipratropium is -2.19. Ipratropium belongs to the Adrenergics, Inhalants; Agents producing tachycardia; Agents to Treat Airway Disease; Alkaloids; Anti-Asthmatic Agents; Anticholinergic Agents; Antimuscarinics Antispasmodics; Atropine Derivatives; Autonomic Agents; Aza Compounds; Azabicyclo Compounds; Belladonna Alliance. Ipratropium is approved and experimental.
Methadone: Methadone is a potent synthetic analgesic that works as a full µ-opioid receptor (MOR) agonist and N-methyl-d-aspartate (NMDA) receptor antagonist. As a full MOR agonist, methadone mimics the natural effects of the body's opioids, endorphins, and enkephalins through the release of neurotransmitters involved in pain transmission. Its unique properties have led to increased use in the last two decades, including a lower risk of neuropsychiatric toxicity compared to other opioids, minimal accumulation in renal failure, good bioavailability, low cost, and a long duration of action. Clinically, methadone is indicated for the management of pain severe enough to require an opioid analgesic and for which alternative treatment options are inadequate. Mechanistically, methadone acts as an agonist of µ- and κ-opioid receptors within the central and peripheral nervous systems, with antagonism of the NMDA receptor and strong inhibition of serotonin and norepinephrine uptake contributing to its antinociceptive activity. Methadone binds extensively to plasma proteins, primarily α1-acid glycoprotein, albumin, and other tissue and plasma proteins, leading to slow transfer between parts of this tissue reservoir and the plasma. Pharmacodynamically, methadone results in analgesia, suppression of opioid withdrawal symptoms, sedation, miosis, sweating, hypotension, bradycardia, nausea and vomiting, and constipation, as well as flushing, pruritus, and urticaria through binding to receptors in the pupillary muscles. Methadone is a solid with a molecular weight of 309.45 and topological polar surface area of 20.31. Its half-life ranges from 7-59 hours due to interindividual differences in pharmacokinetics, and it is approved for use.
Olanzapine: Olanzapine is a thienobenzodiazepine classified as an atypical or second-generation antipsychotic agent. It was introduced in the 1990s and quickly gained traction due to its impressive efficacy, reduced risk for extrapyramidal side effects, and reduced susceptibility to drug-drug interactions. The molecular structure of olanzapine closely resembles that of other antipsychotics, with only minor differences in the number of methyl groups and the absence of a chloride moiety. Olanzapine binds to multiple neuronal receptors, including dopamine D1, D2, D3, and D4 receptors, serotonin 5HT2A, 5HT2C, 5HT3, and 5HT6 receptors, alpha-1 adrenergic receptor, histamine H1 receptor, and multiple muscarinic receptors. This binding activity leads to a decrease in hallucinations, delusions, disorganized speech, disorganized thought, and disorganized behavior, as well as a prevention of anhedonia, flat affect, alogia, avolition, and poor attention. The half-life of olanzapine ranges between 21 to 54 hours, with an average half-life of 30 hours. Olanzapine is a solid and has a molecular weight of 312.44. Its topological polar surface area is 30.87, and its logP value is 2.86. Olanzapine is part of several drug categories, including Adrenergic alpha-1 Receptor Antagonists, Adrenergic alpha-Antagonists, Adrenergic Antagonists, Agents producing tachycardia, Anticholinergic Agents, Antipsychotic Agents, Antipsychotic Agents (Second Generation), Autonomic Agents, and more. Olanzapine was approved for use in the US in 1996, and its mechanisms of action have been extensively studied and reported in medical literature.
Atenolol: Atenolol is a cardioselective beta-blocker, indicated for various cardiovascular conditions. It binds to the β1-adrenergic receptor as an antagonist, selectively binding up to 26 fold more than β2 receptors. This selectivity reduces adenylyl cyclase activity and protein kinase A (PKA) signaling, resulting in decreased heart rate, electrical conductivity, and contractility. The reduction in cardiac output leads to an increase in peripheral vascular resistance, compensating for the reduced myocardial workload. Additionally, atenolol reduces oxygen demand by reducing the mismatch between oxygen supply and demand, particularly during exercise, which can reduce angina pectoris symptoms and improve survival of the remaining myocardium after myocardial infarction. Atenolol also benefits arrhythmic conditions such as atrial fibrillation by controlling rate of action potential generation and allowing for more effective coordinated contractions. However, its reduced contractility may precipitate or worsen heart failure during volume overload. Atenolol is a solid with a molecular weight of 266.34, topological polar surface area of 84.58, and logP value of -0.11. It is part of Adrenergic Agents; Adrenergic Antagonists; Adrenergic beta-1 Receptor Antagonists; Adrenergic beta-Antagonists; Agents causing hyperkalemia; Alcohols; Amines; Amino Alcohols; Antiarrhythmic agents; Antihypertensive Agents; Antihypertensive Agents Indicated for Hypertension. The half-life of atenolol is 6-7 hours, and it is approved for use in various cardiovascular conditions.
Diltiazem:
Diltiazem is a benzothiazepine derivative with antihypertensive and vasodilating properties, approved by the FDA in 1982. It works through various mechanisms of action, including inhibiting the influx of extracellular calcium ions into cardiac and vascular smooth muscle during depolarization. Diltiazem displays an intermediate specificity to target both the cardiac and vascular smooth muscle. Being a potent vasodilator, diltiazem is used clinically as an antihypertensive, anti-arrhythmic, and anti-anginal agent for the management of cardiovascular conditions such as hypertension, chronic stable angina, atrial fibrillation, atrial flutter. Apart from its main FDA-approved indications, diltiazem has also been used off-label for numerous indications, including anal fissures (in topical formulations), migraine prophylaxis, pulmonary hypertension, and rest-related cramps in the lower extremities. Typically available in extended-release oral and intravenous formulations, diltiazem is marketed under various brand names with Cardizem and Tiazac being the most common ones.

Mechanism of Action: Diltiazem is a slow calcium channel blocker that binds to the extracellular site of the alpha-1C subunit of the channel, which is thought to be the S5-6 linker region of the transmembrane domain IV and/or S6 segment of domain III. Diltiazem can get access to this binding site from either the intracellular or extracellular side, but it requires a voltage-induced conformational changes in the membrane. In isolated human atrial and ventricular myocardium, diltiazem suppressed tension over the range of membrane potentials associated with calcium channel activity but had little effect on the tension-voltage relations at more positive potentials. This effect is thought to be mediated by the voltage-dependent block of the L-type calcium channels and inhibition of calcium ion release from the ER stores, without altering the sodium-calcium coupled transport or calcium sensitivity of myofilaments. Through inhibition of inward calcium current, diltiazem exerts a direct ionotropic and energy sparing effect on the myocardium. Diltiazem fslows atrioventricular nodal conduction, which is due to its ability to impede slow channel function.

Pharmacodynamics: Diltiazem is an antihypertensive and vasodilating agent that works by relaxing the vascular muscle and reducing blood pressure. This is related to the long-term therapeutic effects, as lowering the blood pressure reduces the risk of fatal and non-fatal cardiovascular events, primarily strokes and myocardial infarctions. Diltiazem inhibits the influx of extracellular calcium ions across the myocardial and vascular smooth muscle cell membranes during depolarization. Diltiazem is classified as a negative inotrope (decreased force) and negative chronotrope (decreased rate). It is also considered a rate-control drug as it reduces heart rate.

Physical State: Diltiazem is a solid.

Half-life: The plasma elimination half-life is approximately 3.0 - 4.5 hours following single and multiple oral doses. The half-life may slightly increase with dose and the extent of hepatic impairment. The apparent elimination half-life for diltiazem as extended-release tablets after single or multiple dosing is 6 to 9 hours. The plasma elimination half-life is approximately 3.4 hours following administration of a single intravenous injection.

Molecular Properties: Molecular Weight: The molecular weight is 414.52., TPSA: Diltiazem has a topological polar surface area of 59.08., cLogP: The log p value of  is 3.65.
Alprazolam:
Alprazolam is a triazolobenzodiazepine indicated for the treatment of anxiety and panic disorders. It is mainly metabolized by CYP3As and so is contraindicated with CYP3A inhibitors like ketoconazole and itraconazole. Benzodiazepine treatment should be stopped gradually by tapering down a patient's dose to avoid withdrawal symptoms. Alprazolam's adverse effects are generally related to the sedation it can cause. Alprazolam has been mixed with alcohol as a drug of abuse to potentiate the sedative effects of the drug which may lead to coma and death. Alprazolam was given FDA approval on October 16, 1981.

Alprazolam is a triazolobenzodiazepine that acts on benzodiazepine receptors BNZ-1 and BNZ-2. The active metabolites 4-hydroxyalprazolam and alpha-hydroxyalprazolam act on these receptors with 0.20 times the potency of alprazolam, respectively. Alprazolam is 80% protein bound in serum, primarily to serum albumin, and also binds to alpha1-acid glycoprotein with low frequency. The mechanism by which its cell receptor interactions translate to a clinical effect is not known.

Alprazolam is indicated to treat anxiety and panic disorders, and may be prescribed off label for insomnia, premenstrual syndrome, and depression. Its half-life in healthy patients is 11.2 hours, which is longer in the elderly (16.3h), alcoholic liver disease patients (5.8-65.3h), obese patients (9.9-40.4h), and Asian patients (25% higher than Caucasians). The molecular weight of alprazolam is 308.77, and it has a topological polar surface area of 43.07 and a logP value of 2.55.

Alprazolam belongs to several drug categories, including Alcohols, Amines, Amino Alcohols, Anti-Anxiety Agents, Benzazepines, Benzene Derivatives, Benzodiazepines and benzodiazepine derivatives, Biogenic Amines, Biogenic Monoamines, Catechols, Central Nervous System Agents, Central Nervous System Depressants, Cytochrome P enzymes, and others. It was approved by the FDA on October 16, 1981, and is both illicit and investigational for non-medical use.

In conclusion, Alprazolam is a triazolobenzodiazepine used to treat anxiety disorders, panic disorder, and insomnia. It acts on benzodiazepine receptors and has protein binding properties that affect its pharmacokinetics. Its mechanism of action is not fully understood, but it has been shown to have a clinical effect in treating anxiety and panic disorders. Alprazolam belongs to several drug categories and has a long half-life, which can be a benefit or a drawback depending on the patient population.
Rosiglitazone:
Rosiglitazone is an anti-diabetic drug in the thiazolidinedione class of drugs, marketed by GlaxoSmithKline as a standalone drug (Avandia) and in combination with metformin (Avandamet) or with glimepiride (Avandaryl). It is a selective ligand of the intracellular receptor class of the peroxisome proliferator-activated receptors (PPARs), specifically PPARγ. The mechanism of action of rosiglitazone is by activation of the intracellular receptor class of the peroxisome proliferator-activated receptors (PPARs), specifically PPARγ, which has an anti-inflammatory effect and enhances tissue sensitivity to insulin. Rosiglitazone is indicated as an adjunct to diet and exercise to improve glycemic control in adults with type 2 diabetes mellitus. The drug is bound to plasma proteins, primarily albumin, and has a solid physical state. Its half-life is 3-4 hours, and it has a molecular weight of 357.43 and a topological polar surface area of 71.53. Rosiglitazone is part of Alimentary Tract and Metabolism; Blood Glucose Lowering Agents; BSEP/ABCB11 Substrates; Cytochrome P-450 CYP1A2 Inhibitors; Cytochrome P-450 CYP2A6 Inhibitors. Its approval status is approved and investigational.

Rosiglitazone's mechanism of action involves the activation of PPARγ receptors, which regulates the transcription of insulin-responsive genes involved in glucose production, transport, and utilization. This enhances tissue sensitivity to insulin, leading to improved glycemic control in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus. Additionally, rosiglitazone has an anti-inflammatory effect, as evidenced by the decrease in NFκB levels and increase in IκB levels in patients on the drug. Recent research suggests that rosiglitazone may also be beneficial for a subset of patients with Alzheimer's disease who do not express the ApoE4 allele, which is currently under investigation.

Rosiglitazone has several pharmacodynamic effects, including increases in total cholesterol, LDL, and HDL, as well as decreases in free fatty acids. However, these changes are primarily seen during the first 1 to 2 months of therapy with AVANDIA, and LDL levels remain elevated above baseline throughout the trials. In contrast, HDL continues to rise over time. As a result, the LDL/HDL ratio peaks after 2 months of therapy and then appears to decrease over time.

Rosiglitazone is bound to plasma proteins, primarily albumin, and has a solid physical state. Its half-life is 3-4 hours, and it has a molecular weight of 357.43 and a topological polar surface area of 71.53. Rosiglitazone is part of several drug categories, including Alimentary Tract and Metabolism; Blood Glucose Lowering Agents; BSEP/ABCB11 Substrates; Cytochrome P-450 CYP1A2 Inhibitors; Cytochrome P-450 CYP2A6 Inhibitors. Its approval status is approved and investigational, indicating that it is currently being studied for its potential therapeutic uses beyond type 2 diabetes mellitus.
Acetohexamide:
Acetohexamide is a sulfonylurea hypoglycemic agent that is metabolized in the liver to 1-hydrohexamide. It was previously used in the management of diabetes mellitus type 2 (adult-onset) before being discontinued in the US market. The drug works by binding to an ATP-dependent K<sup>+</sup> channel on the cell membrane of pancreatic beta cells, which inhibits a tonic, hyperpolarizing outflux of potassium and depolarizes the cell membrane, leading to increased fusion of insulin granulae with the cell membrane and increased secretion of (pro)insulin. Acetohexamide has a molecular weight of 324.4 and a topological polar surface area of 92.34. It is a solid and has a logP value of 2.25. Acetohexamide is part of the Alimentary Tract and Metabolism, Blood Glucose Lowering Agents, Cytochrome P-450 CYP2C9 Substrates, Cytochrome P-450 Substrates, Drugs Used in Diabetes, Sulfones, and Sulfonylureas drug categories. Its elimination half-life is approximately 5-6 hours, with the parent compound having a half-life of 1.3 hours.

Mechanistically, acetohexamide acts as an intermediate-acting, first-generation oral sulfonylurea by stimulating the pancreatic beta cells to secrete insulin and by helping the body use insulin efficiently. The drug is only effective when there are functional pancreatic beta cells that can produce insulin granules. Acetohexamide has one-third the potency of chlorpropamide and twice the potency of tolbutamide, but similar hypoglycemic efficacy occurs with equipotent dosage of sulfonylureas.

In terms of protein binding, acetohexamide binds to 90% of insulin in the bloodstream, which is an important factor in its mechanism of action. The drug's pharmacodynamics are characterized by its intermediate-acting nature and its ability to stimulate pancreatic beta cells to secrete insulin. Acetohexamide has a relatively short half-life compared to other sulfonylureas, which may impact its efficacy and dosing regimen.

Overall, acetohexamide is an important drug in the management of diabetes mellitus type 2, particularly in patients with functional pancreatic beta cells. Its mechanism of action involves binding to ATP-dependent K<sup>+</sup> channels on pancreatic beta cells and stimulating insulin secretion, making it a valuable tool in the treatment of this condition.
Ampicillin:
Ampicillin is a semi-synthetic derivative of penicillin that functions as an orally active broad-spectrum antibiotic. It is used to treat infections caused by susceptible, usually gram-positive, organisms such as E. coli, P. mirabilis, enterococci, Shigella, S. typhosa and other Salmonella, nonpenicillinase-producing N. gononhoeae, H. influenzae, staphylococci, streptococci including streptococcus pneumoniae. The mechanism of action involves binding to specific penicillin-binding proteins (PBPs) located inside the bacterial cell wall, which inhibits the third and last stage of bacterial cell wall synthesis. This leads to cell lysis through autolysins. Ampicillin is stable against hydrolysis by a variety of beta-lactamases, including penicillinases, cephalosporinases, and extended spectrum beta-lactamases.

Pharmacodynamics: Ampicillin is a penicillin beta-lactam antibiotic that inhibits bacterial cell wall synthesis by binding to PBPs. It has activity against both gram-positive and gram-negative aerobic and anaerobic bacteria, including methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA). The bactericidal activity of Ampicillin results from the inhibition of cell wall synthesis.

Physical State: Ampicillin is a solid.

Molecular Properties: Molecular Weight: 349.41, TPSA: 112.73, cLogP: -1.2.

Drug Categories: Ampicillin is part of the Amides; Aminopenicillins; Anti-Bacterial Agents; Anti-Infective Agents; Antibacterials for Systemic Use; Antiinfectives for Systemic Use; Beta-Lactam Antibacterials; beta-Lactams; Drugs that are Mainly Renally Excreted; Heterocyclic Compounds, Fused-Ring; Lactams; Opioids.

Approval Status: Ampicillin is approved and veterinary approved.
Spironolactone:
Spironolactone is a potassium-sparing diuretic with antihypertensive and antiandrogenic properties. It competitively inhibits mineralocorticoid receptors in the distal convoluted tubule, promoting sodium and water excretion while retaining potassium. This action leads to improved fluid and sodium balance, as well as reductions in blood pressure. Spironolactone is indicated for heart failure, edema in cirrhotic patients, primary hyperaldosteronism, hypertension, nephrotic syndrome, and hirsutism, among other conditions. Its antiandrogenic properties make it a useful off-label treatment for adult acne vulgaris and female pattern hair loss. Spironolactone is also commonly used in medical gender transition. The drug has a half-life of 1.4 hours and is protein bound to >90%. It belongs to the categories of Agents causing hyperkalemia, Antihypertensive Agents, and Cytochrome P-450 CYP2C8 Inhibitors. Spironolactone was approved for medical use in [year].

Spironolactone's mechanisms of action involve competitive inhibition of mineralocorticoid receptors, leading to increased sodium and water excretion and potassium retention. This results in improved fluid and sodium balance, as well as reductions in blood pressure. The drug's protein binding is >90%, with canrenone being as much as 98% bound. Spironolactone's molecular weight is 416.58, and it has a topological polar surface area of 60.44. Its logP value is 2.84.

Spironolactone is a solid at room temperature and has a half-life of 1.4 hours. It belongs to the categories of Agents causing hyperkalemia, Antihypertensive Agents, and Cytochrome P-450 CYP2C8 Inhibitors. Spironolactone was approved for medical use in [year].

The drug's name originates from its chemical structure, which consists of a combination of elements and molecules that work together to produce its unique properties and effects on the body. The name "spironolactone" is derived from the Greek words "spiro," meaning "spiral," and "lactone," indicating a type of compound.

In conclusion, spironolactone is a versatile drug with a range of pharmacological properties that make it useful for treating various medical conditions. Its mechanisms of action involve competitive inhibition of mineralocorticoid receptors, leading to improved fluid and sodium balance, as well as reductions in blood pressure. The drug's protein binding, molecular weight, and logP value are also important factors to consider when prescribing spironolactone for medical use.
Cefpiramide:
Cefpiramide is a third-generation cephalosporin antibiotic that is used to treat severe infections caused by susceptible bacteria, including Pseudomonas aeruginosa. It works by inhibiting bacterial cell wall synthesis via affinity for penicillin-binding proteins (PBPs), resulting in a bactericidal effect. Cefpiramide has a broad spectrum of antibacterial activity and is effective against a wide range of gram-positive and gram-negative bacteria, including methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA). The drug is administered orally or intravenously, and its half-life in plasma is approximately 4.44 hours. Cefpiramide has a topological polar surface area of 212.76 and a logP value of 1.94, indicating that it may be slightly hydrophilic. It belongs to the class of amides, anti-bacterial agents, and anti-infective agents, and is part of the third-generation cephalosporins. Cefpiramide has been approved for use in various countries, including the United States, Canada, and Europe.

Clinically, cefpiramide is used to treat a wide range of infections, including pneumonia, bronchitis, sinusitis, skin infections, and urinary tract infections. It is also effective against osteomyelitis, septicemia, and meningitis caused by susceptible bacteria. Cefpiramide is generally well-tolerated, but it can cause side effects such as nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and headache. Rarely, it may cause more serious adverse reactions, including allergic reactions, hepatitis, and seizures. Drug interactions with cefpiramide are uncommon, but it may interact with certain antacids and antibiotics.

Mechanistically, cefpiramide works by binding to the penicillin-binding proteins (PBPs) in bacterial cells, which is essential for bacterial cell wall synthesis. By inhibiting PBP activity, cefpiramide prevents the formation of new bacterial cell walls, ultimately leading to bacterial death. The drug is bactericidal, meaning that it kills bacteria directly, rather than merely inhibiting their growth. Cefpiramide has been shown to be effective against a wide range of bacterial pathogens, including methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA), which is a major cause of hospital-acquired infections.

In conclusion, cefpiramide is a broad-spectrum cephalosporin antibiotic that is effective against a wide range of bacterial pathogens, including MRSA. It works by inhibiting bacterial cell wall synthesis via affinity for PBPs, resulting in bactericidal activity. Cefpiramide has been approved for use in various countries and is commonly used to treat a wide range of infections, including pneumonia, bronchitis, sinusitis, skin infections, and urinary tract infections.
Trifluridine:
Trifluridine is a fluorinated pyrimidine nucleoside that exhibits antiviral and antineoplastic activities. It is primarily used in the treatment of primary keratoconjunctivitis and recurrent epithelial keratitis due to herpes simplex virus, types 1 and 2. Trifluridine displays effective antiviral activity against Herpes simplex virus type 1 and 2, as well as vacciniavirus, both in vitro and in vivo. It also shows cytotoxic activity against various cancer cell lines, including those resistant to 5-fluorouracil (5-FU). The mechanism of action of trifluridine involves the incorporation into viral DNA during replication, leading to the formation of defective proteins and increased mutation rate. Trifluridine also inhibits thymidylate synthetase (TS) and reversibly binds to human serum albumin. The protein binding of trifluridine is independent of drug concentration and presence of tipiracil. Trifluridine is a solid, with a molecular weight of 296.2 and a topological polar surface area of 99.1. It has a logP value of -0.41. Trifluridine is approved for use in ophthalmic solutions, while its investigational status pertains to its potential use in other indications.

In vitro findings suggest that trifluridine binds to human serum albumin with a high affinity (Kd = 0.24 mM), and the bound fraction is nearly stable over a wide range of drug concentrations (from 0.1 to 10 μM). The binding of trifluridine to human serum albumin is independent of tipiracil, which is added in the antineoplastic combination product to increase the bioavailability of trifluridine. Trifluridine also exhibits protein binding in human plasma, with a mean value of 96% and a range of 80-100%. The protein binding of trifluridine is not affected by drug concentration or tipiracil presence.

Trifluridine displays a half-life of 12 to 18 minutes following ophthalmic administration, which allows for effective antiviral and antineoplastic activity against Herpes simplex virus, types 1 and 2, as well as vacciniavirus. The molecular weight of trifluridine is 296.2, indicating a relatively large size that may influence its pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics. The topological polar surface area of trifluridine is 99.1, which suggests a high degree of hydrophilicity and potential for interactions with biological molecules.

In addition to its antiviral and antineoplastic activities, trifluridine has been shown to inhibit thymidylate synthetase (TS), an enzyme necessary for DNA synthesis and cell proliferation. Up-regulation of TS levels may contribute to the development of resistance to antineoplastic therapies, such as 5-fluorouracil (5-FU). However, the inhibitory effect of trifluridine on TS is not considered sufficient enough to fully contribute to its cytotoxicity in cancer cells.

Trifluridine has been approved for use in ophthalmic solutions, and its investigational status pertains to its potential use in other indications, such as antiviral and antineoplastic therapies. Its mechanism of action involves the incorporation into viral DNA during replication, leading to the formation of defective proteins and increased mutation rate. Trifluridine also exhibits cytotoxic activity against various cancer cell lines, including those resistant to 5-fluorouracil (5-FU). Its protein binding characteristics are not affected by drug concentration or tipiracil presence, and it demonstrates a high degree of hydrophilicity and potential for interactions with biological molecules.
Meperidine: Meperidine is a narcotic analgesic used for the relief of moderate to severe pain, including postoperative pain and the pain of labor. It can produce faster onset of action than morphine with slightly shorter duration of action. Meperidine binds primarily to kappa-opioid receptors, exhibiting both agonist and local anesthetic effects. Its mechanism of action involves inhibition of nociceptive neurotransmitters such as substance P, GABA, dopamine, acetylcholine, and noradrenaline through binding to opioid receptors, leading to hyperpolarization and reduced neuronal excitability. Meperidine also inhibits the release of vasopressin, somatostatin, insulin, and glucagon. The drug is bound to plasma proteins primarily albumin and α1-acid glycoprotein, with reduced binding in cirrhotic or hepatitis patients. Meperidine has a unique ability to interrupt postoperative shivering and shaking chills induced by amphotericin B. It is recommended for relief of moderate to severe acute pain and can be used for intravenous regional anesthesia, peripheral nerve blocks, and intraarticular, epidural, and spinal analgesia. The drug's physical state is a solid, and its half-life in patients with hepatic dysfunction is prolonged to 7-11 hours. Meperidine belongs to the phenylpiperidine class and has a molecular weight of 247.34, topological polar surface area of 29.54, and logP value of 2.23.
Cefalotin:
Cefalotin is a cephalosporin antibiotic, which is used to prevent infection during surgery and to treat various types of infections such as those affecting the blood, bone or joints, respiratory tract, skin, and urinary tract. The mechanism of action of cefalotin involves the inhibition of cell wall synthesis via affinity for penicillin-binding proteins (PBPs), thereby preventing the proper synthesis of the vital cell wall component. Cefalotin has a broad spectrum of antibiotic activity and is administered parenterally. The molecular weight of cefalotin is 396.43, and it has a topological polar surface area of 113.01. Additionally, the log P value of cefalotin is 0.04. Cefalotin belongs to various drug categories such as agents that reduce seizure threshold, amides, anti-bacterial agents, anti-infective agents, and beta-lactams. It is approved for use in humans and animals.

Clinically, cefalotin has been shown to be effective in treating a wide range of bacterial infections, including those caused by Staphylococcus aureus, Streptococcus pneumoniae, Enterobacter aerogenes, and Klebsiella pneumoniae. It is particularly useful in the prevention of surgical site infections (SSIs) and has been shown to reduce the incidence of SSIs by up to 90%. Cefalotin has also been used to treat community-acquired pneumonia, urinary tract infections, and skin and soft tissue infections.

In terms of pharmacokinetics, cefalotin is rapidly absorbed after intravenous administration, with a mean time to peak concentration (Tmax) of approximately 15 minutes. The drug is extensively distributed throughout the body, with a volume of distribution of approximately 300-400 mL/kg. Cefalotin is bound to serum proteins by up to 65-80%, primarily to albumin. The half-life of cefalotin is approximately 30 minutes, and the drug is excreted mainly in the urine, with a small amount being eliminated in the feces.

In terms of adverse effects, cefalotin can cause allergic reactions such as rash, itching, and swelling. It can also cause gastrointestinal disturbances such as nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. Rarely, cefalotin can cause hemolytic anemia, which is a potentially life-threatening complication.

In conclusion, cefalotin is a broad-spectrum cephalosporin antibiotic that is effective in treating various types of bacterial infections. Its mechanism of action involves the inhibition of cell wall synthesis via affinity for penicillin-binding proteins, and it has a wide range of clinical applications. However, cefalotin can cause allergic reactions and gastrointestinal disturbances, and rare complications such as hemolytic anemia can occur.
Imipramine: Imipramine is a dibenzazepine-derivative tricyclic antidepressant (TCA) that acts as a prototypical TCA. It contains a tricyclic ring system with an alkyl amine substituent on the central ring. In non-depressed individuals, imipramine does not affect mood or arousal, but may cause sedation. In depressed individuals, imipramine exerts a positive effect on mood by inhibiting the neuronal reuptake of norepinephrine and serotonin through binding to the sodium-dependent serotonin transporter and sodium-dependent norepinephrine transporter. This increases the concentration of these neurotransmitters in the synaptic cleft, producing knock-on effects in protein kinase signalling which is thought to contribute to changes in neurotransmission and brain physiology that relieve symptoms of depression. Imipramine has less sedative and anticholinergic effects than tertiary amine TCAs, such as amitriptyline and clomipramine. It may be used to treat depression and nocturnal enuresis in children. Unlabeled indications include chronic and neuropathic pain (including diabetic neuropathy), panic disorder, attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD), and post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD). Imipramine is bound to plasma proteins in circulation, with a protein binding ratio of 60-96%. Its molecular weight is 280.42, and it has a topological polar surface area of 6.48 and a logP value of 5.04. Imipramine is approved for use in various indications.
Acitretin: Acitretin is an oral retinoid medication used to treat severe psoriasis in adults. It has a much shorter half-life compared to etretinate, its parent compound, which allows for more rapid onset of action and reduced risk of adverse effects. The mechanism of action of acitretin is unknown, but it is believed to target specific receptors (retinoid receptors such as RXR and RAR) in the skin to normalize the growth cycle of skin cells. It works by inhibiting excessive cell growth and keratinization, reducing the thickening of the skin, plaque formation, and scaling associated with psoriasis. Acitretin is bound to plasma proteins, primarily albumin, with over 99.9% protein binding. Its molecular weight is 326.44, and it has a topological polar surface area of 46.53. The log p value is 6.07. Acitretin belongs to the categories of Alkenes, Antipsoriatics, Antipsoriatics for Systemic Use, Biological Factors, Carotenoids, Cyclohexanes, Cyclohexenes, Cycloparaffins, Dermatologicals, Drugs causing inadvertent photosensitivity, Hepatotoxic Agents, Hydrocarbons, Acyclic, Keratolytic Agents, and Misc. S. It has been approved for use in the treatment of severe psoriasis.
Nabumetone:
Nabumetone is a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) that was initially developed as a less toxic alternative to traditional NSAIDs. It was thought to avoid trapping in the stomach by making it unable to dissociate into ions, thereby reducing gastrointestinal toxicity. However, despite this modification, nabumetone still produces significant adverse effects in the GI tract. The molecule is a pro-drug that is metabolized into its active metabolite, 6-methoxy-2-naphthylacetic acid (6-MNA), which is a potent COX inhibitor similar in structure to traditional NSAIDs. Nabumetone was approved by the FDA in December 1991 under the trade name Relafen for the indication of moderate to severe pain.

Nabumetone's active metabolite, 6-MNA, is an inhibitor of both COX-1 and COX-2, although it exhibits some COX-2 selectivity. This inhibition reduces the conversion of arachidonic acid to prostaglandins (PGs) and thromboxane (TXA2), which are the primary mediators of pain and inflammation. The mechanism of action of nabumetone is similar to that of traditional NSAIDs, as it reduces peripheral and central sensitization of nociceptive neurons due to inflammation, leading to analgesia. However, unlike traditional NSAIDs, nabumetone has a longer half-life and higher protein binding, which may contribute to its greater efficacy and reduced side effect profile.

Nabumetone is effective in reducing mild-moderate acute and chronic nociceptive pain, but its usefulness in neuropathic pain is limited. It has a mean half-life of 24 hours with a range of 19-36 hours, and its molecular weight is 228.29. Its topological polar surface area is 26.3, and it has a logP value of 2.98. Nabumetone is part of several drug categories, including agents causing hyperkalemia, hypertension, analgesics, non-narcotic, anti-inflammatory agents, non-steroidal, and antiinflammatory and antirheumatic products. It has been approved by the FDA for use in humans since 1991.
Fluoxetine:
Fluoxetine is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) drug that gained FDA approval in 1987. It is commonly prescribed to manage depression, obsessive compulsive disorder, bulimia nervosa, and panic disorder, among other conditions. Fluoxetine's mechanism of action involves blocking the serotonin reuptake transporter in the presynaptic terminal, leading to sustained levels of 5-hydroxytryptamine (5-HT) in certain brain areas. However, it has a relatively poor affinity for 5-HT, dopaminergic, adrenergic, cholinergic, muscarinic, and histamine receptors, which explains why it has a more desirable adverse effect profile compared to earlier developed classes of antidepressants. Fluoxetine is protein bound approximately 94% of the time in the plasma, and its half-life ranges from 1-3 days after acute administration and 4-6 days after chronic administration. The drug's long half-life may be beneficial when discontinuing the drug since the risk of withdrawal is minimized. Fluoxetine is part of various categories, including Agents that reduce seizure threshold, Amines, Anticholinergic Agents, and Central Nervous System Depressants. It is approved for use in both acute and maintenance treatment of major depressive disorder, obsessive compulsive disorder, bulimia nervosa, and panic disorder, as well as the treatment of bipolar I disorder and treatment-resistant depression.

Mechanism of Action: Fluoxetine blocks the serotonin reuptake transporter in the presynaptic terminal, leading to sustained levels of 5-hydroxytryptamine (5-HT) in certain brain areas. This action is based on the monoaminergic hypothesis of depression, which posits that depression is caused by dysfunction of neurotransmitters such as serotonin, dopamine, and norepinephrine. The binding of fluoxetine to 5-HT receptors has a relatively poor affinity compared to other classes of antidepressants, which may contribute to its more favorable adverse effect profile.

Clinical Indication: Fluoxetine is approved for the acute and maintenance treatment of major depressive disorder, obsessive compulsive disorder, bulimia nervosa, panic disorder, bipolar I disorder, and treatment-resistant depression. It is commonly prescribed off-label for other conditions, such as anxiety disorders and post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD).

Pharmacodynamics: Fluoxetine's ability to block the serotonin reuptake transporter leads to increased levels of 5-HT in certain brain areas. This increase in 5-HT can lead to improvements in mood, appetite, and sleep, among other symptoms associated with depression and anxiety disorders. However, fluoxetine's binding affinity for 5-HT is relatively low compared to other classes of antidepressants, which may contribute to its more favorable adverse effect profile.

Physical State: Fluoxetine is a solid at room temperature and standard pressure.

Half-life: The half-life of fluoxetine ranges from 1-3 days after acute administration and 4-6 days after chronic administration. This means that the body eliminates the drug slowly over time, leading to a longer duration of action compared to other classes of antidepressants.

Molecular Properties: Fluoxetine has a molecular weight of 309.33 and a topological polar surface area (TPSA) of 21.26. Its logP value is 4.57, indicating that it is moderately soluble in water.

Drug Categories: Fluoxetine belongs to various drug categories, including Agents that reduce seizure threshold, Amines, Anticholinergic Agents, and Central Nervous System Depressants. It is approved for use in both acute and maintenance treatment of major depressive disorder, obsessive compulsive disorder, bulimia nervosa, panic disorder, bipolar I disorder, and treatment-resistant depression.
Duloxetine: Duloxetine is a dual serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor that was first approved by the FDA in 2004 for the treatment of Major Depressive Disorder. Since then, it has received approval for various indications including neuropathic pain, Generalized Anxiety disorder, osteoarthritis, and stress incontinence. Duloxetine works by increasing serotonin and norepinephrine concentrations in Onuf's nucleus, which enhances glutamatergic activation of the pudendal motor nerve and leads to stronger contraction of the external urethral sphinter. This results in a reduction in median incontinence episode frequency at doses of 40 and 80 mg, as well as improvement in Patient Global Impression of Improvement and Incontinence Quality of Life scores. Duloxetine has a molecular weight of 297.42 and a topological polar surface area of 21.26, with a logP value of 4.26. It is part of various drug categories including Agents producing tachycardia, Analgesics, Antidepressive Agents, Central Nervous System Agents, Central Nervous System Depressants, Combined Inhibitors of Serotonin/Norepinephrine Reuptake, Cytochrome P-450 CYP1A2 Substrates, and Cytochrome P-450 CYP2C9 Substrates. Duloxetine continues to be investigated for the treatment of pain in cancer, surgery, and more.
Chlorpromazine:
Chlorpromazine is a prototypical phenothiazine antipsychotic drug. It has several other actions and therapeutic uses, including as an antiemetic and in the treatment of intractable hiccup. Chlorpromazine acts as an antagonist on different postsysnaptic receptors -on dopaminergic-receptors (subtypes D1, D2, D3 and D4), on serotonergic-receptors (5-HT1 and 5-HT2), on histaminergic-receptors (H1-receptors), alpha1/alpha2-receptors (antisympathomimetic properties), and finally on muscarinic (cholinergic) M1/M2-receptors. It has actions at all levels of the central nervous system-primarily at subcortical levels-as well as on multiple organ systems. Chlorpromazine has strong antiadrenergic and weaker peripheral anticholinergic activity; ganglionic blocking action is relatively slight. It also possesses slight antihistaminic and antiserotonin activity. Chlorpromazine is approved and investigational, and vet_approved.

Mechanism of Action: Chlorpromazine acts as an antagonist on different postsynaptic receptors, including dopaminergic-receptors (subtypes D1, D2, D3 and D4), serotonergic-receptors (5-HT1 and 5-HT2), histaminergic-receptors (H1-receptors), alpha1/alpha2-receptors (antisympathomimetic properties), and muscarinic (cholinergic) M1/M2-receptors. This blocking action leads to a decrease in the severity of symptoms associated with schizophrenia, as well as other conditions such as intractable hiccup and acute intermittent porphyria. Additionally, chlorpromazine has sedative and antiemetic properties, which can help alleviate symptoms such as restlessness and apprehension before surgery, and nausea and vomiting.

Pharmacokinetics: Chlorpromazine is administered orally and is rapidly absorbed into the bloodstream. It has a bioavailability of approximately 80%, and its half-life is around 30 hours. Chlorpromazine is bound to plasma proteins, primarily albumin, with a protein binding rate of > 90%. Its elimination is primarily through the liver, with a clearance rate of around 25 liters per hour.

Indications: Chlorpromazine is indicated for the treatment of schizophrenia; to control nausea and vomiting; for relief of restlessness and apprehension before surgery; for acute intermittent porphyria; as an adjunct in the treatment of tetanus; to control the manifestations of the manic type of manic-depressive illness; for relief of intractable hiccups; for the treatment of severe behavioral problems in children (1 to 12 years of age) marked by combativeness and/or explosive hyperexcitable behavior (out of proportion to immediate provocations), and in the short-term treatment of hyperactive children who show excessive motor activity with accompanying conduct disorders consisting of some or all of the following symptoms: impulsivity, difficulty sustaining attention, aggressivity, mood lability, and poor frustration tolerance.

Adverse Effects: Chlorpromazine can cause a range of adverse effects, including weight gain, fall in blood pressure, sedation, ejaculation difficulties, and anticholinergic side effects such as dry mouth, blurred vision, obstipation, difficulty/inability to urinate, sinus tachycardia, ECG-changes, and loss of memory.

Drug Interactions: Chlorpromazine can interact with other medications, including antidepressants, antipsychotics, antihypertensives, and anticholinergics. It is important to inform a healthcare provider of any medications being taken, as these interactions can affect how chlorpromazine works in the body and increase the risk of adverse effects.

Dosage and Administration: Chlorpromazine is typically administered orally, with dosages ranging from 100 to 800 mg per day. The dose may be adjusted based on the patient's response to the medication and any adverse effects that occur.

Contraindications: Chlorpromazine is contraindicated in patients with known hypersensitivity to the drug or any component of its formulation, as well as those with a history of seizures or ECG abnormalities. It is also contraindicated in pregnant women and breastfeeding mothers, as the safety of the medication during these times has not been established.

Overall, chlorpromazine is a valuable medication for the treatment of schizophrenia and other conditions. Its mechanisms of action, pharmacokinetics, indications, adverse effects, drug interactions, dosage and administration, and contraindications are all important factors to consider when prescribing this medication.
Raloxifene: Raloxifene is a second-generation selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) that exhibits tissue-specific effects on breast and uterine tissues, and estrogenic effects on bone, lipid metabolism, and blood coagulation. Available in many countries worldwide, raloxifene was initially approved by the FDA in December 1997 under the market name Evista® for the management and prevention of osteoporosis in postmenopausal women and reduction in risk for invasive breast cancer in postmenopausal women with osteoporosis or those who are at high risk for invasive breast cancer. However, it has a negligible effect on altering the development and progression of breast cancer itself. The most common causes of osteoporosis include postmenopausal deficiency of estrogen and age-related deterioration in bone homeostasis. Due to the risk of bone fractures that may lead to morbidities and reduced quality of life, the management of osteoporosis in postmenopausal women with the use of therapeutic agents in addition to concurrent therapies is critical. Based on findings from competitive binding assays, raloxifene displays binding affinity that is similar to that of estradiol, the predominant circulating estrogen. Estrogens play variable roles at different tissues in females, including the bone, breasts, uterus and liver, by binding to the steroid nuclear hormone receptors, Estrogen Receptor alpha (ERα) or Estrogen Receptor beta (ERβ). These receptors are normally bound to the Heat Shock Protein 90 (Hsp90) when unbound to the ligand. Ligand binding induces a conformational change in the receptor that promotes dissociation of the receptor from Hsp90, dimerization and translocation into the nucleus. This movement into the nucleus allows the receptor to bind to genomic locations based on sequence recognition of the DNA binding domain, also known as the Estrogen Response Elements (EREs). Raloxifene belongs to the selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) drug class that exhibits estrogenic effects on bone and lipid metabolism while mediating anti-estrogenic effects on uterine endometrium and breast tissues. On skeletal tissues, raloxifene stimulates bone-depositing osteoblasts and inhibits bone-resorbing osteoclasts to augment bone mineral density. Raloxifene produces estrogen-like effects on bone, reducing the resorption of bone and increasing bone mineral density in postmenopausal women, thus slowing the rate of bone loss. In a eight-week study evaluating short-term effects of raloxifene in healthy postmenopausal women, there was a decrease in the bone turnover markers, such as serum alkaline phosphatase level, serum osteocalcin level and urinary calcium excretion. Raloxifene is a solid, with a molecular weight of 473.59, topological polar surface area of 70.0, and cLogP value of 6.86. The prolonged half-life has been attributed to the drug's reversible systemic metabolism and significant enterohepatic cycling. Raloxifene is part of BCRP/ABCG2 Substrates; Benzene Derivatives; Benzylidene Compounds; Bone Density Conservation Agents; Cytochrome P-450 CYP2B6 Inhibitors; Cytochrome P-450 CYP2B6 Inhibitors (strong); Cytochrome P-450 CYP2C8 Inhibitors; and Cytochrome P-450 CYP2C8 Inhibitors (strength unknown).
Buspirone:
Buspirone is a novel anxiolytic agent with a unique structure and pharmacological profile. Belonging to the azaspirodecanedione drug class, buspirone is a serotonin 5-HT1A receptor agonist that is not chemically or pharmacologically related to benzodiazepines, barbiturates, and other sedative/anxiolytic drugs. Unlike many drugs used to treat anxiety, buspirone does not exhibit anticonvulsant, sedative, hypnotic, and muscle-relaxant properties. Due to these characteristics, buspirone has been termed 'anxioselective'. First synthesized in 1968 then patented in 1975, it is commonly marketed under the brand name Buspar®. Buspirone was first approved in 1986 by the FDA and has been used to treat anxiety disorders, such as generalized anxiety disorder (GAD), and relieve symptoms of anxiety. It has also been used as a second-line therapy for unipolar depression when the use of selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) is deemed clinically inadequate or inappropriate. The potential use of buspirone in combination with in depression and cognitive impairment via promoting neurogenesis has also been investigated.

The therapeutic action of buspirone in generalized anxiety disorders is thought to be mainly derived from its interaction with two major 5-HT1A receptor subtypes that are involved in the brain's anxiety and fear circuitry to enhance the serotonergic activity in these brain areas. Buspirone acts as a full agonist at presynaptic 5-HT1A receptors, or 5-HT1A autoreceptors, expressed at dorsal raphe while acting as a partial agonist at the postsynaptic 5-HT1A receptors expressed on hippocampus and cortex. 5-HT1A receptors function as inhibitory autoreceptors by being expressed on the soma or dendrites of serotonergic neurons or mediate postsynaptic actions of 5-HT by being highly expressed on the corticolimbic circuits. They are inhibitory G-protein coupled receptors that couple to Gi/Go proteins. When activated, presynaptic 5-HT1A autoreceptors causes neuron hyperpolarization and reduces the firing rate of the serotonergic neuron, thereby decreasing extracellular 5-HT levels in the neuron's projection areas. Activated postsynaptic 5-HT1A receptors promote hyperpolarization to released 5-HT on pyramidal neurons.

Approximately 86% of buspirone is bound to plasma proteins, mainly bound to serum albumin and alpha-1-acid glycoprotein. The clinical effect of buspirone in alleviating the symptoms of generalized anxiety disorders typically takes 2 to 4 weeks to achieve. The delayed onset of action of buspirone suggests that the therapeutic effectiveness in generalized anxiety may involved more than its molecular mechanism of action at the 5-HT1A receptors, or buspirone may induce adaptations of 5-HT1A receptors. Buspirone was not shown to alter the psychomotor or cognitive function in healthy volunteers, and the risk of developing sedation is relatively low compared to other anxiolytics, such as benzodiazepines. Unlike benzodiazepines and barbiturates used in anxiety disorders, buspirone is not associated with a risk for developing physical dependence or withdrawal, or any significant interaction with central nervous system depressants such as ethanol. This is due to the lack of effects on GABA receptors. Buspirone also does not exhibit any anticonvulsant or muscle-relaxing properties, but may interfere with arousal reactions due to its inhibitory action on the activity of noradrenergic locus coerulus neurons.

Buspirone is a solid and has a topological polar surface area of 69.64 and a cLogP value of 2.19. Its molecular weight is 385.51, and it is approved and investigational.
Zidovudine:
Zidovudine is a nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NRTI) that acts as a chain-terminator of viral DNA during reverse transcription. It is a potent inhibitor of HIV replication, with activity against Human Immunodeficiency Virus Type 1 (HIV-1). Zidovudine is phosphorylated to active metabolites that compete for incorporation into viral DNA, inhibiting the HIV reverse transcriptase enzyme competitively and acting as a chain terminator of DNA synthesis. The lack of a 3'-OH group in the incorporated nucleoside analogue prevents the formation of the 5' to 3' phosphodiester linkage essential for DNA chain elongation, thereby terminating viral DNA growth. Zidovudine improves immunologic function, partially reverses HIV-induced neurological dysfunction, and improves certain other clinical abnormalities associated with AIDS. Its principal toxic effect is dose-dependent suppression of bone marrow, resulting in anemia and leukopenia. Zidovudine is a solid and has a molecular weight of 267.24, topological polar surface area (TPSA) of 108.3, and logP value of 0.04. It is approved for use in combination with other antiretroviral agents for the treatment of HIV infections.

Zidovudine acts as a chain-terminator of viral DNA during reverse transcription by incorporating itself into the growing viral DNA chain and terminating it, thus preventing further DNA synthesis. This mechanism of action is different from that of other NRTIs, which compete for incorporation into nascent DNA strands. Zidovudine's unique mechanism of action makes it a valuable component of combination antiretroviral therapy (CART) for the treatment of HIV infections.

Zidovudine has several important pharmacokinetic properties that influence its efficacy and toxicity. Its elimination half-life in HIV-infected patients is approximately 1.1 hours, with a range of 0.5-2.9 hours. This suggests that zidovudine has a relatively short duration of action compared to other NRTIs, which may require longer half-lives for optimal efficacy. Additionally, zidovudine's protein binding capacity is relatively low, at around 30-38%, which may affect its distribution and pharmacokinetics.

In terms of adverse effects, zidovudine can cause dose-dependent suppression of bone marrow, leading to anemia and leukopenia. This is a significant side effect, as it can compromise the patient's immune system and increase the risk of infections. However, this side effect can be managed through careful dosing and monitoring of the patient's blood cell counts.

In conclusion, zidovudine is an important anti-HIV drug that acts as a chain-terminator of viral DNA during reverse transcription. Its unique mechanism of action makes it a valuable component of combination antiretroviral therapy for the treatment of HIV infections. While it can cause dose-dependent suppression of bone marrow, this side effect can be managed through careful dosing and monitoring of the patient's blood cell counts. Overall, zidovudine is an important drug for the treatment of HIV infections, and its unique properties make it a valuable tool in the fight against this disease.
Oxycodone: Oxycodone is a semisynthetic opioid analgesic that was first approved by the FDA in 1950. It is indicated for the treatment of moderate to severe pain, and an extended release formulation is also available for chronic moderate to severe pain requiring continuous opioid analgesics for an extended period. Oxycodone works by binding to the mu opioid receptor in the central nervous system, which can selectively inhibit N-type voltage operated calcium channels and reduce the response to pain. In addition to its analgesic effects, oxycodone also has a range of non-specific effects on various tissues and organs, including the respiratory centre in the brain stem, the cough centre in the medulla, muscles of the pupils, gastrointestinal tract, cardiovascular system, endocrine system, and immune system. The drug is protein bound to serum albumin and alpha1-acid glycoprotein, and its pharmacokinetics include an apparent elimination half-life of 3.2 hours for immediate release formulations and 4.5 hours for extended release formulations. Oxycodone is a solid with a molecular weight of 315.37 and a topological polar surface area of 59.0, as well as being a CYP2D6 substrate, CYP3A substrate, and CYP3A4, CYP3A5, and CYP450 substrate. Despite its approval by the FDA, oxycodone is also illicitly used and has a potential for abuse and addiction.
Tolmetin: Tolmetin is a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory agent (NSAIA) that is similar in mode of action to indomethacin. It is used for the relief of signs and symptoms of rheumatoid arthritis, osteoarthritis, and juvenile rheumatoid arthritis. The mechanism of action of tolmetin is not fully understood, but studies have shown that it inhibits prostaglandin synthetase and reduces the plasma level of prostaglandin E in humans. Tolmetin does not appear to alter the course of the underlying disease, but it is as effective as aspirin and indomethacin in controlling disease activity. It has a biphasic elimination from the plasma, with a rapid phase and a slower phase, and its half-life is approximately 5 hours. Tolmetin has a topological polar surface area of 59.3 and a logP value of 2.21. It belongs to the categories of Acetic Acid Derivatives and Related Substances, Agents causing hyperkalemia, Agents that produce hypertension, Analgesics, Non-Narcotic, Anti-Inflammatory Agents, Non-Steroidal, and Anti-Inflammatory Agents, Non-Steroidal (Non-Selective). Tolmetin is approved for use in various countries, including the United States.
Ritonavir: Ritonavir is an HIV protease inhibitor that interferes with the reproductive cycle of HIV by inhibiting the HIV viral proteinase enzyme, which cleaves the structural and replicative proteins that arise from major HIV genes such as *gag* and *pol*. Ritonavir is now more commonly used as a booster of other protease inhibitors and is available in both liquid formulation and as capsules. It is highly protein-bound in plasma, primarily to albumin and alpha-1 acid glycoprotein, and has a half-life of 3-5 hours. Ritonavir binds to the protease active site and inhibits the activity of the enzyme, preventing cleavage of the viral polyproteins and resulting in the formation of immature non-infectious viral particles. Additionally, ritonavir is a type II ligand that perfectly fits into the CYP3A4 active site cavity and irreversibly binds to the heme iron via the thiazole nitrogen, which decreases the redox potential of the protein and precludes its reduction with the redox partner, cytochrome P450 reductase. Ritonavir may also play a role in limiting cellular transport and efflux of other protease inhibitors via the P-glycoprotein and MRP efflux channels. Modern protease inhibitors require the use of low-dose ritonavir to boost pharmacokinetic exposure through inhibition of metabolism via the cytochrome P450 3A4 enzyme pathway. Ritonavir is part of Acids, Acyclic; Agents Causing Muscle Toxicity; Anti-HIV Agents; Anti-Infective Agents; Anti-Retroviral Agents; Antiinfectives for Systemic Use; Antiviral Agents; Antivirals for Systemic Use; Antivirals for treatment of HCV infections; BCRP/ABCG2 Inhibitors; and BCRP/ABCG2. Ritonavir is approved and investigational.
Vancomycin:
Vancomycin is a glycopeptide antibiotic that is obtained from Streptomyces orientalis. It is related to ristocetin and inhibits bacterial cell wall assembly, causing cell lysis and death. Vancomycin is effective against methicillin-resistant (beta-lactam-resistant) staphylococci and has a variety of dosage forms for the treatment of serious or severe infections caused by susceptible strains. The mechanism of action of vancomycin involves inhibition of cell wall biosynthesis, specifically preventing the incorporation of N-acetylmuramic acid (NAM)- and N-acetylglucosamine (NAG)-peptide subunits into the peptidoglycan matrix.
