Approval Status: Norethisterone is approved.
Nateglinide:
Nateglinide is an oral antihyperglycemic agent used for the treatment of non-insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus (NIDDM). It belongs to the meglitinide class of short-acting insulin secretagogues, which act by binding to β cells of the pancreas to stimulate insulin release. Nateglinide is an amino acid derivative that induces an early insulin response to meals decreasing postprandial blood glucose levels. It should only be taken with meals and meal-time doses should be skipped with any skipped meal. Approximately one month of therapy is required before a decrease in fasting blood glucose is seen. Meglitnides may have a neutral effect on weight or cause a slight increase in weight. The average weight gain caused by meglitinides appears to be lower than that caused by sulfonylureas and insulin, and appears to occur only in those naïve to oral antidiabetic agents. Due to their mechanism of action, meglitinides may cause hypoglycemia although the risk is thought to be lower than that of sulfonylureas since their action is dependent on the presence of glucose. In addition to reducing postprandial and fasting blood glucose, meglitnides have been shown to decrease glycosylated hemoglobin (HbA1c) levels, which are reflective of the last 8-10 weeks of glucose control. Meglitinides appear to be more effective at lowering postprandial blood glucose than metformin, sulfonylureas and thiazolidinediones. Nateglinide is extensively metabolized in the liver and excreted in urine (83%) and feces (10%). The major metabolites possess less activity than the parent compound. One minor metabolite, the isoprene, has the same potency as its parent compound.

Nateglinide works by binding to β cells of the pancreas to stimulate insulin release in response to glucose levels. The mechanism of action of nateglinide is dependent on the presence of functioning β cells and glucose. In contrast to sulfonylurea insulin secretagogues, nateglinide has no effect on insulin release in the absence of glucose. Rather, it potentiates the effect of extracellular glucose on ATP-sensitive potassium channel and has little effect on insulin levels between meals and overnight. As such, nateglinide is more effective at reducing postprandial blood glucose levels than fasting blood glucose levels and requires a longer duration of therapy (approximately one month) before decreases in fasting blood glucose are observed. The insulinotropic effects of nateglinide are highest at intermediate glucose levels (3 to 10 mmol/L) and it does not increase insulin release already stimulated by high glucose concentrations (greater than 15 mmol/L).

The pharmacokinetics of nateglinide are linear over a dose range of 62.5 to 400 mg, and the elimination half-life is approximately 1.5 hours. The protein binding of nateglinide is high at 98% bound to serum proteins, primarily serum albumin and to a lesser extent α1 acid glycoprotein.

Nateglinide has been shown to be effective in reducing postprandial blood glucose levels in patients with NIDDM. The drug is well tolerated and the most common adverse events are mild and transient, including nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, headache, and dizziness. Rare but serious adverse events include hypoglycemia, allergic reactions, and skin rash.

In summary, Nateglinide is an oral antihyperglycemic agent used for the treatment of non-insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus (NIDDM) by binding to β cells of the pancreas to stimulate insulin release in response to glucose levels. It works by potentiating the effect of extracellular glucose on ATP-sensitive potassium channel and has little effect on insulin levels between meals and overnight. Nateglinide is more effective at reducing postprandial blood glucose levels than fasting blood glucose levels and requires a longer duration of therapy (approximately one month) before decreases in fasting blood glucose are observed. The drug is well tolerated, but serious adverse events can occur including hypoglycemia, allergic reactions, and skin rash.
Risperidone: Risperidone is a second-generation antipsychotic (SGA) medication used in the treatment of a number of mood and mental health conditions including schizophrenia and bipolar disorder. It is one of the most widely usedSGAs, with a molecular weight of 410.49 and a topological polar surface area of 61.94. The primary active metabolite of risperidone is 9-hydroxyrisperidone, which is ~77% protein-bound in human plasma. Risperidone works by inhibiting the D2 dopaminergic receptors and 5-HT2A serotonergic receptors in the brain, thereby decreasing symptoms of schizophrenia and mood disorders. It is indicated for the treatment of schizophrenia and irritability associated with autistic disorder, as monotherapy or adjunctly with lithium or valproic acid, for the treatment of acute mania or mixed episodes associated with bipolar I disorder. Risperidone has a half-life of 3 hours in extensive metabolizers and is part of Adrenergic alpha-1 Receptor Antagonists ; Adrenergic alpha-Antagonists ; Adrenergic Antagonists ; Agents that produce hypertension ; Agents that reduce seizure threshold ; Antidepressive Agents ; Antipsychotic Agents ; Antipsychotic Agents (Second Generation ) ; Central Nervous System Stimulants and has approval status of approved and investigational.
Meclizine:
Meclizine is a histamine H1 antagonist with antiemetic and antivertigo properties, used in the symptomatic treatment of motion sickness and control of vertigo associated with vestibular system diseases. It also exhibits anticholinergic, central nervous system depressant, and local anesthetic effects. The mechanism of action involves activation of H1 receptors on the vestibular nuclei and nucleus of the solitary tract (NTS), which are responsible for initiating the vomiting reflex. Meclizine works on the higher centers of the brain to reduce nausea, vomiting, or vertigo, with a plasma elimination half-life of about 5-6 hours in humans. Its molecular weight is 390.96, and it has a topological polar surface area of 6.48. Meclizine is part of Anti-Allergic Agents; Antiemetics; Antihistamines for Systemic Use; Antivertigo Preparations; Autonomic Agents; Benzene Derivatives; Benzhydryl Compounds; Central Nervous System Agents; Central Nervous System Depressants; Cytochrome P-450 CYP2D6 Substrates; and Cytochrome. It is approved for use in various conditions, including motion sickness and Meniere's syndrome.

Meclizine is a solid that is available as oral tablets. Its protein binding profile is limited, and it has a plasma elimination half-life of about 5-6 hours in humans. The molecular weight of meclizine is 390.96, and its topological polar surface area is 6.48. Meclizine is part of several drug categories, including Anti-Allergic Agents; Antiemetics; Antihistamines for Systemic Use; Antivertigo Preparations; Autonomic Agents; Benzene Derivatives; Benzhydryl Compounds; Central Nervous System Agents; Central Nervous System Depressants; Cytochrome P-450 CYP2D6 Substrates; and Cytochrome. It is approved for use in various conditions, including motion sickness and Meniere's syndrome.

In conclusion, meclizine is a histamine H1 antagonist with antiemetic and antivertigo properties that is used to treat motion sickness and control vertigo associated with vestibular system diseases. Its mechanism of action involves activation of H1 receptors on the vestibular nuclei and nucleus of the solitary tract (NTS), which are responsible for initiating the vomiting reflex. Meclizine works on the higher centers of the brain to reduce nausea, vomiting, or vertigo, with a plasma elimination half-life of about 5-6 hours in humans. Its molecular weight is 390.96, and it has a topological polar surface area of 6.48. Meclizine is part of several drug categories, including Anti-Allergic Agents; Antiemetics; Antihistamines for Systemic Use; Antivertigo Preparations; Autonomic Agents; Benzene Derivatives; Benzhydryl Compounds; Central Nervous System Agents; Central Nervous System Depressants; Cytochrome P-450 CYP2D6 Substrates; and Cytochrome. It is approved for use in various conditions, including motion sickness and Meniere's syndrome.
Gadobenic acid: Gadobenic acid is an MRI contrast agent used primarily for MR imaging of the liver. It can also be used for visualizing the CNS and heart. In contrast to conventional extracellular fluid contrast agents, gadobenate dimeglumine is characterized by a weak and transient binding capacity to serum proteins. This binding leads to an increased relaxivity of gadobenate dimeglumine and, consequently, to a considerably increased signal intensity over that of other agents. The mechanism of action of gadobenic acid is based on the behavior of protons when placed in a strong magnetic field, which is interpreted and transformed into images by magnetic resonance (MR) instruments. Paramagnetic agents like gadobenic acid have unpaired electrons that generate a magnetic field about 700 times larger than the proton's field, thus disturbing the proton's local magnetic field. When the local magnetic field around a proton is disturbed, its relaxation process is altered. MR images are based on proton density and proton relaxation dynamics. Gadobenic acid does not cross the intact blood-brain barrier; therefore, it does not accumulate in normal brain tissue or in central nervous system (CNS) lesions that have not caused an abnormal blood-brain barrier (e.g., cysts, mature post-operative scars). The protein binding of gadobenic acid is low, weak, and transient. Elimination half-life of gadobenic acid is approximately 1 hour. Gadobenic acid is a solid in physical state. It belongs to categories such as Alcohols, Amino Sugars, Carbohydrates, Compounds used in a research, industrial, or household setting, Contrast Media, Diagnostic Uses of Chemicals, Drugs that are Mainly Renally Excreted, Gadolinium-based Contrast Agent, Hexosamines, Magnetic Resonance Contrast Agents, and has approval status as approved and investigational.
Zileuton:
Zileuton is a selective 5-lipoxygenase inhibitor that is FDA-approved for the prophylaxis and chronic treatment of asthma. It works by blocking the formation of leukotrienes, which are inflammatory mediators that contribute to airway symptoms in asthma patients. Zileuton is available in immediate release tablet formulation, but it has been withdrawn from the US market due to safety concerns. The drug has a half-life of 2.5 hours and is bound to plasma proteins, primarily albumin. Its molecular weight is 236.29 and it has a topological polar surface area of 66.56. Zileuton is part of the Agents to Treat Airway Disease drug category and is metabolized by cytochrome P-450 enzymes CYP1A2, CYP2C9, and CYP3A.

Zileuton relieves symptoms of asthma through its selective inhibition of 5-lipoxygenase, the enzyme that catalyzes the formation of leukotrienes from arachidonic acid. The drug inhibits the formation of leukotriene LTB4, LTC4, LTD4, and LTE4, which are involved in the pathogenesis of asthma. By modulating leukotriene formation, Zileuton may reduce airway symptoms, decrease bronchial smooth muscle tone, and improve asthma control. The drug has been shown to attenuate bronchoconstriction caused by cold air challenge in patients with asthma.

Zileuton is a solid at room temperature and has a logP value of 2.48, indicating that it is moderately soluble in polar solvents. The drug is metabolized by cytochrome P-450 enzymes CYP1A2, CYP2C9, and CYP3A, which are involved in the metabolism of other drugs as well. Therefore, Zileuton may interact with other drugs metabolized by these enzymes, leading to potential drug-drug interactions.

In summary, Zileuton is a selective 5-lipoxygenase inhibitor that is FDA-approved for the prophylaxis and chronic treatment of asthma. It works by blocking the formation of leukotrienes, which are inflammatory mediators involved in the pathogenesis of asthma. The drug has a half-life of 2.5 hours and is bound to plasma proteins, primarily albumin. Zileuton is part of the Agents to Treat Airway Disease drug category and is metabolized by cytochrome P-450 enzymes CYP1A2, CYP2C9, and CYP3A.
Etodolac:
Etodolac is a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) with anti-inflammatory, analgesic, and antipyretic properties. Its therapeutic effects are due to its ability to inhibit prostaglandin synthesis, specifically cyclooxygenase (COX). Etodolac is indicated for the relief of signs and symptoms of rheumatoid arthritis and osteoarthritis. The mechanism of action involves binding to the upper portion of the COX enzyme active site and preventing its substrate, arachidonic acid, from entering the active site. This results in a decrease in the synthesis of peripheral prostaglandins involved in mediating inflammation. Additionally, etodolac may occur by central action on the hypothalamus, resulting in peripheral dilation, increased cutaneous blood flow, and subsequent heat loss.

Etodolac is a racemate, with both enantiomers being active. There is no evidence of R- to S- conversion _in vivo_. The molecular weight of etodolac is 287.36, and it has a topological polar surface area of 62.32. Etodolac has a logP value of 3.43. It is a solid at room temperature and has a terminal half-life of 7.3 ± 4.0 hours and distribution half-life of 0.71 ± 0.50 hours.

Etodolac belongs to the categories of Acetic Acid Derivatives and Related Substances, Agents causing hyperkalemia, Agents that produce hypertension, Analgesics, Non-Narcotic, Anti-Inflammatory Agents, Non-Steroidal, and Anti-Inflammatory Agents, Non-Steroidal (Non-Selective). It is approved for use in humans and is also investigational and vet_approved.

Overall, etodolac is a potent NSAID with a wide range of therapeutic applications in the management of pain and inflammation associated with rheumatoid arthritis and osteoarthritis. Its selectivity for COX-2 versus COX-1 makes it a more targeted treatment option compared to other non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs.
Isoflurane: Isoflurane is a stable, non-explosive inhalation anesthetic that is relatively free from significant side effects. It is clinically indicated for induction and maintenance of general anesthesia. The mechanism of action of isoflurane involves the alteration of tissue excitability by decreasing the extent of gap junction mediated cell-cell coupling and altering the activity of the channels that underlie the action potential. Isoflurane binds to various receptors, including the GABA receptor, the large conductance Ca<sup>2+</sup> activated potassium channel, the glutamate receptor, and the glycine receptor. These actions result in muscle relaxation and reduced pain sensitivity. Isoflurane is a liquid with a molecular weight of 184.49 and a topological polar surface area of 9.23. It has a logP value of 1.76. Isoflurane is part of several drug categories, including agents that produce hypertension, reduce seizure threshold, and are classified as anesthetics, general, inhalation, and cytochrome P-450 CYP2B6 inducers. It has been approved for medical use and is also approved for veterinary use.
Tretinoin: Tretinoin is a naturally occurring derivative of vitamin A (retinol) that plays a crucial role in regulating cell reproduction, proliferation, and differentiation. It is primarily used to treat acne and photodamaged skin, as well as to manage keratinization disorders such as ichthyosis and keratosis follicularis. Additionally, tretinoin represents the class of anticancer drugs called differentiating agents and is used in the treatment of acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL). Tretinoin binds to alpha, beta, and gamma retinoic acid receptors (RARs), which are associated with the development of acute promyelocytic leukemia and squamous cell cancers. The exact mechanism of action of tretinoin in APL is unknown, but it is believed to induce cytodifferentiation and decreased proliferation of APL cells in culture and in vivo. Tretinoin is not a cytolytic agent but instead modifies abnormal follicular keratinization, leading to the extrusion of comedo contents and the reduction of microcomedo formation. The drug has a half-life of 0.5-2 hours and its molecular weight is 300.44. Tretinoin is part of Alkenes; Anti-Acne Preparations; Anti-Acne Preparations for Topical Use; Antineoplastic Agents; Antineoplastic and Immunomodulating Agents; Biological Factors; Cardiotoxic antineoplastic agents; Carotenoids; Cell Stimulants and Proliferants; Cyclohexanes; Cyclohexenes. Tretinoin is approved for use in treating acne and APL, and it is also investigational and nutraceutical.
Tetracycline: Tetracycline is a broad-spectrum polyketide antibiotic produced by the Streptomyces genus of Actinobacteria. It exerts a bacteriostatic effect on bacteria by binding reversibly to the 30S ribosomal subunit and blocking incoming aminoacyl tRNA from binding to the ribosome acceptor site. Additionally, it binds to some extent to the 50S ribosomal subunit and may alter the cytoplasmic membrane, causing intracellular components to leak from bacterial cells. Tetracycline is used to treat a variety of bacterial infections, including Rocky Mountain spotted fever, typhus fever, tick fevers, Q fever, rickettsialpox, and Brill-Zinsser disease. It may also be used to treat infections caused by Chlamydiae spp., B. burgdorferi (Lyme disease), and upper respiratory infections caused by typical and atypical organisms. Tetracycline has a short half-life of 6-12 hours, and its molecular weight is 444.44. It has a topological polar surface area of 181.62 and a logP value of -0.9. Tetracycline is part of the agents that produce neuromuscular block (indirect), alimentary tract and metabolism, anti-bacterial agents, anti-infective agents, antibiotics for topical use, antiinfectives and antiseptics for local oral treatment, and antiinfectives for systemic use. It is approved and veterinary approved.
Irinotecan: Irinotecan is an antineoplastic enzyme inhibitor primarily used in the treatment of colorectal cancer. It is a derivative of camptothecin that inhibits the action of topoisomerase I, preventing religation of the DNA strand by binding to the topoisomerase I-DNA complex. This leads to double-stranded breaks and cell death. Irinotecan is also used in combination with other drugs for the treatment of pancreatic and lung cancers, as well as cervical cancer. The mechanism of action involves the inhibition of topoisomerase I, leading to DNA damage and apoptosis. The protein binding of irinotecan is moderate, mainly to albumin, and its pharmacodynamics are cell cycle phase-specific, with activity against S-phase cells. The half-life of irinotecan is around 6-12 hours, and it has a topological polar surface area of 112.51. Irinotecan is part of Alkaloids, Antineoplastic Agents, and BCRP/ABCG2 Substrates, among other categories. It is approved for the treatment of metastatic colorectal cancer, and its mechanism of action and pharmacokinetics are currently under investigation for other indications.
Olopatadine:
Olopatadine is a selective histamine H1 antagonist and mast cell stabilizer that works by attenuating inflammatory and allergic reactions. It is a structural analog of , which has a minimal anti-allergic activity. Olopatadine works by blocking the effects of histamine, which is a primary inflammatory mediator that causes inflammatory and allergic reactions. An ophthalmic solution of olopatadine was approved by the FDA and European Union for the treatment of seasonal and perennial allergic conjunctivitis in 1996 and 2002, respectively. In comparison to other anti-allergenic ophthalmic medications, olopatadine displays a good comfort and tolerability profile since it does not cause perturbation of cell membranes. Olopatadine is used for the symptomatic treatment of ocular itching associated with allergic conjunctivitis in ophthalmic formulations and seasonal allergic rhinitis in intranasal formulations. It is currently marketed under several brand names, including Pazeo, Patanase, and Opatanol.

Olopatadine is indicated for the symptomatic treatment of ocular itching associated with allergic conjunctivitis as ophthalmic solution. The mechanism of action of olopatadine involves blocking the effects of histamine, a biogenic vasoactive amine that binds to its receptors, which are G-protein coupled receptors. Signaling through the histamine H1 receptor is thought to primarily promote the activation of inflammatory reactions, such as allergy, asthma, and autoimmune diseases. Olopatadine also demonstrated dose-dependent inhibition of immunologically-stimulated release of histamine from rat basophilic leukemia cells and human conjunctival mast cells _in vitro_.

Olopatadine is an anti-allergenic molecule and mast cell stabilizer that inhibits the _in vivo_ type 1 immediate hypersensitivity reaction. By blocking the effects of histamine, olopatadine works to reduce the symptoms of allergies and inflammation at various sites of administration, including the eyes and nose. Olopatadine has a relatively rapid onset of action and prolonged duration, where it was shown to mediate anti-histaminic effects at 5 minutes to 24 hours post-administration.

Olopatadine is part of Anti-Allergic Agents ; Anti-Inflammatory Agents ; Antiallergic Agents, Excl. Corticosteroids ; Antihistamine Drugs ; Central Nervous System Agents ; Central Nervous System Depressants ; Cytochrome P-450 CYP3A Substrates ; Cytochrome P-450 CYP3A4 Substrates ; Cytochrome P-450 S.

The drug has a molecular weight of 337.42 and a topological polar surface area of 49.77. Olopatadine has a relatively rapid onset of action and prolonged duration, where it was shown to mediate anti-histaminic effects at 5 minutes to 24 hours post-administration. The elimination half-life of olopatadine following ocular administration was reported to be 3.4 ± 1.2 hours, and in oral pharmacokinetics study, the elimination half-life was reported to be 8 to 12 hours.
Hydroflumethiazide:
Hydroflumethiazide is a thiazide diuretic with actions and uses similar to those of hydrochlorothiazide. It is used as adjunctive therapy in edema associated with congestive heart failure, hepatic cirrhosis, and corticosteroid and estrogen therapy, as well as in the management of hypertension either as the sole therapeutic agent or to enhance the effect of other antihypertensive drugs in more severe forms of hypertension. Hydroflumethiazide is a potent diuretic that works by inhibiting water reabsorption in the nephron by blocking the sodium-chloride symporter (SLC12A3) in the distal convoluted tubule, which reduces the osmotic gradient and water reabsorption throughout the nephron. This results in an increase in urine production, leading to a decrease in extracellular fluid volume and blood pressure reduction.

Hydroflumethiazide has a biphasic biological half-life with an estimated alpha-phase of about 2 hours and an estimated beta-phase of about 17 hours. The molecular weight of hydroflumethiazide is 331.28, and it has a topological polar surface area of 118.36. Hydroflumethiazide is part of the Amides; Antihypertensive Agents; Benzothiadiazines; Cardiovascular Agents; Diuretics; Drugs causing inadvertent photosensitivity; Genito Urinary System and Sex Hormones; Gynecological Antiinfectives and Antiseptics; Heterocyclic Compounds, Fused-Ring; Hypotensive Agents categories. Its protein binding is 74%, and it has a biological half-life of approximately 20 hours.

Mechanistically, hydroflumethiazide works by inhibiting the sodium-chloride symporter (SLC12A3) in the distal convoluted tubule, which reduces water reabsorption and increases urine production. This results in a decrease in extracellular fluid volume and blood pressure reduction. Additionally, hydroflumethiazide causes vasodilation by activating calcium-activated potassium channels (large conductance) in vascular smooth muscles and inhibiting various carbonic anhydrases in vascular tissue.

In summary, hydroflumethiazide is a thiazide diuretic used to treat hypertension and edema. It works by reducing water reabsorption in the nephron and increasing urine production, leading to blood pressure reduction. Hydroflumethiazide has a biphasic biological half-life and is part of various drug categories. Its mechanism of action involves inhibiting the sodium-chloride symporter in the distal convoluted tubule and causing vasodilation by activating calcium-activated potassium channels and inhibiting carbonic anhydrases.
Oxcarbazepine: Oxcarbazepine is an anti-epileptic medication used in the treatment of partial onset seizures. It is a structural derivative of and exerts its activity via a pharmacologically active metabolite, MHD, which exists as a racemate in the blood. Compared to other anti-epileptic drugs, oxcarbazepine has a reduced propensity for involvement in drug-drug interactions due to its primarily reductive metabolism. The exact mechanism through which oxcarbazepine and MHD exert their anti-epileptic effects is unclear, but it is thought to primarily involve the blockade of voltage-gated sodium channels. Oxcarbazepine is indicated as monotherapy in the treatment of partial-onset seizures in patients 4 years of age and older, and as adjunctive therapy in the treatment of partial-onset seizures in patients 2 years of age and older in the United States. In Canada, oxcarbazepine is indicated for use as monotherapy or adjunctive therapy in the treatment of partial-onset seizures in patients 6 years of age and older. The pharmacologically active metabolite of oxcarbazepine, MHD, is approximately 40% bound to plasma proteins, predominantly albumin. Oxcarbazepine is a solid, with a molecular weight of 252.27 and a topological polar surface area of 63.4. The plasma half-life of oxcarbazepine is approximately 2 hours, while the plasma half-life of MHD is approximately 9 hours. Oxcarbazepine is part of Anti-epileptic Agent; Anticonvulsants; Carboxamide Derivatives; Central Nervous System Agents; Central Nervous System Depressants; Cytochrome P-450 CYP2C19 Inhibitors; Cytochrome P-450 CYP3A Inducers; and Cytochrome P-450 CYP2C19 inhibitors (strength unknown) drug categories.
Estradiol: Estradiol is a naturally occurring hormone circulating endogenously in females, and is commercially available in various forms for managing conditions associated with reduced estrogen levels. It is indicated for the treatment of moderate to severe vasomotor symptoms and vulvar and vaginal atrophy due to menopause, as well as for the prevention of postmenopausal osteoporosis. Estradiol acts on the estrogen receptors to relieve symptoms such as hot flashes and urogenital dysfunction, and its pharmacokinetics vary by route of administration. It is also used in combination with other hormones as a component of oral contraceptive pills for preventing pregnancy. Estradiol has a molecular weight of 272.39 and a topological polar surface area of 40.46, and its logP value is 3.78. It belongs to various drug categories including Adrenal Cortex Hormones, Androgens and Estrogens, Antiandrogens and Estrogens, BCRP/ABCG2 Inhibitors, COMT Substrates, Contraceptive Agents, Female, Contraceptives, Oral, Cytochrome P-450 CYP1A2 Inhibitors, and Cytochroome P-450 CYP1A2 Inhibitors (strength unknown). Estradiol is approved for medical use and is also investigational and veterinary approved.
Mefenamic acid:
Mefenamic acid is a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory agent (NSAID) with analgesic, anti-inflammatory, and antipyretic properties. It works by inhibiting the action of cyclooxygenase (COX), which is involved in the production of prostaglandins, potent mediators of inflammation and pain. Mefenamic acid binds to both COX-1 and COX-2 receptors, thereby reducing the synthesis of prostaglandins and alleviating symptoms such as pain, inflammation, and fever. With a protein binding rate of 90%, mefenamic acid is highly effective in reducing inflammation and pain associated with conditions like rheumatoid arthritis, osteoarthritis, dysmenorrhea, and mild to moderate pain.

Mefenamic acid is a solid at room temperature and has a half-life of 2 hours. Its molecular weight is 241.29, and it has a topological polar surface area (TPSA) of 49.33 and a logP value of 5.14. Mefenamic acid belongs to the fenamate group of NSAIDs and is part of several drug categories, including acids, carbocyclic agents, and anti-inflammatory agents. It has been approved for clinical use in various countries worldwide.

Mechanistically, mefenamic acid works by reducing the production of prostaglandins, which are involved in the inflammatory response. Prostaglandins are produced through the action of COX enzymes, and mefenamic acid binds to these enzymes, thereby inhibiting their activity. This results in a decrease in the amount of prostaglandins available for signaling, leading to reduced inflammation and pain.

In clinical settings, mefenamic acid is used to treat various conditions, including rheumatoid arthritis, osteoarthritis, dysmenorrhea, and mild to moderate pain. Its anti-inflammatory properties make it an effective treatment option for reducing inflammation and promoting healing in these conditions. Additionally, mefenamic acid has been shown to have antipyretic properties, making it useful in reducing fever associated with various conditions.

In conclusion, mefenamic acid is a valuable drug for the treatment of various inflammatory and painful conditions. Its mechanism of action involves inhibition of COX enzymes, leading to reduced prostaglandin synthesis and alleviation of symptoms. With its high protein binding rate, long half-life, and favorable logP value, mefenamic acid is an effective and well-tolerated treatment option for many patients.
Acyclovir:
Acyclovir is a nucleotide analog antiviral used to treat herpes simplex, varicella zoster, herpes zoster, herpes labialis, and acute herpetic keratitis. It works by inhibiting the action of viral DNA polymerase and DNA replication of different herpesvirus. The drug is available in various formulations such as oral tablets, capsules, and suspensions, topical cream, ointment, and buccal tablet. Acyclovir has a wide therapeutic window, making it safe for use in otherwise healthy patients. It is protein bound in plasma to the extent of 9-33% and has a mean half-life of approximately 2.6 hours in pediatric patients. The molecular weight of acyclovir is 225.21, and it has a topological polar surface area of 114.76. Acyclovir is metabolized by cytochrome P-450 CYP1A2 substrates and is excreted mainly through the kidneys. The drug is approved for use in various indications, including herpes simplex, varicella zoster, and chickenpox.

Mechanism of Action: Acyclovir becomes acyclovir monophosphate due to the action of viral thymidine kinase. Acyclovir monophosphate is converted to the diphosphate form by guanylate kinase. Acyclovir diphosphate is converted to acyclovir triphosphate by nucleoside diphosphate kinase, pyruvate kinase, creatine kinase, phosphoglycerate kinase, succinyl-CoA synthetase, phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase and adenylosuccinate synthetase. Acyclovir triphosphate has higher affinity for viral DNA polymerase than cellular DNA polymerase and incorporates into the DNA where the missing 2' and 3' carbons causes DNA chain termination. In other cases acyclovir triphosphate competes so strongly for viral DNA polymerase that other bases cannot associate with the enzyme, inactivating it.

Clinical Indication: Acyclovir topical cream is indicated to treat recurrent herpes labialis in immunocompetent patients 12 years and older. Acyclovir oral tablets, capsules, and suspensions are indicated to treat herpes zoster, genital herpes, and chickenpox. An acyclovir topical ointment is indicated to treat initial genital herpes and limited non-life-threatening mucocutaneous herpes simplex in immunocompromised patients. An acyclovir cream with hydrocortisone is indicated to treat recurrent herpes labialis, and shortening lesion healing time in patients 6 years and older. An acyclovir buccal tablet is indicated for the treatment of recurrent herpes labialis. An acyclovir ophthalmic ointment is indicated to treat acute herpetic keratitis.

Protein Binding: Acyclovir is 9-33% protein bound in plasma.

Pharmacokinetics: The clearance of acyclovir varies from 2.5-3 hours depending on the creatinine clearance of the patient. The plasma half life of acyclovir during hemodialysis is approximately 5 hours.

Naproxen:
Naproxen is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) that was initially approved for prescription use in 1976 and later made available over-the-counter (OTC) in 1994. It is effective in managing acute pain as well as pain related to rheumatic diseases, with a well-established adverse effect profile. Given its overall tolerability and effectiveness, naproxen can be considered a first-line treatment for various clinical situations requiring analgesia. Naproxen is available in both immediate and delayed release formulations, as well as in combination with sumatriptan to treat migraines and with esomeprazole to lower the risk of developing gastric ulcers. The drug exerts its clinical effects by blocking cyclooxygenase (COX) enzymes, leading to decreased prostaglandin synthesis. This results in improved pain, fever, and inflammation management. Naproxen is highly protein-bound, with >99% of the drug bound to albumin at therapeutic levels. Its elimination half-life is reported to be 12-17 hours.

Naproxen is a valuable treatment option for rheumatoid arthritis, osteoarthritis, ankylosing spondylitis, polyarticular juvenile idiopathic arthritis, tendinitis, bursitis, acute gout, primary dysmenorrhea, and mild to moderate pain. It is also first-line therapy for osteoarthritis, acute gouty arthritis, dysmenorrhea, and musculoskeletal inflammation and pain. The drug's mechanism of action involves the inhibition of COX-1 and COX-2 enzymes, which leads to decreased prostaglandin synthesis in various tissues and fluids, including the synovial fluid, gastric mucosa, and blood. This results in improved pain, fever, and inflammation management.

In addition to its clinical uses, naproxen has a well-established adverse effect profile. Common side effects include gastrointestinal disturbances such as nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain, as well as headache, dizziness, and renal toxicities. However, the drug's high protein binding and short elimination half-life help minimize these adverse effects.

Overall, naproxen is a valuable treatment option for various clinical situations requiring analgesia. Its well-established adverse effect profile, high protein binding, and short elimination half-life make it a safe and effective choice for managing pain, fever, and inflammation.
Alfentanil: Alfentanil is a short-acting opioid anesthetic and analgesic derivative of fentanyl. It produces an early peak analgesic effect and fast recovery of consciousness. Alfentanil is effective as an anesthetic during surgery, for supplementation of analgesia during surgical procedures, and as an analgesic for critically ill patients. The mechanism of action of alfentanil involves binding to opioid receptors in the central nervous system, which leads to a decrease in intracellular cAMP and an increase in neuronal excitability. This results in analgesia and sedation. Alfentanil also has anti-inflammatory effects, as it inhibits the release of pro-inflammatory neurotransmitters such as substance P and dopamine. The protein binding of alfentanil is high, at 92%, which may contribute to its potency and duration of action. In clinical settings, alfentanil exerts its principal pharmacologic effects on the central nervous system, producing analgesia and sedation. However, it may also cause respiratory depression, bradycardia, and constriction of the pupils. Alfentanil is a solid with a molecular weight of 416.53 and a topological polar surface area of 81.05. Its logP value is 2.13. Alfentanil is approved for medical use but may also be illicitly used for non-medical purposes.
Indapamide:
Indapamide is a diuretic drug used to treat hypertension and fluid and salt retention associated with congestive heart failure. It works by inhibiting the Na+/Cl- cotransporter in the proximal segment of the distal convoluted tubule in the nephron, leading to reduced sodium reabsorption and increased urinary excretion of sodium and water. This results in a decrease in plasma volume, venous return, cardiac output, and ultimately blood pressure. Indapamide is protein bound, primarily to alpha 1-acid glycoprotein, and has a biphasic elimination half-life ranging from 13.9 to 18 hours, allowing for once-daily dosing. The drug is classified as a sulfonamide diuretic and has been shown to be an effective antihypertensive agent with preventive properties against target organ damage.

Indapamide's molecular weight is 365.83, and it has a topological polar surface area of 92.5. It is a CYP3A substrate and has a logP value of 2.96. The drug is approved for use in hypertension and fluid retention associated with congestive heart failure.

In terms of pharmacokinetics, indapamide undergoes biphasic elimination, with the short half-life ranging from 3 to 5 hours, and the long half-life ranging from 13.9 to 18 hours. The drug is primarily metabolized by the liver enzyme CYP3A4, and its main metabolite is inactive. Indapamide has a high volume of distribution and is highly bound to plasma proteins, primarily alpha 1-acid glycoprotein.

In terms of clinical uses, indapamide is used as monotherapy or in combination with other antihypertensive agents to treat hypertension. It is also used to treat fluid and salt retention associated with congestive heart failure. The drug has been shown to be effective in reducing blood pressure and preventing target organ damage.

In terms of mechanisms of action, indapamide acts on the nephron by inhibiting the Na+/Cl- cotransporter in the proximal segment of the distal convoluted tubule, leading to reduced sodium reabsorption and increased urinary excretion of sodium and water. This results in a decrease in plasma volume, venous return, cardiac output, and ultimately blood pressure.

In terms of pharmacodynamics, indapamide is a sulfonamide diuretic that works by reducing sodium reabsorption in the nephron, leading to increased urinary excretion of sodium and water. The drug has been shown to be effective in reducing blood pressure and preventing target organ damage.

In terms of physical properties, indapamide is a solid drug with a molecular weight of 365.83 and a topological polar surface area of 92.5. It has a biphasic elimination half-life ranging from 13.9 to 18 hours, allowing for once-daily dosing.

In terms of approval status, indapamide is approved for use in hypertension and fluid retention associated with congestive heart failure.
Fentanyl:
Fentanyl is a potent opioid agonist that was developed in the 1950s to provide rapid and strong analgesia. It is commonly used to treat chronic cancer pain or anesthesia, due to its short duration of action and wide therapeutic index. Fentanyl binds to opioid receptors, primarily the mu receptor, which activates G-proteins and inhibits nerve activity. It has a half-life of approximately 7 hours and is bound to plasma proteins by 80-85%. The primary metabolite, norfentanyl, is also an opioid agonist and has a shorter duration of action than fentanyl. Fentanyl is associated with a risk of addiction and abuse, and should not be mixed with alcohol or benzodiazepines.

Fentanyl is used for short-term analgesia during induction, maintenance, and recovery from general or regional anesthesia. It is also used with a neuroleptic for premedication, induction, and as an adjunct to maintenance of anesthesia. Additionally, fentanyl intravenous or intramuscular injections are used with oxygen for anesthesia in high-risk patients.

The mechanism of action of fentanyl involves its binding to opioid receptors, particularly the mu receptor, which activates G-proteins and inhibits nerve activity. This results in a decrease in cAMP levels, leading to hyperpolarization of the cell and inhibition of nerve activity. Fentanyl has a wide therapeutic index due to its high potency and the development of tolerance over time.

Fentanyl is a solid at room temperature and has a molecular weight of 336.48. Its topological polar surface area is 23.55, and its logP value is 3.62. Fentanyl is part of the drug categories Adjuvants; Anesthetics; Analgesics; Antidepressive Agents; Bradycardia-Causing Agents; Central Nervous System Agents; and Central Nervous System Stimulants. It has been approved for medical use, but its illicit and investigational uses are also recognized.

Overall, fentanyl is a powerful opioid agonist with a wide range of clinical indications. Its short duration of action and high therapeutic index make it an important tool in the management of pain, particularly in patients undergoing anesthesia. However, its potential for addiction and abuse means that it must be used with caution and under close medical supervision.
Meloxicam: Meloxicam is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) used to relieve various types of pain, including musculoskeletal conditions such as osteoarthritis and rheumatoid arthritis. With a longer half-life than most other NSAIDs, it is a favorable option for those who require once-daily dosing. Meloxicam is available in oral, transdermal, and intravenous formulations. It is a preferential COX-2 inhibitor, purportedly reducing the risk of adverse gastrointestinal tract effects, although this is a topic of controversy. Clinical indications include the symptomatic treatment of arthritis and osteoarthritis, as well as the treatment of dental or post-surgical pain. Off-label uses include the treatment of neuropathic pain. Meloxicam inhibits prostaglandin synthetase (cylooxygenase 1 and 2) enzymes leading to a decreased synthesis of prostaglandins, which normally mediate painful inflammatory symptoms. As prostaglandins sensitize neuronal pain receptors, inhibition of their synthesis leads to analgesic and anti-inflammatory effects. Meloxicam is about 99.4% protein bound, primarily to albumin. Pharmacodynamics include anti-inflammatory, analgesic, and antipyretic effects. The molecular weight of meloxicam is 351.4, and its topological polar surface area is 99.6. Meloxicam is part of Agents causing hyperkalemia; Agents that produce hypertension; Analgesics; Analgesics, Non-Narcotic; Anti-Inflammatory Agents; Anti-Inflammatory Agents, Non-Steroidal; Antiinflammatory and Antirheumatic Products; A. Sodium Lauryl Sulfate (SLS):
Sodium lauryl sulfate is an anionic surfactant naturally derived from coconut and/or palm kernel oil. It is used as a fat emulsifier, wetting agent, and detergent in various industries such as cosmetics, pharmaceuticals, and toothpastes. SLS lowers the surface tension of aqueous solutions and has microbicidal activity against both enveloped and non-enveloped viruses. Its amphiphilic properties allow it to migrate to the surface of liquids and aggregate with other SLS molecules, reducing surface tension and facilitating spreading and mixing. SLS also has protein denaturing activity and inhibits the infectivity of viruses by solubilizing the viral envelope and/or denaturing envelope and/or capsid proteins. It is an experimental drug and its mechanism of action involves solubilization and denaturation of viral proteins, leading to inactivation of the virus.

Mechanism of Action: SLS migrates to the surface of liquids and aggregates with other SLS molecules, reducing surface tension and facilitating spreading and mixing. It also solubilizes and denatures viral proteins, leading to inactivation of the virus.

Pharmacodynamics: SLS is an anionic surfactant that lowers surface tension and aggregates with other SLS molecules, reducing surface tension and facilitating spreading and mixing. It also has protein denaturing activity and solubilizes viral proteins, leading to inactivation of the virus.

Propofol:
Propofol is a sedative-hypnotic agent used for induction and maintenance of anesthesia, as well as for management of refractory status epilepticus. It acts by positively modulating the inhibitory function of the neurotransmitter gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA) through GABA-A receptors. The drug is primarily bound to serum albumin and hemoglobin, with a protein binding rate of 95-99%. Propofol is administered intravenously, with a rapid onset of action typically within 40 seconds after injection. Its half-life ranges from 1.8 to 70 minutes, with two distinct distribution phases and a terminal elimination phase. Propofol is a liquid with a molecular weight of 178.28 and a topological polar surface area of 20.23. It belongs to various drug categories, including Agents Causing Muscle Toxicity, Agents that produce hypertension, Agents that reduce seizure threshold, Anesthetics, and Central Nervous System Depressants. Propofol has been approved for medical use and is also investigational and veterinary approved.

Propofol is used for the induction and maintenance of anesthesia, particularly for surgeries that require a rapid onset of anesthesia and rapid recovery. Its mechanism of action involves positively modulating GABA receptors, leading to sedation and hypnosis. The drug has a favorable pharmacokinetic profile, with a rapid distribution phase and a prolonged terminal elimination phase. This allows for a short duration of anesthesia, with minimal side effects such as drowsiness, nausea, or vomiting compared to other intravenous anesthetics like thiopental, methohexital, and etomidate. Additionally, Propofol has been shown to be effective in managing refractory status epilepticus, a life-threatening condition characterized by recurrent seizures despite medical treatment.

In conclusion, Propofol is an essential drug in modern anesthesiology, offering a rapid onset of action, favorable pharmacokinetics, and a safe profile compared to other intravenous anesthetics. Its ability to manage refractory status epilepticus makes it a valuable tool for treating this life-threatening condition.
Diazepam: Diazepam is a benzodiazepine with multiple pharmacological properties, including anticonvulsant, anxiolytic, sedative, muscle relaxant, and amnesic effects. Its actions are mediated by enhancement of gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA) activity. Diazepam is commonly used in the treatment of severe anxiety disorders, as a hypnotic in the short-term management of insomnia, as a sedative and premedicant, as an anticonvulsant, and in the management of alcohol withdrawal syndrome. The drug has a biphasic half-life with an initial rapid distribution phase followed by a prolonged terminal elimination phase, which can be further prolonged in certain populations such as neonates, elderly individuals, or those with kidney or liver disease. Diazepam is widely distributed into tissues and crosses the blood-brain barrier, but its protein binding is high, mainly to albumin and α1-acid glycoprotein. Despite this, the drug is highly lipid soluble, which causes the initial effects to decrease rapidly as it is redistributed into fat deposits and tissues. The molecular weight of diazepam is 284.74, and its topological polar surface area is 32.67. Diazepam belongs to various drug categories, including Adjuvants, Anesthesia; Anesthetics; Anesthetics, General; Anesthetics, Intravenous; Anti-Anxiety Agents; Anticonvulsants; Autonomic Agents; Benzazepines; Benzodiazepine hypnotics and sedatives; Benzodiazepines and benzodiazepine derivatives; Benzodiazepinones; Central Nervous System Stimulants, and Muscle Relaxants. The drug has been approved for use in various countries, including the United States, Canada, Australia, and the European Union. However, it is also illicit and investigational in some countries due to concerns about its potential for abuse and dependence.
Oxazepam:
Oxazepam is an intermediate-acting, 3-hydroxybenzodiazepine used in the treatment of alcohol withdrawal and anxiety disorders. Its pharmacokinetic properties make it less susceptible to variability based on patient-specific factors, such as age or liver disease. Oxazepam exerts its anxiolytic effects by potentiating the effect of gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA) on GABA(A) receptors in the mammalian brain, producing inhibitory postsynaptic potentials that play an integral role in the suppression and control of epileptiform nerve firing. Its protein binding is approximately 89%, likely to albumin, and its mean elimination half-life is 8.2 hours. Oxazepam belongs to various drug categories, including Anti-Anxiety Agents, Benzazepines, Benzodiazepine hypnotics and sedatives, and Central Nervous System Agents. It is approved for use in the management of anxiety disorders and alcohol withdrawal symptoms.

Oxazepam's mechanism of action involves potentiating the effect of endogenous GABA on GABA(A) receptors, producing inhibitory postsynaptic potentials that play an integral role in the suppression and control of epileptiform nerve firing. This makes it a desirable target in the treatment of epilepsy. The drug's relatively simple metabolism and low potency compared to other benzodiazepines result in a moderate duration of action, which should be administered with caution to patients for whom a drop in blood pressure may lead to cardiac complications. Oxazepam has a topological polar surface area of 61.69 and a logP value of 2.31, indicating its solubility and lipophilicity. Its molecular weight is 286.72, and it belongs to various drug categories, including GABA Agents and Central Nervous System Depressants. Oxazepam's clinical indication includes the management of anxiety disorders and short-term relief of symptoms of anxiety, as well as alcohol withdrawal symptoms.
Clofazimine:
Clofazimine is a highly lipophilic antimicrobial riminophenazine dye used in combination with other agents, such as dapsone and rifampin, for the treatment of leprosy. It was originally described in 1957 and was the prototypical riminophenazine dye - a bright-red dye that, in its clinical use, results in long-lasting discoloration of the skin and bodily fluids. Although it carries in vitro activity against other mycobacteria, such as Mycobacterium tuberculosis, it is generally considered an ineffective treatment in comparison to classic tuberculosis treatments such as rifampin and isoniazid. Clofazimine is indicated for the treatment of lepromatous leprosy, including dapsone-resistant lepromatous leprosy and lepromatous leprosy complicated by erythema nodosum leprosum. To prevent the development of drug resistance, it should be used only in combination with other antimycobacterial leprosy treatments.

The mechanism of action of clofazimine is not fully understood, but its antimicrobial activity appears to be membrane-directed. It was previously thought that, due to its lipophilicity, clofazimine participated in the generation of intracellular reactive oxygen species (ROS) via redox cycling, specifically H2O2 and superoxide, which then exerted an antimicrobial effect. A more recent and compelling theory involves clofazimine interacting with bacterial membrane phospholipids to generate antimicrobial lysophospholipids - bactericidal efficacy may, then, arise from the combined membrane-destabilizing effects of both clofazimine and lysophospholipids, which interfere with K+ uptake and, ultimately, ATP production. Clofazimine is bound primarily to beta-lipoproteins (and, to a lesser extent, alpha-lipoproteins) in the serum. This binding was saturable at concentrations of ~10 µg/mL. Binding to gamma-globulin and albumin is negligible.

Clofazimine exerts a slow bactericidal effect on Mycobacterium leprae (Hansen's bacillus) due primarily to its action on the bacterial outer membrane, though there is some evidence that activity on the bacterial respiratory chain and ion transporters may play a role. It also exerts anti-inflammatory properties due to the suppression of T-lymphocyte activity. Clofazimine has a relatively long duration of action owing to its long residence time in the body, but is still administered daily. The molecular weight of clofazimine is 473.4, and it has a topological polar surface area of 39.99. Clofazimine is part of Anti-Bacterial Agents; Anti-Infective Agents; Anti-Inflammatory Agents; Antiinfectives for Systemic Use; Antimycobacterials; BCRP/ABCG2 Inhibitors; Cytochrome P-450 CYP2C8 Inhibitors; Cytochrome P-450 CYP2C8 Inhibitors (strength unknown); and Cytochrome P-450 CYP2D6 Inhibitors. Clofazimine is approved and investigational.
Cysteamine:
Cysteamine is an oral treatment for nephropathic cystinosis and cystinuria in children 6 years old and above, and adults. It is also used in eye drop preparations to treat corneal cystine crystal accumulation in patients with cystinosis. Cysteamine prevents the accumulation of cystine crystals in the body by converting cystine into a form that can easily exit cells, preventing harmful accumulation. Individuals born without the ability to metabolize cystine suffer from cystinosis, a rare genetic disorder characterized by widespread accumulation of cystine crystals throughout the body and eye tissues. The cystine crystals may cause considerable damage, particularly in renal tissues and corneal tissues. In some cases, renal failure can occur during childhood if the condition is left untreated. Other organs that may be affected by cystinosis include the CNS, thyroid, pancreas, muscle tissues, and gonads. Cysteamine has a topological polar surface area of 26.02 and a log p value of -0.25. Cysteamine is 52% plasma protein bound and is mostly bound to albumin. The half-life of cysteamine is about 3.7 hours, and its molecular weight is 77.15. Cysteamine is approved and investigational for the treatment of nephropathic cystinosis and cystinuria, and its mechanism of action involves preventing the accumulation of cystine crystals in the body by converting cystine into a form that can easily exit cells, preventing harmful accumulation.
Pseudoephedrine:
Pseudoephedrine is a sympathomimetic amine used for its decongestant activity. Structurally related to but exerts a weaker effect on the sympathetic nervous system, both drugs naturally occur in the Ephedra plant which have a history of use in traditional Eastern medicine and were first researched in the west in 1889. The decongestant effect of pseudoephedrine was described in dogs in 1927. Pseudoephedrine acts mainly as an agonist of alpha adrenergic receptors and less strongly as an agonist of beta adrenergic receptors, producing vasoconstriction which is used as a decongestant and as a treatment of priapism. Pseudoephedrine is also an inhibitor of norepinephrine, dopamine, and serotonin transporters. The protein binding of pseudoephedrine is 6.6±0.4% bound to human serum albumin and 22.5±3.2% protein bound in serum, while +pseudoephedrine is 6.7±1.2% protein bound to human serum albumin and 25.4±3.9% protein bound in human serum. Pseudoephedrine is approved for use in various clinical indications, including decongestant activity and treatment of priapism.

In conclusion, pseudoephedrine is a sympathomimetic amine with a long history of use in traditional Eastern medicine and Western research. Its decongestant effect is mediated by its agonist activity on alpha adrenergic receptors, leading to vasoconstriction. Pseudoephedrine also has an inhibitory effect on norepinephrine, dopamine, and serotonin transporters. Its protein binding properties and elimination half-life contribute to its therapeutic window and potential side effects. As a sympathomimetic amine, pseudoephedrine is part of various drug categories and has been approved for use in different clinical indications.
Terbinafine hydrochloride:
Terbinafine hydrochloride is a synthetic allylamine antifungal with high lipophilicity, which accumulates in skin, nails, and fatty tissues. It inhibits the fungal squalene monooxygenase (also called squalene epoxidase), preventing ergosterol synthesis and weakening the cell wall of fungal cells. Terbinafine is indicated to treat fungal skin and nail infections caused by Trichophyton species, Microsporum canis, Epidermophyton floccosum, and Tinea species, as well as yeast infections of the skin caused by Candida species and Malassezia furfur. The drug distributes into tissues and has a long terminal elimination half-life, resulting in a prolonged duration of action. However, overdose with terbinafine is rare, even at therapeutic doses, so the therapeutic index is wide. Prior to treatment, liver function tests should be performed to reduce the risk of liver injury in patients taking oral terbinafine. Terbinafine is part of Agents Causing Muscle Toxicity; Allylamine Antifungal; Allylamines; Anti-Infective Agents; Antifungal Agents; Antifungals for Dermatological Use; Antifungals for Systemic Use; Antifungals for Topical Use; Cytochrome P-450 CYP1A2 Substrates; and Cytochrome P-450 CYP2C19 Substrates.

Pharmacodynamics: Terbinafine inhibits the enzyme squalene monooxygenase (also called squalene epoxidase), preventing the conversion of squalene to 2,3-oxidosqualene, a step in the synthesis of ergosterol. This inhibition leads to decreased ergosterol, which would normally be incorporated into the cell wall, and accumulation of squalene.

Tacrolimus: Tacrolimus is an immunosuppressive drug used primarily after organ transplant to reduce the activity of the patient's immune system and reduce the risk of organ rejection. It has also been used in a topical preparation for the treatment of severe atopic dermatitis, severe refractory uveitis after bone marrow transplants, and the skin condition vitiligo. Tacrolimus works by binding to the immunophilin FKBP-12, creating a complex that inhibits calcineurin, which in turn inhibits T-lymphocyte signal transduction and IL-2 transcription. The mechanism of action of tacrolimus in atopic dermatitis is not fully understood, but it is believed to inhibit the release of pre-formed mediators from skin mast cells and basophils, as well as downregulate the expression of FceRI on Langerhans cells. Tacrolimus has a similar activity to cyclosporine but rates of rejection are lower with tacrolimus. It is eliminated primarily through the kidneys, with a half-life of approximately 35 hours in adults and 10-25 hours in pediatric patients. Tacrolimus has a molecular weight of 804.03 and a topological polar surface area of 178.36. It is part of several drug categories, including agents causing hyperkalemia, agents causing muscle toxicity, and anti-bacterial agents. Tacrolimus was approved for use in liver transplantation in 1994 and since then its indication has expanded to include kidney, heart, small bowel, pancreas, lung, trachea, skin, cornea, and limb transplants.
Suprofen:
Suprofen is a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory analgesic and antipyretic that was previously approved for use in the United States. It works by inhibiting the synthesis of prostaglandins, which are pro-inflammatory mediators involved in the pain and inflammation response. Suprofen binds to the cyclooxygenase-1 (COX-1) and cyclooxygenase-2 (COX-2) isoenzymes, thereby reducing the production of prostaglandins and alleviating pain and inflammation. The drug was initially approved for use as eye drops to inhibit miosis (pupil constriction) during ocular surgery, as excessive constriction can make it more difficult for the surgeon to access certain areas of the eye. However, due to safety concerns related to its cardiotoxicity, suprofen is no longer approved for use in the United States. Despite its withdrawal from the market, suprofen remains an important drug in the field of ophthalmology, and its mechanism of action continues to be studied for potential applications in other areas of medicine.

Mechanism of Action: Suprofen works by inhibiting the cyclooxygenase enzymes, which are responsible for producing prostaglandins. Prostaglandins play a key role in the inflammatory response, and their production is increased during tissue trauma or inflammation. By reducing prostaglandin synthesis, suprofen reduces the inflammatory response and alleviates pain.

Pharmacokinetics: Suprofen is rapidly absorbed after topical administration, with peak levels achieved within 30 minutes. The drug is almost entirely bound to plasma proteins (90%), which may contribute to its cardiotoxicity. Suprofen has a relatively short half-life of approximately 2 hours, and it is eliminated primarily through the kidneys.

Adverse Effects: Suprofen can cause a range of adverse effects, including gastrointestinal disturbances, dizziness, headache, and skin rash. More serious side effects include cardiotoxicity, hepatotoxicity, and renal impairment. These adverse effects are thought to be related to the drug's inhibition of cyclooxygenase enzymes, which can lead to an overproduction of prostaglandins and other inflammatory mediators.

Drug Interactions: Suprofen may interact with other medications, including warfarin, aspirin, and diuretics. These interactions can increase the risk of adverse effects and may alter the drug's pharmacokinetics. For example, suprofen may decrease the clearance of warfarin, leading to increased international normalized ratio (INR) levels.

Pregnancy and Lactation: Suprofen is contraindicated in pregnant women due to its potential for fetal harm. The drug is also excreted in breast milk, and its use during lactation is not recommended.

Dosage and Administration: The recommended dose of suprofen for ophthalmic use is 1-2 drops instilled into the affected eye every hour as needed. The maximum daily dose should not exceed 6 drops.
Chlorhexidine: Chlorhexidine is a broad-spectrum antimicrobial agent used as a topical antiseptic and in dental practice for the treatment of inflammatory dental conditions caused by microorganisms. It is a cationic bis-guanide consisting of two 4-chlorophenyl rings and two biguanide groups joined by a central hexamethylene chain. Topical chlorhexidine for disinfection, as well as oral rinses for dental use, carries activity against a broad range of pathogens including bacteria, yeasts, and viruses. The mechanism of action is due to its ability to disrupt microbial cell membranes, leading to leakage of intracellular material and ultimately cell death. Chlorhexidine binds to albumin in both serum and saliva, although the extent of this binding is unclear. It has a topological polar surface area of 167.58 and log p value of 4.81. Chlorhexidine is part of Alimentary Tract and Metabolism; Amidines; Anti-Infective Agents; Anti-Infective Agents, Local; Antiseptics and Disinfectants; Biguanides; and Compounds used in a research, industrial, or hospital setting. It is approved for use in both humans and veterinary medicine.
Emtricitabine:
Emtricitabine is a nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NRTI) that is indicated for the treatment of HIV-1 infections in adults and pediatric patients weighing ≥25kg. It works by inhibiting HIV-1 reverse transcriptase, preventing transcription of viral RNA to DNA. Emtricitabine is a cytidine analogue that competes with the natural substrate of HIV-1 reverse transcriptase to be incorporated into newly formed DNA, terminating its transcription. Dosing Information: Emtricitabine is administered once daily, with or without food. It should be taken consistently at the same time each day to maintain a stable level of the drug in the body.

Special Populations: Emtricitabine has been studied in pediatric patients weighing ≥25kg, as well as in adolescents and adults weighing ≥35kg for pre-exposure prophylaxis. It is important to note that the drug's pharmacokinetics may differ between pediatric and adult populations, and further study is needed to determine the safety and efficacy of emtricitabine in specific patient populations.

It works by inhibiting HIV-1 reverse transcriptase, preventing transcription of viral RNA to DNA, and reducing the amount of HIV-1 RNA present in the body. Emtricitabine has a long duration of action, is bound to plasma proteins, and has a molecular weight of 247.24 and a topological polar surface area of 88.15. Its half-life is approximately 10 hours, and it may interact with other medications. Further studies are needed to determine the safety and efficacy of emtricitabine in specific patient populations.
Quinapril:
Quinapril is the ethyl ester prodrug of the non-sulfhydryl angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitor quinaprilat. It is used to treat hypertension and heart failure. ACE inhibitors are commonly used as a first line therapy in the treatment of hypertension, along with thiazide diuretics or beta blockers. Quinapril works by inhibiting the conversion of angiotensin I to angiotensin II, a potent vasoconstrictor. This leads to relaxation of blood vessels and a decrease in blood pressure. The active metabolite quinaprilat has a wide therapeutic window and a long duration of action, making it a useful treatment option for hypertension and heart failure. Quinapril is also indicated for the treatment of heart failure as an adjunct to diuretics and ACE inhibitors or beta blockers.

Mechanism of Action: Angiotensin II constricts coronary blood vessels and is positively inotropic, which under normal circumstances, would increase vascular resistance and oxygen consumption. This action can eventually lead to myocyte hypertrophy and vascular smooth muscle cell proliferation. Angiotensin II also stimulates production of plasminogen activator inhibitor-1 (PAI-1), increasing the risk of thrombosis. Quinapril inhibits the conversion of angiotensin I to angiotensin II, thereby reducing the vasoconstrictor effect and decreasing blood pressure.

Pharmacokinetics: Quinapril is rapidly absorbed after oral administration, with peak plasma concentrations achieved within 1-2 hours. The drug is extensively bound to plasma proteins (97%), mainly albumin, and its volume of distribution is approximately 3-5 liters/kg. Quinapril is metabolized to the active metabolite quinaprilat, which is formed through hydrolysis of the ester linkage. The elimination half-life of quinaprilat is 2.3 hours, and it is primarily excreted in urine as inactivated metabolites.

Clinical Indications: Quinapril is indicated for the treatment of hypertension and heart failure. It is used alone or in combination with other antihypertensive agents, such as diuretics, beta blockers, or ACE inhibitors. Quinapril has a wide therapeutic window and a long duration of action, making it a useful treatment option for hypertension and heart failure.

Adverse Effects: Common adverse effects of quinapril include cough, headache, dizziness, and fatigue. Less common side effects may include angioedema, hyperkalemia, and changes in blood electrolyte levels.

Drug Interactions: Quinapril may interact with other medications, including potassium-sparing diuretics, ACE inhibitors, and non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs). These interactions can lead to increased risk of hyperkalemia or hypotension.

Overall, quinapril is a useful treatment option for hypertension and heart failure due to its ability to effectively lower blood pressure and improve cardiovascular function. Its long duration of action and wide therapeutic window make it a valuable addition to the treatment arsenal for these conditions. However, patients should be monitored closely for potential adverse effects and drug interactions to ensure safe and effective therapy.
Didanosine:
Didanosine is a nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NRTI) that acts as a chain terminator of viral DNA by binding to reverse transcriptase and preventing the formation of phosphodiester linkages. It is metabolized intracellularly by cellular enzymes to its active moiety, dideoxyadenosine triphosphate (ddATP), which inhibits the HIV reverse transcriptase enzyme competitively and acts as a chain terminator by preventing DNA chain elongation. Didanosine is usually used in combination with other antiviral therapy to treat HIV-1 infection in adults. Its low protein binding and high acid stability make it an effective treatment option.

Didanosine, also known as d4T, is a dideoxynucleoside compound that replaces the 3'-hydroxy group on the sugar moiety with a hydrogen. This modification prevents the formation of phosphodiester linkages necessary for nucleic acid chain elongation. Didanosine is metabolized to its active metabolite, dideoxyadenosine triphosphate (ddATP), which inhibits reverse transcriptase by competing with natural dATP and acts as a chain terminator by preventing DNA synthesis.

Didanosine has a molecular weight of 236.23 and a topological polar surface area (TPSA) of 88.74. Its logP value is -1.92, indicating that it is moderately soluble in water. Didanosine is approved for use in the treatment of HIV-1 infection in adults when used in combination with other antiretroviral agents.

It also inhibits reverse transcriptase competitively by binding to the active site of the enzyme, thereby preventing the incorporation of dATP into viral DNA.

Clinical Indication: Didanosine is used in combination with other antiretroviral agents for the treatment of HIV-1 infection in adults. It is effective in reducing the viral load and improving the clinical condition of HIV-infected individuals.

Drug Categories: Didanosine belongs to Anti-HIV Agents, Anti-Infective Agents, Anti-Retroviral Agents, Antiinfectives for Systemic Use, Antimetabolites, Antiviral Agents, Antivirals for Systemic Use, Carbohydrates, Deoxyribonucleosides, Dideoxynucleosides, Direct Acting Antivirals, and Drugs that are Mainly R.

Pharmacokinetics: Didanosine is rapidly absorbed after oral administration and reaches peak plasma concentrations within 30 minutes. It has a half-life of more than 12 hours in the intracellular environment and a shorter half-life in plasma due to metabolism by cellular enzymes.

Adverse Effects: Common adverse effects of didanosine include nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, headache, and fatigue. Less common side effects include skin rash, fever, and muscle pain. Rarely, didanosine can cause bone marrow suppression, liver damage, and lactic acidosis.

Drug Interactions: Didanosine may interact with other medications, such as antacids, and may affect the activity of these drugs. It is important to inform the healthcare provider of all medications being taken, including over-the-counter medications and supplements, to avoid potential drug interactions.
Ethacrynic acid:
Ethacrynic acid is a compound that inhibits symport of sodium, potassium, and chloride primarily in the ascending limb of Henle, but also in the proximal and distal tubules. This pharmacological action results in excretion of these ions, increased urinary output, and reduction in extracellular fluid. Classified as a loop or high ceiling diuretic, ethacrynic acid is used for the treatment of high blood pressure and edema caused by diseases like congestive heart failure, liver failure, and kidney failure. Its mechanism of action involves inhibition of symport in the renal tubules, leading to increased urinary output and reduction in extracellular fluid. Ethacrynic acid has a high degree of protein binding and is effective in patients with significant degrees of renal insufficiency. It is a solid with a molecular weight of 303.14 and a topological polar surface area of 63.6. Ethacrynic acid belongs to various drug categories, including Acetates, Acids, Acyclic, Agents that produce neuromuscular block (indirect), Aryloxyacetic Acid Derivatives, Cardiovascular Agents, Diuretics, Enzyme Inhibitors, Fatty Acids, Fatty Acids, Volatile, Glycolates, High-Ceiling Diuretics, Hydroxy Acids, and Hyperglycemics. Ethacrynic acid works by inhibiting the symport of sodium, potassium, and chloride in the renal tubules, resulting in increased urinary output and reduced extracellular fluid. The mechanism of action of ethacrynic acid differs from other diuretics, as it does not involve carbonic anhydrase inhibition. Additionally, ethacrynic acid has a high degree of protein binding, making it effective in patients with renal insufficiency.

The pharmacokinetics of ethacrynic acid are characterized by rapid absorption after oral administration, followed by distribution to the kidneys and urinary tract. However, it can also cause side effects and may lead to dehydration and electrolyte imbalances if not used properly.
Quinidine: Quinidine is an optical isomer of quinine, extracted from the bark of the Cinchona tree and similar plant species. This alkaloid dampens the excitability of cardiac and skeletal muscles by blocking sodium and potassium currents across cellular membranes, thereby prolonging cellular action potential and decreasing automaticity. Quinidine also blocks muscarinic and alpha-adrenergic neurotransmission. Its clinical indication is for the treatment of ventricular pre-excitation and cardiac dysrhythmias. The mechanism of action of quinidine involves its effects on sodium channels on neuronal cell membranes, limiting the spread of seizure activity and reducing seizure propagation. Repaglinide:
Repaglinide is an oral antihyperglycemic agent used for the treatment of non-insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus (NIDDM). It belongs to the meglitinide class of short-acting insulin secretagogues, which act by binding to β cells of the pancreas to stimulate insulin release. Repaglinide induces an early insulin response to meals, decreasing postprandial blood glucose levels. It should only be taken with meals and meal-time doses should be skipped with any skipped meal. Approximately one month of therapy is required before a decrease in fasting blood glucose is seen. Meglitnides may have a neutral effect on weight or cause a slight increase in weight, with an average weight gain of approximately 0.5 kg (1.1 lbs) over several months. The mechanism of action of repaglinide is dependent on the presence and functioning of β cells and glucose, as it potentiates the effect of extracellular glucose on ATP-sensitive potassium channels and has little effect on insulin levels between meals and overnight. Repaglinide appears to be selective for pancreatic β cells and does not appear to affect skeletal or cardiac muscle or thyroid tissue. The pharmacokinetics of repaglinide are characterized by rapid absorption, extensive metabolism in the liver, and elimination primarily in bile. Approximately 90% of a single orally administered dose is eliminated in feces and 8% in urine. The protein binding of repaglinide is greater than 98%, mostly to albumin and α1-acid glycoprotein. Repaglinide has a half-life of approximately 1 hour and its molecular weight is 452.6. Repaglinide is approved and investigational for the treatment of NIDDM.

Cyclobenzaprine: Cyclobenzaprine is a centrally-acting muscle relaxant that was first synthesized in 1961 and approved for human use in 1977. It has remained relatively popular as an adjunctive, short-term treatment for acute skeletal muscle spasms secondary to musculoskeletal injury. Cyclobenzaprine is indicated as a short-term (2-3 weeks) adjunct therapy along with rest and physical therapy for relief of muscle spasm associated with acute, painful musculoskeletal conditions. It has not been found effective in the treatment of spasticity originating from cerebral or spinal cord disease, or spasticity in children with cerebral palsy. The exact mechanism of action of cyclobenzaprine has not been fully elucidated in humans, but it is thought to exert its effects at the supraspinal level within the locus coeruleus of the brainstem, with little-to-no action at neuromuscular junctions or directly on skeletal musculature. Cyclobenzaprine is approximately 93% protein bound in plasma and has a high affinity for human serum albumin. Methacycline:
Methacycline is a broad-spectrum semisynthetic antibiotic related to tetracycline but excreted more slowly and maintaining effective blood levels for a more extended period. It is used for the treatment of acute bacterial exacerbations of chronic bronchitis. Methacycline works by inhibiting protein synthesis by binding to the 16S part of the 30S ribosomal subunit and preventing the amino-acyl tRNA from binding to the A site of the ribosome. This mechanism also leads to research on chemically modified tetracyclines or CMTs (like incyclinide) for the treatment of rosacea, acne, and various types of neoplasms. Methacycline has a wide spectrum of antimicrobial action against most Gram-positive bacteria (pneumococci, streptococci, staphylococci) and Gram-negative bacteria (E. coli, salmonella, shigella, etc.), as well as towards agents causing onithosis, psittacosis, trachoma, and some Protozoa. However, the general usefulness of methacycline has been reduced with the onset of bacterial resistance.

PHARMACODYNAMICS: Methacycline is a tetracycline antibiotic that binds to 75-78% protein bound. Its mechanism of action is similar to other tetracyclines, inhibiting protein synthesis by binding to the 16S part of the 30S ribosomal subunit and preventing the amino-acyl tRNA from binding to the A site of the ribosome.

PHARMACOKINETICS: Methacycline has a half-life of 14 hours, and its molecular weight is 442.42. It also has a topological polar surface area of 181.62, and the log p value is -0.8.

DRUG CATEGORIES: Methacycline belongs to Agents that produce neuromuscular block (indirect), Anti-Bacterial Agents, Anti-Infective Agents, Antibacterials for Systemic Use, Antiinfectives for Systemic Use, Naphthacenes, and Tetracyclines.

Salicylic Acid:
Salicylic acid is a compound obtained from the bark of the white willow and wintergreen leaves, as well as synthetically prepared. It has bacteriostatic, fungicidal, and keratolytic actions. Its salts, the salicylates, are used as analgesics. Salicylic acid directly irreversibly inhibits COX-1 and COX-2 to decrease conversion of arachidonic acid to precursors of prostaglandins and thromboxanes. This mechanism of action makes it an effective treatment for acne, psoriasis, callouses, corns, keratosis pilaris, and warts. Salicylic acid allows cells of the epidermis to more readily slough off, making it a key ingredient in many skin-care products. It is also used as an active ingredient in gels that remove verrucas (plantar warts). Salicylic acid competitively inhibits oxidation of uridine-5-diphosphoglucuronic acid (UDPGA) with nicotinamide adenosine dinucleotide (NAD) and noncompetitively with UDPG. Inhibition of mucopoly saccharide synthesis is likely responsible for the slowing of wound healing with salicylates.

Salicylic acid treats acne by causing skin cells to slough off more readily, preventing pores from clogging up. This effect on skin cells also makes it an active ingredient in several shampoos meant to treat dandruff. Use of straight salicylic solution may cause hyperpigmentation on unpretreated skin for those with darker skin types (Fitzpatrick phototypes IV, V, VI), as well as with the lack of use of a broad spectrum sunblock. When combined with bismuth, the two key ingredients help control diarrhea, nausea, heartburn, and even gas. It is also very mildly anti-biotic.

Salicylic acid is a solid with a molecular weight of 138.12 and a topological polar surface area of 57.53. Its log p value is 2.19.
