The elimination half-life of simeprevir following 200mg dose administration is about 41 hours in HCV-positive patients and 10 to 13 hours in individuals without HCV infection.

In summary, simeprevir is a potent and highly specific inhibitor of the HCV NS3/4A protease, which is essential for viral replication. Its unique resistance profile and pharmacokinetic properties make it an important treatment option for patients with chronic HCV infection, particularly those with genotype 1 without cirrhosis or with compensated cirrhosis.

It is used in the treatment of osteoporosis, anemia, and as an agent to stimulate muscle growth in malnourished or underdeveloped patients. Anabolic-androgenic steroids (AAS), such as oxymetholone, have been abused by bodybuilders and athletes, leading to a large variety of detrimental effects, including cardiovascular events. Oxymetholone works by binding to the androgen receptor, which is activated by the hormone response elements (HREs) in the chromosomal DNA. The molecular weight of oxymetholone is 332.48, and it has a topological polar surface area of 57.53. Oxymetholone is part of Alimentary Tract and Metabolism; Anabolic Agents; Anabolic Agents for Systemic Use; Anabolic Steroids; Androgens; Androstan Derivatives; Androstanes; Androstanols; Cytochrome P-450 CYP2D6 Inhibitors (strength unknown); and Cytochrome P-450 CYP2D6 Inhibitors. The approval status of oxymetholone is approved and illicit.

Oxymetholone is indicated in the treatment of anemias caused by deficient red cell production, such as acquired aplastic anemia, congenital aplastic anemia, myelofibrosis, and the hypoplastic anemias due to the administration of myelotoxic drugs. It should not replace other supportive measures, such as transfusion, correction of iron, folic acid, vitamin B12 or pyridoxine deficiency, antibacterial therapy, and the appropriate use of corticosteroids. The mechanism of action of oxymetholone involves its binding to the androgen receptor, which is activated by the hormone response elements (HREs) in the chromosomal DNA. Free testosterone (T) is transported into the cytoplasm of target tissue cells, where it can bind to the androgen receptor or be reduced to 5α-dihydrotestosterone (DHT) by the cytoplasmic enzyme 5α-reductase. DHT binds to the same androgen receptor even more strongly than T, so that its androgenic potency is about 2.5 times that of T.

Prucalopride: Prucalopride is a dihydrobenzofurancarboxamide derivative from the benzofurane family that selectively stimulates 5-HT4 receptors and thus, it presents enterokinetic properties. The high selectivity of prucalopride allowed further development as it prevented the cardiac adverse reactions observed due to non-target effects of precedent therapies. Prucalopride was developed by Shire Development LLC and approved for use in Europe in 2009, in Canada on December 7, 2011 and by the FDA on December 17, 2018. It is indicated for the treatment of chronic idiopathic constipation (CIC) in adults. Prucalopride acts as a selective stimulator of the 5-HT4 receptors while having no interaction with hERG channel or 5-HT1 receptors which reduces significantly the cardiovascular risk found in other similar drugs. In animal studies, prucalopride induced a dose-dependent stimulation of contractile activity in the proximal colon and inhibition of the contractility in the distal colon. It also stimulates and amplifies giant migratory contraction which is the high-amplitude type of contraction that initiates the urge to defecate. Thus, prucalopride not only accelerates the colonic transit but also accelerates gastric emptying and small bowel transit. The plasma protein binding of prucalopride is of 30%. The reported half-life of prucalopride is of around 18-20 hours. Liraglutide:
Liraglutide is a synthetic analog of human glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1) and acts as a GLP-1 receptor agonist. It is made by attaching a C-16 fatty acid (palmitic acid) with a glutamic acid spacer on the remaining lysine residue at position 26 of the peptide precursor. Liraglutide was granted FDA approval on January 25, 2010 and is indicated in combination with diet and exercise to improve glycemic control in patients 10 years and older with type 2 diabetes mellitus. It is also indicated to reduce the risk of major adverse cardiovascular events in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus as well as cardiovascular disease. The prolonged action of liraglutide is achieved by attaching a fatty acid molecule at position 26 of the GLP-1 molecule, enabling it to bind reversibly to albumin within the subcutaneous tissue and bloodstream and be released slowly over time. Liraglutide has a topological polar surface area of 1513.76 and is part of Alimentary Tract and Metabolism ; Amino Acids, Peptides, and Proteins ; Blood Glucose Lowering Agents ; Drugs Used in Diabetes ; Gastrointestinal Hormones ; GLP-1 Agonists ; Glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1) Agonists ; Glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1) an. Liraglutide has a molecular weight of 3751.26 and a terminal half-life of 13 hours. The mechanism of action of liraglutide is the increased secretion of insulin and decreased secretion of glucagon in response to glucose as well as slower gastric emptying. Liraglutide does not adversely affect glucagon secretion in response to low blood sugar. The protein binding of liraglutide is greater than 98%.

Mechanism of Action: Liraglutide acts as a GLP-1 receptor agonist, increasing the activity of the GLP-1 receptor on pancreatic beta cells, leading to increased insulin secretion and decreased glucagon secretion. The prolonged action of liraglutide is achieved by attaching a fatty acid molecule at position 26 of the GLP-1 molecule, enabling it to bind reversibly to albumin within the subcutaneous tissue and bloodstream and be released slowly over time. This results in a more gradual increase in cyclic AMP, leading to a more prolonged increase in insulin secretion. Additionally, liraglutide slows gastric emptying, which can help to improve glycemic control by reducing the peak glucose levels after a meal.

Clinical Indication: Liraglutide is indicated for the treatment of type 2 diabetes mellitus in combination with diet and exercise. It is also indicated for reducing the risk of major adverse cardiovascular events in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus as well as cardiovascular disease.

Pharmacokinetics: Liraglutide has a terminal half-life of 13 hours and is eliminated primarily through the kidneys. The molecular weight of liraglutide is 3751.26.

Drug Interactions: Liraglutide may interact with other medications, including warfarin, insulin, and sulfonylureas, which can affect blood glucose levels. Patients should inform their healthcare provider of all medications they are taking, including over-the-counter medications and supplements.

Side Effects: Common side effects of liraglutide include nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and headache. Less common side effects can include hypoglycemia, dizziness, and fatigue.

Contraindications: Liraglutide is contraindicated in patients with a history of pancreatitis or thyroid cancer. It should be used with caution in patients with a history of hypersensitivity reactions or in patients with severe renal impairment.

Dosage and Administration: The recommended starting dose of liraglutide is 0.6 mg subcutaneously once daily, and the maximum recommended dose is 1.2 mg per day. Liraglutide should be administered as a single injection in the abdomen, and patients should be advised to rotate the injection site to minimize local reactions.

Risk Management: Liraglutide can cause hypoglycemia, particularly when used with other antidiabetic medications. Patients should be monitored closely for signs of hypoglycemia, and their dosages may need to be adjusted accordingly. Additionally, liraglutide may interact with other medications, including warfarin, insulin, and sulfonylureas, which can affect blood glucose levels. Patients should inform their healthcare provider of all medications they are taking, including over-the-counter medications and supplements.
Gadofosveset trisodium:
Gadofosveset trisodium is an intravenous contrast agent used with magnetic resonance angiography (MRA) to enhance the visibility of blood vessels during imaging. This non-invasive diagnostic tool allows for the evaluation of aortoiliac occlusive disease (AIOD) in adults with known or suspected peripheral vascular disease. Gadofosveset trisodium binds reversibly to endogenous serum albumin, resulting in a longer vascular residence time and increased magnetic resonance relaxivity compared to non-protein binding contrast agents. This binding also decreases the relaxation time (T1) of water protons, leading to an increase in signal intensity (brightness) of blood. The half-life of gadofosveset trisodium is 18.5 hours, and it is approved for use as a contrast agent in MRA.

Mechanism of Action: Gadofosveset trisodium causes signal enhancement by shortening the T1 of water molecules that interact with it, primarily due to its rotation rate. The contrast agent complex's rotation rate determines the magnitude of relaxation enhancement, which occurs only when bound to human serum albumin.

Protein Binding: Gadofosveset trisodium binds reversibly to endogenous serum albumin, with a protein binding percentage of 80-90%.

Pharmacodynamics: The relaxation enhancement increase occurs only when bound to human serum albumin, indicating that the binding to serum albumin is essential for the pharmacological effect.

Physical State: Gadofosveset trisodium is a solid.

Half-life: The half-life of gadofosveset trisodium is 18.5 hours.

Drug Categories: Gadofosveset trisodium belongs to the categories of Compounds used in a research, industrial, or household setting; Contrast Media; Diagnostic Uses of Chemicals; Drugs that are Mainly Renally Excreted; Elements; Gadolinium-based Contrast Agent; Lanthanoid Series Elements; Magnetic Resonance Angiography; Magne.

Methyltestosterone: Methyltestosterone is a synthetic anabolic steroid used for treating men with testosterone deficiency or similar androgen replacement therapies. It also has antineoplastic properties and has been used secondarily in women with advanced breast cancer. As a schedule III drug in the US, methyltestosterone is available only by prescription and its distribution is restricted. Its effects occur by way of two main mechanisms: by activation of the androgen receptor (directly or as DHT), and by conversion to estradiol and activation of certain estrogen receptors. Free testosterone (T) is transported into the cytoplasm of target tissue cells, where it can bind to the androgen receptor, or can be reduced to 5α-dihydrotestosterone (DHT) by the cytoplasmic enzyme 5α-reductase. DHT binds to the same androgen receptor even more strongly than T, so that its androgenic potency is about 2.5 times that of T. The T-receptor or DHT-receptor complex undergoes a structural change that allows it to move into the cell nucleus and bind directly to specific nucleotide sequences of the chromosomal DNA. The areas of binding are called hormone response elements (HREs), and influence transcriptional activity of certain genes, producing the androgen effects. Methyltestosterone is bound to sex hormone-binding globulin and 2% remains unbound, while the rest is bound to albumin and other proteins. Its half-life is approximately 6-8 hours, and its molecular weight is 302.46. Methyltestosterone belongs to various drug categories such as 3-Oxoandrosten (4) Derivatives, Anabolic Agents, Androgens, Androgens and Estrogens, Androstanes, Androstenes, Androstenols, Antineoplastic Agents, Antineoplastic Agents, Hormonal, Cytochrome P-450 CYP2B6 Substrates, Cytochrome P-450 CYP3A Substrates, and Cytochrome P-450 CYP. Its approval status is approved.
Fospropofol: Fospropofol is a water-soluble prodrug that is converted to the active ingredient propofol in the liver. It is a short-acting hypnotic/sedative/anesthetic agent that does not cause injection-site pain due to its inability to activate TRPA1. Fospropofol was approved by the FDA in December 2008 for monitored anesthesia care sedation in patients undergoing diagnostic procedures such as bronchoscopy and colonscopy, or minor surgical procedures such as arthroscopy and bunionectomy. After in-vivo conversion into propofol by endothelial alkaline phosphatase, propofol crosses the blood-brain barrier and binds to GABA-A receptors, increasing chloride conductance and inhibiting the firing of new action potentials in post-synaptic neurons. Both fospropofol and its active metabolite propofol are highly protein bound, primarily to albumin, with no effect on propofol's binding to albumin. Fospropofol has a molecular weight of 288.28, topological polar surface area of 75.99, and logP value of 2.13. It is part of the drug categories Agents that reduce seizure threshold, Anesthetics, General, Benzene Derivatives, Central Nervous System Agents, Central Nervous System Depressants, Hypnotics and Sedatives, and Phenols.
Mangafodipir:
Mangafodipir is a contrast agent used as a diagnostic tool administered intravenously to enhance contrast in magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the liver and pancreas. This drug is made up of paramagnetic manganese (II) ions combined with the chelating agent fodipir (dipyridoxyl diphosphate, DPDP). The manganese absorption into tissues that makes the normal tissue appear brighter in MRI is limited in abnormal or cancerous tissue. Enhanced contrast by mangafodipir improves visualization and detection of lesions of the liver formed from metastatic disease or hepatocellular carcinomas. The contrast agent is present as mangafodipir trisodium marketed under the name Teslascan. Teslascan has been removed from the Drug Product List by FDA in 2003, and withdrawn from the European market in 2012.

Manganese absorption into tissues is high affinity and selectivity, and the ligand fodipir is distributed to the extracellular fluid and later eliminated via urine. Mangafodipir shortens the longitudinal relaxation time (T1) of targeted tissues during MRI, where signal intensity or brightness is increased in normal liver parenchyma. Overall, there is increased contrast between normal tissue and abnormal tissue with lesions because there is a difference between cellular compositions, and manganese uptake in metastatic tissue or focal lesions is minimal or nearly absent.

The protein binding of manganese is approximately 27% but negligible for fodipir. Manganese is transported to the liver via α2-macroglobulin and to a lesser extent, albumin. The mean initial plasma half-life of manganese metals is approximately 20 minutes and 50 minutes for fodipir (dipyridoxyl diphosphate, DPDP).

In conclusion, Mangafodipir is a contrast agent used in MRI of the liver and pancreas, which enhances the visualization and detection of lesions in these organs. The drug is made up of paramagnetic manganese (II) ions combined with the chelating agent fodipir, and it has high affinity and selectivity for the liver parenchyma. Mangafodipir shortens the longitudinal relaxation time of targeted tissues during MRI, leading to increased signal intensity or brightness in normal liver parenchyma. Azapropazone:
Azapropazone is a solid drug with a molecular weight of 300.36 and a topological polar surface area of 56.22. It belongs to various drug categories, including agents causing hyperkalemia, producers of hypertension, analgesics, non-narcotic analgesics, anti-inflammatory agents, non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), antigout preparations, and antiinflammatory and antirheumatic products. However, its approval status is withdrawn due to safety concerns.

Pharmacologically, azapropazone acts as an NSAID and a potassium-sparing diuretic, increasing potassium excretion in the urine. It is believed to work by inhibiting the production of prostaglandins, which are pro-inflammatory mediators involved in various physiological processes such as pain, fever, and inflammation. By blocking the production of these prostaglandins, azapropazone can reduce inflammation and alleviate symptoms associated with conditions like arthritis and menstrual cramps.

Clinically, azapropazone has been used to treat a variety of conditions, including osteoarthritis, rheumatoid arthritis, acute pain, and menstrual cramps. However, its use has largely been discontinued due to safety concerns related to its potential to cause hyperkalemia, or elevated potassium levels in the blood. This can be particularly dangerous for patients with pre-existing heart conditions, as it can lead to cardiac arrhythmias and other complications.

In summary, azapropazone is a withdrawn drug that was once used to treat various inflammatory conditions due to its NSAID and potassium-sparing diuretic properties. However, safety concerns related to hyperkalemia have led to its discontinuation in clinical practice.

Chloramphenicol succinate:
Chloramphenicol succinate is an ester prodrug of chloramphenicol, a bacteriostatic antibiotic. The use of chloramphenicol succinate and chloramphenicol has decreased due to the risk of potentially fatal blood dyscrasias. However, chloramphenicol succinate is still indicated to treat serious and susceptible bacterial infections where less dangerous drugs are ineffective or contraindicated. The mechanism of action of chloramphenicol succinate involves binding to the residues A2451 and A2452 in the 23S rRNA of _E. coli_, which prevents translation. Chloramphenicol succinate is 57-92% protein bound in plasma, and its half-life in patients with normal renal and hepatic function is 0.6-2.7h. Chloramphenicol succinate belongs to several drug categories, including Alcohols, Anti-Bacterial Agents, Anti-Infective Agents, Benzene Derivatives, Glycols, Narrow Therapeutic Index Drugs, Nitro Compounds, Nitrobenzenes, P-glycoprotein substrates, and Propylene Glycols. Chloramphenicol succinate has been approved for use in various countries.

Chloramphenicol is a broad-spectrum antibiotic that is effective against a wide range of bacterial infections, including gram-positive and gram-negative organisms. However, its use has been limited due to the risk of serious blood dyscrasias, such as aplastic anemia, neutropenia, and bone marrow failure. These adverse effects are thought to be associated with the inhibition of the enzyme cytochromes P450IA2 and P450CYP3A4, which are involved in the metabolism of chloramphenicol. Therefore, the use of chloramphenicol succinate, which is a prodrug that is converted to the active form chloramphenicol in the body, may help to reduce the risk of these adverse effects.

Chloramphenicol succinate works by binding to the 23S rRNA of bacteria, specifically to the residues A2451 and A2452. This binding prevents the bacterial ribosomes from translating messenger RNA into protein, thereby inhibiting bacterial growth and reproduction. Chloramphenicol succinate has a narrow therapeutic index, which means that it can be toxic or ineffective at high doses or in patients with certain medical conditions. Therefore, its use must be carefully monitored and managed by healthcare professionals.

In summary, chloramphenicol succinate is an ester prodrug of chloramphenicol, a broad-spectrum antibiotic that is used to treat serious bacterial infections. While its use has been limited due to the risk of blood dyscrasias, chloramphenicol succinate may offer a safer alternative for patients who require this type of treatment. However, its use must be carefully managed and monitored to avoid adverse effects.
Indoxyl sulfate: Indoxyl sulfate is a solid drug belonging to the category of Heterocyclic Compounds, Fused-Ring; Indoles. It is an experimental substance that has not yet been approved for clinical use. The pharmacological properties of indoxyl sulfate are characterized by its ability to act as a protein synthesis inhibitor, thereby interfering with the growth and reproduction of microorganisms. In particular, it has been shown to be effective against a wide range of bacteria, including methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA). The clinical uses of indoxyl sulfate include its potential as an antibiotic for the treatment of bacterial infections, particularly those caused by MRSA. Its mechanism of action involves the inhibition of protein synthesis, which ultimately leads to the death of bacterial cells. However, further research is needed to fully understand the safety and efficacy of indoxyl sulfate in humans, as well as its potential side effects and drug interactions.
Myristic Acid: Myristic acid is a solid, experimental drug or substance that belongs to the categories of Fatty Acids and Lipids. It is currently in the experimental stage and has not yet been approved for clinical use. Myristic acid is a saturated fatty acid with a 14-carbon chain, consisting of a straight chain with a carboxyl group (-COOH) at one end and a methyl group (-CH3) at the other end. Its chemical formula is CH3(CH2)13CHO. Myristic acid has been studied for its potential therapeutic applications, including its ability to reduce inflammation and modulate immune responses. However, further research is needed to determine its safety and efficacy in humans before it can be approved for clinical use.
Warfarin Alcohol (R,S-Warfarin):
Warfarin alcohol (R,S-Warfarin) is an experimental drug with a solid physical state. It is a racemic mixture of the R- and S-enantiomers of warfarin, a coumarin-type anticoagulant. The drug works by inhibiting the vitamin K-epoxide reductase enzyme, which is responsible for the regeneration of vitamin K-dependent clotting factors in the liver. By inhibiting this enzyme, warfarin alcohol reduces the body's ability to form blood clots, thereby preventing thrombosis and embolism.

Clinically, warfarin alcohol has been investigated as a potential treatment for various cardiovascular conditions, including atrial fibrillation, venous thromboembolism, and stroke. It has also been studied in the prevention of deep vein thrombosis following surgery or immobilization. While early studies showed promising results, the drug's experimental status and potential side effects have limited its widespread use.

Mechanistically, warfarin alcohol acts by binding to the vitamin K-epoxide reductase enzyme, which is responsible for the conversion of vitamin K-dependent clotting factors in the liver. By inhibiting this enzyme, warfarin alcohol reduces the body's ability to form blood clots, thereby preventing thrombosis and embolism. The drug's racemic structure allows for both R- and S-enantiomers to bind to the enzyme, further potentiating its anticoagulant effects.

Despite its potential, warfarin alcohol remains an experimental drug due to its limited clinical availability and potential side effects, including bleeding complications. Further research is needed to fully understand the drug's pharmacokinetics, pharmacodynamics, and safety profile before it can be considered for widespread use in clinical practice.
Warfarin alcohol:
Warfarin alcohol is an experimental drug that is a solid at room temperature. It is a combination of the well-known anticoagulant warfarin and alcohol. The exact mechanism of action of this drug is not yet fully understood, but it is believed to work by enhancing the anticoagulant effects of warfarin. Warfarin alcohol has shown promise in preclinical studies as a potential treatment for a variety of conditions, including deep vein thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, and stroke. However, due to its experimental status, further research is needed to determine its safety and efficacy in humans.

Warfarin alcohol is metabolized by the liver enzyme cytochrome P450, which can result in drug interactions with other medications. It is important to closely monitor patients receiving warfarin alcohol for signs of bleeding or clotting abnormalities, as well as for potential side effects such as nausea, vomiting, and headache. Proper dosing and monitoring are critical when using this drug, and it is recommended that healthcare professionals have experience in managing anticoagulant therapy before administering warfarin alcohol to patients.

In summary, warfarin alcohol is an experimental drug that combines the anticoagulant effects of warfarin with the potential for enhanced efficacy. While it shows promise in preclinical studies, further research is needed to determine its safety and efficacy in humans. Due to its metabolism by cytochrome P450 and potential for drug interactions, close monitoring and proper dosing are essential when using this drug.
Triflusal: Triflusal is a 2-acetoxy-4-trifluoromethylbenzoic acid, a chemically related molecule to aspirin but not a derivative. Its benefits include the lack of action on the arachidonic acid pathway, driven production of nitric oxide, and increased cyclic nucleotide concentration on endothelial cells, resulting in vessel expansion. As a secondary prevention of ischemic stroke, triflusal offers a lower risk of bleeding due to its irreversible inhibition of cycloxygenase-1 in platelets. Triflusal has been registered in Europe, South America, and South Korea for the prevention of Stroke and myocardial infarction. Mechanistically, it binds almost completely to plasma proteins and affects various targets, including NF kappa B, a gene expression regulatory factor for cycloxygenase-a and cytokines. Studies have shown either no significant difference or a better efficacy and safety profile compared to acetylsalicylic acid. Triflusal has been shown to protect cerebral tissue due to its inhibition of lipid peroxidation resulting from anoxia-reoxygenation. Its physical state is a solid, with a half-life of 0.5 +/- 0.1h in healthy humans and 34.3 +/- 5.3h for its metabolite HTB. Triflusal belongs to various drug categories, including Acids, Carbocyclic ; Anticoagulants ; Antiplatelet agents ; Benzene Derivatives ; Benzoates ; Blood and Blood Forming Organs ; Hematologic Agents ; Hydroxy Acids ; Hydroxybenzoates ; Phenols ; Platelet Aggregation Inhibitors Excl. Heparin. Although it is commercialized in different countries, triflusal is not approved by the FDA, EMA or HealthCanada.
Ticagrelor: Ticagrelor, also known as AZD6140, is a pharmaceutical drug that belongs to the class of ADP (adenosine diphosphate) derivatives. It was first introduced in the medical literature in 2003 and is marketed by Astra Zeneca under the brand names Brilinta in the US and Brilique or Possia in the EU. Ticagrelor acts as a P2Y12 receptor antagonist, which means it blocks the action of ADP on platelets, thereby reducing the risk of cardiovascular events such as myocardial infarction, stroke, and death. The drug has a moderate duration of action, being given twice daily, and a wide therapeutic index, allowing for safe use at high single doses. However, patients should be counselled about the potential risks of bleeding, dyspnea, and bradyarrhythmias associated with its use. Ticagrelor has a molecular weight of 522.57 g/mol, a topological polar surface area of 138.44 square meters, and a logP value of 2.55. It is a solid at room temperature and has a plasma half-life of approximately 8 hours for the parent compound and 12 hours for the active metabolite. Ticagrelor is part of several drug categories, including anticoagulants, antiplatelet agents, blood and blood forming organs, carbohydrates, cytochrome P-450 CYP2C9 inhibitors (weak), cytochrome P-450 CYP3A inhibitors, cytochrome P-450 CYP3A substrates, and cytochrome P-450 CYP3A4 inhibitors. The drug has been approved for use in various countries around the world.
Ivacaftor:
Ivacaftor, also known as Kalydeco or VX-770, is a drug used for the management of Cystic Fibrosis (CF). It is manufactured and distributed by Vertex Pharmaceuticals. Approved by the Food and Drug Administration on January 31, 2012, and by Health Canada in late 2012, ivacaftor is administered as a monotherapy and also administered in combination with other drugs for the management of CF. The drug received expanded approval in May 2017 for 33 CFTR mutations. Ivacaftor binds to and potentiates the channel opening ability of CFTR proteins on the cell membrane, thereby improving CF symptoms and modulating underlying disease pathology. The drug is bound to plasma proteins primarily to alpha 1-acid glycoprotein and albumin, with approximately 99% of ivacaftor being bound to plasma proteins. The apparent terminal half-life was approximately 12 hours following a single dose of ivacaftor, with a log P value of 3.82. Ivacaftor is part of Amines; Aniline Compounds; Benzene Derivatives; Chloride Channel Activation Potentiators; Cystic Fibrosis Transmembrane Conductance Regulator Potentiators; Cytochrome P-450 CYP2C9 Inhibitors; Cytochrome P-450 CYP3A Inhibitors; and Cytochrome P-450 

Mechanism of Action: Ivacaftor acts by potentiating the channel opening probability (or gating) of CFTR protein in patients with impaired gating mechanisms. This is achieved by binding to and increasing the opening ability of CFTR proteins on the cell membrane, thereby improving CF symptoms and modulating underlying disease pathology. The drug is indicated for the management of CF in patients with G551D mutation, as it binds to and potentiates the channel opening ability of CFTR proteins on the cell membrane.

Clinical Indication: Ivacaftor is indicated for the management of CF in patients age 2 years and older who have a mutation in the CFTR gene that is responsive to ivacaftor potentiation, including G551D. The drug received expanded approval in May 2017 for 33 CFTR mutations.

Physical State: Ivacaftor is a solid.

Half-life: The apparent terminal half-life was approximately 12 hours following a single dose of ivacaftor.

Molecular Properties: Molecular Weight: 392.5; TPSA: 78.43; cLogP: 3.82.
Vismodegib: Vismodegib is a drug that inhibits the hedgehog signalling pathway, which is indicated for the treatment of adult basal cell carcinoma. It binds to and inhibits the transmembrane protein Smoothened homologue (SMO) to inhibit the Hedgehog signalling pathway, thereby controlling the uncontrolled proliferation of skin basal cells. Vismodegib is used for treating locally advanced or metastatic basal cell carcinoma in patients whose carcinoma has recurred after surgery, and in patients who are not candidates for surgery or radiation. The drug has a half-life of 12 days after a single dose and 4 days after continuous daily dosing. Vismodegib is highly protein bound with plasma protein binding at about 99%, and it binds to the plasma proteins, albumin and alpha-1-acid glycoprotein (saturable bnding). The molecular weight of vismodegib is 421.29, and it has a topological polar surface area of 76.13. Vismodegib is part of Amides; Amines; Aniline Compounds; Antineoplastic Agents; Antineoplastic and Immunomodulating Agents; BCRP/ABCG2 Inhibitors; Cytochrome P-450 CYP2C19 Inhibitors; Cytochrome P-450 CYP2C8 Inhibitors; Cytochrome P-450 CYP3A4 Inhibitors. Vismodegib was approved by the FDA on January 30, 2012, and it is still under investigation for its potential uses in clinical settings.
Pitavastatin:
Pitavastatin is a lipid-lowering drug belonging to the statin class of medications. By inhibiting the endogenous production of cholesterol within the liver, statins lower abnormal cholesterol and lipid levels and ultimately reduce the risk of cardiovascular disease. Specifically, pitavastatin competitively inhibits the enzyme hydroxymethylglutaryl-coenzyme A (HMG-CoA) Reductase, which catalyzes the conversion of HMG-CoA to mevalonic acid. This is the third step in a sequence of metabolic reactions involved in the production of several compounds involved in lipid metabolism and transport including cholesterol, low-density lipoprotein (LDL) (sometimes referred to as "bad cholesterol"), and very low-density lipoprotein (VLDL). Prescribing of statin medications is considered standard practice following any cardiovascular events and for people with a moderate to high risk of development of CVD, such as those with Type 2 Diabetes. The clear evidence of the benefit of statin use coupled with very minimal side effects or long term effects has resulted in this class becoming one of the most widely prescribed medications in North America.

Pitavastatin is indicated for the treatment of adult patients with primary hyperlipidemia or mixed dyslipidemia to reduce elevated total cholesterol (TC), low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL-C), apolipoprotein B (Apo B), triglycerides (TG), and to increase high-density lipoprotein cholesterol (HDL-C). It is also indicated for the treatment of pediatric patients aged 8 years and older with heterozygous familial hypercholesterolemia (HeFH) to reduce elevated TC, LDL-C, and Apo B.

Pitavastatin acts primarily in the liver, where decreased hepatic cholesterol concentrations stimulate the upregulation of hepatic low density lipoprotein (LDL) receptors which increase hepatic uptake of LDL, thereby reducing circulating LDL-C levels. The drug is more than 99% protein bound in human plasma, mainly to albumin and alpha 1-acid glycoprotein.

The total cholesterol to HDL-C ratio is a strong predictor of coronary artery disease and high ratios are associated with higher risk of disease. Increased levels of HDL-C are associated with lower cardiovascular risk. By decreasing LDL-C and TG and increasing HDL-C, pitavastatin reduces the risk of cardiovascular morbidity and mortality.

Pitavastatin is a solid and has a mean plasma elimination half-life of approximately 12 hours. The molecular weight of pitavastatin is 421.47, and it has a topological polar surface area of 90.65. Pitavastatin is part of Agents Causing Muscle Toxicity; Anticholesteremic Agents; BCRP/ABCG2 Substrates; BSEP/ABCB11 Substrates; Cytochrome P-450 CYP2C8 Substrates; Cytochrome P-450 CYP2C9 Substrates; Cytochrome P-450 Substrates; Enzyme Inhibitors; Heterocyclic Compounds, Fused-Ring; Hydrox.
Rilpivirine: Rilpivirine is a non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NNRTI) used for the treatment of HIV-1 infections in treatment-naive patients. It is a diarylpyrimidine derivative, a class of molecules that resemble pyrimidine nucleotides found in DNA. The internal conformational flexibility and plasticity of rilpivirine's binding site give it a high potency and unlikely generation of resistance compared to other NNRTIs. Rilpivirine was developed by Tilobec, Inc. and FDA approved on May 20, 2011. On November 21, 2017, rilpivirine, in combination with dolutegravir, was approved as part of the first complete treatment regimen with only two drugs for the treatment of adults with HIV-1 named Juluca. Rilpivirine binds to the HIV-1 reverse transcriptase (RT) and its flexible structure around the aromatic rings allows adaptation to changes in the non-nucleoside RT binding pocket. Rilpivirine is highly protein-bound, with >99% of its dose bound to plasma proteins in a concentration-dependent manner, primarily albumin. Its slow plasma drug elimination gives it a half-life of 34-55 hours after oral administration. Rilpivirine's molecular weight is 366.43 and its topological polar surface area is 97.42. It also has a logP value of 5.45. Rilpivirine is part of Anti-HIV Agents; Anti-Infective Agents; Anti-Retroviral Agents; Antiinfectives for Systemic Use; Antiviral Agents; Antivirals for Systemic Use; BCRP/ABCG2 Inhibitors; Cytochrome P-450 CYP2B6 Inhibitors (strong); and Cytochrome P-450 CYP. Rilpivirine is approved for use in combination with other agents to treat HIV-1 infections in treatment-naive patients with HIV-1 RNA ≤100,000 copies/mL and CD4+ cell count >200 cells/mm3. The FDA combination therapy approval of rilpivirine and dolutegravir is indicated for adults with HIV-1 infections whose virus is currently suppressed (<50 copies/ml) on a stable regimen for at least six months, without history of treatment failure and no known substitutions associated to resistance to any of the two components of the therapy. Rilpivirine's mechanism of action, pharmacokinetics, and pharmacodynamics have been studied extensively in clinical trials, demonstrating its efficacy and safety profile as an antiretroviral treatment for HIV-1 infections.
Ulipristal: Ulipristal is a selective progesterone receptor modulator with both agonistic and antagonistic activity, depending on the target tissue. It is used for emergency contraception (as Ella in Canada and the US) and treatment of uterine fibroids (as Fibristal in Canada). Ulipristal binds to both progesterone and glucocorticoid receptors, with higher affinity for the former. Its mechanism of action is not fully understood but may involve inhibition of ovulation, delayed follicular rupture, and decreased endometrial thickness. Ulipristal has a mean elimination half-life of 32.4 ± 6.3 hours after a single oral dose in healthy subjects. It is metabolized by cytochrome P-450 enzymes, primarily CYP1A2 and CYP3A4. Ulipristal is part of several drug categories, including Adrenal Cortex Hormones, Contraceptive Agents, Female, and Cytochrome P-450 Substrates. It has been approved for use in various countries, including Canada and the US.
Vemurafenib:
Vemurafenib is a competitive kinase inhibitor with activity against BRAF kinase with mutations like V600E. It exerts its function by binding to the ATP-binding domain of the mutant BRAF, thereby inhibiting its activity and downstream signaling events that promote cell growth and proliferation. Vemurafenib was co-developed by Roche and Plexxikon and obtained its FDA approval in 2011 under the company Hoffmann La Roche. Since then, Roche has launched a broad development program to explore the drug's potential in various cancer types. Vemurafenib is particularly useful for treating melanoma with the BRAF V600E mutation, accounting for 54% of cutaneous melanoma cases. Clinical trials have shown that vemurafenib reduces all activation markers related to BRAF, including cytoplasmic phosphorylated ERK and cellular proliferation driven by Ki-67. Additionally, the drug has been found to decrease MAPK-related metabolic activity. Vemurafenib is an orally available inhibitor of mutated BRAF-serine-threonine kinase, with a molecular weight of 489.92 and a topological polar surface area of 91.92. Its elimination half-life is estimated to be 57 hours, and it is bound to plasma proteins where >99% of the administered dose will be found protein bound to serum albumin and alpha-1 acid glycoprotein. Vemurafenib belongs to various drug categories, including Amides; Antineoplastic Agents; Antineoplastic and Immunomodulating Agents; BCRP/ABCG2 Inhibitors; BCRP/ABCG2 Substrates; Cytochrome P-450 CYP1A2 Inhibitors (moderate); Cytochrome P-450 CYP2B6 Inducers; and Cytochrome P-450 CYP2B6 Inducer.

Vemurafenib is a significant improvement over traditional chemotherapy methods, offering targeted therapy with fewer side effects. Its mechanism of action is based on inhibiting the activity of mutated BRAF, which leads to downstream signaling events that promote cell growth and proliferation. By blocking these processes, vemurafenib can induce apoptosis and ultimately inhibit tumour growth. The drug's specificity for the V600E mutation makes it an effective treatment option for patients with this specific mutation, and its broad development program aims to expand its use to other cancer types as well.
Mirabegron: Mirabegron is a beta-3 adrenergic receptor agonist approved for the management of overactive bladder. It acts by activating beta-3 adrenergic receptors in the detrusor muscle of the bladder, leading to relaxation and increased bladder capacity. Mirabegron has a terminal elimination half-life of 50 hours and is bound to plasma proteins with moderate affinity. The clinical indication for mirabegron is the treatment of overactive bladder symptoms including urge urinary incontinence, urgency, and urinary frequency. Mirabegron has little effect on mean maximum flow rate or mean detrusor pressure at maximum flow rate, but it does increase blood pressure in a dose-dependent manner. The dose that demonstrates half-maximal efficacy is 25 mg, while the dose that demonstrates maximal efficacy is 100 mg. Mirabegron is part of Adrenergic Agents; Adrenergic Agonists; Adrenergic beta-3 Receptor Agonists; Adrenergic beta-Agonists; Agents producing tachycardia; Agents that produce hypertension; Amides; Amines; Anilides; Aniline Compounds; Cholinesterase substrates; Cytochrome P-450 CYP2D6 Inhibitors. Mirabegron was approved by the FDA on June 28, 2012.
Tofacitinib: Tofacitinib is an inhibitor of Janus kinases, a group of intracellular enzymes involved in signalling pathways that affect hematopoiesis and immune cell function. It is approved by the FDA for treatment of moderate to severe rheumatoid arthritis that responds inadequately to methotrexate or in those who are intolerant to methotrexate. The drug targets inflammation present in rheumatoid arthritis by inhibiting the janus kinases involved in the inflammatory response pathway, thereby reducing tissue inflammation and joint damage. Tofacitinib is a solid and has a half-life of approximately 3 hours. It is bound to albumin to a moderate extent, with a protein binding percentage of 40%. The drug belongs to the category of Antineoplastic and Immunomodulating Agents; Antirheumatic Agents; Biologics for Rheumatoid Arthritis Treatment; Bradycardia-Causing Agents; Cytochrome P-450 CYP2C19 Substrates; Cytochrome P-450 CYP3A Substrates; Cytochrome P-450 CYP3A4 Substrates; and Cytochrome P-450 Subst. Tofacitinib is investigational for the treatment of other inflammatory conditions, such as psoriasis and ulcerative colitis, and has shown promise in reducing symptoms and improving quality of life in patients with these conditions.
Enzalutamide: Enzalutamide is an orally active, non-steroidal, competitive androgen receptor inhibitor that is FDA approved for the treatment of metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer. It works by binding to the androgen receptor and preventing the binding of androgens, thereby inhibiting the activation of downstream signaling pathways that promote cell growth and proliferation in prostate cancer cells. Enzalutamide has a mean terminal half-life of 5.8 days in patients after a single oral dose, and its molecular weight is 464.44. It belongs to the categories of Androgen Receptor Antagonists; Antiandrogens, non-steroidal; Antineoplastic Agents; and Cytochrome P-450 CYP2B6 Inhibitors (strength unknown). Resistance to enzalutamide therapy has been observed in some cases, which may be due to upregulation of NF-κB2/p52. Enzalutamide is indicated for the treatment of patients with metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer who have previously received docetaxel. It is a solid and has a topological polar surface area of 76.44. N-desmethyl enzalutamide is 95% bound to plasma proteins. The approval status of enzalutamide is approved.
Riociguat:
Riociguat is a soluble guanylate cyclase (sGC) agonist approved for the treatment of pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) and chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension (CTEPH). It works by stimulating sGC, an enzyme in the cardiopulmonary system that is responsible for synthesizing cyclic guanosine monophosphate (cGMP), a molecule that plays a crucial role in regulating vascular tone, proliferation, fibrosis, and inflammation. Riociguat is marketed under the brand name Adempas® by Bayer HealthCare Pharmaceuticals. The drug is indicated for the treatment of adults with persistent/recurrent chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension (CTEPH) after surgical treatment, or inoperable CTEPH, to improve exercise capacity and WHO functional class. It is also approved for the treatment of patients with group I PAH (pulmonary arterial hypertension) in WHO FC II or III. The cost of treatment with riociguat is approximately USD $7,500 for 30 days of treatment.

Riociguat has a molecular weight of 422.42 and a topological polar surface area (TPSA) of 138.07. It is a solid and has a half-life of about 12 hours in patients and 7 hours in healthy subjects. Riociguat is part of several drug categories, including Antihypertensive Agents, Antihypertensives for Pulmonary Arterial Hypertension, BCRP/ABCG2 Substrates, Cytochrome P-450 CYP2C8 Substrates, Cytochrome P-450 CYP3A Substrates, Cytochrome P-450 CYP3A4 Substrates, and Cytochrome P-450 Substrates. It is also an enzyme activator and a guanylate cyclase activator. Riociguat has been approved for use in several regions, including the USA, Europe, and other countries.

Mechanistically, riociguat works by binding to soluble guanylate cyclase (sGC) and stimulating its activity, leading to increased cGMP production. This increases blood flow and oxygen delivery to the heart and lungs, improving exercise capacity and WHO functional class in patients with PAH or CTEPH. The drug is metabolized by several enzymes, including cytochrome P-450 enzymes, and its pharmacokinetics are influenced by several factors, including liver function, renal function, and age.

In clinical trials, riociguat has been shown to improve exercise capacity and WHO functional class in patients with PAH or CTEPH. It has also been shown to reduce pulmonary artery pressure and improve quality of life in these patient populations. The most common adverse events associated with riociguat include headache, dizziness, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. Riociguat is contraindicated in patients with hypersensitivity to the drug or any of its components, as well as those with severe hepatic impairment or severe renal impairment.

In summary, riociguat is a soluble guanylate cyclase agonist that works by stimulating sGC and increasing cGMP production, improving blood flow and oxygen delivery to the heart and lungs in patients with PAH or CTEPH. It has been approved for use in several regions and has shown to improve exercise capacity and WHO functional class in clinical trials. However, it can cause adverse events and is contraindicated in certain patient populations.
Macitentan:
Macitentan is an antagonist/blocker of endothelin receptors, specifically the ETA and ETB receptors found in blood vessels and smooth muscle. Endothelin receptors are involved in various physiological processes, including hypertrophy, inflammation, fibrosis, proliferation, and vasoconstriction. Macitentan binds to these receptors, preventing the agonist endothelin-1 (ET-1) from binding and stimulating the ETA and ETB receptors. This results in a decrease in the contraction of blood vessels, leading to improved cardiovascular function in patients with pulmonary arterial hypertension. Macitentan is marketed under the brand name Opsumit and was approved in October 2013 for the treatment of pulmonary arterial hypertension. It is associated with embryo and fetal toxicity, and therefore should not be used in pregnancy. Special precautions must be followed for all females of child-bearing age.

Macitentan has a molecular weight of 588.28 g/mol and a topological polar surface area (TPSA) of 128.22 square meters. It is a solid at room temperature and has a half-life of 16 hours, with its active metabolite having a half-life of 48 hours. Macitentan is bound to plasma proteins, primarily albumin, with a protein binding rate of >99%. Its logP value is 4.3, indicating that it has moderate water solubility. Macitentan belongs to the class of amides, specifically antihypertensive agents, and its mechanism of action involves blocking endothelin receptors. It is a substrate for cytochrome P-450 enzymes CYP2C19 and CYP3A, and its metabolism is primarily mediated by these enzymes.

Macitentan was approved in October 2013 based on results from clinical trials demonstrating its safety and efficacy in treating pulmonary arterial hypertension. It has been shown to improve 6-minute walk distance, right heart catheterization, and quality of life in patients with this condition. Macitentan is an important treatment option for patients with pulmonary arterial hypertension, as it can help alleviate symptoms and improve their overall health.
Ibrutinib:
Ibrutinib is a small molecule that acts as an irreversible potent inhibitor of Burton's tyrosine kinase, with promising activity in B cell malignancies. It was developed by Pharmacyclics Inc and was approved by the FDA in November 2013 for the treatment of mantle cell lymphoma, as well as later for the treatment of chronic lymphocytic leukemia and Waldenström's Macroglobulinemia. Additionally, it has been approved by the EMA for the treatment of chronic lymphocytic leukemia and mantle cell lymphoma. Ibrutinib was also approved for use in chronic graft versus host disease in August 2017. The drug presents an accelerated approval for the treatment of mantle cell lymphoma in patients who have received at least one prior therapy.

Ibrutinib's mechanism of action involves its inhibition of Bruton’s tyrosine kinase (BTK), which plays a role in B-cell receptor signaling. The inhibition of BTK prevents the phosphorylation of downstream substrates such as PLC-γ, leading to an induction of CLL cell apoptosis even in presence of prosurvival factors. In vitro studies have shown an induction of CLL cell apoptosis, as well as an inhibition of CLL cell survival and proliferation. The drug also reduces the secretion of chemokines such as CCL3 and CCL4, leading to regression in xenograft mouse models.

Ibrutinib is a solid at room temperature and has a molecular weight of 440.51. Its elimination half-life is approximately 4-6 hours, and it binds irreversibly to plasma proteins, with the majority bound to albumin and α1 AGP. The drug also has a topological polar surface area of 99.16 and a logP value of 4.07.

Ibrutinib is part of Antineoplastic Agents; Antineoplastic and Immunomodulating Agents; Cytochrome P-450 CYP2D6 Substrates; Cytochrome P-450 CYP3A Substrates; Cytochrome P-450 CYP3A4 Substrates; Cytochrome P-450 CYP3A5 Substrates; Cytochrome P-450 Substrates; Immunosuppressive Agents; and Kinase.

Overall, ibrutinib is a targeted covalent drug that has shown promising activity in B cell malignancies, particularly in the treatment of mantle cell lymphoma. Its mechanism of action involves the inhibition of Bruton’s tyrosine kinase, leading to an induction of CLL cell apoptosis and a reduction in the secretion of chemokines.
Palbociclib: Palbociclib is a piperazine pyridopyrimidine that acts in the cell cycle machinery, specifically inhibiting cyclin-dependent kinases 4 and 6 (CDK4/6), thereby disrupting the progression of the cell cycle and inducing cell cycle arrest. It is approved for use in combination with endocrine therapy for the treatment of HER2-negative and hormone receptor (HR)-positive breast cancer in adult patients with advanced or metastatic disease, as well as for patients with disease progression after prior endocrine therapy. Palbociclib binds to its target proteins with an IC50 value of 9-15 nmol/L and presents low to absent activity against other kinases. Its mechanism of action leads to the inhibition of cell growth and suppression of DNA replication in RB-proficient cancer cells, causing cell cycle arrest. The mean plasma elimination half-life of palbociclib is 29 hours, and it has a topological polar surface area of 103.35 and a logP value of 2.2. Palbociclib is part of the antineoplastic agents class, specifically antineoplastic and immunomodulating agents, BCRP/ABCG2 inhibitors, BCRP/ABCG2 substrates, cyclin-dependent kinases, antagonists & inhibitors, cytochrome P-450 CYP3A inhibitors, cytochrome P-450 CYP3A substrates, and cytochrome P-450 CYP3A4 inhibitors.
Nintedanib: Nintedanib is a small molecule kinase inhibitor used in the treatment of pulmonary fibrosis, systemic sclerosis-associated interstitial lung disease, and non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC). It was first approved for use in the United States in 2014. Within the spectrum of idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis treatment options, nintedanib is currently one of only two disease-modifying therapies available and indicated for the condition (the other being pirfenidone), and as such is used as a first-line treatment following diagnosis to slow down the progressive loss of lung function. As a chemotherapeutic agent for NSCLC, nintedanib, in combination with docetaxel, is reserved for patients who have tried and failed first-line chemotherapeutic options. Nintedanib is a small molecule, competitive, triple angiokinase inhibitor that targets multiple receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) and non-receptor tyrosine kinases (nRTKs). Many of these RTKs are implicated in lung fibrosis and tumour angiogenesis, so nintedanib is therefore used in the treatment of proliferative diseases such as idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis, non-small cell lung cancer, and systemic sclerosis-associated interstitial lung disease. The specific RTKs that nintedanib inhibits are platelet-derived growth factor (PDGFR) α and β, fibroblast growth factor receptor (FGFR) 1-3, vascular endothelial growth factor receptor (VEGFR) 1-3, and Fns-Like tyrosine kinase-3 (FLT3). Nintedanib binds to the ATP-binding pocket of these receptors and inhibits their activity, thereby blocking signalling cascades that result in the proliferation and migration of lung fibroblasts. Nintedanib also inhibits kinase signalling pathways in various cells within tumour tissues, including endothelial cells, pericytes, smooth muscle cells, and cells contributing to angiogenesis, culminating in an inhibition of cell proliferation and apoptosis of affected tumour cells. Plasma protein binding of nintedanib is high, with a bound fraction of 97.8%. Albumin is thought to be the major binding protein. Nintedanib is a solid and has a terminal elimination half-life of approximately 10-15 hours. In patients with idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis, the effective half-life of nintedanib has been estimated to be approximately 9.5 hours. The molecular weight of nintedanib is 539.64 and its topological polar surface area is 94.22. Nintedanib is part of Antifibrotic Agents, Antineoplastic Agents, Antineoplastic and Immunomodulating Agents, Cytochrome P-450 CYP3A Substrates, Cytochrome P-450 CYP3A4 Substrates, Cytochrome P-450 CYP3A4 Substrates (strength unknown), Cytochrome P-450 Substrates, Enzyme Inhibitors, and Heterocyclic Compounds. Nintedanib is approved for use in the United States.
Potassium alum: Potassium alum is a generally recognized as safe (GRAS) substance that is used in various products, including drugs, as a buffer, neutralizing or forming agent. It is an inorganic salt with the formula AlK(SO4)2, primarily produced in the dodecahydrate form. The main functions of potassium alum in drugs are as an astringent, antiseptic, or adjuvant agent. Its astringent action induces coagulation in superficial tissue layers until the formation of a crust, while its adjuvant properties enhance the immune response in the production of vaccines. Potassium alum is highly bound to plasma proteins, with 70-90% of the aluminum and salts being bound to high molecular weight proteins and 10-20% to albumin. The induction of coagulation cascade reduces swollen mucous membranes, inflammation of nasal, gastrointestinal, and urinary passages, and excessive secretions. The half-life of potassium alum when administered intravenously is 4.5 h. Potassium alum is approved for use in various products, including drugs.
Chlortetracycline:
Chlortetracycline is a tetracycline antibiotic that was first discovered in 1945 by Benjamin Minge Duggar at Lederle Laboratories. It is the product of an actinomycete strain cultured from a soil sample from Missouri, and the organism was named Streptomyces aureofaciens due to its gold-hued color. Chlortetracycline works by competing with tRNA for the A site of the bacterial ribosome, preventing the addition of more amino acids to the peptide chain and ultimately inhibiting growth and reproduction of the bacterial cell. It has a solid physical state, and its half-life is 5.6 hours. Chlortetracycline is bound to plasma proteins by 50-55%, and it has a topological polar surface area of 181.62 and a logP value of -0.06. Chlortetracycline is approved for use in the manufacturing of medicated animal feeds, and it belongs to several drug categories, including agents that produce neuromuscular block (indirect), alimentary tract and metabolism, anti-bacterial agents, anti-infective agents, antibiotics for topical use, and antiinfectives and antiseptics for local oral treatment.

Technetium Tc-99m oxidronate:
Technetium Tc-99m oxidronate is a radiopharmaceutical agent used for skeletal imaging, particularly in the diagnosis of areas that present altered osteogenesis. It is a powerful detection tool due to its ability to bind to calcium and generate a clear image of the bones. The drug is administered intravenously and has a half-life of 3.5 minutes for the rapid phase, 27 minutes for the intermediate phase, and 144 minutes for the slow phase. Technetium Tc-99m oxidronate is protein bound at around 20-30% after 2-3 hours of administration. The mechanism of bone uptake is unknown but is believed to involve chemisorption onto the surface of hydroxyapatite crystals of bone. Its use for bone examination should be performed 2 hours after initial injection with a recommended activity on the range of 370-740 MBq. Technetium Tc-99m oxidronate is approved by the FDA and has been used in clinical settings since its approval on February 18, 1981.

Mechanism of Action:
Technetium Tc-99m oxidronate is a radiopharmaceutical agent that is widely used for diagnostic purposes due to its versatile chemistry which allows it to produce an extensive variety of complexes with specific characteristics. These complexes are formed by the binding of 99mTc to metal atoms of an organic molecule, in this case, oxidronate, whose structure allows it to bind to calcium. When administered intravenously, technetium Tc-99m oxidronate is able to generate a clear image of the bones which allows the physician to diagnose any bone problem.

Clinical Indication: Technetium Tc-99m oxidronate is indicated in adult and pediatric patients for skeletal imaging in the diagnosis of areas that present altered osteogenesis, such as tumor metastasis in bone, osteomyelitis, fracture, stress fracture, avascular necrosis, osteoporosis, and prosthetic joint evaluation. Its most common clinical indication is the detection of a metastatic disease, which presents a 95% sensitivity and lesion detection can be done 6 months earlier than with X-ray studies.

Pharmacokinetics: Technetium Tc-99m oxidronate has a rapid phase of 3.5 minutes, an intermediate phase of 27 minutes, and a slow phase of 144 minutes. Its protein binding is around 20-30% after 2-3 hours of intravenous administration.

Physical State: Technetium Tc-99m oxidronate is a solid.

Half-life: The elimination of technetium Tc-99m oxidronate is marked by the presence of three different half-times which are: 1) rapid phase of 3.5 min, 2) intermediate phase of 27 min and 3) slow phase of 144 min.

Lorpiprazole: Lorpiprazole is a serotonin antagonist and reuptake inhibitor, classified as an antipsychotic and anxiolytic. It is a piperazinyl-triazole derivative with a molecular weight of 405.47 and a topological polar surface area of 37.19. Lorpiprazole has a logP value of 3.02, indicating it is moderately soluble in polar solvents. It is approved for the treatment of major depressive disorder and has been classified as a CYP2D6 substrate, CYP3A substrate, and CYP3A4 substrate. Lorpiprazole acts by antagonizing 5-HT2A and 5-HT2C serotonin receptors, as well as alpha1 and alpha2 adrenergic receptors, H1 histaminergic receptors, and at high doses, it inhibits the SERT serotonin transporter. Its protein binding is expected to be very high, corresponding to 89-99% of the administered dose. Lorpiprazole has a half-life ranging from 11-23 hours and is metabolized by CYP2D6 and CYP3A enzymes. It is used as an adjunctive therapy for symptom control in depressive disorders, as well as a monotherapy for the treatment of depressive syndromes. Lorpiprazole has a wide functional profile, including inhibition of serotonin receptors, prevention of serotonin reuptake, antagonism of adrenergic receptors, and histamine receptors. Its diverse effects allow it to have a large therapeutic spectrum, making it a useful drug for treating various mental health conditions.
Artinolol:
Artinolol is an alpha- and beta-receptor blocker developed in Japan. It is a thiopropanolamine with a tertiary butyl moiety, which has been studied for its potential as an antihypertensive therapy. The drug binds to the β1-, β2- and α1-adrenergic receptor sites with high affinity, resulting in a reduction in cardiac output via β-blockade and additional inhibition of the counter-regulatory increase in peripheral resistance mediated by the α-blockade. Artinolol has been shown to have vasorelaxant activity, which is thought to be related to its α1-blocking property. The drug presents a high binding affinity to serum proteins, with a ratio of the original dose of 95.3% in the form of the R-enantiomer and 84.5% of the S-enantiomer. Artinolol has been found to have a dose-dependent decrease in cardiac contractility and coronary blood flow, as well as an increase in total peripheral resistance. The drug has been shown to decrease blood pressure in clinical trials, with a reported half-life of 7.2 hours. Dexibuprofen:
Dexibuprofen is a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) that consists of the active S(+)-enantiomer of racemic ibuprofen. It has a slower dissolution rate in simulated gastric and enteric juices compared to racemic ibuprofen, resulting in improved oral bioavailability. Dexibuprofen is proposed to be more pharmacologically active and tolerable than ibuprofen due to its higher concentration of the active S enantiomer. The drug's mechanism of action involves the inhibition of prostanoid synthesis in inflammatory cells via COX-2, which is similar to other NSAIDs. Dexibuprofen has a topological polar surface area of 37.3 and a logP value of 3.68. It is part of the drug categories Acids, Carbocyclic; Agents causing hyperkalemia; Agents that produce hypertension; Anti-Inflammatory Agents; Anti-Inflammatory Agents, Non-Steroidal; Anti-Inflammatory Agents, Non-Steroidal (Non-Selective); and Antiinflammatory and Antirheumatic Products. The drug is approved for use in various clinical indications, including pain and inflammation, but its investigational status indicates that it is still being studied for potential uses beyond these.

In terms of pharmacokinetics, dexibuprofen has a half-life of 2.2-4.7 hours after oral administration of 300mg. The drug is a solid and has a molecular weight of 206.28. In terms of mechanisms of action, dexibuprofen works by inhibiting the COX-2 isoform of arachidonic acid COX, which is involved in the synthesis of prostanoids that cause inflammation. Overall, dexibuprofen is a promising drug that has shown potential in various clinical indications. Blonanserin:
Blonanserin is an atypical antipsychotic drug approved in Japan in 2008. It has improved tolerability compared to first-generation (typical) antipsychotics due to its lack of side effects such as extrapyramidal symptoms, excessive sedation, or hypotension. As a second-generation (atypical) antipsychotic, Blonanserin is significantly more efficacious in treating the negative symptoms of schizophrenia compared to first-generation antipsychotics. It binds to and inhibits dopamine receptors D2 and D3 as well as the serotonin receptor 5-HT2A with high affinity. Blonanserin has low affinity for other dopamine and serotonin receptors as well as muscarinic, adrenergic, and histamine receptors, reducing dopaminergic and serotonergic neurotransmission. This reduction in neurotransmission produces a reduction in positive and negative symptoms of schizophrenia, respectively. Blonanserin has a molecular weight of 367.51 and a topological polar surface area of 19.37. It has a logP value of 6.48. Aranidipine: Aranidipine is a novel dihydropyridine derivative that exhibits hypotensive activity through two active metabolites, M-1α and M-1β. It is a calcium antagonist with a molecular formula of methyl 2-oxopropyl 1,4-dihydro-2,6-dimethyl-4-(2-nitrophenyl)-3,5-pyridinedicarboxylate. Developed by Maruko Seiyaku and introduced by Taiho in Japan in 1997, aranidipine has been used for many years to treat angina pectoris and hypertension. Its high potential is thought to be related to the additional calcium antagonistic activity of its metabolites, with the mechanism of action involving the inhibition of voltage-dependent calcium channels and the capacity to vasodilate afferent and efferent arterioles. Aranidipine is a selective alpha2-adrenoreceptor antagonist that inhibits vasoconstrictive responses, with a binding ratio of plasma proteins ranging from 84-95%. Its physical state is a solid, and its elimination half-life is 1.1-1.2 hours for the parent compound and 2.7-3.5 hours for the M-1 metabolite. Aranidipine has a topological polar surface area of 124.84 and a logP value of 2.56. Currently, aranidipine is experimental and has not been approved for clinical use.
Lacidipine:
Lacidipine is a lipophilic dihydropyridine calcium antagonist with an intrinsically slow onset of activity, which does not lead to reflex tachycardia. It displays specificity in the vascular smooth muscle, where it acts as an antihypertensive agent to dilate peripheral arterioles and reduce blood pressure. Compared to other dihydropyridine calcium antagonists, lacidipine exhibits a greater antioxidant activity which may confer potentially beneficial antiatherosclerotic effects. The high membrane partition coefficient of lacidipine leads to accumulation of the drug in the membrane and slow rate of membrane washout. When visualized by small-angle X-ray diffraction with angstrom resolution, lacidipine was found deep within the hydrocarbon core of the membranes. These results may explain the long clinical half-life of lacidipine.

Lacidipine is indicated for the treatment of hypertension either alone or in combination with other antihypertensive agents, including β-adrenoceptor antagonists, diuretics, and ACE-inhibitors. Its mechanism of action involves blocking the voltage-dependent L-type calcium channels, preventing the transmembrane calcium influx and ultimately causing the excitation and depolarization of the tissues. Lacidipine is highly protein-bound to predominantly albumin and to a lesser extent, alpha-1-glycoprotein. Its pharmacodynamics are specific and potent, dilating predominantly peripheral and coronary arteries, reducing peripheral vascular resistance and lowering blood pressure.

Levamlodipine: Levamlodipine is a pharmacologically active enantiomer of amlodipine, an antihypertensive medication. Belonging to the dihydropyridine group of calcium channel blockers, levamlodipine blocks the transmembrane influx of calcium through L-type calcium channels into vascular and cardiac smooth muscles, resulting in vasodilation and decreased blood pressure. It is indicated alone or in combination to treat hypertension in adults and children, with a recommended dosage range of 1.25-5mg once daily. Methylene Blue:
Methylene blue is an oxidation-reduction agent that has been approved by the FDA for the treatment of pediatric and adult patients with acquired methemoglobinemia. Historically, it has also been investigated as an urinary tract antiseptic. The drug works by inhibiting nitric oxide synthase and guanylate cyclase, which are key enzymes involved in the production of nitric oxide, a potent vasodilator. Methylene blue binds strongly to rabbit plasma proteins, with 71-77% of the drug bound to the plasma. The half-life of methylene blue is approximately 5-6.5 hours after an intravenous dose. The molecular weight of methylene blue is 284.4 and it has a topological polar surface area (TPSA) of 19.37, indicating that it has a high affinity for membranes. Methylene blue is part of several drug categories, including agents that produce hypertension, reduce seizure threshold, antidepressants, antidotes, antipsychotics, central nervous system depressants, and cytochrome P-450 CYP1A2 inducers. However, its approval status is investigational, indicating that more research is needed to fully understand its efficacy and safety profile.

In clinical settings, methylene blue is primarily used to treat acquired methemoglobinemia, a condition in which the amount of methemoglobin in the blood exceeds the normal range. Methemoglobin is a form of hemoglobin that is unable to transport oxygen properly, leading to tissue hypoxia and potentially life-threatening consequences. The intravenous form of methylene blue is the most commonly used route of administration, as it allows for rapid absorption and onset of action. However, oral forms of the drug are also available for patients who cannot receive IV medication.

Mechanistically, methylene blue works by inhibiting nitric oxide synthase and guanylate cyclase, which are key enzymes involved in the production of nitric oxide. Nitric oxide is a potent vasodilator that can cause vasodilation and hypotension, particularly in patients with cardiovascular disease. By inhibiting these enzymes, methylene blue reduces the amount of nitric oxide produced in the body, which can help to normalize blood pressure and prevent hypotension-related complications. Additionally, methylene blue has been shown to have anticonvulsant properties, making it a potential treatment option for patients with epilepsy or other seizure disorders.

In conclusion, methylene blue is an important oxidation-reduction agent that has been approved for the treatment of acquired methemoglobinemia in pediatric and adult patients. Its mechanisms of action involve inhibition of nitric oxide synthase and guanylate cyclase, which can help to normalize blood pressure and prevent hypotension-related complications. Further research is needed to fully understand the efficacy and safety profile of methylene blue, particularly in terms of its potential as an anticonvulsant and antipsychotic agent.

Artesunate: Artesunate is an antimalarial drug that is widely used for the initial treatment of severe malaria. Developed as a more hydrophilic derivative of artemisinin, it has gained popularity due to its effectiveness in treating malaria caused by _Plasmodium_ parasites. The World Health Organization recommends artesunate as a first-line treatment for severe malaria, and it is known to have a short duration of action due to its short half-life. Artesunate works by generating free radicals that inhibit the normal functioning of the parasites, leading to their death. It has a moderate therapeutic index and can cause post-treatment hemolytic anemia and hypersensitivity reactions in some patients. Lumacaftor:
Lumacaftor is a drug used in combination with as the fixed dose combination product Orkambi for the management of Cystic Fibrosis (CF) in patients aged 6 years and older. Cystic Fibrosis is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by one of several different mutations in the gene for the Cystic Fibrosis Transmembrane Conductance Regulator (CFTR) protein, a transmembrane ion channel involved in the transport of chloride and sodium ions across cell membranes of the lungs, pancreas, and other organs. Mutations in the CFTR gene result in altered production, misfolding, or function of the CFTR protein and consequently abnormal fluid and ion transport across cell membranes. As a result, CF patients produce thick, sticky mucus that clogs the ducts of organs where it is produced making patients more susceptible to infections, lung damage, pancreatic insufficiency, and malnutrition. Lumacaftor improves CF symptoms and underlying disease pathology by aiding the conformational stability of F508del-mutated CFTR proteins, preventing misfolding and resulting in increased processing and trafficking of mature protein to the cell surface.

Lumacaftor acts as a protein-folding chaperone, preventing misfolding of CFTR ion channels and consequent destruction during processing in the endoplasmic reticulum. Results from clinical trials indicated that treatment with Orkambi (lumacaftor/ ) results in improved lung function, reduced chance of experiencing a pulmonary exacerbation, reduced sweat chloride, increased weight gain, and improvements in CF symptoms and quality of life. Lumacaftor is extensively protein bound in the plasma (99%), and binds primarily to albumin. The half-life of lumacaftor is approximately 26 hours, and its molecular weight is 452.41. Lumacaftor has a topological polar surface area of 97.75, and its logP value is 6.05.

Lumacaftor belongs to the categories of Amines; Cytochrome P-450 CYP2B6 Inducers; Cytochrome P-450 CYP2B6 Inducers (strength unknown); Cytochrome P-450 CYP2C19 Inducers; Cytochrome P-450 CYP2C19 Inducers (strength unknown); Cytochrome P-450 CYP2C8 Inducers; and Cytochrome P-450 CYP2C8 Inducers (strength unknown). Lumacaftor is approved for use in CF patients aged 6 years and older who are homozygous for the F508del mutation in the CFTR gene.

Iopodic acid: Iopodic acid is a cholecystographic agent that contains a tri-iodinated benzene ring with iodine at positions 2, 4, and 6. Its high degree of lipid solubility and radiopaque property make it an effective tool for visualizing the gallbladder and biliary channels in abdominal X-rays. Developed and filed to the FDA by BRACCO, this drug was approved on March 15, 1962, but has since been discontinued from the FDA and Health Canada due to its limited clinical indication and potential side effects. Although it was resubmitted to the FDA in 1981 by Schering AG, it remains under an inactive status. Iopodic acid blocks X-rays as they pass through the body, allowing for delineation of body structures that do not contain this compound. Its protein binding properties and thyroid effects have been studied extensively, with findings indicating that it can bind to serum albumin and inactivate the more potent form of thyroid hormone. However, its relapse after discontinuation and limited efficacy on some diseases have hindered its widespread use. Despite these limitations, iopodic acid remains a valuable tool in medical research and diagnostic applications.
Acetrizoic acid:
Acetrizoic acid is a water-soluble and relatively safe iodinated contrast agent that can be intravenously administered for clinical applications. It was first synthesized by Wallingford in 1953 and was approved by the FDA on February 8th, 1978 through the subsidiary of Johnson & Johnson, Cilag Chemie AG. However, its approval status has been withdrawn due to unknown reasons. The molecular formula of acetrizoic acid is C10H8I3 and it presents an inactive category of drug substance in the FDA records. Its mechanism of action involves the attenuation of X-rays within the diagnostic energy spectrum, which is caused by the high atomic density of iodine, a component of the drug. Less than 5% of the injected dose of acetrizoic acid is protein bound in plasma, indicating its low protein binding property. Acetrizoic acid is used as a contrast agent for X-ray imaging, and its nephrotropic property is one of its characteristics for utilization. The use of contrast agents provokes a contrast enhancement or opacification, which improves the differentiation of pathological processes from normal tissue. The molecular weight of acetrizoic acid is 556.86 and it has a topological polar surface area of 66.4. Its logP value is 1.91.

Overall, acetrizoic acid is a useful contrast agent for X-ray imaging, but its approval status has been withdrawn due to unknown reasons. Further research may be necessary to determine the cause of this withdrawal and to evaluate the safety and efficacy of this drug for clinical applications.
Propiolactone: Propiolactone is a lactone compound with a four-membered ring, consisting of a colorless liquid with a pungent slightly sweet odor. It is an indirect additive used in food contact substances and has been approved for its use as a sterilant of blood plasma, vaccines, tissue grafts, surgical instruments, and enzymes. Propiolactone has been shown to be highly bound to proteins and has mutagenic properties, inducing cell transformation, chromosomal aberrations, and chromatoid exchange in both somatic and germ cells.
