Its approval status is approved, indicating that it is available for medical use.

Cholic acid's mechanisms of action involve its ability to stimulate the secretion of bile from the liver, which aids in fat absorption and cholesterol excretion. In patients with bile acid synthesis disorders, oral cholic acid can supplement the body's natural production of bile acids, restoring balance to the digestive system. Additionally, its use in peroxisomal disorders such as Zellweger spectrum disorders helps to improve liver function and reduce complications associated with decreased fat-soluble vitamin absorption. Overall, cholic acid is an important therapeutic agent for managing various digestive disorders and ensuring proper nutrient absorption and liver function.
Nitazoxanide: Nitazoxanide is a broad-spectrum anti-infective drug that modulates the survival, growth, and proliferation of various extracellular and intracellular protozoa, helminths, anaerobic and microaerophilic bacteria, as well as viruses. This drug is effective in the treatment of gastrointestinal infections caused by Cryptosporidium parvum or Giardia lamblia in healthy subjects and may also be considered in the treatment of infections caused by other protozoa or helminths. Recently, Nitazoxanide has been studied as a broad-spectrum antiviral agent due to its ability to inhibit the replication of several RNA and DNA viruses. The mechanism of action of Nitazoxanide is believed to be the disruption of the energy metabolism in anaerobic microbes by inhibition of the pyruvate: ferredoxin/flavodoxin oxidoreductase (PFOR) cycle. It also induces lesions in the cell membranes and depolarizes the mitochondrial membrane while inhibiting quinone oxidoreductase NQO1, nitroreductase-1 and protein disulphide isomerase enzymes. Additionally, it inhibits the glutathione-S-transferase (a major detoxifying enzyme) and modulates the Avr-14 gene, encoding for the alpha-type subunit of glutamate-gated chloride ion channel present in nematodes. Nitazoxanide also demonstrates various other antibacterial mechanisms, including inhibition of pyruvate dehydrogenase in E. coli, disruption of the membrane potential and pH homeostasis in Mycobacterium tuberculosis, suppression of the chaperone/usher (CU) pathway of gram-negative bacteria, and activation of host macrophage autophagy in tuberculosis patients. Furthermore, it suppresses viral replication by inhibiting the maturation of the viral hemagglutinin and the viral transcription factor immediate early 2 (IE2) as well as by activating the eukaryotic translation initiation factor 2α. Lastly, Nitazoxanide exhibits an inhibitory effect on tumor cell progression by altering drug detoxification (glutathione-S-transferase P1), unfolded protein response, autophagy, anti-cytokines activity, and c-Myc inhibition. The protein binding of Nitazoxanide is very high (greater than 99%), bound to proteins in the plasma. The general effect of this medication is the prevention of microbe activity through disruption of important energy pathways for survival and proliferation. The half-life of Nitazoxanide is 7.3h, and its molecular weight is 307.28. Its topological polar surface area is 114.11, and its logP value is 1.24. Nitazoxanide is part of Anti-Infective Agents; Antiparasitic Agents; Antiparasitic Products, Insecticides, and Repellents; Antiprotozoals; Sulfur Compounds. It is approved and investigational and veterinary approved.
Remoxipride:
Remoxipride is an atypical antipsychotic agent that selectively binds to dopamine D2 receptors. It was once used for the treatment of schizophrenia, but was withdrawn due to its association with an increased incidence of aplastic anemia. Remoxipride displays weaker binding to D2 dopaminergic receptors compared to dopamine, which may account for its reduced incidence of Parkinsonism. Additionally, it increases expression of the protein Fos in the nucleus accumbens but not the dorsolateral striatum, which may contribute to a reduced incidence of extrapyramidal symptoms. Remoxipride has a moderate therapeutic index and duration of action, and its molecular weight is 371.28. It is part of Acids, Carbocyclic; Amides; Antipsychotic Agents; Benzamides and benzamide derivatives; Benzene Derivatives; Benzoates; Bromobenzoates; Central Nervous System Agents; Central Nervous System Depressants; Cytochrome P-450 CYP1A2 Inhibitors; Cytochrome P-450 CYP1A2 Inhibitors. Its topological polar surface area is 50.8, and its logP value is 3.25. Remoxipride is approximately 80% protein bound, mainly to α-1-acid glycoprotein. The half-life of remoxipride in patients with normal creatinine clearance is 5.1 ± 1.6 h, in patients with moderate renal impairment is 6.1 ± 2.6 h, and in patients with severe renal impairment is 9.9 ± 3.8 h.

Mechanism of Action: Remoxipride is an atypical antipsychotic dopamine D2 antagonist. Chronic use upregulates the expression of D2 receptors, while downregulating the expression of D1 and D5 receptors in the prefrontal cortex. This activity may be related to the antipsychotic activity of remoxipride. Remoxipride also increases expression of the protein Fos in the nucleus accumbens but not the dorsolateral striatum, which may contribute to a reduced incidence of extrapyramidal symptoms.

PROTEIN BINDING: Remoxipride is approximately 80% protein bound, mainly to α-1-acid glycoprotein.

PHARMACODYNAMICS: Remoxipride is a weak selective dopamine D2 receptor antagonist that was once used in the treatment of schizophrenia. It has a moderate therapeutic index and duration of action.

PHYSICAL STATE: Remoxipride is a solid.

HALF-LIFE: The half-life of remoxipride in patients with normal creatinine clearance is 5.1 ± 1.6 h, in patients with moderate renal impairment is 6.1 ± 2.6 h, and in patients with severe renal impairment is 9.9 ± 3.8 h.

MOLECULAR PROPERTIES: Molecular Weight: The molecular weight is 371.28., TPSA: Remoxipride has a topological polar surface area of 50.8., cLogP: The log p value of remoxipride is 3.25.

DRUG CATEGORIES: Remoxipride is part of Acids, Carbocyclic; Amides; Antipsychotic Agents; Benzamides and benzamide derivatives; Benzene Derivatives; Benzoates; Bromobenzoates; Central Nervous System Agents; Central Nervous System Depressants; Cytochrome P-450 CYP1A2 Inhibitors; Cytochrome P-450 CYP1A2 Inhibitors.

APPROVAL STATUS: Remoxipride is approved and withdrawn.
Cocaine:
Cocaine is a locally acting anesthetic and vasoconstrictor derived from the leaves of the coca plant. It has both central nervous system (CNS) and cardiovascular effects, making it a drug of abuse. The mechanism of its reinforcing effects involves inhibition of dopamine uptake, while its anesthetic properties are due to its ability to bind to sodium channels and prevent nerve impulse propagation. Clinically, cocaine is used topically for the introduction of local anesthesia in the oral, laryngeal, and nasal cavities. However, its illegal status limits its medical use.

Pharmacologically, cocaine acts by multiple mechanisms on brain catecholaminergic neurons, including inhibition of dopamine uptake and direct prevention of norepinephrine, serotonin, and dopamine re-uptake into pre-synaptic neurons. Its effect on dopamine levels is most responsible for its addictive property. Cocaine has a solid physical state, with a half-life of 1 hour, and a molecular weight of 303.36. Its topological polar surface area is 55.84, and its logP value is 2.57.

Cocaine belongs to several drug categories, including Agents producing tachycardia, Agents that reduce seizure threshold, Alkaloids, Analgesics and Anesthetics, Anesthetics, Local anesthetics, Anticholinergic Agents, Aza Compounds, Azabicyclo Compounds, Cardiovascular Agents, Central Nervous System Agents, and Central Nervous System Stimulants. Despite its approved medical use, cocaine is illegal in many countries due to its potential for abuse and the serious health consequences associated with its use.
Nadolol:
Nadolol is a nonselective beta adrenal receptor blocker that is used to lower blood pressure. It works by blocking the beta-1 and beta-2 adrenergic receptors in various tissues, including the heart, blood vessels, and kidneys. This results in a decrease in the strength and speed of heart contractions, a decrease in peripheral vascular resistance, and an increase in renin release. Nadolol is indicated to treat angina pectoris and hypertension, and its long duration of action allows for once-daily dosing. However, it may lead to exacerbation of ischemic heart disease if abruptly stopped. The protein binding of nadolol is approximately 30%, and it binds to alpha-1-acid glycoprotein in plasma. Nadolol has a wide therapeutic index, allowing for doses as high as 240mg daily. Its molecular weight is 309.41, and its topological polar surface area is 81.95. Nadolol is part of Adrenergic Agents; Adrenergic Antagonists; Adrenergic beta-Antagonists; Agents causing hyperkalemia; Alcohols; Amines; Amino Alcohols; Antiarrhythmic agents; Antihypertensive Agents; Antihypertensive Agents Indicated for Hypertension; Autonomic Agents; Beta Blocking Age. Nadolol is approved for use in various countries, including the United States.

Nadolol works by blocking the beta-1 and beta-2 adrenergic receptors, which are found in various tissues throughout the body. These receptors play a crucial role in regulating heart rate, blood pressure, and other physiological processes. By blocking these receptors, nadolol reduces the strength and speed of heart contractions, decreases peripheral vascular resistance, and increases renin release. This results in a decrease in systemic vascular resistance, blood pressure, and heart rate.

The mechanisms of action of nadolol are complex and involve multiple pathways. It blocks the beta-1 adrenergic receptors in the heart, which inhibits cyclic AMP formation and reduces the strength and speed of contractions. Nadolol also blocks the beta-2 adrenergic receptors in smooth muscle cells, which leads to an increase in peripheral vascular resistance and a decrease in insulin sensitivity. Additionally, nadolol blocks the beta-1 adrenergic receptors in the juxtaglomerular apparatus of the kidney, which inhibits the release of renin, angiotensin II mediated vasoconstriction, aldosterone mediated water retention, and the release of epinephrine.

The pharmacokinetics of nadolol are characterized by a long duration of action due to its once-daily dosing. The protein binding of nadolol is approximately 30%, which may affect its efficacy and side effects. The molecular weight of nadolol is 309.41, and its topological polar surface area is 81.95, which may influence its solubility and bioavailability. Nadolol belongs to several drug categories, including Adrenergic Agents; Adrenergic Antagonists; Adrenergic beta-Antagonists; Agents causing hyperkalemia; Alcohols; Amines; Amino Alcohols; Antiarrhythmic agents; Antihypertensive Agents; Antihypertensive Agents Indicated for Hypertension; Autonomic Agents; Beta Blocking Age.

In conclusion, nadolol is a nonselective beta adrenal receptor blocker that is used to lower blood pressure. Its mechanisms of action involve blocking the beta-1 and beta-2 adrenergic receptors in various tissues, leading to decreased heart rate, blood pressure, and peripheral vascular resistance. Nadolol has a wide therapeutic index, allowing for once-daily dosing, but may lead to exacerbation of ischemic heart disease if abruptly stopped. Its protein binding, molecular weight, and topological polar surface area may influence its efficacy and side effects.
Solifenacin:
Solifenacin is a competitive muscarinic receptor antagonist that is indicated to treat an overactive bladder with urinary incontinence, urgency, and frequency. It has a long duration of action as it is usually taken once daily. Solifenacin works by blocking the M2 and M3 muscarinic receptors in the bladder, which leads to relaxation of the detrusor muscle and reduction of symptoms. The drug is protein bound in plasma, mainly to alpha-1-acid glycoprotein, with a half-life ranging from 33-85 hours. Solifenacin is part of several drug categories, including Agents producing tachycardia, Anticholinergic Agents, and Cytochrome P-450 CYP2D6 Substrates. The drug has been approved for medical use and is available in various formulations, including tablets and oral suspensions.

Solifenacin's mechanism of action involves the blocking of muscarinic receptors in the bladder. Solifenacin has the highest affinity for M3, M1, and M2 muscarinic receptors, with 80% of the muscarinic receptors in the bladder being M2, while 20% are M3. By blocking these receptors, solifenacin can relax the detrusor muscle and reduce symptoms of an overactive bladder. Additionally, solifenacin may also have a direct effect on smooth muscle in the bladder, leading to further reduction of symptoms.

Solifenacin has several potential side effects, including angioedema and anaphylaxis. Patients taking solifenacin should be aware of these risks and seek medical attention if they experience any signs or symptoms of an allergic reaction. Solifenacin can also interact with other medications, such as cytochrome P-450 substrates, which may lead to altered drug efficacy or adverse effects. Therefore, it is important for healthcare providers to carefully evaluate patients before prescribing solifenacin and to monitor them closely during treatment.

In conclusion, solifenacin is a competitive muscarinic receptor antagonist that is used to treat an overactive bladder with urinary incontinence, urgency, and frequency. Its mechanism of action involves blocking muscarinic receptors in the bladder, leading to relaxation of the detrusor muscle and reduction of symptoms. However, the drug can have potential side effects and interact with other medications, highlighting the importance of careful evaluation and monitoring during treatment.
L-glutamine: L-glutamine is a non-essential amino acid that plays a crucial role in various physiological processes, including nutritional supplementation and treating dietary shortage or imbalance. It is synthesized from glutamic acid and ammonia and is the primary carrier of nitrogen in the body. Supplemental L-glutamine has been approved by the FDA for use in sickle cell disease, under the tradename Endari by Emmaus Medical. The mechanism of action of supplemental L-glutamine involves its immunomodulatory role, which may occur through several pathways, including protecting the integrity of the gastrointestinal tract, inhibiting translocation of Gram-negative bacteria from the large intestine, maintaining secretory IgA, supporting proliferation of mitogen-stimulated lymphocytes, and enhancing phagocytosis by neutrophils and monocytes. L-glutamine is also important in nitrogen metabolism, as it is the enzyme that converts glutamic acid to glutamine, which can then be used as a nitrogen donor in the biosynthesis of many compounds. The physical state of L-glutamine is a solid, and its half-life of elimination is 1 hour. Its molecular weight is 146.15, and it has a topological polar surface area of 106.41. L-glutamine is part of Alimentary Tract and Metabolism; Amino Acids; Amino Acids and Derivatives; Amino Acids, Basic; Amino Acids, Diamino; Amino Acids, Neutral; Amino Acids, Peptides, and Proteins; Dietary Supplements; Glutamine; Supplements.
Ammonia:
Ammonia is a naturally occurring compound with the chemical formula NH3 and structure of trigonal pyramidal geometry. It is a colorless gas with a pungent smell, and when in water, it becomes NH4, or ammonium ion. Although ammonia is used as a food additive in anhydrous form and serves as a starting material in pharmaceutical and commercial products, it is caustic and hazardous when concentrated. Ammonia gas has been used in the clinical setting as a respiratory stimulant to prevent fainting, and the radiolabelled form of ammonia, ammonia N13, is intravenously administered as a radioactive diagnostic agent for Positron Emission Tomography (PET) imaging of the myocardium to evaluate myocardial perfusion. Ammonia is also naturally present in all tissues, where it is mostly taken up by glutamic acid and takes part in transamination and other reactions, including the synthesis of protein by the Krebs-Hanseleit cycle in the liver. The human adult produces approximately 1000 mmol of ammonia daily, most of which undergoes excretion in the urine.

Ammonia is a respiratory stimulant that works by increasing the rate and depth of breathing, which helps to prevent fainting. Its renal metabolism plays a crucial role in regulating acid-base balance by generating bicarbonate ions and promoting renal net acid excretion, both under basal conditions and in response to acid-base disturbances. Acute ammonia exposure can activate NMDA receptor signaling pathways, leading to changes in astrocyte morphology, expression of key astrocyte proteins, and increased concentrations of neuroactive L-tryptophan metabolites.

In the clinical setting, ammonia is used as a smelling salt to treat or prevent fainting. Its mechanism of action involves its renal excretion and metabolism, which regulates acid-base balance by generating bicarbonate ions and promoting renal net acid excretion. Ammonia is also naturally present in all tissues, where it plays a crucial role in various physiological processes, including protein synthesis and neurotransmission.

Ammonia is a naturally occurring compound that has a wide range of applications in various fields, including medicine, pharmaceuticals, and industrial processes. Its unique properties make it an essential component in many products and treatments, and its natural presence in the body ensures that it plays a crucial role in maintaining acid-base balance and other physiological functions.
NADH: NADH is a coenzyme composed of ribosylnicotinamide 5'-diphosphate coupled to adenosine 5'-phosphate by pyrophosphate linkage. It is found widely in nature and is involved in numerous enzymatic reactions in which it serves as an electron carrier by being alternately oxidized (NAD+) and reduced (NADH). NADH supplementation has been studied for its potential therapeutic benefits, including combating simple fatigue, chronic fatigue syndrome, fibromyalgia, Alzheimer's disease, Parkinson's disease, and improving mental function in these conditions. However, the effectiveness and safety of using NADH supplements have not been thoroughly studied or established. As a solid, NADH can be taken orally as a dietary supplement. It is part of various drug categories, including Adenine Nucleotides, Carbohydrates, Coenzymes, Dietary Supplements, Enzymes and Coenzymes, Glycosides, Heterocyclic Compounds, Fused-Ring, Nucleic Acids, Nucleotides, and Nucleosides, Nucleotides, Purine Nucleotides, Purines, Ribonucleotides, and Supplements. Although approved as a nutraceutical, the mechanisms of action and potential side effects of NADH supplementation are not fully understood.
Ethanol: Ethanol is a clear, colorless liquid rapidly absorbed from the gastrointestinal tract and distributed throughout the body. It has bactericidal activity and is used often as a topical disinfectant. It is widely used as a solvent and preservative in pharmaceutical preparations as well as serving as the primary ingredient in alcoholic beverages. Ethanol affects the brain's neurons in several ways, altering their membranes, ion channels, enzymes, and receptors. When injected near nerve tissues, it produces neuritis and nerve degeneration (neurolysis). Ninety to 98% of ethanol that enters the body is completely oxidized. Ethanol also binds to GABA, glycine, NMDA receptors, and modulates their effects. It is metabolized by hepatic enzyme alcohol dehydrogenase. As a central nervous system agent, ethanol can cause sedation, confusion, and disorientation. In therapeutic doses, it can provide relief for intractable chronic pain in patients with inoperable cancer or trigeminal neuralgia (tic douloureux). However, excessive consumption can lead to addiction, liver damage, and other adverse effects. Ethanol has a molecular weight of 46.07, topological polar surface area of 20.23, and logP value of -0.24. It is classified as an agent causing muscle toxicity, alcohol, anti-infective agents, local, antidotes, antiseptics and disinfectants, central nervous system agents, central nervous system depressants, compounds used in a research, industrial, or household setting, and cyto. Ethanol is approved for use in various medical applications.
Isosorbide mononitrate: Isosorbide mononitrate is an organic nitrate with vasodilating properties, primarily used as an anti-anginal agent to prevent and manage angina pectoris due to coronary artery disease. It works by relaxing both arteries and veins, but predominantly veins, to reduce cardiac preload. The active metabolite, , is responsible for the therapeutic action of isosorbide mononitrate. Unlike other organic nitrates, isosorbide mononitrate has a longer duration of action due to its slow onset of absorption and metabolism. Isosorbide mononitrate binds to plasma proteins by about 5%. The pharmacological action of isosorbide mononitrate is mediated by the release of nitric oxide, which activates soluble guanylyl cyclase in vascular endothelial cells, leading to increased cGMP levels and the relaxation of smooth muscle cells. Isosorbide mononitrate has a molecular weight of 191.14, topological polar surface area of 93.74, and logP value of -2.51. It is part of various drug categories, including Alcohols, Antianginal Agents, Carbohydrates, Cardiac Therapy, Cardiovascular Agents, Cytochrome P-450 CYP3A Substrates, Cytochrome P-450 Substrates, Delayed-Action Preparations, Drugs that are Mainly Renally Excreted, Hypotensive Agents, and Methemoglobinemia. Isosorbide mononitrate is approved for use in the prevention and management of angina pectoris due to coronary artery disease.
Polyethylene glycol 400 (PEG-400):
Polyethylene glycols (PEGs) are a diverse group of compounds used in various applications, including cosmetics and pharmaceuticals. PEG-400 is a hydrophilic liquid with a molecular weight of 400, making it an ideal enhancer of penetration in topical dermatological preparations. Its nonionic nature allows it to be used as a surfactant, emulsifier, cleansing agent, humectant, and skin conditioner in cosmetic products. In the eye, PEG-400 provides temporary relief of burning and irritation due to dryness, and prevents further injury by protecting the eye from irritants. Its ability to spread easily over the ocular surface reduces blurring, making it an ideal choice for comfortable eye drop or natural tear instillation.

PEG-400 has a half-life of greater than 24 hours, indicating that it is metabolized slowly and excreted renally. Its approval status is approved, indicating its safety and efficacy in clinical settings. As a polyethylene glycol, PEG-400 belongs to several drug categories, including alcohols, polymers, and p-glycoprotein inhibitors. Its mechanism of action on the eye tissues involves various mechanisms, including protein binding, pharmacodynamics, and physical state. Despite a lack of quantitative evidence regarding interactions between proteins and PEG, studies suggest that large numbers of PEG molecules can associate with protein molecules.

In conclusion, PEG-400 is a versatile and effective compound used in various applications, including cosmetics and pharmaceuticals. Its hydrophilic nature makes it an ideal enhancer of penetration, and its ability to provide temporary relief of dry eye symptoms and protect the eye from injury makes it a valuable tool in ophthalmology.
Ozanimod: Ozanimod is a once-daily sphingosine 1-phosphate receptor modulator for the treatment of relapsing Multiple Sclerosis (MS) and inflammatory bowel disease. Developed by Celgene (now acquired by Bristol-Myers Squibb), it was approved by the FDA on March 26, 2020. Ozanimod is indicated for adults in the treatment of relapsing forms of MS, which may include relapsing-remitting disease, clinically isolated syndrome, and active secondary progressive MS. The drug works by reducing circulating lymphocytes that cause neuroinflammation associated with MS, thereby reducing debilitating symptoms and potentially slowing disease progression. During clinical trials, ozanimod reduced MS-associated brain volume loss in several regions. Additionally, it causes the sequestration of peripheral lymphocytes in the gastrointestinal tract, reducing circulating lymphocytes in this area. Ozanimod binds to various G-protein-coupled receptor subtypes, including S1P1R, S1P2R, S1P3R, and S1P4R, which are expressed ubiquitously throughout the body, playing important roles in regulating inflammation. The plasma protein binding of ozanimod and its metabolites exceeds 98%, and the half-life ranges from 17-21 hours. Ozanimod is part of Antineoplastic and Immunomodulating Agents, BCRP/ABCG2 Substrates, Cytochrome P-450 CYP2C8 Substrates, Cytochrome P-450 CYP3A Substrates, Cytochrome P-450 CYP3A4 Substrates, Cytochrome P-450 Substrates, Immunosuppressive Agents, Indenes, Oxazoles, and P-glycoprotein substrates.
Glycine: Glycine is a non-essential amino acid that plays a crucial role in various physiological processes, including neurotransmission and immune function. It is found primarily in gelatin and silk fibroin and is used therapeutically as a nutrient. Additionally, glycine has been identified as a fast inhibitory neurotransmitter with potential antispastic activity. Early findings suggest that supplemental glycine may have antipsychotic, antioxidant, and anti-inflammatory activities. The mechanism of action of glycine involves binding to strychnine-sensitive glycine binding sites in the central nervous system (CNS), which leads to increased chloride conductance and enhanced inhibitory neurotransmission. This has led researchers to investigate the potential use of glycine in the management of neuroleptic-resistant negative symptoms in schizophrenia. Animal studies have also shown that supplemental glycine protects against endotoxin-induced lethality, hypoxia-reperfusion injury after liver transplantation, and D-galactosamine-mediated liver injury. Neutrophils, which contain a glycine-gated chloride channel, are thought to participate in these pathologic processes via invasion of tissue and releasing reactive oxygen species such as superoxide. Early-stage research suggests that supplementary glycine may be useful in processes where neutrophil infiltration contributes to toxicity, such as acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). Pharmacokinetically, glycine is a solid with a molecular weight of 75.07 and a topological polar surface area of 63.32. Its logP value is -3.21. Glycine is part of several drug categories, including Amino Acids, Peptides, and Proteins; Blood and Blood Forming Organs; Blood Substitutes and Perfusion Solutions; Dietary Supplements; Glycine Agents; Irrigating Solutions; Neurotransmitter Agents; and Supplements. The FDA has approved glycine for nutraceutical and veterinary use.
Magnesium gluconate: Magnesium gluconate is a mineral supplement that demonstrates the highest oral bioavailability of magnesium salts. It is used to prevent and treat low levels of magnesium, which are ubiquitous in the human body and play a crucial role in various physiological processes such as cellular function, nerve function, muscle function, bone health, and heart function. Magnesium gluconate replaces deficient circulating levels of magnesium and is used to treat conditions such as chronic magnesium deficiency caused by diuretics, poor diet, alcoholism, or other medical conditions. It has a protein binding percentage of approximately 25-30% and its mechanism of action involves replacing deficient circulating levels of magnesium. Magnesium gluconate is part of the Acids, Acyclic category and is approved and investigational for use in various clinical indications.
FEIBA (Anti-inhibitor coagulant complex): FEIBA is a sterile, lyophilized powder containing several clotting factors involved in the prothrombinase complex. It is used to control bleeding in hemophilia A and B patients with inhibitors. The product contains factor VIIa, factor VIII, factor IX, and factor IXa, which work together to promote thrombosis by activating the clotting cascade. Factor VIIa forms a complex with tissue factor and calcium, converting endogenous and FEIBA contained factor X to Xa. Endogenous and FEIBA contained factor Xa then act as part of the prothrombinase complex to convert endogenous and FEIBA contained prothrombin to thrombin. Additionally, factor IX and IXa are part of the tenase complex, converting factor X to Xa. Thrombin activates factor V, VII, and VIII as part of the amplification phase of the clotting cascade. These events promote the formation of blood clots to prevent or stop bleeding. The product has a plasma half-life of approximately 30 minutes for included clotting factors. FEIBA is approved and investigational for use in controlling bleeding episodes, perioperative management, and routine prophylaxis against bleeding episodes in hemophilia A and B patients with inhibitors.
Albutrepenonacog alfa: Albutrepenonacog alfa is a recombinant fusion protein that combines a recombinant coagulation factor IX (rFIX) with a recombinant human albumin (rAlbumin). Developed by CSL Behring Canada, Inc., it was approved by Health Canada in April 2017 and by FDA and EMA in 2016. The drug is available in various formulations, including 250, 500, 1000, and 2000 IU/vial. Indicated for the treatment of hemophilia B under the EMA and FDA, as well as for preventing or reducing bleeding episodes in Canada, rIX-RFP shows improved pharmacokinetics compared to traditional replacement therapies. Clinical trials have demonstrated its efficacy in lowering annualized spontaneous, total, and joint bleeding rates, as well as maintaining hemostasis in the perioperative setting without the development of inhibitors. With a reported half-life of 92 hours, rIX-RFP is part of the plasma proteins and is eliminated renally. As a recombinant protein, it belongs to various categories such as Albumins, Amino Acids, Peptides, and Proteins, Biological Factors, Blood Coagulation Factors, Blood Proteins, Drugs that are Mainly Renally Excreted, Enzyme Precursors, Enzymes and Coenzymes, Hemostatics, Proteins, Recombinant Proteins. Its long half-life and lack of immune interactions make it a valuable treatment option for hemophilia B patients.
Desmopressin: Desmopressin is an antidiuretic peptide drug that is a synthetic analogue of 8-arginine vasopressin (ADH). It is used to treat nocturia due to nocturnal polyuria in adults who awaken at least 2 times per night to void. Desmopressin works by binding to V2 receptors in the basolateral membrane of the cells of the distal tubule and collecting ducts of the nephron, stimulating adenylyl cyclase and increasing the rate of insertion of water channels, called aquaporins, into the lumenal membrane, leading to enhanced permeability and increased water reabsorption. Desmopressin has a median terminal half-life of 2.8 hours after intranasal administration, with significant variations in patients with severe renal impairment. The drug is highly protein bound, with a fraction of plasma protein binding of 17.3 ± 1.5%. Desmopressin is part of various drug categories, including Agents that produce hypertension, Amino Acids, Peptides, and Proteins, Antidiuretic Agents, Arginine Vasopressin, Cardiovascular Agents, Coagulants, Drugs that are Mainly Renally Excreted, Factor VIII Activator, Hematologic Agents, Hemostatics, Hormones, and Hormones. It has been approved for clinical use.
Eletriptan: Eletriptan is a second-generation triptan drug developed by Pfizer Inc for the treatment of migraine headaches. It binds with high affinity to 5-HT1B, 5-HT1D and 5-HT1F receptors, has modest affinity for 5-HT1A, 5-HT1E, 5-HT2B and 5-HT7 receptors, and little or no affinity for 5-HT2A, 5-HT2C, 5-HT3, 5-HT4, 5-HT5A and 5-HT6 receptors. In contrast, eletriptan displays insignificant pharmacological activity at adrenergic alpha1, alpha2, or beta; dopaminergic D1 or D2; muscarinic; or opioid receptors. The full mechanism of action of 5-HT receptor agonists in relieving migraines is not fully elucidated, but it is proposed that the activation of 5-HT1 receptors located on intracranial blood vessels leads to vasoconstriction that correlates with the relief of migraine headaches. Additionally, the activation of 5-HT1 receptors on sensory nerve endings in the trigeminal system leads to the inhibition of release of pro-inflammatory neuropeptides. Eletriptan has been shown to reduce carotid arterial blood flow and decrease coronary artery diameter in the anesthetized dog, and it has also been shown to inhibit trigeminal nerve activity in the rat. The terminal elimination half-life of eletriptan is approximately 4 hours, and its molecular weight is 382.52. Eletriptan is part of Agents that produce hypertension; Amines; Analgesics; Antidepressive Agents; Antimigraine Preparations; Biogenic Amines; Biogenic Monoamines; Central Nervous System Depressants; Cytochrome P-450 CYP2A6 Inducers; Cytochrome P-450 CYP2C19 Substrates; Cytochrome P-450 CY. Eletriptan is approved and investigational.
Dapsone:
Dapsone is a sulfone active against a wide range of bacteria, including Mycobacterium leprae, the causative agent of leprosy. Its mechanism of action is similar to that of sulfonamides, which involves inhibition of folic acid synthesis in susceptible organisms. Dapsone is also used in combination with pyrimethamine for the treatment of malaria. The drug has anti-inflammatory properties and is employed in the management of leprosy and dermatitis herpetiformis. It is absorbed rapidly and nearly completely from the gastrointestinal tract, and is distributed throughout total body water, with a tendency to be retained in skin and muscle, particularly in the liver and kidneys. Dapsone has a topological polar surface area of 86.18 and a logP value of 0.89.

PHARMACODYNAMICS: Dapsone acts against bacteria and protozoa by inhibiting the synthesis of dihydrofolic acid through competition with para-amino-benzoate for the active site of dihydropteroate synthetase. The anti-inflammatory action of the drug is unrelated to its antibacterial action and is still not fully understood.

MECHANISM OF ACTION: Dapsone acts against bacteria and protozoa in the same way as sulphonamides, that is by inhibiting the synthesis of dihydrofolic acid through competition with para-amino-benzoate for the active site of dihydropteroate synthetase.

PROTEIN BINDING: Dapsone binds to proteins in the body with an affinity constant of 70-90%.

PHARMACOKINETICS: Dapsone is absorbed rapidly and nearly completely from the gastrointestinal tract. It is distributed throughout total body water and is present in all tissues, with a tendency to be retained in skin and muscle, particularly in the liver and kidneys.

HALF-LIFE: The half-life of dapsone is 28 hours (range 10-50 hours).

MOLECULAR PROPERTIES: The molecular weight of dapsone is 248.3, and its topological polar surface area is 86.18. Its logP value is 0.89.

DRUG CATEGORIES: Dapsone is part of Anti-Acne Preparations; Anti-Acne Preparations for Topical Use; Anti-Bacterial Agents; Anti-Infective Agents; Antibiotics for Pneumocystis Pneumonia; Antiinfectives for Systemic Use; Antimalarials; Antimycobacterials; Antiparasitic Agents; Antiprotozoals.

APPROVAL STATUS: Dapsone is approved and investigational.
Dronabinol:
Dronabinol is a synthetic form of delta-9-tetrahydrocannabinol (Δ⁹-THC), the primary psychoactive component of cannabis (marijuana). THC demonstrates its effects through weak partial agonist activity at Cannabinoid-1 (CB1R) and Cannabinoid-2 (CB2R) receptors, which results in the well-known effects of smoking cannabis such as increased appetite, reduced pain, and changes in emotional and cognitive processes. Due to its evidence as an appetite stimulant and an anti-nausea agent, Dronabinol is approved for use in anorexia associated with weight loss in patients with AIDS and for the treatment of nausea and vomiting associated with cancer chemotherapy in patients who have failed to respond adequately to conventional antiemetic treatments. The plasma protein binding of dronabinol and its metabolites is approximately 97%, and it has a topological polar surface area of 29.46 and a logP value of 7.24. Dronabinol is part of Agents producing tachycardia; Alimentary Tract and Metabolism; Analgesics, Non-Narcotic; Antiemetics and Antinauseants; BCRP/ABCG2 Inhibitors; Cannabinoid Receptor Agonists; Cannabinoids and similars; Central Nervous System Agents; Central Nervous System Depressants. It is approved and illicit.

Dronabinol works by binding to cannabinoid receptors in the body, particularly the CB1R and CB2R. This binding leads to a variety of effects, including increased appetite, reduced pain, and changes in emotional and cognitive processes. The exact mechanism of action of dronabinol is not fully understood, but it is believed to act as a weak partial agonist at these receptors, which means that it activates the receptor to some extent, but does not fully mimic the effects of endogenous cannabinoids.

The clinical indications for dronabinol are limited to patients with anorexia associated with weight loss in patients with AIDS and nausea and vomiting associated with cancer chemotherapy in patients who have failed to respond adequately to conventional antiemetic treatments. This is due to its ability to stimulate appetite and reduce nausea and vomiting, which are common side effects of these conditions.

The pharmacokinetics of dronabinol are characterized by a rapid absorption after oral administration, with peak plasma concentrations reached within 2-4 hours. The elimination phase of dronabinol can be described using a two-compartment model with an initial (alpha) half-life of about 4 hours and a terminal (beta) half-life of 25-36 hours. The protein binding of dronabinol and its metabolites is approximately 97%, which means that most of the drug is bound to proteins in the bloodstream, which can affect its distribution and pharmacokinetics.

In conclusion, dronabinol is a synthetic form of delta-9-tetrahydrocannabinol, the primary psychoactive component of cannabis, which has been approved for use in limited clinical indications due to its ability to stimulate appetite and reduce nausea and vomiting. Its mechanism of action is not fully understood, but it is believed to act as a weak partial agonist at cannabinoid receptors, leading to a variety of effects on the central nervous system.
Montelukast: Montelukast is a leukotriene receptor antagonist, specifically cysteinyl leukotriene receptor type-1 (CysLT1), which is approved for clinical use by the US FDA since 1998 under the brand name Singulair. It belongs to the LTRA category of drugs and acts by blocking the binding of cysteinyl leukotrienes (CysLT) to their corresponding receptors, thereby inhibiting the mediation of bronchoconstriction, inflammation, and asthma symptoms. Montelukast is available as a generic and brand-name product worldwide, with millions of prescriptions annually. Despite FDA-led investigations into possible neuropsychiatric effects in individuals using montelukast, the drug remains extensively used globally due to its efficacy in reducing symptoms of asthma and allergic rhinitis. The agent has a solid physical state, with a mean plasma half-life ranging from 2.7 to 5.5 hours in healthy young adults. Montelukast is bound to plasma proteins by greater than 99%, and its topological polar surface area (TPSA) is 70.42, while its logP value is 8.47. The molecular weight of montelukast is 586.19, and it belongs to several drug categories, including acids, acyclic agents, anti-asthmatic agents, and cytochrome P-450 CYP1A2 inducers. Montelukast has shown significant efficacy in blocking early and late phase bronchoconstriction caused by antigen challenge by 75% and 57%, respectively, in a placebo-controlled crossover study (n=12).
Rofecoxib:
Rofecoxib is a selective cyclooxygenase-2 (COX-2) inhibitor used for the treatment of osteoarthritis, rheumatoid arthritis, acute pain in adults, and primary dysmenorrhea, as well as acute treatment of migraine attacks with or without auras. It is a solid drug with a half-life of 17 hours and a mean oral bioavailability at therapeutically recommended doses of approximately 93%. Rofecoxib targets proteins including elastin and prostaglandin G/H synthase 2, and is metabolized by cytochrome P450 1A2, Cytochrome P450 3A4, Cytochrome P450 2C9, Cytochrome P450 2C8, and Prostaglandin G/H synthase 1. Its mechanism of action involves the inhibition of prostaglandin synthesis through the selective inhibition of COX-2 isoenzyme at sites of inflammation, resulting in reduced synthesis of certain prostaglandins from their arachidonic acid precursors. Rofecoxib has little to no affinity for COX-1 and does not inhibit platelet aggregation.

Rofecoxib is part of several drug categories, including Agents causing hyperkalemia; Agents that produce hypertension; Analgesics; Non-Narcotic Analgesics; Anti-Inflammatory Agents; Anti-Inflammatory Agents, Non-Steroidal; Antiinflammatory and Antirheumatic Products; and Antiinflammatory and Antirheumatic Products, Non-Steroids. It has been approved and investigational, as well as withdrawn from the market due to concerns about increased risk of heart attack and stroke associated with long-term, high-dosage use.
Zafirlukast: Zafirlukast is an oral leukotriene receptor antagonist (LTRA) used for the maintenance treatment of asthma. It works by blocking the action of leukotrienes, which are inflammatory molecules that cause airway constriction and inflammation in asthma patients. Zafirlukast is available as a tablet and is usually dosed twice daily. Its clinical indication is for the prophylaxis and chronic treatment of asthma, and it has been shown to be effective in reducing symptoms and improving lung function in these patients. The drug has a long half-life of 10 hours and its molecular properties include a topological polar surface area of 115.73 and a logP value of 7.09. Zafirlukast is part of the Agents to Treat Airway Disease category and has been approved for use in humans. However, its efficacy and safety have not been established in all patient populations, and it is currently being investigated for its potential use in other respiratory conditions.
Voriconazole: Voriconazole is a triazole antifungal medication employed to treat serious fungal infections, particularly those seen in immunocompromised patients. It is indicated for the treatment of invasive candidiasis, pulmonary aspergillosis, and emerging fungal infections caused by Scedosporium apiospermum and Fusarium spp. The drug works by binding to and inhibiting the enzyme 14-alpha sterol demethylase, leading to depletion of ergosterol in fungal cell membranes. This causes changes in plasma membrane permeability and growth inhibition. Voriconazole has a topological polar surface area (TPSA) of 76.72 and a logP value of 0.52, indicating its molecular properties. It is available in solid form and has been approved for use in various clinical indications. Pharmacodynamics: Voriconazole acts by binding to the enzyme 14-alpha sterol demethylase, which is responsible for ergosterol biosynthesis in fungal cell membranes. The inhibition of this enzyme leads to a decrease in ergosterol levels, causing changes in plasma membrane permeability and growth inhibition. Fungal plasma membranes are similar to mammalian plasma membranes, with the nonpolar sterol ergosterol being the primary sterol component. Membrane sterols play a crucial role in maintaining fungal cell structure, regulating membrane fluidity, and possibly controlling certain physiological events. Clinical Indications: Voriconazole is indicated for the treatment of esophageal candidiasis, invasive pulmonary aspergillosis, and serious fungal infections caused by Scedosporium apiospermum and Fusarium spp. These infections are typically seen in immunocompromised patients, such as those with HIV/AIDS or undergoing chemotherapy. Mechanism of Action: The mechanism of action of voriconazole is based on its ability to bind to and inhibit the enzyme 14-alpha sterol demethylase, leading to depletion of ergosterol in fungal cell membranes. This causes changes in plasma membrane permeability and growth inhibition. Protein Binding: Voriconazole has a protein binding capacity of 58%. Approval Status: Voriconazole is approved for use in various clinical indications, including esophageal candidiasis, invasive pulmonary aspergillosis, and serious fungal infections caused by Scedosporium apiospermum and Fusarium spp.
Chlorpropamide:
Chlorpropamide is an oral antihyperglycemic agent used for the treatment of non-insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus (NIDDM). It belongs to the sulfonylurea class of insulin secretagogues, which act by stimulating β cells of the pancreas to release insulin. Sulfonylureas increase both basal insulin secretion and meal-stimulated insulin release. Medications in this class differ in their dose, rate of absorption, duration of action, route of elimination and binding site on their target pancreatic β cell receptor. Sulfonylureas also increase peripheral glucose utilization, decrease hepatic gluconeogenesis and may increase the number and sensitivity of insulin receptors. Sulfonylureas are associated with weight gain, though less so than insulin. Due to their mechanism of action, sulfonylureas may cause hypoglycemia and require consistent food intake to decrease this risk. The risk of hypoglycemia is increased in elderly, debilitated and malnourished individuals. Chlorpropamide is not recommended for the treatment of NIDDM as it increases blood pressure and the risk of retinopathy (UKPDS-33). Up to 80% of the single oral dose of chlorpropramide is metabolized, likely in the liver; 80-90% of the dose is excreted in urine as unchanged drug and metabolites. Renal and hepatic dysfunction may increase the risk of hypoglycemia.

Chlorpropamide is an oral medication that works by stimulating the release of insulin from the β cells of the pancreas, thereby lowering blood glucose levels in patients with NIDDM. It belongs to the sulfonylurea class of drugs, which are known for their ability to increase both basal and meal-stimulated insulin secretion. The mechanism of action of chlorpropamide is based on its binding to ATP-sensitive potassium channels on the pancreatic cell surface, reducing potassium conductance and depolarizing the membrane, leading to the secretion of insulin.

Chlorpropamide has a high binding affinity for plasma proteins, which may affect its pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics. The drug is metabolized in the liver, with approximately 80% of the dose being recovered in the urine as unchanged drug and metabolites. The half-life of chlorpropamide is approximately 36 hours, with interindividual variation ranging from 25-60 hours.

Chlorpropamide has been shown to increase peripheral glucose utilization, decrease hepatic gluconeogenesis, and may increase the number and sensitivity of insulin receptors. However, it is associated with weight gain, though less so than insulin. Due to its mechanism of action, chlorpropamide may cause hypoglycemia, particularly in elderly, debilitated, and malnourished individuals. To decrease the risk of hypoglycemia, consistent food intake is required.

In conclusion, chlorpropamide is a valuable medication for the treatment of NIDDM when used in conjunction with diet and exercise. Its mechanism of action is based on its ability to stimulate insulin secretion from the β cells of the pancreas, thereby lowering blood glucose levels. However, it is important to be aware of the potential side effects and risks associated with its use, including weight gain, hypoglycemia, and increased blood pressure.
Etoposide: Etoposide is a semisynthetic derivative of podophyllotoxin that exhibits antitumor activity by inhibiting DNA synthesis by forming a complex with topoisomerase II and DNA. This complex induces breaks in double-stranded DNA and prevents repair by topoisomerase II binding, leading to cell death. Etoposide acts primarily in the G2 and S phases of the cell cycle and is protein bound to 97%. Its mechanism of action involves inhibition of DNA topoisomerase II alpha isoform, resulting in anti-tumor activity, while inhibition of the beta isoform leads to carcinogenic effects. Etoposide is used in combination with other chemotherapeutic agents for the treatment of refractory testicular tumors and as first-line treatment in patients with small cell lung cancer, as well as other malignancies such as lymphoma, non-lymphocytic leukemia, and glioblastoma multiforme. At high concentrations, it causes lysis of cells entering mitosis, while at low concentrations, it inhibits cells from entering prophase. Etoposide is a solid with a molecular weight of 588.56 and a topological polar surface area of 160.83. Its logP value is -0.11. Candesartan:
Candesartan is an angiotensin-receptor blocker (ARB) that may be used alone or with other agents to treat hypertension. It is administered orally as the prodrug, candesartan cilexetil, which is rapidly converted to its active metabolite, candesartan, during absorption in the gastrointestinal tract. Candesartan lowers blood pressure by antagonizing the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS); it competes with angiotensin II for binding to the type-1 angiotensin II receptor (AT1) subtype and prevents the blood pressure increasing effects of angiotensin II. Unlike angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors, ARBs do not have the adverse effect of dry cough. Candesartan may be used to treat hypertension, isolated systolic hypertension, left ventricular hypertrophy and diabetic nephropathy. It may also be used as an alternative agent for the treatment of heart failure, systolic dysfunction, myocardial infarction and coronary artery disease in those intolerant of ACE inhibitors.

Candesartan cilexetil is a solid and has a topological polar surface area (TPSA) of 143.34 and a log p value of 7.08. The half-life of candesartan is approximately 9 hours, and its molecular weight is 610.67. Candesartan is part of Agents Acting on the Renin-Angiotensin System; Agents causing hyperkalemia; Angiotensin 2 Receptor Blocker; Angiotensin II Antagonists and Diuretics; Angiotensin Receptor Antagonists; Antihypertensive Agents; Antihypertensive Agents Indicated for Hypertension. It has been approved for use in clinical practice.

The mechanism of action of candesartan is based on its ability to selectively block the binding of angiotensin II to AT1 receptors in many tissues, including vascular smooth muscle and the adrenal glands. This inhibits the AT1-mediated vasoconstrictive and aldosterone-secreting effects of angiotensin II and results in an overall decrease in blood pressure. Candesartan is greater than 10,000 times more selective for AT1 than AT2, which reduces the risk of adverse effects associated with ACE inhibitors. In addition, candesartan inhibition of aldosterone secretion may increase sodium and water excretion while decreasing potassium excretion, further contributing to blood pressure lowering.

In conclusion, candesartan is a valuable tool in the management of hypertension and other cardiovascular disorders due to its ability to effectively lower blood pressure without causing dry cough, a common adverse effect associated with ACE inhibitors. Its high selectivity for AT1 receptors and lack of effects on bradykinin-induced vasodilation make it an attractive alternative to traditional antihypertensive agents.
Thalidomide:
Thalidomide is a piperidinyl isoindole that has been reintroduced for the treatment of various immunological and inflammatory disorders, including erythema nodosum leprosum (ENL). It exhibits immunosuppressive and anti-angiogenic activity by inhibiting the release of tumor necrosis factor-alpha from monocytes and modulating other cytokine actions. The mechanism of action of thalidomide in ENL is not fully understood, but available data suggest that it may involve suppression of excessive TNF-a production and down-modulation of selected cell surface adhesion molecules involved in leukocyte migration. As a cancer treatment, thalidomide may act as a VEGF inhibitor. Thalidomide is a solid with a mean half-life of elimination ranging from approximately 5 to 7 hours following a single dose. However, its approval status is approved and investigational and withdrawn.

Thalidomide was initially introduced as a non-barbiturate hypnotic but was withdrawn from the market due to teratogenic effects. It has since been reintroduced for the treatment of various immunological and inflammatory disorders, including ENL. Thalidomide's immunosuppressive and anti-angiogenic properties make it an effective treatment option for patients with ENL, who often experience significant cutaneous manifestations. However, the mechanism of action of thalidomide in ENL is not fully understood, and further research is needed to determine its exact mechanisms of immunosuppression and anti-angiogenesis. Additionally, thalidomide's withdrawal from the market due to teratogenic effects highlights the importance of thorough safety testing and regulation in the development and approval of new drugs.
Diphenhydramine:
Diphenhydramine is a first-generation H1 receptor antihistamine that is widely used for the treatment of seasonal allergies, insect bites and stings, and rashes. However, it also has antiemetic, antitussive, hypnotic, and antiparkinson properties due to its competitive antagonism of histamine H1 receptors within the central nervous system. As a non-prescription over-the-counter medication, diphenhydramine is formulated as tablets and creams, and its mechanism of action involves the antagonism of H1 receptors on various tissues throughout the body, including respiratory smooth muscles, vascular endothelial cells, the gastrointestinal tract, cardiac tissue, immune cells, the uterus, and the central nervous system. Diphenhydramine has protein binding of approximately 78% and its pharmacodynamics include anti-histaminic, anti-emetic, anti-vertigo, and sedative properties. The elimination half-life of diphenhydramine ranges from 2.4-9.3 hours in healthy adults, and it is part of several drug categories, including Agents producing tachycardia, Amines, Aminoalkyl Ethers, Anesthetics, Local Anesthetics, Anti-Allergic Agents, Anticholinergic Agents, Antiemetics, Antihistamines for Systemic Use, and Antihistamines for Topical Use.

Mechanism of Action: Diphenhydramine predominantly works via the antagonism of H1 (Histamine 1) receptors. Such H1 receptors are located on respiratory smooth muscles, vascular endothelial cells, the gastrointestinal tract (GIT), cardiac tissue, immune cells, the uterus, and the central nervous system (CNS) neurons. When the H1 receptor is stimulated in these tissues it produces a variety of actions including increased vascular permeability, promotion of vasodilation causing flushing, decreased atrioventricular (AV) node conduction time, stimulation of sensory nerves of airways producing coughing, smooth muscle contraction of bronchi and the GIT, and eosinophilic chemotaxis that promotes the allergic immune response.

Clinical Indication: Diphenhydramine is a first-generation histamine H1 receptor antagonist (H1 antihistamine) that is widely available as a non-prescription, over-the-counter (OTC) medication. As an OTC medication, diphenhydramine is typically formulated as tablets and creams indicated for use in treating sneezing, runny nose, itchy/watery eyes, itching of nose or throat, insomnia, pruritis, urticaria, insect bites/stings, allergic rashes, and nausea.

Ifosfamide:
Ifosfamide is a chemotherapeutic agent that belongs to the class of nitrogen mustards and synthetic analogs of cyclophosphamide. It is an alkylating agent and immunosuppressive drug used in various chemotherapeutic regimens for the treatment of different types of cancer, including germ cell testicular cancer, cervical cancer, soft tissue sarcomas, osteosarcoma, bladder cancer, ovarian cancer, small cell lung cancer, and non-Hodgkin's lymphoma. Ifosfamide works by requiring biotransformation in the liver through the cytochrome P450 system before it becomes active. The active metabolites alkylate or bind with many intracellular molecular structures, including nucleic acids, leading to cell death through DNA damage. Ifosfamide has a molecular weight of 261.08 and a topological polar surface area of 41.57. It is a solid and has a half-life of 7-15 hours, which increases with age. Ifosfamide is approved for clinical use.

Mechanism of Action: The exact mechanism of ifosfamide's cytotoxic effects is not fully understood, but it is believed to be similar to other alkylating agents. The active metabolites of ifosfamide alkylate or bind with many intracellular molecular structures, including nucleic acids, leading to cell death through DNA damage.

Clinical Indication: Ifosfamide is used as a component of various chemotherapeutic regimens for the treatment of different types of cancer, including germ cell testicular cancer, cervical cancer, soft tissue sarcomas, osteosarcoma, bladder cancer, ovarian cancer, small cell lung cancer, and non-Hodgkin's lymphoma.

Pharmacokinetics: Ifosfamide requires biotransformation in the liver by mixed-function oxidases (cytochrome P450 system) before it becomes active. The major urinary metabolites, dechloroethyl ifosfamide and dechloroethyl cyclophosphamide, are formed upon enzymatic oxidation of the chloroethyl side chains and subsequent dealkylation. Ifosfamide is cycle-phase nonspecific.

Drug Interactions: Ifosfamide can interact with DNA through alkylation reactions. It has been shown to increase the activity of other chemotherapeutic agents, such as cyclophosphamide and ifosphoramide, by inhibiting their metabolism.

Toxicology: Ifosfamide can cause bone marrow suppression, gastrointestinal toxicity, and hepatotoxicity. It can also lead to secondary malignancies, such as leukemia and lymphoma, through its alkylating effects on DNA.

Prescription Information: Ifosfamide is typically prescribed for patients with advanced or recurrent cancer who have failed other treatment options. It is important to closely monitor patient's blood cell counts and liver function during treatment with ifosfamide. Patients should be educated about the potential side effects and toxicities associated with this drug, as well as the importance of adhering to the recommended dosage and administration schedule.

Drug Combinations: Ifosfamide is often combined with other chemotherapeutic agents, such as doxorubicin, bleomycin, and methotrexate, in various chemotherapeutic regimens for the treatment of different types of cancer.

Pregnancy and Lactation: Ifosfamide is contraindicated in pregnant women due to its potential teratogenic effects on the fetus. It is also excreted in breast milk, and the drug's potential risks and benefits for lactating women should be carefully evaluated before use.

Drug Disposition: Ifosfamide is extensively metabolized in the liver, with major metabolites including dechloroethyl ifosfamide, dechloroethyl cyclophosphamide, and 4-hydroxyifosfamide. The drug has a short half-life and is primarily eliminated through the urine.

Toxicity: Ifosfamide can cause bone marrow suppression, gastrointestinal toxicity, hepatotoxicity, and secondary malignancies, such as leukemia and lymphoma. Patients should be closely monitored for these potential side effects during treatment with ifosfamide.

Immunopharmacology: Ifosfamide has been shown to suppress the immune system through its alkylating effects on DNA. It can also increase the activity of other chemotherapeutic agents, such as cyclophosphamide and ifosphoramide, by inhibiting their metabolism.

The active metabolites of ifosfamide alkylate or bind with many intracellular molecular structures, including nucleic acids, leading to cell death through DNA damage.

Clinical Use: Ifosfamide is used in various chemotherapeutic regimens for the treatment of different types of cancer, including germ cell testicular cancer, cervical cancer, soft tissue sarcomas, osteosarcoma, bladder cancer, ovarian cancer, small cell lung cancer, and non-Hodgkin's lymphoma.

Overall, ifosfamide is a valuable chemotherapeutic agent that has been shown to be effective in the treatment of various types of cancer. Its mechanism of action involves alkylation reactions with DNA, leading to cell death through DNA damage. However, it can also cause bone marrow suppression, gastrointestinal toxicity, hepatotoxicity, and secondary malignancies, such as leukemia and lymphoma. Zopiclone:
Zopiclone is a novel hypnotic agent used in the treatment of insomnia. Its mechanism of action is based on modulating benzodiazepine receptors, which involves interacting with the gamma-aminobutyric acid-benzodiazepine (GABA<sub>B</sub>Z) receptor chloride channel macromolecular complex. Zopiclone binds selectively to the brain alpha subunit of the GABA A omega-1 receptor, leading to an enhancement of the inhibitory actions of GABA and producing therapeutic (hypnotic and anxiolytic) and adverse effects. Approximately 45% of zopiclone is bound to protein, and its elimination half-life is approximately 5 hours, with a prolonged half-life in patients with hepatic insufficiency. Zopiclone, a nonbenzodiazepine hypnotic from the pyrazolopyrimidine class, is indicated for the short-term treatment of insomnia. Zopiclone binds selectively to the brain alpha subunit of the GABA A omega-1 receptor, leading to an enhancement of the inhibitory actions of GABA and producing therapeutic (hypnotic and anxiolytic) and adverse effects. The clinical indication for zopiclone is the short-term treatment of insomnia, which affects millions of people worldwide. Zopiclone has been shown to improve sleep quality and reduce the time it takes to fall asleep in patients with insomnia.

Mechanistically, zopiclone acts on the GABA A omega-1 receptor complex by binding selectively to the brain alpha subunit of the GABA A omega-1 receptor. In conclusion, zopiclone is a novel hypnotic agent used in the treatment of insomnia. Ketamine:
Ketamine is an NMDA receptor antagonist with a potent anesthetic effect. It was developed in 1963 as a replacement for phencyclidine (PCP) by Calvin Stevens at Parke Davis Laboratories. Since its approval in 1970, ketamine has been used primarily as an anesthetic agent for children and patients undergoing minor surgeries, as well as for veterinary purposes. Ketamine interacts with N-methyl-D-aspartate (NMDA) receptors, opioid receptors, monoaminergic receptors, muscarinic receptors, and voltage-sensitive calcium ion channels, producing a unique anesthetic state characterized by profound analgesia, normal pharyngeal-laryngeal reflexes, normal or slightly enhanced skeletal muscle tone, cardiovascular and respiratory stimulation, and occasionally a transient and minimal respiratory depression. The anesthetic state produced by ketamine has been termed "dissociative anesthesia" due to its selective interruption of association pathways of the brain before producing somesthetic sensory blockade. Ketamine has a topological polar surface area of 29.1 and a logP value of 2.93, indicating its molecular properties. It is a solid and has an reported half-life of 186 min in preclinical studies. Ketamine is part of several drug categories, including agents producing tachycardia, amino acids, acidic amino acids, and peptides and proteins. It is approved for both human and veterinary use.

Mechanism of Action: Ketamine interacts with N-methyl-D-aspartate (NMDA) receptors, opioid receptors, monoaminergic receptors, muscarinic receptors, and voltage-sensitive calcium ion channels. Unlike other general anesthetic agents, ketamine does not interact with GABA receptors. This unique mechanism of action produces a distinct anesthetic state characterized by profound analgesia, normal pharyngeal-laryngeal reflexes, normal or slightly enhanced skeletal muscle tone, cardiovascular and respiratory stimulation, and occasionally a transient and minimal respiratory depression.

Clinical Indication: Ketamine is indicated as an anesthetic agent for recommended diagnostic and surgical procedures. If skeletal muscle relaxation is needed, it should be combined with a muscle relaxant. If the surgical procedure involves visceral pain, it should be supplemented with an agent that obtunds visceral pain. Ketamine can be used for induction of anesthesia prior to other general anesthetic agents and as a supplement of low potency agents.

Pharmacodynamics: The anesthetic state produced by ketamine has been termed "dissociative anesthesia" in that it appears to selectively interrupt association pathways of the brain before producing somesthetic sensory blockade. Ketamine may selectively depress the thalamoneocortical system before significantly obtunding the more ancient cerebral centers and pathways (reticular-activating and limbic systems).

Half-life: The reported half-life in preclinical studies for ketamine is 186 min.

Hexobarbital: Hexobarbital is a barbiturate that serves as an effective hypnotic and sedative. It was once commonly used as an anesthetic for surgery, particularly in the 1940s and 1950s. The drug binds to a distinct binding site at the GABA-A receptor, increasing the duration of time for which the Cl- ionopore is open. This results in a prolonged post-synaptic inhibitory effect in the thalamus. Hexobarbital has a relatively quick onset of action and a short duration of action, but it can be difficult to control the depth of anesthesia, making it dangerous. The molecular weight of hexobarbital is 236.27, and its topological polar surface area is 66.48. It has a logP value of 1.63. Trabectedin:
Trabectedin is a marine-derived antitumor agent discovered in the Carribean tunicate _Ecteinascidia turbinata_ and now produced synthetically. It has a unique mechanism of action, binding to the minor groove of DNA and interfering with cell division and genetic transcription processes, as well as DNA repair machinery. Approved for use in Europe, Russia, and South Korea for the treatment of advanced soft tissue sarcoma, it is currently under evaluation for the treatment of breast cancer, prostate cancer, and pediatric sarcomas. Both the European Commission and the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) have approved trabectedin as an orphan drug in soft tissue sarcomas and ovarian cancer. Trabectedin interacts with the minor groove of DNA, covalently binding to it and blocking cell division at the G2 phase while also inhibiting overexpression of the multidrug resistance-1 gene (MDR-1) coding for the P-glycoprotein that is a major factor responsible for cells developing resistance to cancer drugs. The agent is also thought to interfere with the nucleotide excision repair pathways of cancer cells, suggesting that it could be effective in the treatment of many cancer types including melanoma and sarcoma, as well as lung, breast, ovarian, endometrial, and prostate cancers; clinical evaluations are underway in these indications.

Pharmacologically, trabectedin has a molecular weight of 761.84 and a topological polar surface area of 168.72. It is a solid with a half-life of 33-50 hours and is bound to DNA with a high affinity. Trabectedin also inhibits cytochrome P-450 CYP2C19, an enzyme involved in drug metabolism. As such, it can have significant drug interactions, and dosage adjustments may be necessary.

Its protein binding is 94-98%, and its pharmacokinetics are complex, with multiple compartments and nonlinear elimination.

In conclusion, Trabectedin is a unique antitumor agent with a distinct mechanism of action, approved for use in soft tissue sarcoma and under evaluation for various other cancer types. Its pharmacological properties and clinical indications make it an interesting drug for further investigation and potential use in cancer treatment.

Talniflumate:
Talniflumate is an anti-inflammatory molecule studied and used as a mucin regulator in the treatment of cystic fibrosis, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and asthma. It is also used in inflammatory conditions such as rheumatoid arthritis. Phase I trials with talniflumate for the treatment of cystic fibrosis and COPD were completed in August 2001, but this research has now been discontinued. Talniflumate has been approved for approximately 20 years in Argentina and other countries (excluding the United States, Europe, and Japan).

Talniflumate is a phthalidyl ester of nifumic acid, which has potent analgesic and anti-inflammatory effects. It works by selectively blocking the activity of core mucin-synthesizing enzyme GCNT3 (core 2 b-1,6 N-acetylglucosaminyltransferase), leading to a decrease in mucin production and improvement in respiratory function in patients with cystic fibrosis. Additionally, talniflumate blocks prostaglandin synthesis by cyclooxygenases, which aids in pain and inflammation management.

Human Recombinant Antihemophilic Factor:
NAME: Human Recombinant Antihemophilic Factor (AHF) or Factor VIII

Description: Human recombinant antihemophilic factor (AHF) or Factor VIII is a 2332 residue glycosylated protein produced by CHO cells. It is used to treat hemophilia A, von Willebrand disease, and Factor XIII deficiency. The drug works by binding to factor IXa along with calcium and phospholipid, facilitating the clotting cascade and promoting blood coagulation.

Pharmacodynamics: Antihemophilic factor binds factor IXa along with calcium and phospholipid, converting factor X to factor Xa, which is essential for blood clotting. The drug's mechanism of action is based on the increase in plasma levels of AHF, which can temporarily correct the coagulation defect of patients with hemophilia A (classical hemophilia).

Physical State: Human recombinant antihemophilic factor is a solid.

Half-life: The half-life of human recombinant antihemophilic factor is 8.4-19.3 hours.

Paragraph:
Human recombinant antihemophilic factor (AHF) or Factor VIII is a vital drug used to treat hemophilia A, von Willebrand disease, and Factor XIII deficiency. It works by increasing the levels of antihemophilic factor in the blood, which enables the body to form clots and stop bleeding. This protein is produced by CHO cells and consists of 2332 residues, with glycosylation adding to its stability and effectiveness. The drug's mechanism of action involves binding to factor IXa along with calcium and phospholipid, converting factor X to factor Xa, which is essential for blood clotting. With a half-life of 8.4-19.3 hours, the drug provides a temporary correction of coagulation defects in patients with hemophilia A (classical hemophilia). As an investigational drug, its approval status is still being evaluated. Nonetheless, human recombinant antihemophilic factor has revolutionized the treatment of bleeding disorders and significantly improved the quality of life for individuals affected by these conditions.
Betrixaban:
Betrixaban is a non-vitamin K oral anticoagulant that selectively and reversibly inhibits the factor Xa protein, thereby preventing thrombin generation without affecting platelet aggregation. Developed by Portola Pharmaceuticals Inc., betrixaban is indicated for the prophylaxis of venous thromboembolism (VTE) in adult patients with moderate to severe restricted mobility or at risk for VTE due to medical conditions or surgical interventions. Betrixaban's mechanism of action is based on its ability to competitively and reversibly bind to the factor Xa protein, thereby preventing thrombin generation without affecting platelet aggregation. With a long half-life of 19-27 hours and a high protein binding rate of around 60%, betrixaban provides sustained anticoagulation over an extended period. Betrixaban belongs to the class of acids, carbocyclic compounds, amides, anticoagulants, and factor Xa inhibitors. Betrixaban's clinical utility lies in its ability to prevent VTE in high-risk patients, including those with mobility restrictions or at risk due to surgery or other medical conditions. VTE can lead to severe consequences, such as deep vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism, which are a leading cause of preventable death in hospitalized patients. By providing sustained anticoagulation over an extended period, betrixaban offers a valuable alternative to traditional vitamin K-dependent anticoagulants, which have limitations in certain patient populations. As with any anticoagulant, close monitoring and dose adjustments are necessary to ensure safe and effective use of betrixaban.
Lonoctocog Alfa:
Lonoctocog alfa is a recombinant antihemophilic factor (AHF) used for the treatment of hemophilia A, von Willebrand disease, and Factor XIII deficiency. It works by providing an increase in plasma levels of AHF, which temporarily corrects the coagulation defect in patients with hemophilia A (classical hemophilia). Lonoctocog alfa binds factor IXa along with calcium and phospholipid, forming a complex that converts factor X to factor Xa, facilitating the clotting cascade. The half-life of lonoctocog alfa is approximately 8.4-19.3 hours. It is classified under the drug category of Hemostatics and has been approved for use in patients with hemophilia A and von Willebrand disease, while it is still under investigation for the treatment of Factor XIII deficiency.

Lonoctocog alfa is a recombinant protein produced through genetic engineering, consisting of a polypeptide chain composed of 2,189 amino acids. It is designed to mimic the structure and function of endogenous AHF, with improved stability and shelf life compared to traditional AHF products. The recombinant protein is produced in Escherichia coli bacteria using a yeast expression system, and it undergoes extensive quality control testing to ensure its safety and efficacy.

The pharmacokinetics of lonoctocog alfa have been studied in healthy volunteers and patients with hemophilia A. The drug is well-distributed into blood compartments, with a mean volume of distribution of approximately 150 liters. The protein is primarily bound to plasma proteins, with less than 1% of the administered dose found in the cerebrospinal fluid. Lonoctocog alfa has been shown to be safe and well-tolerated in clinical trials, with adverse events similar to those associated with other AHF products.

In conclusion, lonoctocog alfa is a promising treatment option for patients with hemophilia A, von Willebrand disease, and Factor XIII deficiency. Its unique structure and production method offer advantages over traditional AHF products, and its pharmacokinetics have been shown to be consistent with other AHF drugs. Further investigation is needed to fully evaluate the safety and efficacy of lonoctocog alfa in clinical practice.
Moroctocog alfa:
Moroctocog alfa, also known as BDDrFVIII (B domain deleted recombinant factor VIII), is a recombinant DNA-based drug with functional characteristics comparable to those of endogenous coagulation Factor VIII. It is produced through recombinant DNA technology and purification, resulting in a 1438 amino acid, 170 kDa protein. Clinical evaluation has shown that BDDrFVIII is pharmacokinetically equivalent to full-length recombinant FVIII. Moroctocog alfa is approved by Health Canada for the control and prevention of hemorrhagic episodes, and for routine and surgical prophylaxis in patients with hemophilia A (congenital factor VIII deficiency or classic hemophilia). The mechanism of action of Moroctocog alfa involves binding to factor IXa along with calcium and phospholipid, which converts factor X to factor Xa to facilitate the clotting cascade. The half-life of Moroctocog alfa is approximately 11.8 (± 5.1) hours. Moroctocog alfa belongs to the categories of Amino Acids, Peptides, and Proteins; Biological Factors; Blood Coagulation Factors; Blood Proteins; Hemostatics; Proteins; Recombinant Proteins.

The administration of Moroctocog alfa provides an increase in plasma levels of Antihemophilic Factor, which can temporarily correct the coagulation defect of patients with hemophilia A. As factor VIII is the specific clotting factor deficient in patients with hemophilia A, replacement of clotting factor with Moroctocog alfa is the cornerstone of the prevention and treatment of bleeding for this disorder. Moroctocog alfa has a mean terminal elimination half-life of approximately 11.8 (± 5.1) hours, indicating a relatively long half-life compared to some other recombinant factor VIII products. This may provide advantages in terms of dosing frequency and convenience for patients.

In summary, Moroctocog alfa is a recombinant DNA-based drug that provides a functional substitute for endogenous coagulation Factor VIII in patients with hemophilia A. Its pharmacokinetic properties, clinical uses, and mechanism of action make it an important treatment option for these patients.

Tibolone:
Tibolone is a synthetic steroid hormone drug that acts as an agonist primarily at estrogen receptors (ER), with a preference for ER alpha. It is approved and investigational for the relief of post-menopausal symptoms and for the prevention of osteoporosis. The drug's effects are owed to the activity of its metabolites in various tissues, including bone, brain, and vaginal tissues. Additionally, tibolone's ability to act as an agonist primarily at ER alpha, while not stimulating endometrial tissues, reduces the risk of endometrial cancer, making it a safer alternative to other hormonal treatments.

Mechanistically, tibolone works by binding to estrogen receptors in various tissues, including bone, brain, and vaginal tissues. Corticotropin (ACTH or adrenocorticotrop: Corticotropin is a polypeptide hormone produced and secreted by the pituitary gland, playing a crucial role in the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal (HPA) axis.
