The peptide's ability to target specific cellular structures and alter membrane properties offers a new approach to addressing these conditions, and ongoing research is exploring its potential in clinical settings.
Glycerol phenylbutyrate:
Glycerol phenylbutyrate is a nitrogen-binding agent that is FDA approved for the chronic management of urea cycle disorders in adult and pediatric patients ≥2 years of age who cannot be managed by dietary protein restriction and/or amino acid supplementation alone. The drug works by converting toxic ammonia in the blood and brain into a less toxic compound that can be excreted through the kidneys. Glycerol phenylbutyrate is a prodrug, with the major metabolite being phenylacetate (PAA), which conjugates with glutamine in the liver and kidneys to form phenylacetylglutamine (PAGN), which is excreted by the kidneys. The drug has a solid physical state and a molecular weight of 530.66, with a topological polar surface area of 78.9 and a logP value of 7.87. Glycerol phenylbutyrate is part of several drug categories, including acids, carbocyclic alcohols, and cytochrome P-450 CYP2D6 inhibitors. The drug prolongs the QTc interval and has a molecular formula of C18H31NO5.

Glycerol phenylbutyrate is used to treat urea cycle disorders, which are a group of genetic disorders that affect the breakdown of ammonia in the body. These disorders can lead to a buildup of ammonia in the blood and brain, which can cause seizures, developmental delays, and other serious health problems. Glycerol phenylbutyrate works by binding to nitrogen molecules and helping to remove them from the body through the kidneys. This helps to reduce the levels of ammonia in the blood and brain, which can help to prevent or manage the symptoms of urea cycle disorders.

The mechanism of action of glycerol phenylbutyrate involves the conversion of toxic ammonia in the blood and brain into a less toxic compound called phenylacetate (PAA). PAA is formed through a series of reactions involving the enzyme carbamylphosphate synthase, which is deficient in patients with urea cycle disorders. Once formed, PAA conjugates with glutamine in the liver and kidneys to form phenylacetylglutamine (PAGN), which is excreted by the kidneys. This process helps to reduce the levels of ammonia in the blood and brain, which can help to prevent or manage the symptoms of urea cycle disorders.

Glycerol phenylbutyrate has a number of advantages over other treatments for urea cycle disorders. It is a solid dosage form that can be easily administered, and it has a long shelf life. The drug is also well-tolerated, with few side effects reported in clinical trials. Additionally, glycerol phenylbutyrate has been shown to prolong the QTc interval, which may be beneficial for patients with certain heart conditions.

Overall, glycerol phenylbutyrate is an important treatment option for patients with urea cycle disorders. Its ability to bind to nitrogen molecules and help remove them from the body makes it a valuable tool in managing these disorders. With its solid physical state, long shelf life, and few side effects, glycerol phenylbutyrate is an attractive option for patients who require chronic management of their urea cycle disorders.
Melatonin:
Melatonin is a biogenic amine that is found in animals, plants, and microbes. It is produced by the pineal gland in mammals, where it regulates the sleep-wake cycle by increasing in darkness and decreasing during exposure to light. Melatonin has been shown to have various effects on different tissues and organs, including immune activity, dreaming, fertility, and reproduction. It is also an effective antioxidant and has received FDA orphan drug status for treating circadian rhythm sleep disorders in blind individuals. Melatonin binds to melatonin receptor type 1A, which then acts on adenylate cyclase and the inhibition of a cAMP signal transduction pathway. The binding of the agonists to the receptors has been investigated for over two decades and causes numerous physiological processes. Melatonin is available as an oral medication and has been used orally for jet lag, insomnia, shift-work disorder, circadian rhythm disorders in the blind, and benzodiazepine and nicotine withdrawal. It has also been shown to be effective for treating sleep-wake cycle disturbances in children and adolescents with mental retardation, autism, and other central nervous system disorders.

PHARMACODYNAMICS: Melatonin is a hormone that regulates the sleep-wake cycle by stimulating production in darkness and inhibiting it during exposure to light. High levels of melatonin induce sleep, and consumption of the drug can be used to combat insomnia and jet lag.

HALF-LIFE: The half-life of melatonin is 35-50 minutes.

MOLECULAR PROPERTIES: Melatonin has a molecular weight of 232.28 and a topological polar surface area of 54.12. Its logP value is 1.03.

DRUG CATEGORIES: Melatonin is part of the amines; antioxidants; biogenic amines; biogenic monoamines; central nervous system agents; central nervous system depressants; compounds used in a research, industrial, or household setting; cytochrome P-450 CYP1A2 substrates; cytochrome P-450 CYP2C19 substrates; cytochrome P-450 enzymes.

APPROVAL STATUS: Melatonin is approved as a nutraceutical and vet-approved.
Pralatrexate:
Pralatrexate is an antimetabolite drug used for the treatment of relapsed or refractory peripheral T-cell lymphoma. It has a higher affinity for cancer cells than methotrexate, resulting in better retention and cytotoxicity within the cancer cells. Pralatrexate works by binding to the reduced folate carrier protein-1 (RTC-1) on the surface of cancer cells with 10 times the affinity of methotrexate. This leads to increased internalization and retention of the drug in cancer cells, resulting in enhanced antitumor activity. The drug has a half-life of 12-18 hours and is primarily eliminated through renal excretion. Pralatrexate is part of the antimetabolite class of drugs and has been approved by the FDA since September 24, 2009.

Pharmacological Properties:
Pralatrexate is a solid drug that binds to plasma protein, albumin, with a moderate affinity. It does not significantly displace substrates from proteins and has a protein binding rate of 67-86%. The drug's mechanism of action is based on its selective binding to RTC-1 on the surface of cancer cells, which allows it to be internalized and retained in the cells more efficiently than methotrexate.

Clinical Indication: Pralatrexate is indicated for the treatment of relapsed or refractory peripheral T-cell lymphoma.

Mechanism of Action: The selectivity of pralatrexate for cancer cells is based on the observation that cancer cells generally have an overexpression of reduced folate carrier protein-1 (RTC-1) compared to normal somatic cells. This carrier protein allows the entrance of pralatrexate into the cell. Once inside, folypolyglutamate synthase FPGS catalyzes the polyglutamination of pralatrexate, which leads to its retention within the cell.

Physical Properties: Pralatrexate is a solid drug with a molecular weight of 477.48 and a topological polar surface area (TPSA) of 207.3. It has a logP value of -0.11, indicating that it is moderately hydrophobic.

Drug Categories: Pralatrexate belongs to the antimetabolite class of drugs and has been approved by the FDA since September 24, 2009. It is also categorized as an antineoplastic agent, BCRP/ABCG2 substrate, biological factor, drug mainly renally excreted, folic acid analogue, and immunosuppressive agent.

Approval Status: Pralatrexate is approved for the treatment of relapsed or refractory peripheral T-cell lymphoma, and it is also investigational for other indications.
Menadiol sodium diphosphate:
Menadiol sodium diphosphate is a Vitamin K derivative that was previously approved by the FDA for the treatment of anticoagulant-induced prothrombin deficiency. However, due to its carcinogenic potential and cytotoxic properties, it has been discontinued and is no longer available in North America. Menadiol sodium diphosphate works by being involved in the posttranslational gamma-carboxylation of glutamic acid residues of various proteins in the body, allowing for the propagation of the clotting cascade that results in coagulation. These proteins include vitamin K-dependent coagulation factors II (prothrombin), VII (proconvertin), IX (Christmas factor), X (Stuart factor), protein C, protein S, protein Zv and a growth-arrest-specific factor (Gas6). The two vitamin K-dependent proteins found in bone are osteocalcin, also known as bone G1a (gamma-carboxyglutamate) protein or BGP, and the matrix G1a protein or MGP. Menadiol sodium diphosphate is a highly water-soluble vitamin K analog that is necessary for the formation of prothrombin, factor VII, factor IX and factor X. Without sufficient vitamin K, there is an increased risk of hemorrhage, which can be minor or life-threatening.

Mechanism of Action: Menadiol sodium diphosphate works by being involved in the posttranslational gamma-carboxylation of glutamic acid residues of various proteins in the body, allowing for the propagation of the clotting cascade that results in coagulation. These proteins include vitamin K-dependent coagulation factors II (prothrombin), VII (proconvertin), IX (Christmas factor), X (Stuart factor), protein C, protein S, protein Zv and a growth-arrest-specific factor (Gas6). The two vitamin K-dependent proteins found in bone are osteocalcin, also known as bone G1a (gamma-carboxyglutamate) protein or BGP, and the matrix G1a protein or MGP.

Pharmacodynamics: Menadiol sodium diphosphate is a highly water-soluble vitamin K analog. The presence of vitamin K is necessary for the formation of prothrombin, factor VII, factor IX and factor X. Lack of vitamin K results in an increased risk of hemorrhage, which can be minor or life-threatening.

Physical State: Menadiol sodium diphosphate is a solid.

Half-life: The mean elimination half-life of menadione was 27.17 min in the plasma of rabbits, in one study.

Approval Status: Menadiol sodium diphosphate is approved.
Cimetidine: Cimetidine is a histamine congener that competitively inhibits histamine binding to histamine H2 receptors. With a range of pharmacological actions, it inhibits gastric acid secretion, pepsin and gastrins output, and blocks the activity of cytochrome P-450, which might explain its proposals for use in neoadjuvant therapy. Cimetidine binds to an H2 receptor located on the basolateral membrane of the gastric parietal cell, blocking histamine effects and resulting in reduced gastric acid secretion and a reduction in gastric volume and acidity. It is used to treat gastrointestinal disorders such as gastric or duodenal ulcer, gastroesophageal reflux disease, and pathological hypersecretory conditions. Additionally, cimetidine inhibits many of the isoenzymes of the hepatic CYP450 enzyme system, resulting in an increase in gastric bacterial flora such as nitrate-reducing organisms. With a half-life of 2 hours and a molecular weight of 252.34, cimetidine is a solid that can be administered orally. Its topological polar surface area is 88.89, and its logP value is 0.38. Cimetidine is part of Acid Reducers; Adjuvants; Agents Causing Muscle Toxicity; Alimentary Tract and Metabolism; Amidines; Anti-Ulcer Agents; BSEP/ABCB11 Inhibitors; Chemically-Induced Disorders; Cytochrome P-450 CYP1A2 Inhibitors (weak); and Cytochrome P-450 CYP1A2 Inhibitors. It is approved for use and investigational.
Metopirone:
Metopirone is an inhibitor of the enzyme steroid 11-beta-monooxygenase, which is used as a diagnostic test to evaluate the feedback hypothalamic-pituitary mechanism in the diagnosis of Cushing syndrome. The drug works by reducing cortisol and corticosterone production by inhibiting the 11-beta-hydroxylation reaction in the adrenal cortex. This leads to an increase in adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) production by the pituitary, resulting in a marked elevation of cortisol and corticosterone precursors in the plasma and urine. Metopirone may also suppress biosynthesis of aldosterone, resulting in a mild natriuresis. The pharmacological effect of metopirone is to reduce cortisol and corticosterone production by inhibiting the enzymatic steps leading to their production in the adrenal cortex. This feedback mechanism exerted by cortisol results in an increase in adrenocortical secretion of their immediate precursors, 11-desoxycortisol and desoxycorticosterone, which are weak suppressors of ACTH release, and a corresponding elevation of these steroids in the plasma and of their metabolites in the urine. The drug is administered orally and has a half-life of 1.9 ±0.7 hours. Metopirone is part of Cytochrome P-450 CYP2A6 Inhibitors, Cytochrome P-450 CYP2E1 Inhibitors, Cytochrome P-450 CYP3A Inducers, and Cytochrome P-450 CYP3A Inhibitors.

The mechanism of action of metopirone is as follows: the pharmacological effect of metopirone is to reduce cortisol and corticosterone production by inhibiting the enzymatic steps leading to their production in the adrenal cortex. This feedback mechanism exerted by cortisol results in an increase in adrenocortical secretion of their immediate precursors, 11-desoxycortisol and desoxycorticosterone, which are weak suppressors of ACTH release, and a corresponding elevation of these steroids in the plasma and of their metabolites in the urine.

In conclusion, metopirone is an inhibitor of the enzyme steroid 11-beta-monooxygenase, which is used as a diagnostic test to evaluate the feedback hypothalamic-pituitary mechanism in the diagnosis of Cushing syndrome. The drug works by reducing cortisol and corticosterone production by inhibiting the 11-beta-hydroxylation reaction in the adrenal cortex, leading to an increase in adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) production by the pituitary, resulting in a marked elevation of cortisol and corticosterone precursors in the plasma and urine. Metopirone may also suppress biosynthesis of aldosterone, resulting in a mild natriuresis. This feedback mechanism exerted by cortisol results in an increase in adrenocortical secretion of their immediate precursors, 11-desoxycortisol and desoxycorticosterone, which are weak suppressors of ACTH release, and a corresponding elevation of these steroids in the plasma and of their metabolites in the urine.
Mibefradil:
Mibefradil is a tetralol calcium channel blocking agent that was withdrawn from the market in 1998 due to potentially harmful interactions with other drugs. It was initially developed for the treatment of angina and high blood pressure, as it works by inhibiting the influx of calcium ions across both the T (low-voltage) and L (high-voltage) calcium channels of cardiac and vascular smooth muscle. Mibefradil causes vasodilation in vascular smooth muscle, leading to a decrease in peripheral vascular resistance and a resulting decrease in blood pressure. It also slows sinus and atrioventricular (AV) node conduction, producing a slight reduction in heart rate and a slight increase in the PR interval. The mechanism by which mibefradil reduces angina is not known, but it is thought to be attributed to a reduction in heart rate, total peripheral resistance (afterload), and the heart rate-systolic blood pressure product at any given level of exercise. The result of these effects is a decrease in cardiac workload and myocardial oxygen demand. Mibefradil has a molecular weight of 495.64, topological polar surface area (TPSA) of 67.45, and logP value of 6.36. It belongs to the group of medicines called calcium channel blocking agents or more commonly, calcium channel blockers, and its chemical structure is a benzimidazoyl-substituted tetraline. Mibefradil is primarily bound to alpha 1-acid glycoprotein with a protein binding of ≥ 99%.

Mechanism of Action: Mibefradil works by inhibiting the influx of calcium ions across both the T (low-voltage) and L (high-voltage) calcium channels of cardiac and vascular smooth muscle. This leads to vasodilation in vascular smooth muscle, resulting in a decrease in peripheral vascular resistance and a subsequent decrease in blood pressure. Additionally, mibefradil slows sinus and atrioventricular (AV) node conduction, producing a slight reduction in heart rate and a slight increase in the PR interval.

Clinical Indication: Mibefradil was initially developed for the treatment of angina and high blood pressure. Its withdrawal from the market was due to potentially harmful interactions with other drugs.

Protein Binding: Mibefradil has a protein binding of ≥ 99%, primarily to alpha 1-acid glycoprotein.

Pharmacodynamics: Mibefradil belongs to a group of medicines called calcium channel blocking agents, or more commonly, calcium channel blockers. Calcium channel blocking agents affect the movement of calcium into the cells of the heart and blood vessels. As a result, they relax blood vessels and increase the supply of blood and oxygen to the heart while reducing its workload. Mibefradil is a benzimidazoyl-substituted tetraline that selectively binds and inhibits T-type calcium channels.

Physical State: Mibefradil is a solid.

Half-life: The half-life of mibefradil at steady state is 17 to 25 hours.
Hydrocortisone succinate:
Hydrocortisone succinate is a corticosteroid drug that belongs to the class of glucocorticoids. It is a synthetic version of hydrocortisone, which is produced by the adrenal cortex in the human body. Hydrocortisone succinate is used to treat a variety of conditions, including inflammatory disorders such as allergic reactions, asthma, and eczema, as well as colitis, lupus erythematosus, and rheumatoid arthritis. It works by reducing the activity of the immune system, which helps to reduce inflammation and prevent tissue damage. Hydrocortisone succinate is also used to treat adrenal insufficiency, a condition in which the adrenal glands do not produce enough cortisol, a hormone that is essential for maintaining blood sugar levels, blood pressure, and metabolism.

Hydrocortisone succinate is available in a variety of formulations, including oral tablets, capsules, and liquid solutions, as well as topical creams and ointments. It is typically taken once or twice daily, depending on the condition being treated and the severity of the symptoms. The drug is metabolized by the liver and excreted primarily in the feces, with a small amount excreted in the urine. Hydrocortisone succinate has several side effects, including weight gain, mood changes, and increased risk of infections. It can also cause more serious side effects, such as Cushing's syndrome, a condition in which the body produces too much cortisol, and osteoporosis, a condition in which the bones become weak and brittle.

Mechanistically, hydrocortisone succinate works by binding to glucocorticoid receptors in the nucleus of cells, where it regulates the expression of genes involved in inflammation and immune response. It also inhibits the production of pro-inflammatory cytokines, such as tumor necrosis factor-alpha (TNF-alpha) and interleukin-1 beta (IL-1beta), which are involved in the inflammatory response. By reducing inflammation, hydrocortisone succinate helps to prevent tissue damage and promote healing.

In terms of pharmacokinetics, hydrocortisone succinate is metabolized by the liver enzyme cytochrome P-450 (CYP) 3A, which is responsible for its induction. The drug's half-life is approximately 2-3 hours, and it is excreted primarily in the feces. Hydrocortisone succinate is also a substrate for the drug transporter P-glycoprotein (P-gp), which is responsible for its transport across cell membranes.

In terms of clinical uses, hydrocortisone succinate is used to treat a variety of inflammatory conditions, including allergic reactions, asthma, and eczema. It is also used to treat colitis, lupus erythematosus, and rheumatoid arthritis. Hydrocortisone succinate has been shown to be effective in reducing inflammation and improving symptoms in these conditions.

In terms of drug interactions, hydrocortisone succinate can interact with a variety of drugs, including warfarin, diazepam, and phenytoin. These interactions can affect the metabolism and efficacy of the drug, and may increase the risk of side effects. Patients should inform their healthcare provider of all medications they are taking, including over-the-counter medications and supplements, to avoid potential interactions.

In summary, hydrocortisone succinate is a corticosteroid drug that is used to treat a variety of inflammatory conditions. It works by reducing the activity of the immune system and is available in several formulations. The drug has several side effects and can interact with other medications, so patients should inform their healthcare provider of all medications they are taking.
Levomefolic acid: Levomefolic acid is an active metabolite of folic acid, playing a crucial role in one-carbon metabolism reactions. It is primarily found in the bloodstream and tissues, where it regulates important cellular functions such as DNA synthesis, gene expression regulation, amino acid synthesis and metabolism, and myelin synthesis and repair. As a unique form of folate that can cross the blood-brain barrier, it acts as a cofactor in the production of monoamine neurotransmitters such as dopamine, serotonin, and norepinephrine. The mean elimination half-life is approximately 3 hours after oral administration for 7 days. Levomefolic acid has a topological polar surface area of 198.48 and log p value of -2.25. It is available commercially as the crystalline form of the calcium salt (Metafolin(R)), which provides stability required for supplementation. Supplementation with levomefolic acid is preferred over folic acid due to its reduced potential for masking vitamin B12 deficiency symptoms. Levomefolic acid has been approved and investigational for various clinical indications, including the treatment and prevention of folate deficiency, antidote against folic acid antagonists, and adjunct therapy for patients undergoing antidepressant pharmacotherapy. It is also being studied for its potential use in cardiovascular diseases.
Polaprezinc: Polaprezinc is a chelated form of zinc and L-carnosine, approved for the first time in Japan for the treatment of gastric ulcers. It has been found to be effective in pressure ulcer treatment and may also be useful against small intestine mucosal injury associated with long-term aspirin therapy. The mechanism of action of polaprezinc involves increasing the expression of various antioxidant enzymes, including superoxide dismutase 1 (SOD-1), SOD-2, heme oxygenase-1 (HO-1), glutathione S-transferase (GST), glutathione peroxidase (GSH-px), peroxidredoxin-1 (PRDX1; PRXI) and PRXD5 (PRXV). This promotes tissue healing by eliminating free radicals. Polaprezinc is a solid with a molecular weight of 289.6 and a half-life of approximately 2 hours in rats. It belongs to the categories of Amino Acids, Peptides, and Proteins; Anti-Ulcer Agents; Dipeptides; Gastrointestinal Agents; Metal cations; Metal divalent cations; Nerve Tissue Proteins; Neuropeptides; Oligopeptides; Peptides; Proteins; Zinc Compounds. Currently, polaprezinc is experimental and has not been approved for clinical use outside of Japan.
Brexanolone:
Brexanolone is a synthetic neuroactive steroid that has been approved by the US FDA as the brand name product Zulresso for the treatment of postpartum depression (PPD) in adult females. It is the first drug to have ever been approved specifically for the treatment of PPD, a life-threatening condition characterized by feelings of sadness, worthlessness or guilt, cognitive impairment, and/or suicidal ideation. Studies have shown that PPD can have profound negative effects on the maternal-infant bond and later infant development. Brexanolone works by potentiating GABA-mediated currents at synaptic and extrasynaptic GABA(a) receptors, leading to an increase in the activity of GABA at these receptors. This mechanism of action is distinct from that of benzodiazepines, which bind to a different binding site on GABA(a) receptors. The plasma protein binding of brexanolone is greater than 99%, and its terminal half-life is approximately 9 hours. Brexanolone is part of the Anesthetics, Anticonvulsants, Biopolymers, Central Nervous System Agents, Central Nervous System Depressants, Compounds used in a research, industrial, or household setting, Corpus Luteum Hormones, Cyclodextrins, Dextrins, Diet, Food, and Nutrition, and Drug Categories categories.

Brexanolone is indicated for the treatment of postpartum depression in adult females, and its development and availability provide a new and promising therapy where few existed before. The mechanism of action of brexanolone is believed to involve potentiation of GABA-mediated currents at synaptic and extrasynaptic GABA(a) receptors, leading to an increase in the activity of GABA at these receptors. This action is distinct from that of benzodiazepines, which bind to a different binding site on GABA(a) receptors. The plasma protein binding of brexanolone is greater than 99%, and its terminal half-life is approximately 9 hours.

Brexanolone is a synthetic neuroactive steroid that occurs naturally in the body when the female sex hormone progesterone is metabolized. It has been shown to exhibit activity as a barbiturate-like, positive allosteric modulator of both synaptic and extrasynaptic GABA(a) receptors. The binding site of brexanolone on GABA(a) receptors is distinct from that of benzodiazepines, which bind to a different binding site on GABA(a) receptors.

Brexanolone has been approved and investigational for the treatment of postpartum depression in adult females. Its development and availability provide a new and promising therapy where few existed before. Brexanolone is part of the Anesthetics, Anticonvulsants, Biopolymers, Central Nervous System Agents, Central Nervous System Depressants, Compounds used in a research, industrial, or household setting, Corpus Luteum Hormones, Cyclodextrins, Dextrins, Diet, Food, and Nutrition, and Drug Categories categories.
Oxaliplatin:
Oxaliplatin is a platinum-based chemotherapy drug that belongs to the same family as cisplatin and carboplatin. It is typically administered in combination with fluorouracil and leucovorin, known as Folfox, for the treatment of colorectal cancer. Compared to cisplatin, oxaliplatin has two amine groups replaced by cyclohexyldiamine, which enhances its antitumor activity. The chlorine ligands are replaced by oxalate derived from oxalic acid, improving water solubility. Oxaliplatin is marketed under the trademark Eloxatin by Sanofi-Aventis.

Oxaliplatin works by undergoing non-enzymatic conversion to active derivatives via displacement of the labile oxalate ligand, leading to formation of transient reactive species that covalently bind with macromolecules. These species then bind preferentially to guanine and cytosine moieties of DNA, causing cross-linking and inhibition of DNA synthesis and transcription. The drug also binds irreversibly to albumin and gamma-globulins, and to a lesser extent to erythrocytes.

Oxaliplatin selectively inhibits the synthesis of deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) by binding preferentially to guanine and cytosine moieties. The molecular weight of oxaliplatin is 397.29, and it has a triphasic decline in ultrafilterable platinum levels following administration, with two distribution phases and a long terminal elimination phase.

Oxaliplatin is part of Antineoplastic Agents, specifically Antineoplastic and Immunomodulating Agents, BCRP/ABCG2 Substrates, Coordination Complexes, Immunosuppressive Agents, Moderate Risk QTc-Prolonging Agents, Myelosuppressive Agents, Narrow Therapeutic Index Drugs, and OCT2 Substrates. It is approved for use in the treatment of advanced carcinoma of the colon or rectum and adjuvant treatment of stage III colon cancer patients who have undergone complete resection of the primary tumor.
Carboplatin:
Carboplatin is an organoplatinum compound that possesses antineoplastic activity. It is indicated for the initial treatment of advanced ovarian carcinoma in combination with other approved chemotherapeutic agents, and for the palliative treatment of patients with ovarian carcinoma recurrent after prior chemotherapy, including those who have been previously treated with cisplatin. Carboplatin works by three different mechanisms: attaching alkyl groups to DNA bases, forming cross-links between DNA strands, and inducing mispairing of nucleotides leading to mutations. It is not bound to plasma protein but the platinum itself from carboplatin irreversibly binds to plasma proteins and is slowly eliminated with a minimum half-life of 5 days. Carboplatin is an antineoplastic agent that belongs to the class of alkylating agents, which stop tumor growth by cross-linking guanine bases in DNA double-helix strands directly attacking DNA. It is cell cycle-nonspecific and works by three different mechanisms all of which achieve the same end result - disruption of DNA function and cell death.

Carboplatin has a molecular weight of 371.26 and a topological polar surface area of 107.88. It is part of Antineoplastic Agents; Antineoplastic and Immunomodulating Agents; BCRP/ABCG2 Substrates; Compounds used in a research, industrial, or household setting; Cross-Linking Reagents; Drugs that are Mainly Renally Excreted; Immunosuppressive Agents; Indicators and Reagents. Carboplatin is approved for use in clinical settings.
Busulfan: Busulfan is a bifunctional alkylating agent that has a selective immunosuppressive effect on the bone marrow. It is not a structural analog of the nitrogen mustards, but rather an alkylating agent that contains 2 labile methanesulfonate groups attached to opposite ends of a 4-carbon alkyl chain. Once hydrolyzed, these groups produce carbonium ions that alkylate DNA, leading to disruption of nucleic acid function and ultimately cell death. Busulfan is used in the palliative treatment of chronic myeloid leukemia, but it does not provide permanent remission. According to the Fourth Annual Report on Carcinogens, busulfan is listed as a known carcinogen. Its mechanism of action involves the alkylation of DNA through guanine-adenine intrastrand crosslinks, which cannot be repaired by cellular machinery and leads to apoptosis. Overexpression of MGST2, a glutathione s-transferase, is thought to confer resistance to busulfan. Busulfan is part of several drug categories, including Acids, Noncarboxylic Alcohols, and Alkylating Drugs. It has a molecular weight of 246.29, topological polar surface area of 86.74, and log p value of -0.59. Busulfan is approved and investigational for use in conditioning regimens prior to allogeneic hematopoietic progenitor cell transplantation for chronic myelogenous leukemia, as well as for bone marrow transplantation for acute myeloid leukemia and nonmalignant diseases.
Curcumin:
Curcumin, a highly pleiotropic molecule, exhibits antibacterial, anti-inflammatory, hypoglycemic, antioxidant, wound-healing, and antimicrobial activities. Despite proven efficacy against numerous experimental models, poor bioavailability due to poor absorption, rapid metabolism, and rapid systemic elimination have been shown to limit the therapeutic efficacy of curcumin. Investigated for the treatment and supportive care of various clinical conditions including proteinuria, breast cancer, multiple myeloma, depression, and Non Small Cell Lung Cancer (NSCLC), curcumin acts as a scavenger of oxygen species, inhibiting lipid peroxidation and peroxide-induced DNA damage. Via modulating various signalling molecules, it suppresses key elements in cellular signal transduction pathways pertinent to growth, differentiation, and malignant transformation. Curcumin may exert choleretic effects by increasing biliary excretion of bile salts, cholesterol, and bilirubin, as well as increasing bile solubility. Intravenous application of 25 mg/kg bw curcumin to rats resulted in an increase in bile flow by 80 and 120%. In the rat model of inflammation, curcumin was shown to inhibit edema formation. In nude mouse that had been injected subcutaneously with prostate cancer cells, administration of curcumin caused a marked decrease in the extent of cell proliferation, a significant increase of apoptosis and micro-vessel density. Curcumin inhibited arachidonic acid-induced platelet aggregation _in vitro_.

Curcumin is under investigation for the treatment and supportive care of various clinical conditions including mucositis, rectal cancer, prostate cancer, chronic schizophrenia, and Mild Cognitive Impairment (MCI). Its mechanism of action involves modulating various signalling molecules, inhibiting lipid peroxidation, and suppressing key elements in cellular signal transduction pathways pertinent to growth, differentiation, and malignant transformation. The drug is poorly absorbed due to rapid metabolism and systemic elimination, leading to limited therapeutic efficacy. However, its antibacterial, anti-inflammatory, hypoglycemic, antioxidant, wound-healing, and antimicrobial activities make it a promising candidate for various clinical applications. Further research is necessary to overcome the limitations of curcumin's bioavailability and improve its therapeutic efficacy.
Chlorambucil: Chlorambucil is a nitrogen mustard alkylating agent used as an antineoplastic agent for the treatment of various malignant and nonmalignant diseases. Although it is less toxic than most other nitrogen mustards, it has been listed as a known carcinogen in the Fourth Annual Report on Carcinogens (NTP 85-002, 1985). Chlorambucil works by three different mechanisms: attachment of alkyl groups to DNA bases, resulting in the DNA being fragmented by repair enzymes in their attempts to replace the alkylated bases, preventing DNA synthesis and RNA transcription from the affected DNA; DNA damage via the formation of cross-links which prevents DNA from being separated for synthesis or transcription; and the induction of mispairing of the nucleotides leading to mutations. Chlorambucil is an antineoplastic in the class of alkylating agents that is used to treat various forms of cancer, including chronic lymphatic (lymphocytic) leukemia, childhood minimal-change nephrotic syndrome, and malignant lymphomas including lymphosarcoma, giant follicular lymphoma, Hodgkin's disease, non-Hodgkin's lymphomas, and Waldenström’s Macroglobulinemia. Chlorambucil is a solid with a molecular weight of 304.21 and a topological polar surface area of 40.54. The half-life of chlorambucil is 1.5 hours, and its log p value is 3.63. Chlorambucil is part of Agents that reduce seizure threshold; Alkylating Activity; Alkylating Drugs; Antineoplastic Agents; Antineoplastic Agents, Alkylating; Antineoplastic and Immunomodulating Agents; Hydrocarbons, Halogenated; Immunosuppressive Agents; Mustard Compounds; Myelosuppressive Drugs. Chlorambucil is approved for use in medical practice.
Hydrogen Peroxide:
Hydrogen peroxide is a simple peroxide compound with the chemical formula H2O2. It is an unstable substance that can undergo potentially explosive thermal decomposition when heated to its boiling point. In the body, hydrogen peroxide is produced during the reduction of oxygen through a two-electron transfer reaction. As a natural byproduct of metabolism, it readily undergoes decomposition by catalase in normal cells. Hydrogen peroxide is widely used as a disinfectant and sterilizer, exhibiting antimicrobial properties against most microorganisms, including dormant forms with known high resistance profiles such as bacterial spores and protozoal cysts. The oxidizing radical generated in the Fenton reaction is thought to be the basis of its biocidal actions, leading to oxidative damage to proteins, membrane lipids, and DNA via oxidation.

As a liquid, hydrogen peroxide has a molecular weight of 34.01 and a topological polar surface area (TPSA) of 40.46. It belongs to several drug categories including Alimentary Tract and Metabolism, Anions, Anti-Infective Agents, Local, Antifibrinolytic Agents, Antiinfectives and Antiseptics for Local Oral Treatment, Antiseptics and Disinfectants, and Compounds used in research, industrial or household settings. Hydrogen peroxide is approved and veterinary-approved for use as a disinfectant and sterilizer. Its mechanism of action involves the generation of free hydroxyl radicals through the Fenton reaction, leading to oxidative damage to microorganisms.
Selenious acid:
Selenious acid is a solid form of sodium selenite, a selenium-containing compound. It plays an essential role in protecting cells from oxidative damage caused by peroxides produced during cellular metabolism due to its component glutathione peroxidase. The half-life of selenious acid has been observed to be 30 days in beagle dogs. Selenious acid belongs to several drug categories, including Alimentary Tract and Metabolism, Diet, Food, and Nutrition, Drugs that are Mainly Renally Excreted, Food, Food and Beverages, Growth Substances, Micronutrients, Mineral Supplements, Minerals, Physiological Phenomena, Replacement Preparations, Selenium Compounds, and is approved and investigational.

As a medical and pharmaceutical expert, I can explain that selenious acid is a vital compound in the body's defense against oxidative stress. It does this by serving as a component of glutathione peroxidase, an enzyme that protects cells from damage caused by peroxides produced during cellular metabolism. The half-life of selenious acid has been observed to be 30 days in beagle dogs, indicating its relatively long duration of action. Selenious acid is classified under various drug categories, highlighting its diverse functions and applications. While it is approved for use in some contexts, it is also investigational, suggesting ongoing research into its potential therapeutic benefits. Overall, selenious acid plays a crucial role in maintaining the body's antioxidant defenses and protecting against oxidative stress.
Indocyanine Green:
Indocyanine Green is a water-soluble, tricarbocyanine dye with a peak spectral absorption at 800 nm. It has a chemical name of 1 H-Benzindolium, 2-indol-2-ylidene]-1,3,5-heptatrienyl]-1,1-dimethyl-3-(4-sulfobutyl)-,hydroxide, inner salt, sodium salt. The drug is formulated as a sterile lyophilized powder and has a pH of approximately 6.5 when reconstituted. Each vial contains 25 mg of Indocyanine Green with no more than 5% sodium iodide. Indocyanine Green for Injection USP is primarily used to determine cardiac output, hepatic function, and liver blood flow. The drug undergoes negligible extrahepatic or enterohepatic circulation and is taken up almost exclusively by the hepatic parenchymal cells, which then secrete it into the bile. After biliary obstruction, the dye appears in the hepatic lymph, suggesting that the biliary mucosa is intact but allows diffusion of bilirubin. The drug has a half-life of 150 to 180 seconds and is approved for use as an index of hepatic function. Indocyanine Green acid form is part of BSEP/ABCB11 Substrates, Cardiac Function, Coloring Agents, Compounds used in a research, industrial, or household setting, Liver Function, Roentgenography.

Indocyanine Green is a valuable tool for assessing hepatic function and cardiac output. Its ability to be taken up almost exclusively by the hepatic parenchymal cells and secreted into the bile makes it an ideal dye for determining liver blood flow. The drug's half-life of 150 to 180 seconds allows for accurate measurements of cardiac output, and its negligible extrahepatic or enterohepatic circulation reduces the risk of false positives or negatives in hepatic function tests. Additionally, Indocyanine Green's use in research, industrial, or household settings makes it a versatile tool for various applications. Overall, Indocyanine Green is an important drug with a wide range of clinical indications and uses.
Esculin:
Esculin is a bioflavanoid found in various plant species, including barley and the horse chestnut. It belongs to the glycoside family, consisting of a sugar group bonded through its anomeric carbon to another group via a C-, S-, N-, O-, or Se-glycosidic bond. Esculin has been identified as a vasoprotective agent with a range of pharmacological properties, including capillary protection, inhibition of catabolic enzymes, and antioxidant activity. Topical application of esculin increases capillary density and improves the morphological aspect of smallest blood vessels, with an absorption half-life of approximately 1 hour and an elimination half-life of around 20 hours. Esculin is approved for use in various medical applications, including after sun treatments.

Pharmacodynamics: Esculin's primary mechanism of action is its ability to improve capillary permeability and fragility. It achieves this by inhibiting enzymes such as hyaluronidase and collagenase, thus preserving the integrity of the perivascular connective tissue. Additionally, esculin exhibits antioxidant properties, protecting triglycerides against auto-oxidation at high temperatures. This may contribute to its anti-inflammatory activity, making it a suitable product for various medical applications.

Physical State: Esculin is a solid at room temperature.

Half-life: The absorption half-life of esculin is approximately 1 hour, while the elimination half-life is around 20 hours.

Drug Categories: Esculin belongs to several drug categories, including benzopyrans, carbohydrates, coumarins, glucosides, glycosides, heterocyclic compounds, fused-ring pyrans.

Approval Status: Esculin is approved for use in various medical applications.
Levomethamphetamine:
Levomethamphetamine is a sympathomimetic vasoconstrictor used in some over-the-counter (OTC) nasal decongestant inhalers in the United States. It is the L-enantiomer of methamphetamine and works by crossing the blood-brain-barrier and acting as a TAAR1 agonist, functioning as a selective norepinephrine releasing agent in the central nervous system. This results in increased vasocontriction, which can help alleviate nasal congestion. The elimination half-life of levomethamphetamine is between 13.3 and 15 hours, and it has a molecular weight of 149.24 and a topological polar surface area of 12.03. Levomethamphetamine has a logP value of 1.89. It is approved for use in OTC nasal decongestant inhalers.

Mechanism of Action:
Levomethamphetamine works by crossing the blood-brain-barrier and binding to TAAR1 receptors, which are found in the central nervous system. This binding leads to the release of norepinephrine from noradrenergic neurons, resulting in increased vasocontriction. The mechanism of action is thought to be due to the activation of alpha-2 adrenergic receptors on smooth muscle cells in blood vessels, leading to vasoconstriction and decreased blood flow to the nasal passages.

Clinical Uses:
Levomethamphetamine is primarily used as a decongestant in OTC nasal inhalers. It is effective in reducing nasal congestion caused by colds, allergies, and other conditions. The drug's ability to reduce nasal secretions and increase blood flow to the nasal passages makes it a useful treatment option for individuals experiencing difficulty breathing through their nose.

Pharmacokinetics:
The elimination half-life of levomethamphetamine is between 13.3 and 15 hours, which means that the body takes approximately this amount of time to remove the drug completely. The molecular weight of levomethamphetamine is 149.24, and its topological polar surface area is 12.03. These properties may affect the drug's absorption, distribution, metabolism, and excretion.

Toxicology:
Levomethamphetamine has been shown to be toxic to the central nervous system in high doses. The drug can cause cardiovascular problems, such as hypertension and tachycardia, as well as neurological symptoms like tremors and convulsions. Prolonged use of levomethamphetamine can lead to dependence and addiction.

Drug Interactions:
Levomethamphetamine may interact with other medications, including those used to treat hypertension, depression, and anxiety. It is important to inform a healthcare provider of any medications being taken, as these interactions can have serious consequences.

Common Side Effects:
Common side effects of levomethamphetamine include headache, fatigue, and insomnia. Less common side effects may include nausea, vomiting, and increased heart rate. In rare cases, more serious side effects such as stroke, heart attack, and seizures can occur.

Drug Category:
Levomethamphetamine is a sympathomimetic drug that belongs to the category of vasoconstrictors. It works by increasing norepinephrine release in the central nervous system, leading to increased vasocontriction and decreased blood flow to the nasal passages.

Therapeutic Indications:
Levomethamphetamine is primarily used as a decongestant in OTC nasal inhalers. It is effective in reducing nasal congestion caused by colds, allergies, and other conditions. The drug's ability to reduce nasal secretions and increase blood flow to the nasal passages makes it a useful treatment option for individuals experiencing difficulty breathing through their nose.

Adverse Reactions:
Common side effects of levomethamphetamine include headache, fatigue, and insomnia. Less common side effects may include nausea, vomiting, and increased heart rate. In rare cases, more serious side effects such as stroke, heart attack, and seizures can occur.

Drug/Substance History:
Levomethamphetamine has a long history of use as a decongestant in OTC nasal inhalers. It was first introduced in the 1950s and has been widely used since then. The drug's popularity has led to its widespread availability and use, making it a common treatment option for individuals experiencing nasal congestion.

Contraindications:
Levomethamphetamine is contraindicated in individuals with known hypersensitivity to the drug or any of its components. It should also be used with caution in individuals with a history of cardiovascular disease, hypertension, or anxiety disorders. Pregnant or breastfeeding women should avoid using levomethamphetamine, as its safety during pregnancy and lactation has not been established.

Drug/Substance Use During Pregnancy:
The safety of levomethamphetamine use during pregnancy has not been established. As a sympathomimetic drug, it may cross the placenta and affect fetal development. Therefore, pregnant women should avoid using levomethamphetamine unless absolutely necessary and under the close supervision of a healthcare provider.

Drug/Substance Use During Lactation:
It is not known whether levomethamphetamine passes into breast milk or what effects it may have on an infant. Therefore, breastfeeding women should avoid using levomethamphetamine and consult with a healthcare provider for alternative treatments.

In summary, levomethamphetamine is a sympathomimetic vasoconstrictor used in OTC nasal decongestant inhalers. It works by crossing the blood-brain-barrier and binding to TAAR1 receptors, leading to increased norepinephrine release and vasocontriction. The drug has a elimination half-life of between 13.3 and 15 hours, a molecular weight of 149.24, and a topological polar surface area of 12.03. Common side effects include headache, fatigue, and insomnia, while more serious side effects such as stroke, heart attack, and seizures can occur in rare cases. Levomethamphetamine is contraindicated in individuals with known hypersensitivity to the drug or any of its components, and should be used with caution in individuals with a history of cardiovascular disease, hypertension, or anxiety disorders. Pregnant or breastfeeding women should avoid using levomethamphetamine unless absolutely necessary and under the close supervision of a healthcare provider.
Trastuzumab deruxtecan: Trastuzumab deruxtecan is a HER-2 directed antibody attached to a topoisomerase inhibitor that has been approved for use in certain types of metastatic, unresectable breast cancer. It is classified as an antibody-drug conjugate and distinguishes itself from other members of its class through the use of a cleavable peptide linker. Trastuzumab deruxtecan has been granted FDA approval for specific patients with HER-2 positive breast cancer who have failed other treatments. The drug works by binding to HER2 found on malignant cells, followed by internalization and linker cleavage through lysosomal enzymes. After release through cleavage, the small molecule portion of the drug, deruxtecan (DXd), causes targeted DNA damage and apoptosis in cancer cells due to its ability to cross cell membranes. The protein binding of Dxd is estimated at 97%. Trastuzumab deruxtecan demonstrates antitumor activity against certain types of HER2 positive breast cancer, although clinical trials are still ongoing to confirm its efficacy. The median elimination half-life of trastuzumab deruxtecan is about 5.8 days. Trastuzumab deruxtecan belongs to the categories of Amino Acids, Peptides, and Proteins; Antibodies; Antibodies, Monoclonal; BCRP/ABCG2 Substrates; Blood Proteins; Cytochrome P-450 CYP3A Substrates; Cytochrome P-450 CYP3A4 Substrates; Cytochrome P-450 Substrates; Globulins; Immunoglobulins; Immunoproteins. Trastuzumab deruxtecan is both approved and investigational.
Chondroitin sulfate:
Chondroitin sulfate is a glycosaminoglycan commonly used as a symptomatic slow-acting drug for osteoarthritis (SYSADOA). It has been shown to provide pain relief and increased joint mobility after regular administration, with a long-lasting effect even after treatment has ended. Chondroitin sulfate is composed of alternating 1,3-N-acetyl-β-d-galactosamine and 1,4-β-d-glucuronic acid units, which are linked together through 4-O- and/or 6-O-sulfations. The specific pattern of these sulfations can affect the drug's biological activities. Chondroitin sulfate is available as an over-the-counter dietary supplement in North America and as a prescription drug under the European Medicines Agency (EMA).

The clinical indication for chondroitin sulfate is the alleviation of pain and inflammation from primary osteoarthritis. It has been shown to improve joint function and slow disease progression, making it a valuable treatment option for those suffering from this condition. Osteoarthritis is characterized by progressive structural and metabolic changes in joint tissues, including cartilage degradation, subchondral bone sclerosis, and inflammation of the synovial membrane.

Chondroitin sulfate functions within the intricate extracellular matrix, providing new building blocks for synthesis. It is believed that this supply of chondroitin sulfate can help restore damaged joint tissues, leading to improved pain and function. The mechanism of action of chondroitin sulfate is not fully understood, but it is thought to have anti-inflammatory properties by reducing synovitis and preventing pro-inflammatory cytokine up-regulation in arthritis models.

The protein binding of chondroitin sulfate has been reported to be very low, at only 0.23% of the total protein. This suggests that the drug is unlikely to cause significant changes in plasma protein levels. Chondroitin sulfate has a slow onset of action and a maximal effect attained after several months of treatment, making it a long-term therapy option for osteoarthritis management.

In conclusion, chondroitin sulfate is a glycosaminoglycan with a well-established clinical indication for the alleviation of pain and inflammation from primary osteoarthritis. Its slow onset of action and long-lasting effect make it a valuable treatment option for those suffering from this condition. Further research is needed to fully understand the mechanism of action of chondroitin sulfate and its potential as a therapeutic agent.
Propacetamol: Propacetamol is a non-opioid analgesic drug that has been widely used in other countries since 1985. It is a prodrug of paracetamol, meaning it is completely hydrolyzed to paracetamol after administration. As a result, the mechanism of action of propacetamol is directly linked to the activity of paracetamol, which inhibits prostaglandin synthesis by inhibiting COX-1 and COX-2. This inhibition leads to a low anti-inflammatory activity, making it less effective in high inflammatory conditions such as rheumatoid arthritis. However, propacetamol presents a weak inhibition of COX-1 and COX-2, which translates into a mild analgesic and antipyretic activity. Additionally, propacetamol can form N-arachidonoylphenolamine, an activator of capsaicin receptor (TRPV1) and cannabinoid CB1, contributing to its analgesic properties. The half-life of propacetamol is 3.6 hours, and it has a topological polar surface area of 58.64 and a logP value of 1.66. Propacetamol belongs to the categories of Acetaminophen and Prodrugs; Acetanilides; Agents causing hyperkalemia; Agents that produce hypertension; Amides; Amines; Analgesics; Analgesics, Non-Narcotic; Anilides; Aniline Compounds; Anti-Inflammatory Agents; Anti-Inflammatory Agents, Non-Steroidal; Antirheum. Propacetamol is experimental and not approved for use in the United States.
Vayarin:
Vayarin is a prescription medical food for the clinical dietary management of certain lipid imbalances associated with attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) in children. It contains Lipirinen, a proprietary composition of phosphatidylserine-omega 3, EPA (eicosapentaenoic acid), and docosahexaenoic acid (DHA). The exact mechanism by which Vayarin exerts its effects is not fully understood, but it is believed to regulate important proteins in neuronal cell membranes, influence neurotransmitter activity, and increase brain glucose concentrations. Administration of specially processed formulations consisting of PS conjugated to omega-3 fatty acids was found to significantly increase DHA levels in the brain tissue of rats. Vayarin is currently available only by prescription in the USA and has also been used for management of hypertriglyceridemia.

Vayarin is part of Cytochrome P-450 CYP2E1 Inhibitors, Cytochrome P-450 CYP2E1 Inhibitors (strength unknown), and Cytochrome P-450 Enzyme Inhibitors. Its half-life is approximately 2 hours, and it is approved and investigational.

The mechanism of action of Vayarin involves the regulation of important proteins in neuronal cell membranes, including sodium/calcium ATPase and protein kinase C, which perform crucial functions in many signal transduction pathways. PS interacts with Raf-1 protein kinase to promote a cascade of reactions that are believed to be involved in the survival of cells. Additionally, PS influences neurotransmitter activity, such as the release of acetylcholine (Ach), dopamine, and noradrenaline. It is also thought to increase brain glucose concentrations.

In children with ADHD, circulating concentrations of omega-3 long-chain polyunsaturated fatty acids are lower compared to healthy children of the same age. These lipids play an essential role in central nervous system development and function, and their deficiency is directly associated with decreased brain phosphatidylserine. Vayarin contains PS conjugated to omega-3 fatty acids, which was found to significantly increase DHA levels in the brain tissue of rats.

The clinical indication for Vayarin is ADHD in children, and it has also been used for management of hypertriglyceridemia. The drug is available only by prescription in the USA, and its safety and efficacy have been studied in clinical trials.
Evening primrose oil: Evening primrose oil is a liquid dietary supplement derived from the seeds of the Oenothera biennis plant. It contains a variety of essential fatty acids, including gamma-linolenic acid (GLA), which is thought to be the key active ingredient. Evening primrose oil has been approved in over-the-counter dietary supplements by Health Canada and the European Medicines Agency (EMA), but its status as a new dietary ingredient in the United States is currently "Inadequate basis for expectation of safety" according to the Food and Drug Administration (FDA). The oil is used to improve the essential fatty acid content in plasma, erythrocyte, and platelet lipids, as well as to increase alpha-tocopherol levels in non-diabetic and type I diabetic patients. It also serves as a prostaglandin precursor and has been shown to affect the fatty acid composition of serum lipids and adipose tissue. Administration of evening primrose oil is part of long-term therapy, and thus, immediate results are not expected. The drug is classified as an agent that reduces seizure threshold, anti-inflammatory agent, antirheumatic agent, biological product, central nervous system agent, complex mixture, dermatological, dietary fat, and nutraceutical.
Strontium chloride (Sr-89):
Strontium chloride (Sr-89) is a paliative therapeutic option used to relieve pain from bone metastases, specifically in cases of metastatic castrate-resistant prostate cancer. It works by concentrating in areas of increased osteogenesis, similar to calcium divalent ion, and binds to plasma proteins. Once combined with external beam radiotherapy, it emits β particles with a maximum range in tissue of 6-8mm, reducing new bone metastases and producing an analgesic role. The half-life of Sr-89 is 50.5 days, allowing for multiple doses to be administered over a prolonged period. As a liquid, it can be easily administered through various routes, including intravenously or intramuscularly. Despite its potential tumoricidal effect, there have been reports of apparent tumor regression in some patients. However, further research is needed to fully understand the mechanism of action and optimal usage of Sr-89.

In clinical trials, Sr-89 has been shown to provide significant pain relief and improved quality of life for patients with bone metastases. The drug's ability to bind to plasma proteins and its long half-life make it an attractive option for patients who require prolonged treatment. Additionally, the radiation emitted by Sr-89 can help reduce new bone metastases, providing a dual benefit of pain relief and tumor reduction.

Mechanism of Action:
Strontium chloride 89, similar to calcium divalent ion, concentrates in areas of increased osteogenesis. Once combined with external beam radiotherapy, it emits β particles with a maximum range in tissue of 6-8mm, reducing new bone metastases and producing an analgesic role.

Clinical Indication:
Sr-89 is indicated as a paliative for the relief of bone pain in patients with skeletal metastases. It is important to confirm the presence of bone metastases prior to beginning therapy.

Pharmacodynamics:
Metastatic bone lesions are zones of high bone mineral turnover, therefore there is a constant need of calcium supply for the development of the malignancy. Sr-89 is a divalent ion, similar to calcium, therefore it is taken up by sites of active osteogenesis, relieving bone metastatic-driven pain without generating important side effects and presenting a very little radioprotection concern.

Physical State:
Strontium chloride Sr-89 is a liquid.

Half-life:
Strontium chloride 89 presents a half-life of 50.5 days.
Mersalyl:
Mersalyl is the sodium salt form of mersalyl acid, a mercurial diuretic. It is an outdated drug that was formerly used to treat edema due to its powerful diuretic properties. However, its approval has been discontinued by the FDA due to its toxicity and the availability of less toxic non-mercury containing diuretics. Mersalyl acid is a mercurial compound that acts on the renal tubules, increasing the excretion of sodium and chloride, in approximately equal amounts, and of water. This results in a decrease in blood pressure and edema. Interestingly, it has been found to have antiviral properties in mice. Mersalyl is a solid and belongs to various drug categories including Alkylmercury Compounds, Diuretics, and Organomercury Compounds.

PHARMACODYNAMICS: Mersalyl acid is an organomercuric compound that combines with other elements such as chlorine, sulfur, or oxygen to form inorganic mercury compounds (salts). It is used as a diuretic and combines with carbon to make organic mercury compounds.

CLINICAL INDICATION: Mersalyl was primarily used to treat elevated blood pressure and edema.

MECHANISM OF ACTION: Mersalyl acts on the renal tubules, increasing the excretion of sodium and chloride in approximately equal amounts, and of water. This results in a decrease in blood pressure and edema.

APPROVAL STATUS: Mersalyl is experimental and its approval has been discontinued by the FDA due to its toxicity and the availability of less toxic non-mercury containing diuretics.

Loteprednol Etabonate (LE):
NAME: Loteprednol Etabonate (LE)

Description: Loteprednol etabonate is a topical corticoid anti-inflammatory used in ophthalmic solutions for the treatment of steroid responsive inflammatory conditions of the eye such as allergic conjunctivitis, uveitis, acne rosacea, superficial punctate keratitis, herpes zoster keratitis, iritis, cyclitis, and selected infective conjunctivitides. As a nasal spray, it can be used for the treatment and management of seasonal allergic rhinitis. The drug works by inhibiting the inflammatory response to various inciting agents, likely delaying or slowing healing. It inhibits edema, fibrin deposition, capillary dilation, leukocyte migration, capillary proliferation, fibroblast proliferation, deposition of collagen, and scar formation, which are commonly associated with inflammation. Corticosteroids like loteprednol etabonate bind to and activate the glucocorticoid receptor, modulating inflammation through multiple mechanisms. The drug also has strong protein binding, which reduces its pharmacodynamic action and adverse effects in the systemic circulation.

Clinical Indication: Loteprednol etabonate ophthalmic products are specifically indicated for the treatment of post-operative inflammation and pain following ocular surgery.

Mechanism of Action: The exact mechanisms by which loteprednol etabonate inhibits inflammation are not fully understood, but it is believed to act through multiple pathways, including induction of phospholipase A2 inhibitory proteins, collectively called lipocortins, and inhibition of arachidonic acid release from membrane phospholipids by phospholipase A2. These proteins control the biosynthesis of potent mediators of inflammation such as prostaglandins and leukotrienes by inhibiting the release of their common precursor arachidonic acid.

Pharmacodynamics: Loteprednol etabonate has a binding affinity to steroid receptors that is 4.3 times greater than dexamethasone, a commonly used corticosteroid. This particular class of steroids consists of bioactive molecules whose in-vivo transformation to non-toxic substances can be predicted from their chemistry and knowledge of enzymatic pathways in the body.

Physical State: Loteprednol etabonate is a solid.

Half-life: The terminal half-life of loteprednol etabonate as determined when administered intravenously at a dose of 5 mg/kg in the dog animal model is 2.8 hours.

Molecular Properties: Molecular weight: 466.96, TPSA: 99.13, cLogP: 3.34.

Drug Categories: Loteprednol etabonate is part of Adrenal Cortex Hormones; Androstadienes; Androstanes; Androstenes; Anti-Allergic Agents; Corticosteroids; Cytochrome P-450 CYP3A Substrates; Cytochrome P-450 CYP3A4 Substrates; Cytochrome P-450 Substrates; Fused-Ring Compounds; Immunosuppressive Agents; and St.

Approval Status: Loteprednol etabonate is approved for use in the treatment of various ophthalmic conditions.
Edetate calcium disodium:
Edetate calcium disodium is a metal ion chelator used to reduce blood concentrations and depot stores of lead from the body. It is on the World Health Organization Model List of Essential Medicines and is indicated for reducing blood levels and depot stores of lead in acute and chronic lead poisoning. Edetate calcium disodium distributes into tissues such as the kidney and bone, where it chelates lead ions. The lead ions are then eliminated in normal urinary excretion of edetate. While lead in certain tissues such as the liver and bone redistribute to other tissues after edetate calcium disodium treatment, lead levels do not decrease to levels seen in unexposed patients. Edetate calcium disodium has a wide therapeutic index and a long duration of action, with doses given at least a day apart. Patients should be counseled regarding the risk of increased intracranial pressure with intravenous infusions. The half-life of edetate calcium disodium is 20-60 minutes. Edetate calcium disodium anhydrous is a solid and is part of Anticoagulants, Calcium Chelating Activity, Calcium Chelating Agents, Chelating Activity, Chelating Agents, Compounds used in a research, industrial, or household setting, Cytochrome P-450 CYP3A Inhibitors, and Cyt. Edetate calcium disodium has been approved for use.

Edetate calcium disodium works by chelating lead ions in the body, reducing blood concentrations and depot stores of lead. The chelated lead is then eliminated through normal urinary excretion. The drug's wide therapeutic index and long duration of action allow for effective treatment of acute and chronic lead poisoning, while its lack of effects on lead levels in unexposed patients indicates that it can effectively reduce lead burden without causing harm to healthy tissues. Additionally, the drug's ability to redistribute lead from certain tissues such as the liver and bone to other tissues after treatment suggests that it may be effective in reducing lead burden in tissues where the metal is not normally present.

Edetate calcium disodium anhydrous is a solid, which allows for ease of storage and handling. Its long half-life means that doses can be given at least a day apart, minimizing the risk of adverse effects associated with repeated drug administration. However, patients should still be monitored closely to ensure that lead levels are adequately reduced and to detect any signs of intracranial pressure increase during intravenous infusions.

In conclusion, edetate calcium disodium is a valuable treatment option for reducing blood concentrations and depot stores of lead in acute and chronic lead poisoning. Its wide therapeutic index, long duration of action, and ability to redistribute lead from certain tissues make it an effective tool in managing lead exposure. Further research is needed to fully understand the drug's mechanisms of action and to optimize its use in clinical practice.
Edetate disodium anhydrous:
Edetate disodium anhydrous is a polyvalent chelating agent used to treat hypercalcemia and digitalis toxicity associated ventricular arrhythmias. It works by chelating divalent and trivalent ions such as calcium, magnesium, and zinc, reducing their concentrations in the blood. The therapeutic index of edetate disodium anhydrous is wide, allowing for high doses to be tolerated without significant side effects. However, patients should be counseled about the risks of postural hypotension, myocardial contractility, hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia, and hypoglycemia. Edetate disodium anhydrous is available as a solid dosage form and is approved for emergency treatment of hypercalcemia and digitalis toxicity associated ventricular arrhythmias.

PHARMACODYNAMICS: Edetate disodium anhydrous is a polyvalent ion chelator that reduces blood concentrations of calcium or digitalis. It has a long duration of action, as patients are generally given 1 daily dose. The therapeutic index is wide, as high doses are generally well tolerated.

CLINICAL INDICATION: Edetate disodium anhydrous is indicated for emergency treatment of hypercalcemia and digitalis toxicity associated ventricular arrhythmias.

MECHANISM OF ACTION: Edetate disodium anhydrous chelates divalent and trivalent ions such as magnesium, zinc, and calcium. The chelate is excreted in the urine, reducing concentrations of these ions in the blood.

PHARMACOKINETICS: Edetate disodium anhydrous is rapidly absorbed after oral administration and reaches peak plasma concentrations within 30 minutes. The drug is extensively distributed into tissues, with a volume of distribution of approximately 1.5 liters per kilogram of body weight. The drug is metabolized in the liver to inactive metabolites, which are excreted primarily in the urine.

DRUG CATEGORIES: Edetate disodium anhydrous is part of Anticoagulants; Calcium Chelating Activity; Calcium Chelating Agents; Chelating Activity; Chelating Agents; Cytochrome P-450 CYP3A Inhibitors; Cytochrome P-450 CYP3A4 Inhibitors; Cytochrome P-450 CYP3A4 Inhibitors (strength unknown); Cytochrome P-450 Enzymes.

APPROVAL STATUS: Edetate disodium anhydrous is approved and veterinary approved.
Capecitabine:
Capecitabine is an orally-administered chemotherapeutic agent used in the treatment of metastatic breast and colorectal cancers. It is a prodrug that is enzymatically converted to fluorouracil (FU) in the tumor, where it inhibits DNA synthesis and slows growth of tumor tissue. Capecitabine is also used as an adjuvant therapy following complete resection of primary tumors in patients with stage III colon cancer when monotherapy with fluorouracil is preferred. The use of capecitabine in combination regimens for advanced gastric cancer is currently being investigated.

Capecitabine works by selectively activating thymidine phosphorylase, an enzyme found in higher concentrations in many tumors compared to normal tissues or plasma. This leads to the formation of FU, which is further metabolized to two active metabolites, 5-fluoro-2'-deoxyuridine 5'-monophosphate (FdUMP) and 5-fluorouridine triphosphate (FUTP), within normal and tumor cells. These metabolites cause cell injury by two different mechanisms, including inhibition of thymidylate synthesis and interference with RNA processing and protein synthesis.

Capecitabine has a solid physical state and a half-life of 45-60 minutes for capecitabine and its metabolites. Its molecular weight is 359.35, and it has a topological polar surface area of 120.69. Capecitabine is part of the drug categories Antimetabolites; Antineoplastic Agents; Antineoplastic and Immunomodulating Agents; Carbohydrates; Cardiotoxic antineoplastic agents; Cytidine Deaminase Substrates; Cytochrome P-450 CYP2C9 Inhibitors; Cytochrome P-450 CYP2C9 Inhibitors (strong); and Cytochrome P-450 CYP2C.

Capecitabine has been approved for use in the treatment of metastatic breast cancer and colon cancer, and its use is currently being investigated for advanced gastric cancer.
Tegafur-uracil: Tegafur-uracil is an anti-tumor compound that contains tegafur (1-(2-tetrahydrofuryl)-5-fluorouracil) and uracil in a molar ratio of 1:4. Developed by Taiho Pharmaceutical Co Ltd, it is approved for the first-line treatment of metastatic colorectal cancer with concomitant administration of calcium folinate. The mechanism of action involves the generation of active metabolites through the transformation of tegafur to 5-fluorouracil, which are then inhibited by uracil, leading to increased blood and tissue levels. Tegafur-uracil has a serum binding protein of 52% for tegafur and negligible protein binding for uracil. The pharmacodynamics of the combination allow for improved oral bioavailability, reduced dosage frequency, and increased half-life. Tegafur-uracil is a solid with a molecular weight of 312.26 and is part of Cytochrome P-450 CYP2A6 Substrates and Cytochrome P-450 Substrates. Its approval status is approved and investigational in different countries, but not yet approved by the FDA, Health Canada, or EMA.
Tyropanoic acid:
Tyropanoic acid is a radiocontrast agent used in cholecystography, under various trade names including Bilopaque, Lumopaque, Tyropaque, and Bilopac. The molecule contains three heavy iodine atoms that obstruct X-rays in the same way as calcium in bones, resulting in a visible image. After injection, it is rapidly excreted into the bile. Tyropanoic acid is part of the category of Compounds used in a research, industrial, or household setting, specifically Hepatotropic X-Ray Contrast Media and Watersoluble X-Ray Contrast Media. Its molecular weight is 641.03, with a topological polar surface area of 66.4 and a logP value of 4.15. The drug has been approved for use in cholecystography, providing a valuable diagnostic tool for the detection and visualization of gallstones.

Mechanistically, tyropanoic acid works by obstructing X-rays through the presence of its heavy iodine atoms, similar to how calcium in bones blocks X-rays during conventional X-ray imaging. The drug is rapidly excreted into the bile after injection, ensuring a rapid onset of action and minimizing any potential side effects. Its low protein binding rate of less than 5% further contributes to its effectiveness as a contrast agent in cholecystography. Overall, tyropanoic acid is an important diagnostic tool for the evaluation of gallstones, providing clear and detailed images of the biliary tree and any potential obstructions or abnormalities.
Niraparib: Niraparib is an orally active PARP inhibitor, approved by the FDA in March 2017 for the maintenance treatment of adult patients with recurrent epithelial ovarian, fallopian tube, or primary peritoneal cancer who are in complete or partial response to platinum-based chemotherapy. Niraparib works by inhibiting the activity of poly (ADP-ribose) polymerase (PARP) enzymes, PARP-1 and PARP-2, which play a role in DNA repair. In vitro studies have shown that niraparib-induced cytotoxicity may involve inhibition of PARP enzymatic activity and increased formation of PARP-DNA complexes resulting in DNA damage, apoptosis, and cell death. The drug has been shown to decrease tumor growth in mouse xenograft models of human cancer cell lines with deficiencies in BRCA1/2, as well as in human patient-derived xenograft tumor models with homologous recombination deficiency that had either mutated or wild type BRCA1/2. Niraparib has an oral bioavailability of 83%, and its mean half-life is 36 hours following multiple daily doses of 300 mg. The molecular weight of niraparib is 320.4, and it has a topological polar surface area of 72.94. Niraparib belongs to various drug categories, including Antineoplastic Agents, Antineoplastic and Immunomodulating Agents, Enzyme Inhibitors, Heterocyclic Compounds, Fused-Ring, Narrow Therapeutic Index Drugs, Poly(ADP-ribose) Polymerase Inhibitors, and Pyrazoles.
Bendroflumethiazide: Bendroflumethiazide is a thiazide diuretic with actions and uses similar to those of hydrochlorothiazide. It has been used in the treatment of familial hyperkalemia, hypertension, edema, and urinary tract disorders. As a diuretic, bendroflumethiazide inhibits active chloride reabsorption at the early distal tubule via the Na-Cl cotransporter, resulting in an increase in the excretion of sodium, chloride, and water. Thiazides like bendroflumethiazide also inhibit sodium ion transport across the renal tubular epithelium through binding to the thiazide sensitive sodium-chloride transporter. This results in an increase in potassium excretion via the sodium-potassium exchange mechanism. The antihypertensive mechanism of bendroflumethiazide is less well understood although it may be mediated through its action on carbonic anhydrases in the smooth muscle or through its action on the large-conductance calcium-activated potassium (KCa) channel, also found in the smooth muscle. Bendroflumethiazide has a solid form and its half-life is 8.5 hours. Its molecular weight is 421.41, and it has a topological polar surface area of 118.36 and a log p value of 1.73. Bendroflumethiazide is part of the Amides; Antihypertensive Agents; Antihypertensive Agents Indicated for Hypertension; Benzothiadiazines; Bradycardia-Causing Agents; Cardiovascular Agents; Diuretics; Genito Urinary System and Sex Hormones; Gynecological Antiinfectives and Antiseptics; and Heterocyclic Classes drug categories. It is approved for use in various medical conditions, including high blood pressure and management of edema related to heart failure.
Trichlormethiazide:
Trichlormethiazide is a thiazide diuretic with properties similar to those of hydrochlorothiazide. It is used in the treatment of oedema (including that associated with heart failure) and hypertension. The mechanism of action of Trichlormethiazide involves inhibition of the active reabsorption of chloride in the ascending loop of Henle, as well as sodium inhibition via the Na-Cl cotransporter. This results in excretion of sodium, chloride, and water, leading to diuresis. Additionally, Trichlormethiazide inhibits sodium ion transport across the renal tubular epithelium through binding to the thiazide-sensitive sodium-chloride transporter, resulting in an increase in potassium excretion via the sodium-potassium exchange mechanism. The antihypertensive mechanism of Trichlormethiazide is less well understood, although it may be mediated through its action on carbonic anhydrases in the smooth muscle or through its action on the large-conductance calcium-activated potassium (KCa) channel, also found in the smooth muscle.

Trichlormethiazide is indicated as adjunctive therapy in edema associated with congestive heart failure, hepatic cirrhosis, and corticosteroid and estrogen therapy. It has also been found useful in edema due to various forms of renal dysfunction such as nephrotic syndrome, acute glomerulonephritis, and chronic renal failure. Trichlormethiazide is also indicated in the management of hypertension either as the sole therapeutic agent or to enhance the effectiveness of other antihypertensive drugs in the more severe forms of hypertension. Like other thiazides, Trichlormethiazide promotes water loss from the body (diuretics). They inhibit Na+/Cl- reabsorption from the distal convoluted tubules in the kidneys. Thiazides also cause loss of potassium and an increase in serum uric acid. Thiazides are often used to treat hypertension, but their hypotensive effects are not necessarily due to their diuretic activity. Thiazides have been shown to prevent hypertension-related morbidity and mortality although the mechanism is not fully understood. Thiazides cause vasodilation by activating calcium-activated potassium channels (large conductance) in vascular smooth muscles and inhibiting various carbonic anhydrases in vascular tissue.

Trichlormethiazide is a solid, with a molecular weight of 380.64 and a topological polar surface area of 118.36. Its logP value is 0.88. Trichlormethiazide belongs to the drug categories of Amides, Antihypertensive Agents, Benzothiadiazines, Cardiovascular Agents, Diuretics, Genito Urinary System and Sex Hormones, Gynecological Antiinfectives and Antiseptics, Heterocyclic Compounds, Fused-Ring, Hyperglycemia-Associated Agents, Low-Ceiling Diuretic. It is approved and veterinary approved.
Mercaptopurine: Mercaptopurine is an antimetabolite antineoplastic agent with immunosuppressant properties. It interferes with nucleic acid synthesis by inhibiting purine metabolism and is used, usually in combination with other drugs, in the treatment of or in remission maintenance programs for leukemia. The mechanism of action involves competition with hypoxanthine and guanine for the enzyme hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRTase), leading to the formation of thioinosinic acid (TIMP) which inhibits several reactions involving inosinic acid (IMP). Mercaptopurine is also converted to deoxythioguanosine, a nucleotide derivative that can be incorporated into DNA.
